DOC.HEAD: Bank Explosion Kills Three, Injures 14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES in lead to show two people in serious condition; INSERTS 2 grafs after 13th, `The dead...' to UPDATE with conditions and details of injured; Picks up 14th graf pvs, `Hope Ostheimer...'; DELETES redundant 24th graf pvs, `Ron Walters...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: An explosion shattered a two-story bank Tuesday, killing three people and injuring 14 others, officials said. Two people were listed in serious condition. Firefighters and volunteers dug by hand through the rubble of the downtown Crested Butte National Bank to pull out survivors, witnesses said. The entire building was leveled except for the vault. The cause of the blast in this Rocky Mountain ski resort was not immediately determined, but authorities said they were investigating the possibility of a bomb or methane gas buildup. Crested Butte Police Chief Hank Smith said two restaurants received bomb threats over the week, and one of them was evacuated. Mayor Wes Light said three bodies were pulled from the rubble, and the 14 others believed inside during the explosion were pulled out. ``A huge explosion occurred. I felt the floor drop beneath me,'' said bank teller Joe Sabino, who was treated at Gunnison County Hospital for scratches and burns on his hands. ``Fortunately, nothing came into contact with me,'' Sabino said. ``It (the rubble) built a little cave around me. I was little bit upside down.'' The federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms sent a 12-person response team to the scene, and Gov. Roy Romer made National Guard units available to provide assistance if needed. The explosion occurred at 9:15 a.m., shortly after the bank opened. About 200 people responded quickly to the scene and started digging with their hands. ``They started digging through the rubble, helping the people who were still alive,'' said Mark Reaman, a photographer for the Chronicle & Pilot newspaper. ``The whole town would suddenly become silent, stopping to see if they could hear someone. It was the most eerie thing I've ever heard. Luckily, many times they found someone who was still alive.'' The dead were identified as bank employees Jade Woelk, Donna Smith and Monica Henning. Their ages were not available. Thom Cox, the bank president, was in St. Mary's Hospital in Grand Junction where he underwent leg surgery and was being treated for possible broken ribs, officials said. He was reported in serious but stable condition. Roxy Lypps was admitted to intensive care with second- and third-degree burns over 30 to 40 percent of her body and was in serious but stable condition. Hope Ostheimer, who works nearby, said the building ``completely collapsed on itself.'' ``People started running from their cars and businesses and just started digging,'' said a passerby who identified himself only by his first name, Brad. ``I started digging, but I wigged out when I saw the condition of one of the victims,'' he said. ``One guy crawled out,'' but the rest were trapped. Dusty Demerson, who was in his shop at Color West Photography about a block from the bank, also went to investigate. ``The president of the bank ... was hanging out the back of the bank by his legs and we got him down,'' he said. By that time, ambulances arrived and Demerson also started digging for survivors. Six of the injured were taken to Gunnison County Hospital 30 miles away; the others were treated at clinics, the mayor said. Tom Yates, chief of the Gunnison Police Department, said three people were in critical condition. Bob Gillen, communications director for the Crested Butte ski area, said the resort put its disaster plan into effect and handled rescue operations. ``We're doing this as if this was an avalanche, because what we have here is a material avalanche,'' he said. ``They're doing it by hand. We have some heavy equipment there, but most of the rescuers are using their hands.'' ``There was an explosion, but there are no natural gas lines in there. We're puzzled by it,'' said Gillen. ``It doesn't make sense.'' ``I'm not ruling out a bomb, and I'm not ruling out an explosion from methane buildup,'' Smith said. ``We've just completed the rescue effort, and we're just now beginning the investigation.'' Crested Butte, population about 1,000, is 9,000 feet high in the western Colorado mountains. Heavy snow hampered rescue efforts and delayed the arrival of ambulances from Gunnison, Gillen said. An airplane did manage to land in Gunnison and stood by to take victims to St. Mary's Hospital in Grand Junction, western Colorado's largest hospital. Bank officials said they plan to open up a temporary bank on Wednesday in another building.

DOC.HEAD: Police Disband Opposition Blockades; 5 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Police broke up opposition party sit-ins at eight city halls in Guerrero state on Tuesday, and at least three police and two activists were killed, government and party officials said. The center-left Democratic Revolutionary Party had paralyzed 20 of the southwestern state's 75 city governments for three months, protesting alleged fraud in Dec. 3 elections. Gov. Francisco Ruiz Massieu said five people were killed in the police actions. ``Now peace has been restored,'' Ruiz Massieu said in a television interview. At a Mexico City news conference held by eight Guerrero state Democratic Revolutionary Party leaders, party spokesman Ricardo Pascoe said: ``We are confronting state terrorists that want repression.'' Government officials said about 200 state police and cadets were called out to remove 350 people. Opposition party leaders said about 80 supporters were injured and 30 arrested. Two party members were reportedly killed when police broke up the sit-in at the Ometepec city hall about 50 miles southeast of Acapulco, Guerrero party chief Rosalio Wences Reza said. Two policemen were killed with automatic weapons when they tried to protesters at the nearby Cruz Grande town hall, Guerrero state government spokesman Francisco Javier Rangel said by telephone. Federal Highway Police Commander Mario Juarez Servin reported another officer killed in the confrontations, the government news agency Notimex said. The state called on police to act ``because of what happened Feb. 27, when party members tried to take over the Acapulco and Zihuatanejo airports,'' the state government said in a statement. Three people were killed in confrontations when police stopped protesters on airport roads last week in the resort cities of Acapulco and Ixtapa, near Zihuatenejo. Rangel said the state government is concerned about the state's image, because tourism is its main source of income and employment. Tourism is Mexico's third-largest source of foreign exchange. State legislators agreed Tuesday to measures allowing power-sharing in seven Guerrero communities where city halls are still blockaded, a state news release said. Rangel said he didn't know if more police actions would be taken to end blockades.

DOC.HEAD: Four Charges Dropped, Buckey Lawyer Makes Unusual Move to Keep Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `An afternoon...' to UPDATE with judge denying request. Picks up 8th graf, `Davis said...
DOC.TEXT: Raymond Buckey pleaded innocent Tuesday to eight revived charges involving three girls in the McMartin Pre-School molestation case after his attorney requested that a sex charge slated for dismissal be retained. ``I am innocent, your honor, I plead not guilty,'' Buckey told Superior Court Judge Stanley M. Weisberg. The judge formally dismissed four unresolved charges against Buckey and held in abeyance one contested charge. The case now has been reduced from hundreds of counts that once involved 41 alleged abuse victims from the now-defunct Manhattan Beach preschool. Defense attorney Danny Davis asked the judge not to dismiss one allegation against Buckey involving the son of Judy Johnson, the mother whose complaints triggered the investigation, saying it would allow him to present to jurors ``the genesis of this case.'' The defense has previously said the case was the result of community hysteria churned by Mrs. Johnson, who also accused a Los Angeles school board member of molesting her child. She has since died of a liver ailment related to alcoholism. ``It seems a little strange that the defense would be objecting to the dismissal of this particular count, but I'm willing to listen,'' Weisberg said. At an afternoon hearing, Weisberg denied the request, as well as a defense motion to remove the Los Angeles district attorney's office from the case. Davis said statements by District Attorney Ira Reiner indicate he has forfeited objectivity in the case. He cited a state Supreme Court ruling that in the test of a prosecutor's office decision to pursue charges ``it is not that it shall win a case, but that justice shall be done.'' Deputy District Attorney Joseph Martinez said Reiner has a right to his opinion. ``What the D.A. is saying is that he believes Mr. Buckey to have committed these offenses. What kind of a D.A. would say that he is going to prosecute someone that he feels is innocent?'' Martinez asked before the hearing. There were 13 counts unresolved by jurors in the trial, which lasted nearly three years and cost taxpayers more than $10 million. Jurors in the first trial were leaning toward acquittal of the charges involving the three youngsters in the new trial. ``I don't know why they're doing it,'' Buckey said outside the courtroom before his arraignment on the renewed charges. ``They've got three of their weakest witnesses.'' Buckey predicted trial would take a year. ``Another year of McMartin, mini-McMartin, chiseled down as this case goes into overtime, falling apart until finally the second jury kicks it out.'' Davis said two of the three children testified at the first trial, and included fantastic accounts of molestation. He also said at other stages of the case they recanted and then restated the allegations. ``They will say Ray Buckey wore a beard and a mustache, flew in an airplane. ... We will have stories of a house with seven, eight bubble baths being taken by children all over the house, stories of a Farmer Bill, stories of going to a ranch,'' said Davis, referring to the previous testimony by the girls. When Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, finally came to trial in 1987, what had originally been hundreds of counts of child molestation was pruned to 64 counts and a shared count of conspiracy and five other defendants were dropped. The 41 children once said to have been abused was reduced to 11.

DOC.HEAD: Founder of Philadelphia Eye Institute Dies
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Harold Glendon Scheie, founder and former director of the Scheie Eye Institute of Philadelphia, died in his sleep on Monday. He was 80 years old. Scheie died of cancer, said Sarah Jarvis, a spokeswoman for the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. Scheie was dedicated to the advancement of ophthalmic science and patient care for more than 55 years, and his research findings had a profound effect on eye care throughout the world. Scheie was responsible for the development of key surgical techniques, including the treatment of congenital cataracts and glaucoma. He also helped develop the diagnostic test for myasthenia gravis with Dr. George Gammon in the late 1930s. Scheie was the first to describe in detail the rare inherited metabolic disease that can cloud the cornea, now called Scheie's syndrome. Many of today's ophthalmogical instruments and procedures bear his name, including the Scheie procedure used in glaucoma surgery. Dr. William N. Kelly, executive vice president of the University of Pennsylvania and dean of the School of Medicine, described Scheie as a pioneer in ophthalmic sciences. ``From the beginning of his professional career, as the hospital's first resident in ophthalmology, it was clear that great things would come from Harold G. Scheie,'' Kelly said. ``The Scheie Eye Institute is but one example of his many accomplishments.'' The institute opened in 1972 with Scheie as its director. The total eye-care facility houses the Department of Ophthalmology of Penn's School of Medicine and is based at Presbyterian Medical Center of Philadelphia. Scheie was a native of Brookings, S.D. He graduated with honors in 1935 from the University of Minnesota School of Medicine, and later moved to Philadelphia. Scheie's interest in ophthalmic science developed during his two-year internship at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in 1935. He is survived by his wife, Mary Ann Tallman; son, Eric Scheie of Berkeley, Calif.; and daughter, Nancy Scheie of Somerville, N.J. Services for Scheie were scheduled at the Arlington National Cemetery Chapel in Arlington, Va., for March 13. A memorial service will be held at the University of Pennsylvania on March 19.

DOC.HEAD: Snubbed Teen Wounds 10 With Shotgun
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager snubbed by youths playing a pickup basketball game returned in a van with a shotgun and sprayed the group with blasts of birdshot, wounding 10, police said Monday. None of the injuries were serious, although one of the players was hit in the head and another in the back, police said. The rest were hit in the arms, legs and upper bodies. All 10 were released after treatment at Jackson Memorial Hospital. Police late Monday arrested Eric Leon Keaton, 19, of Miami on charges of attempted first-degree murder and use of a firearm in the commission of a felony in the incident, said spokesman Armando Villorin. The group, which included two junior-varsity high school players, was playing Sunday on a court Sunday outside an elementary school when the youth, a stranger, asked to play but was told he couldn't get into the game, witnesses told police. The teen left, but returned a few minutes later, riding in the passenger seat of a small van. The van slowed as it passed within 20 feet of the court and the teen fired a shotgun twice into the group, the witnesses said.

DOC.HEAD: With Young Men Gone to War, Boys and Older Men Do the Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Amidullah's shoe-repair shop is a rough wooden box in which he can barely stand erect. He is 9 years old and has been the chief support of a large family since his father was killed two months ago. In the muddy market lanes of Kabul, small boys and old men compete for jobs pulling carts loaded with sacks of Soviet flour, Japanese television sets and cartons of West German hand lotion. The human mules even tow shiny red motorbikes to showrooms rather than ride them. Most young men seen in the capital are in uniform. The others usually are on crutches, their feet or entire legs lost to land mines in a dozen years of civil war. In a factory outside a military base, about 1,000 women make army uniforms. Only 20 percent are married but about 50 percent have become pregnant, one said, shaking her head sadly. She and others said prostitution is a disturbing new phenomenon in Kabul. Life has never been easy in this ancient land, whose name conjures mystery, intrigue and adventure. Today, the traditional hard-scrabble existence is compounded by a war that has produced neither victor nor vanquished and won't go away. Afghanistan's descent into war began in 1973 when Mohammad Daoud deposed his cousin, King Zahir Shah, while the king was abroad. Daoud was assassinated in April 1978 in a Communist coup. The Kremlin sent military forces in December 1979 to rescue its proteges from internal power struggles and a war with Moslem guerrillas. The insurgents get most of their support from the United States, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia. In the 12 years since the 1978 coup, the party has changed leaders twice by assassination and once in a power play, either engineered or supported by the Soviets, that installed President Najib in 1986. Soviet combat forces withdrew a year ago, leaving the Afghan army to fight the guerrillas alone. To the surprise of the United States and others, government troops have not merely held their own, but have expanded their area of control, reopening supply routes and making deals with local guerrilla commanders. Limited success has come at a high price. The government says half its resources go the war effort. In a chaotic economy, children and teen-agers who work as manual laborers and prostitutes earn more than their fathers, who have government jobs, according to interviews with Kabul residents of all social levels. ``I think this war is making us more backward,'' said a Kabul professional educated in Eastern Europe, who insisted his name not be used. ``The generation of 12- to 15-year-olds, they will be illiterate. You will have a generation sick with non-education, with heroin and hashish. This is a result of _ I don't know _ war, revolution, government, people's hate. It's very sad.'' In his wooden cubicle, which he opened soon after his father died in an auto crash, barefoot Amidullah handed a pair of highly polished black boots to a customer. He said he earned about 100 afghanis a day, three times what his 12-year-old brother Wahidullah makes working in a bakery. Amidullah is the main breadwinner for his mother and his seven brothers and sisters. At the unrealistic official rate, Amidullah's earnings translate to $1.81 a day, but amount to only 20 cents at the more accurate black market rate. Amidullah said the combined earnings of the two brothers were ``sometimes enough for food, sometimes not.'' Said Omar sells rock-like lumps of brown, crudely refined sugar at the Mujahedeen Market on Kabul's outskirts. The market got its name because the goods sold there are from territory held by the guerrillas, who call themselves mujahedeen, or holy warriors. Omar, 48, said he had four sons and three daughters, and ``number eight child is coming.'' He and 10-year-old Zalmai sat on their cart of sugar, shielded from the cold rain by a tarpaulin of bright orange. ``Some days I am not eating lunch, because if I eat lunch, my family won't have food,'' Omar said. No one in his family has been killed or wounded in the war, but rockets fell near his house not long ago. ``I am afraid of the rockets,'' he said. ``I made a sort of hole under my house. When the rockets come, I go with my family underground.'' Kabul has its pockets of affluence _ of fancy houses, big cars, lavish weddings, glitzy sweaters and acid-washed jeans. Mohammad Jamil, who is 42 and has four children, reckons he has a good job because he sells cars on commission rather than working for a salary, but times are still bad. ``Five years ago, we were selling and buying five or six cars a day,'' he said. ``Just now, we can't sell one car in a month.'' In January, he sold a 1983 Mercedes Benz to a rich merchant for 7 million afghanis ($14,000 on the black market). Jamil's 1 percent commission brought him 70,000 afghanis ($140), or 20,000 more than President Najib's official monthly salary.

DOC.HEAD: Plan Devised To Control Development Gobbling Up Amazon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report. Another in a series of stories planned in advance of 20th anniversary observances for Earth Day in April.
DOC.TEXT: The chaotic development that is gobbling up the Amazon rain forest could finally be reined in with a new plan developed by officials of Amazon countries and leading scientists from around the world. ``That's some of the most encouraging news about the Amazon rain forest in recent years,'' said Thomas Lovejoy, a tropical ecologist at the Smithsonian Institution and an Amazon specialist. ``It contrasts markedly with a year ago, when there was nothing to read about conservation in the Amazon, especially in Brazil, except bad news,'' Lovejoy said in a recent interview. Sixty percent of the Amazon, the world's largest tropical rain forest, lies in Brazil, but the forest also covers parts of eight surrounding countries. Lovejoy was one of the organizers of an unusual workshop held in mid-January in Manaus, Brazil, a sprawling city of 1 million people in the heart of the Amazon. It was the center of Brazil's once-thriving rubber trade. The workshop, which brought together all the governments and scientists with interests in the rain forest, culminated with a plan to regulate development in up to 80 percent of the Amazon region. It was the first time that all parties concerned with the Amazon had met to pool their knowledge and agree on conservation priorities, the meeting's participants said. The plan devised at the workshop has no legal force. But it has broad government support and is likely to serve as a guide for national conservation programs, participants said. Many of the areas to be preserved will be open to so-called multiple-use development, which preserves the forest while allowing tourism and the commercial exploitation of fibers, fruits and medicinal plants. Brazil, struggling with a teetering economy and pressured by developers and peasant farmers to clear the forest for cattle ranching or farming, has been ambivalent about the need to conserve the Amazon. Brazil participated in the Manaus workshop, however, and the setting of priorities was ``all done with the blessing of Brazil,'' Lovejoy said. Tropical rain forests are giant, living warehouses for thousands of plant andanimal species. The Amazon alone is home to 30 percent of the world's plant and animal species. One study found that a single square yard of leaf litter taken from the deep shadows of the Amazon floor contained 800 ants representing 50 species. Towering forest canopies up to 300 feet above the forest floor are home to countless birds and insects that live their lives without ever setting foot on the ground. One group of orchid species grows only near the top of the canopy; an entirely different collection of orchids grows at the bottom. At the Manaus meeting, more than 100 specialists met in small groups to assess conservation priorities. Insect specialists compared data on such creatures as the stinging ant that defends acacia trees against predators. Mammologists took inventory of the Amazon's screeching monkeys. Ichthyologists considered such oddities as the fish that eats fallen fruits and nuts on the Amazon River's banks when it overflows. Botanists, ornithologists and others did the same. Then they pooled their information and marked up maps of the Amazon. When they were done, the areas determined to be worth saving covered 70 percent to 80 percent of the Amazon. ``The bulk of the Amazon is a biological priority; there's no way of getting around that,'' said Russell Mittermeier, president of Conservation International and an authority on endangered monkeys. Mittermeier emphasized, however, that the plan set realistic goals for the establishment of national parks and reserves, along with multiple-use areas where some development could occur. It is not realistic to build a fence around 70 percent to 80 percent of the Amazon, he said. Only the most critical areas should be placed off limits to development. ``Ten to 20 percent of the entire Amazon should be in protected parks or preserves, ideally,'' he said. At present, 2 percent of the Amazon is protected. Brazil was not alone in its support for the conservation plan. ``The results of this meeting are a major contribution towards the work that has got to be done,'' said Stanley Malone, director of the Suriname Forest Service. Suriname was one of eight Amazon countries that agreed in 1978 to develop a unified approach to management of the Amazon, Malone said. What the officials lacked, however, was a guide to which areas most needed protection. That determination has now been made, based on the number of different species a given area contained, and on how many of those species were endemic, or unique, to the area. ``Now we'll have to see what develops from this,'' Mittermeier said. A new Brazilian president, Fernando Collor de Mello, will be inaugurated March 15, and with him will come a new Brazilian environmental policy. Whether the policy will include support for the Manaus plan is uncertain. ``As always, everything depends on key individuals,'' Mittermeier said. ``I'm basically always optimistic,'' he said. ``I feel sure that we can develop appropriate solutions, although it may take a lot of work.''

DOC.HEAD: Racing Commission Official, Family, Found Dead in Home
DOC.TEXT: A Texas Racing Commission official and his family were found apparently shot to death in their home, authorities said. David Joost, 41-year-old director of administration for the Texas Racing Commission, was discovered dead Monday at the home in Buda, near Austin, along with his 35-year-old wife, Susan, and their children, Eric, 10, and Laura, 5. Sheriff Paul Hastings said it appeared all four died of gunshot wounds but that a cause of death would not be released until autopsies today. A revolver was found in the home, but Hastings would not speculate on whether it had been used in the shootings. There was no sign of forced entry at the home. ``I don't want to have any suggestion that this is a murder-suicide, because we don't know,'' Hastings said. ``All we have is a family who has apparently met death by violent means. We could have four murders.'' Joost, who handled administrative duties for the Racing Commission, failed to show up at a commission meeting Monday morning. A co-worker and a constable went to the home, about 10 miles south of Austin, just before noon. The body of Mrs. Joost, an employee of the surface mining and reclamation division of the Texas Railroad Commission, was found in the master bedroom in bed with her daughter. The son's body was in his bedroom and Joostf's in a bathroom. Sheriff's spokeswoman Laura Vasquez said Sunday and Monday newspapers in the driveway led investigators to believe the family had been dead more than 24 hours. Racing commission spokeswoman Angie Roberts said the agency had no comment on the deaths. She did say Joost not named in a $1 billion lawsuit filed against the commission Feb. 23 by the Houston Turf Club. The club, which was spurned in its bid to win a license to build a horse racing track, alleged that the commission and other state officials and private individuals conspired to control the racing industry in Texas.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supreme Court Invalidates Most N.C. Death Row Sentences
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina's 84 death row inmates won't go free, but many of their lives could be spared under a U.S. Supreme Court ruling overturning a key part of the state's death-penalty law, authorities said. The court Monday set aside the death sentence of Dock McKoy Jr. for the 1984 murder of a deputy sheriff because under the state law, the sentencing jury couldn't consider any mitigating factor, or one that might lessen the sentence, unless all 12 jurors agreed. Writing for the court, Justice Thurgood Marshall said the unanimity requirement is unconstitutional. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Antonin Scalia and Sandra Day O'Connor dissented in the 6-3 vote. ``The opinion itself is just very sweeping,'' said Gordon Widenhouse, assistant appellate defender for the state. ``We're ecstatic.'' ``The decision does not mean that any death row inmates will go free, but it does mean that as many as 70 convicted murderers must have new sentencing hearings,'' Attorney General Lacy Thornburg said. ``It means in each case that another jury will be required to again decide the appropriate punishment.'' Eighty-two men are on death row at Central Prison in Raleigh and two women have been sentenced to die at the N.C. Correctional Institution for Women, also in Raleigh, said Bill Poston, a state Department of Correction spokesman. Poston said officers at Central Prison gave word of the ruling to several of the inmates and asked them to spread the news. Poston said none of the inmates had expressed a reaction Monday. The state attorney general's office believes the ruling should affect only defendants who received death sentences beginning in 1985, said Jim Coman, senior deputy attorney general. ``But I'm sure all the attorneys for all the death row inmates will appeal,'' he said. Thornburg said he would ask the Legislature to re-examine the death penalty law ``and make changes that will make the sentence of death more enforceable.'' Malcolm Hunter Jr., the state appellate defender who challenged the North Carolina law, said he had not yet spoken with McKoy. But he said he was not sure McKoy is ``really able to appreciate it. ... He's over 70, in very poor mental, emotional and physical health. He's sort of a pathetic creature right now.'' McKoy was convicted of shooting Anson County Deputy Sheriff William Kress Horne three days before Christmas 1984. Neighbors reported that McKoy was drinking and shooting, and the sheriff's department responded once and asked him to stop. When deputies were called to the house a second time, deputies asked McKoy to step outside. Instead, he opened a screen door and fired his gun, shooting Horne, who was standing behind his patrol car with his pistol drawn. At his trial, McKoy had offered an insanity defense.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Sets off Legal Debate With Opinion that Ship Could Have Sunk
DOC.TEXT: The Exxon Valdez would have sunk in just over an hour if Joseph Hazelwood had moved it off a reef after it ran aground, an expert witness said over defense protests the testimony was irrelevant. Lawyers for the skipper argued that the grounded tanker was immovable after it hit a reef last March 24 and there was no risk it would capsize. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone, while indicating he agreed the tanker was solidly stuck, allowed the testimony Monday. He said jurors had already heard too much about the skipper's alleged efforts to move the ship to be told now to disregard it. William Vorus, a professor of naval architecture at the University of Michigan, gave jurors an elaborate account of a computer simulation of the grounding, as well as a scholarly dissertation on how a ship stays afloat. The witness, who said his engineering firm was being paid $40,000 by the state for its work on the prosecution, calculated the Exxon Valdez would have capsized 75 minutes after grounding if it had been freed from the reef in 10 minutes. Hazelwood, 43, is charged with criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. The seaman from Huntington, N.Y., faces up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. The Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude, devastating the rich population of wildlife in Prince William Sound and coating hundreds of miles of rocky shore with black goo in the nation's worst oil spill. The most serious charge against Hazelwood, criminal mischief, involves acting recklessly in disregarding a known risk. Deputy District Attorney Brent Cole has focused on Hazelwood's behavior after the grounding to prove this charge with witnesses saying the skipper ordered the engines turned on and the ship pointed forward. But in a brief filed with the judge Monday, defense attorney Dick Madson argued that there was no risk that the ship would come off the reef or capsize and that Hazelwood could not have disregarded a risk that didn't exist. Johnstone said testimony from prosecution witnesses has convinced him that the ship was hard aground on the reef and could not be moved off by its own power. ``My inclination now is that physical impossibility is not evidence of the crime of criminal mischief,'' the judge said in a hearing outside the jury's presence. He said he would make a final ruling later. But he refused to block prosecution testimony on the issue after Cole argued that Hazelwood's actions could relate to whether his judgment was impaired by alcohol. The Alaska statute covering criminal mischief says that a person may act recklessly if he is unaware of a risk because of intoxication. Cole did not explain how that provision would operate if no risk was involved. Defense attorney Michael Chalos objected that Vorus' testimony was ``sheer speculation,'' but the judge overruled him.

DOC.HEAD: Holperin Survives Recall Vote Forced by Indian Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with complete returns; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Earlier, Holperin ...'
DOC.TEXT: A state lawmaker on Tuesday withstood a recall election brought by opponents of Indian spearfishing, handily defeating his challenger. Democratic Rep. James Holperin, the first state lawmaker to face a recall since 1932, had 9,535 votes or 69 percent to 4,380 or 31 percent for Sayner businessman Gene Ahlborn with all precincts reporting, unofficial returns showed. Holperin takes on Republican Brian Sherren, a St. Germain resort and recreational vehicle park owner, on April 3. Sherren, although running unopposed in the GOP primary, garnered 601 votes. Earlier, Holperin said the voter turnout would be critical. The recall election was brought by opponents of spearfishing rights for Wisconsin's Chippewa Indians. ``I am very pleased with the outcome. ... It is not a foregone conclusion that this is a guarantee of victory in April,'' Holperin told reporters at his campaign headquarters. Holperin said he was reluctant to read too much into the special election victory, saying it only showed voters want him on the ballot next month and believed in the normal cycle of elections rather than recalls. The recall was sparked by critics of Indian spearfishing, a right federal courts have said the state's six Chippewa bands retained in 19th-century treaties with the U.S. government. The issue has caused years of unrest, uncertainty and tension in northern Wisconsin between Indians, who want to exercise a legal right, and non-Indians, who complain their livelihoods are being destroyed. Organizers of the recall said Holperin, a four-term incumbent, had lost touch with his constituents on the issue and had failed to help reach an agreement to end the dispute. The city clerk in Rhinelander, the largest town in Holperin's district, which encompasses Vilas and Oneida counties, said about 21 percent of the eligible voters had cast ballots by mid-afternoon.

The recall has its roots in a 1983 federal court ruling that said Wisconsin's six Chippewa bands retained the right to spearfish, hunt, cut timber and gather food on off-reservation public lands under 19th-century treaties that ceded northern Wisconsin to the U.S. government. The ruling is under appeal. Vilas and Oneida counties have been the scene of angry confrontations between non-Indians and Chippewa spearfishermen during tribal fishing seasons of recent years. Organizers of the recall were especially critical of Holperin's support last year for Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson's plan to lease the treaty rights of the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa band for 10 years. The Lac du Flambeau would have received $50 million worth of cash and other aid in exchange for curtailing the exercise of treaty rights. Tribal members rejected the plan in a vote last fall. Holperin, 39, a former radio and television newscaster, was elected to the Assembly in 1982. Ahlborn, 50, became a Democrat in 1976. He is a buyer for a family-owned business that sells chainsaw supplies to retailers. He has served on the Vilas County Board of Supervisors since 1983 and was elected to the Northland Pines School District in Eagle River in 1981. The recall was organized by a group called Stop Treaty Abuse-Wisconsin, which claims that Indian treaties are unfair because they give Indians unequal rights. No state representative has ever been successfuly recalled in Wisconsin. The last recall election was in 1932, when Republican Sen. Otto Mueller of Wausau retained his seat.

DOC.HEAD: Boys' Fun Shuts Down 6,000 Homes
DOC.TEXT: Two boys tossing around a piece of pipe got it tangled in electrical wires, knocking out power and cable TV service to thousands of customers, authorities said. ``They didn't realize they were throwing it so high,'' Palm Beach Gardens police Sgt. William Yakshe said. The boys apologized, he said. The two friends, 12 and 15, got the pipe lodged in wires Sunday afternoon, causing a loud bang, said Steve Totter, Florida Power & Light customer service supervisor. As many as 6,000 customers were without power for up to 3\ hours. Cable TV customers also lost service briefly, but the number affected was not immediately known. ``I don't think they will do it again,'' Totter said. ``They're just lucky they didn't get hurt.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged With Stealing Manure From His Uncle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gleyn is cq in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A 24-year-old man has been accused of stealing up to $200 worth of cow manure from his uncle. Donald C. Magoon of Ellenburg Center was charged with petty larceny Sunday after his uncle, Gleyn Magoon, claimed he caught his nephew stealing a $10 load of manure from his farm in Ellenburg, said state Trooper William Bush. Gleyn Magoon claimed his nephew stole 10 to 20 loads of manure over time, Bush said. ``He noticed over a period of time that manure was missing from the pile,'' Bush said. ``I could only conjecture what he was using it for.''

DOC.HEAD: Italian Communists Hold Congress To Consider Renewal
DOC.TEXT: Italian Communists spurred by the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe want to set their party on a new course this week, one their leader believes can ultimately unite Italy's fractured political left. An 1,100-delegate extraordinary congress of the Italian Communist Party meets Wednesday through Saturday in Bologna to consider party leader Achille Occhetto's proposal for a rebirth of the largest Communist Party in the West. Occhetto is calling for, in effect, creating a broad new party that will seek to unite Italy's leftist parties under a single umbrella and effectively challenge the dominant Christian Democrats. The Communists are Italy's second-largest party but have been kept out of the national government for more than 42 years. Despite bitter opposition from the party's old guard, Occhetto's plan seems to have the support of about 67 percent of the delegates. That's more than enough votes to assure him success and perhaps lead the party to adopt a new name and drop the hammer and sickle from its symbol. In November, just days after the Berlin Wall crumbled, Occhetto stunned Italian Communists when, without consulting other party leaders, he suggested the party change its name and set out on ``a new street to unify the forces of progress.'' The party's Central Committee, instead of adopting his proposal, called for the extraordinary congress and decided to leave the decision to the delegates in Bologna. For Occhetto, the rebirth of the party is a gamble aimed at reversing its sagging political fortunes. The Christian Democrats have led or dominated all Italian governments since World War II. Occhetto hopes a rebirth of the 1.4 million-member party would move it closer to the ideas of the Greens, the Radical Party and liberal Catholics, thus creating a new political force. ``Divisions among leftists have caused the permanent victory of the Christian Democrats,'' he said in November. Occhetto also would like that force eventually to include Italy's Socialist Party, the country's third largest. But the Socialists don't feel the same pressures. They have been coalition partners with the Christian Democrats for the last decade. Socialist leader Bettino Craxi, watching the steady electoral slide of the Italian Communists, has campaigned to lead his party past the Communists in the polls. If he succeeds, the Socialists will become the second largest party and the de facto leader of the Italian left.

DOC.HEAD: China's Shandong Province Requires VD Tests for Job-Seekers
DOC.TEXT: The largely rural Chinese province of Shandong has enacted new regulations requiring all job applicants to undergo tests for venereal disease, an official newspaper reported today. The regulations were drawn up after the coastal province recorded 2,690 cases of VD in 1989, a more than fourfold increase over the previous year, the China Daily said. Authorities may now require all applicants for jobs in state or collectively-run enterprises to prove they are free of venereal diseases, and can ask health centers to carry out VD tests on prostitutes, criminals and vagrants. Couples will be allowed to marry only after proving they are VD-free, the report said. Doctors may not give private treatment to VD patients without the authorization of local health offices. The daily said the rise of extra-marital sex was the main reason for the rapid spread of VD in the province. China in 1964 announced it had eliminated VD from the country, but has acknowledged that sexual diseases have made a strong comeback in the 1980s as a result of increased contact with the outside world, a revival of prostitution and changing attitudes toward sex. The nation has recorded more than 200,000 cases of VD since the early 1980s, with the southern provinces bordering Hong Kong, China's most open areas, among the hardest hit. But the spread of VD is also being taken seriously in more remote areas such as Shandong, which has relatively few direct contacts with the outside world. The national government now requires all foreigners taking up residency in China to show proof they are free from VD and AIDS. Chinese returning from three months or more abroad must also show documents they are not infected by the diseases.

DOC.HEAD: No Sun, No Sand, But Let's Switch On The Fans
LaserPhoto PAR14
DOC.TEXT: To the roar of rock music and the glare of spotlights, the world's top windsurfers have moved indoors to prove they no longer depend on nature's breezes. Switch on the fans, and off they go. Combining theatrical glitz, engineering wizardry and high-level sporting skills, organizers lured 10,000 spectators Monday night _ at more than $20 a head _ to watch the world's first indoor windsurfing competition on a miniature ocean in Paris' largest sports arena. The sideboards and concrete flooring that normally contain the ice skating rink at Bercy arena were lined with a bright blue plastic sheet and filled with 5.55 million gallons of water. Twenty massive circular fans, weighing a ton each, were placed along one side of the basin, producing a wind of more than 20 knots that kept two large flags in the facing grandstands flapping vigorously. The basin was 230 feet long, 98 feet wide and only 27 inches deep. Judo mats under the lining cushioned the windsurfers when they fell, which was often. The competition, to conclude tonight, includes both slalom races and a jumping event, using a ramp equipped with plastic rollers to allow smooth passage for the boards. American star Robby Niash, recipient of the loudest cheers during the introductions, had said following an afternoon practice session that the jumping would be a ``bad joke'' because the competitors had only a small fraction of the usual space they need to pick up speed. But Niash looked happier after easily winning his first slalom heat over three other racers, two of whom promptly capsized when the race began with a slide down four side-by-side ramps. The competitors _ 10 women and 24 men _ came from throughout Western Europe, as well as Canada, Australia and the United States. Plans for the event were first announced April 1 in a French windsurfing magazine, and at the time roused suspicions that it was an April Fools hoax. But skeptics underestimated the persistence of chief organizer Frederic Beauchene, whose earlier exploits included a windsurf across the English Channel and later, in tandem with a partner, a trans-Atlantic crossing. Beauchene began contemplating the idea of indoor windsurfing while running a weather-plagued world championship in France in 1982. ``We had enough wind only one day out of 10,'' he said. ``The racers are frustrated, the spectators also. The sport is inconsiderate.'' The indoor alternative not only solves the wind problem, Beauchene notes, but facilitates television coverage and makes the sport accessible to people in inland cities such as Paris. He hopes the Bercy competition will lead to a full-fledged international indoor circuit that would include West Germany, Holland, Japan and the United States. The German-made fans were switched on two-by-two, introduced by the master of ceremonies with almost as much fanfare as the racers. Marco Lebaron, the chief engineer, had said earlier that the surge of power needed to switch all 20 fans on simultaneously could cause an explosion. The volume of water in the basin is so vast that it cannot all be pumped directly into the nearby Seine river in time for a horse jumping show at Bercy on Wednesday. Instead, the water will be allowed to flood several basement rooms, then removed gradually. Whether indoor windsurfing turns out to be a transitory gimmick or a legitimate boost for an exciting but not widely followed sport, only time will tell. But it certainly poses new challenges for the competitors. A French sports magazine, Le Sport, quoted one unidentified racer as saying this would be the first time he would be able to hear boos if he did badly.

DOC.HEAD: Flea Markets Spring to Life as Private Enterprise Allowed
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Iustinian Dondera looked over his wares _ five bars of soap, three videocassettes, two bags of coffee and a toy car _ and contemplated the joys of capitalism. ``There are many more people selling, and better products,'' he said, gesturing to vendors hunched over car hoods spread with goods. ``This is really business,'' he added, grinning. Dondera was one of hundreds of people selling blue jeans, ladies' underwear, deodorant and other impossible-to-find items at a weekend flea market on the edge of Bucharest. It is one of three weekly flea markets that have sprung to life in the capital in recent weeks and the most obvious sign of free enterprise to emerge since the December overthrow of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. ``Before, the police would confiscate everything,'' added Dondera's companion, who identified himself only as Dan. ``Now they don't do that.'' In the Ghencea neighborhood on the outskirts of Bucharest, the government charges vendors 13 lei, the equivalent of 65 cents, to set up a stand in the old dirt market area. But hundreds of other people set up shop outside the market gates without paying, choking a mile-long stretch of road. On car hoods or on blankets on the ground, sellers lay out U.S. cigarettes, John Travolta record albums, Bulgarian chocolates and car parts. One young man offered labels with the names of Italian designers. ``To give clothes more value,'' he explained. The stalls were jammed by thousands of Romanians who must normally wait in long lines for the few consumer items available in shops. Gabriel Toma, 22, stood patiently as his girlfriend held up blue-jean skirts from a selection on a car trunk. ``We don't find things in the stores so we are here,'' he said. ``But it's more expensive than it should be, of course, and the quality is not always right.'' Nonetheless, he held up a prize: a box of a dozen colors of eye shadow, a rare find in Bucharest shops. Some vendors sold their old clothes or books. Others confessed to having developed private channels to get the imported goods long denied Romanians under Ceausescu's export-driven plans to pay off the country's foreign debt. Mircea, a young man in a black sweater and red, silky sweatpants, explained that he had driven to Turkey to buy blue jeans, which he was now selling for 1,200 lei (about $60) a pair out of his trunk. He said he and his partner earned a profit of $15 a pair. ``I must live,'' he said. ``In the factory I earn 2,500 lei ($125) a month. That's nothing.'' Down the road, 27-year-old Manuela Brenner was ordering a potential customer to smell the Hungarian soap she was selling from a cardboard stand. ``You won't find that in the stores,'' her husband Radu advised the customer. The couple said they had driven to western Romania, near the Hungarian border, to find toiletries they could sell to supplement their incomes. ``If you only knew how I got hold of them. It was very difficult,'' Mrs. Brenner admonished the customer as he tried to negotiate a lower price. She told a reporter that people were adapting quickly to being merchants, even though they had lived in a highly centralized economy for four decades. ``Romanians have the idea of business in their blood,'' she beamed. Recently, the centralized economic system has begun to crack. The ruling Provisional Council of National Unity decreed last month that private businesses could be established with up to 20 employees. The government has declared that it intends to introduce more market forces to turn around a ravaged economy. However, major measures are not expected before May elections. But at Sunday's market, capitalism was settling in well, with vendors as excited as buyers. One man worked his way through the swarms of buyers thrusting a single black lace bra into women's faces. ``Only 150 lei,'' he declared, about $7. Another man waved a yellow polyester blouse. ``One-hundred-percent cotton.'' He yelled. ``No, 1,000-percent cotton.'' Brenner interrupted a reporter trying to question the customer examining the Hungarian soap. ``Business first,'' he said briskly. ``Time is money.''

DOC.HEAD: 29 Coal Barges Hit New Orleans Bridge
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-nine coal barges broke loose and three of them sank Monday after hitting the older of the two Greater New Orleans Bridge twin spans over the Mississippi River. ``Twenty-six are floating free and being rounded up by five or more tugs. So far, some have drifted down as far as the Industrial Canal _ about 3| or four miles,'' said Coast Guard Lt. Bob Carson. He said the bridge and river remained open. Damage to the bridge apparently was confined to the system designed to keep boats away from the bridge, he said. ``I doubt that the actual bridge abutments were touched,'' said Carson. The barges were under tow by the tugboat Lillian Clark when the accident occurred about 7 p.m., Carson said.

DOC.HEAD: CBO Sees Deficit Double Bush's Estimate
DOC.TEXT: The Congressional Budget Office says next year's deficit will be twice what President Bush is estimating, but the red ink will go down sharply in the next few years if Congress adopts all of the president's proposals. A new report by the CBO, a non-partisan agency, predicts the deficit for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 will be about $131 billion under Bush's plan, nearly $70 billion more than the White House predicts. The administration budget is too optimistic in its forecast of economic conditions and interest rates and it fails to include a short-term cash infusion needed for the cleanup of the savings and loan industry next year, the CBO said. As a result of the S&L costs, the congressional agency estimated Monday that the fiscal 1991 deficit will be $161 billion if no deficit-cutting action is taken, up from $138 billion it estimated in January. The White House said its program would reduce the deficit to about $61 billion, far less than the CBO's $131 billion. But that is based on its estimate of a deficit of only about $100 billion before deficit-cutting action is taken. The administration, in its budget submitted in January, did not include additional costs for the thrift buyouts. Barbara Clay, spokeswoman for the president's Office of Management and Budget, said that cost would be factored into the administration's midyear budget update in July. But OMB might not agree with the $26 billion additional cost estimate of the CBO, she said. The CBO said its estimate of the deficit-reduction value of Bush's budget was about $31 billion, some $6 billion less than claimed by the White House. One big difference is that the CBO estimates the president's tax increase proposals are worth $9.4 billion, compared with $15.7 billion in the administration estimate. CBO Director Robert Reischauer said the $31 billion in deficit reduction would put the government on a path toward a balanced budget, even if not as quickly as Bush claims. ``By historical standards, that is a great deal more than we have achieved in recent years,'' he said. The CBO projects the budget will be near balance by fiscal 1995, two years later than the administration's forecast, if Bush's program is adopted. Under the Gramm-Rudman law, Congress and the administration are required to reduce the deficit in fiscal 1991 to $64 billion or less. The administration produces the estimates that determine whether that target is met. The CBO estimates are advisory.

DOC.HEAD: Chicken Skin in McNuggets? Consumer Group Seeks Ingredient Disclosure
DOC.TEXT: If you really want to know that your cheeseburger contains 711 calories and there's chicken skin in your McNugget, it may soon be easier to find out. Fast-food companies are under pressure from a consumer group insisting that four large chains honor a 1986 nutrition disclosure agreement. Consumers need to know that McDonald's and Burger King fry their potatoes in beef fat, says Michael Jacobson, executive director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest. They need to know that McDonald's Chicken McNuggets contain ground-up chicken skin, that Burger King's Whopper with cheese contains 711 calories and that milkshakes often contain artificial colorings, said Jacobson, whose group is enlisting help from officials in three states. ``This is the first complaint that we've received,'' Burger King spokeswoman Cori Zywotow said after learning that product information brochures were available at only six of 14 outlets surveyed by the Washington-based center. ``We certainly believe our consumers should know what they're eating,'' she added. ``We provide guides to all of our restaurants. We certainly will go back and take a look ourselves and, if they are not being given out, remedy the situation.'' The center, a nonprofit health advocacy group with 200,000 members, outlined its complaints on Monday against Burger King, McDonald's, Wendy's and Kentucky Fried Chicken. In letters to the attorneys general of California, New York and Texas, Jacobson said the chains are violating a 1986 agreement to give customers on-the-spot information about ingredients and nutrition and make sure customers know the booklets are available. The agreement worked out with the three state officials was supposed to apply to outlets nationwide, according to the center. ``We are sorry to report ... that, after initial compliance, the voluntary program has broken down,'' Jacobson said in the letter. Based on a survey of eight states and the District of Columbia, he said, only Jack in the Box appears to be honoring the agreement. Jacobson urged the attorneys general to consider prosecuting the companies if they don't fully comply within 60 days. The four chains have been invited to meet with Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox and talk about the problem. ``We want them to continue providing nutritional information,'' said Mattox spokesman Ron Dusek. ``Whether or not the states would be inclined to sue over the violations of this agreement, I don't know.'' ``We are dismayed that the fast food companies have chosen to drop this policy and we'd like to see it returned,'' said Leslie Gersing, a spokeswoman for New York Attorney General Robert Abrams. But she added, ``This is something we'd like to do without having to resort to legislation.'' Denny Lynch, a spokesman for Wendy's, said the company has not discontinued a policy of offering menu information, although none was available at any of the 14 outlets surveyed by the center. ``They might have run out of them,'' Lynch said. ``That's easily fixed. We'll just remind our restaurant operators that the ingredient and nutrition brochures are available and ask them to have a supply on hand.'' Only three of 13 Kentucky Fried Chicken outlets in the survey had nutrition pamphlets on hand. Spokesman Dick Detwiler said that was because a new, updated booklet was being published at the time of the survey. He said the pamphlet has been distributed to company-owned stores and those franchises that want to provide it. Terri Capatosto, a spokeswoman for McDonald's, said her company never agreed to anything except a one-year distribution of nutrition information in New York in 1986. However, she said McDonald's current national policy is to have complete product information available and booklets are sent to restaurants regularly. The center found brochures available at eight of 18 outlets and concluded that the policy ``is being ignored by many of their stores.'' The consumer group reached its conclusions after surveying restaurants in Virginia, Louisiana, Ohio, Wyoming, New Mexico, Texas, California and New York in addition to Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Killed in Mexican Truck-Bus Collision
DOC.TEXT: A truck and bus crashed head-on in southern Sonora state, killing 20 people and injuring 19, the government news agency Notimex reported. It said Monday's accident occurred when a tire blew out on the truck, causing it to veer into the bus's path along federal Highway 15. The accident occurred near Rosita, about 350 miles south of the Arizona border at Nogales. The drivers of both the truck and bus were killed instantly, Notimex said. It said that some of the injured were in serious condition and the death toll could climb.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 8 a.m. EST _ set by source
DOC.HEAD: House Democratic Leader Proposes First Direct US Aid to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: It is time for the United States to begin providing direct aid to the Soviet Union to encourage political and economic change and to abandon President Bush's ``timid posture,'' House Democratic leader Richard Gephardt said today. ``America must think creatively and act boldly,'' the 1988 presidential candidate said in a speech prepared for a meeting of the liberal Center for National Policy. ``We should be investing in our own self-interest. And stability, democracy and a market economy in the Soviet Union are in America's strong self-interest,'' he said. The proposal seemed certain to spark debate on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers have been pressing for increased aid to other countries emerging from the shadow of Moscow's domination but have not ventured to propose immediate direct aid to the Soviet Union itself. Gephardt, D-Mo., proposed starting with a ``Food for Freedom'' program to send U.S. food aid to the Soviets. The United States also should waive trade restrictions with Moscow, including those on high-technology exports, and provide guarantees for businesses that want to invest in the Soviet Union, he said. Gephardt noted an appeal by President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, made in a Feb. 21 speech to Congress, to help his country by helping the Soviet Union continue on its reformist road. If Havel, who was imprisoned by the communists, can call for aid to the Soviets, ``the least we can do is listen,'' Gephardt said in a speech that also contained his harshest criticism to date of Bush's policy toward Eastern Europe. ``A stronger Soviet economy will facilitate the process of peace,'' said Gephardt. ``How can the Soviets pull Red Army troops out of Eastern Europe if they have no jobs and no homes for them to return to in Russia?'' Direct U.S. aid is possible now because ``the Cold War as we have known it for four decades is over,'' Gephardt said. While the possibility remains that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could be ousted or his reforms could fail, superpower competition in arms and influence has changed in fundamental ways, he said. The United States since May 1985 has sold 20 million metric tons of U.S.-grown wheat to the Soviet Union under subsidies worth hundreds of millions of dollars, but has never provided direct aid of the kind Gephardt proposed. The Bush administration, in its budget for the year that begins Oct. 1, has proposed an additional $300 million in unspecified aid to emerging East European democracies. Gephardt said the amount should be at least $500 million, ``and that is only the beginning.'' ``If we have the fortitude and the determination to seize the day,'' he said, ``we can ensure that the days of the Cold War will never return.'' But he accused Bush of ``a lack of leadership in this most crucial moment,'' throwing billions into the military budget to defend against ``communists who don't want to be communists any more'' while ignoring their economic needs. ``It's as though George Bush's Pentagon budget were written by someone who hadn't read a newspaper in a year,'' Gephardt said. Most of the administration's budget was drafted last year, after the opening of the Berlin Wall but before many of the other dramatic developments in Eastern Europe. ``I believe the answer lies in the president's lack of vision,'' Gephardt said. Americans seem reluctant to provide aid to Eastern Europe ``because their president is not leading them,'' he said. ``He is not helping them understand the new world we live in _ its challenges, its opportunities, its dangers.'' Gephardt added: ``His timid posture may well create a self-fulfilling prophecy that at best confirms the status quo and at worst condemns the fragile new democracies to failure.''

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter's Low Public Profile Speeding Jury Selection
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Jury selection scheduled to resume 9:45 a.m. EST; will be led
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: John Poindexter's low public profile compared with that of Oliver North is making it a relatively simple task to select a jury for the former national security adviser's Iran-Contra trial. Seventeen women and four men were sent into a pool of prospective jurors in the first day of jury selection Monday. Only six people were disqualified, largely because they had too much familiarity with the Iran-Contra scandal. At North's trial last year, it took more than a week to select a jury, primarily because so many prospective jurors had been exposed to North's televised testimony to Congress in which the former White House aide admitted many of the activities that eventually led to criminal charges against him. Like North, Poindexter gave public testimony to Congress under a grant of immunity, but some prospective jurors could not recognize him in the courtroom Monday. ``He's the handsome man here with the glasses and moustache,'' defense attorney Richard Beckler told a potential juror at one point, beckoning toward his client seated across the room. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene took care of the problem of exposure to Poindexter's immunized testimony before jury selection began. The judge excused 76 potential jurors who said on a questionnaire that they had been exposed to Poindexter's testimony. Those 76 came from a total of 206 potential jurors. In the North case, all but 16 of the first 54 potential jurors indicated they had some familiarity with North's testimony on Capitol Hill. Twelve jurors and six alternates will be drawn for the Poindexter trial from a pool of at least 40. Greene included in the jury pool a former Bush campaign aide who years ago had been babysat by one of Poindexter's attorneys. ``Just because counsel babysat for her doesn't cast any doubt on her,'' the judge said. Among the six who were disqualified was a Food and Drug Administration employee who said he had heard that North's secretary, Fawn Hall, shredded documents in the scandal. Hall is expected to testify at Poindexter's trial. ``If someone is shredding documents, they don't want me to know about it,'' said the man. ``If they don't want me to know about it, I want to know why they are shredding.'' Others sent into the jury pool include a postal employee who recalled Poindexter's name from North's trial last year; a retired police officer who said he would treat former President Reagan's testimony the same as that of any other witness; and a registered nurse who said she understood Poindexter had been indicted on charges of defrauding the government in connection with arms sales. Poindexter actually is under indictment on charges of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. The charges relate to Poindexter's alleged coverup of North's secret resupply network to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua and to Poindexter's alleged lies concerning a November 1985 shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran. Reagan gave videotaped testimony for Poindexter's trial Feb. 16-17 and Poindexter's lawyers are expected to replay it in court.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Leader: Bush Not Ruling Out Jewish Residents in East Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is offering assurances that he is not adopting a new policy that would rule out Jewish residents in the eastern half of Jerusalem, a U.S. Jewish leader says. Seymour Reich, a New York lawyer who is president of B'nai B'rith and head of the Conference of American Jewish Organizations, said Monday night that Bush ``did acknowledge that it might have been unfortunate for him to have referred to East Jerusalem in the same reference to settlers on the West Bank'' at a news conference last Saturday. Reich spoke with Bush by telephone for 25 minutes on Monday. Afterward, the White House issued a statement urging American Jewish leaders to help promote a pre-election dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians as soon as possible. ``This remains the surest path available to promoting a peace that would ensure Israeli security and the legitimate political rights of Palestinians,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Members of Reich's conference were disturbed by Bush's comment Saturday that, ``We do not believe there should be new settlements in the West Bank or in East Jerusalem.'' Reich, interviewed by telephone, said, ``Any suggestion that East Jerusalem can be compared with settlements in the West Bank was very disturbing.'' The word ``settlement'' had never before been used in connection with Jerusalem, he said. The West Bank and East Jerusalem were captured from Jordan in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. East Jerusalem has been united with the rest of the city, which Israel made its capital, but the West Bank has been administered separately, with Jordan paying the salaries of local government employees there until 1988. ``There are no settlements in Jerusalem,'' Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Sunday, though 120,000 Jews now live there. Negotiations on the status of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, captured from Egypt in 1967, between Israel and Palestinians have been a longtime aim of U.S. policy. The White House statement said Bush ``also reiterated that U.S. policy toward Jerusalem is unchanged,'' with the United States supporting ``a united Jerusalem whose final status is determined by negotiations.'' Reich called attention to the next sentence in the White House statement: ``The president also made clear the U.S. support for Jews, as well as others, to live there in the context of a negotiated settlement.'' ``The implication is that East Jerusalem is different from settlements in the West Bank,'' said Reich. The United States has long opposed Israel's policy of settling Jewish families in the West Bank. Fitzwater said the United States would oppose any efforts to frustrate the right of Soviet Jews to move to Israel. Bush indicated again that the United States will back a $400 million loan guarantee for housing the Soviet refugees ``provided the United States and Israel can work out assurances that satisfy the United States on settlement activity,'' Fitzwater said. The United States has said it will not help out if the Israeli government settles immigrants from the Soviet Union in the West Bank. Shamir and his governing Likud Party have been divided over whether to accept the U.S. proposal for peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians. The Likud ministers in the Israeli Cabinet gave conditional approval Monday to going ahead. The chief condition was that the positions of the Likud and its political rival and coalition partner, the Labor Party, be coordinated in any talks with Palestinians in Cairo. A new complication arose when Palestinian leaders in the occupied territories said Monday no one would serve on a delegation to negotiate with israel unless the Palestine Liberation Organization chose the delegation. Israel refuses to deal with the PLO on the grounds that it is a terrorist organization bent on the destruction of Israel.

DOC.HEAD: US Ambassador Recalled From Guatemala
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to Guatemala is in Washington, called back temporarily to signal U.S. dismay with the government's failure to stop a mounting wave of political killings. Ambassador Tom Stroock arrived Monday for one week of consultations with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and other officials. When he returns to Guatemala City he will be carrying a message to President Vinicio Cerezo, said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``We are highlighting ... today by what I believe is a very strong, forthright statement'' of U.S. concern with the stalled investigations of the killings, many of which were directed at left-wing activists, she said. ``We believe that these investigations should be given the highest priority and that all investigative-type resources should be directed toward bringing to justice those individuals who are guilty,'' Ms. Tutwiler added. The FBI has sent forensic experts to Guatemala to help in the investigations. While the United States has ``provided substantial assistance to increase the investigative capacity of the police and the judicial system, the perpetrators have still not ... been subjected to the rule of law,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``Given this situation, the secretary of state has requested that Ambassador Stroock return to the United States to review the situation.'' Guatemalan government spokeswoman Claudia Arenas Bianchi said in a telephone interview in Guatemala City: ``There is no temporary withdrawal of Ambassador Stroock. He only left for meetings at the Department of State.'' Cerezo and his Christian Democrats blame a rightist campaign to destabilize the government, including two coup attempts last year by army officers. But foreign diplomats and government critics blame Cerezo for incompetence and say he is paralyzed by fear of right-wing violence. The United States wants an investigation into last summer's killings of five university students and several left-wing activists, including one American. Many of the 77 politically motivated killings listed by human rights groups since last summer have been attributed to right-wing activists. Some foreign diplomats say the methods in some of the killings point to involvement by state security forces. But Ms. Tutwiler said the United States does not know who is responsible. ``Guatemala's democracy continues to be challenged by acts of terrorism and human rights abuses perpetrated by extremists who seek to undermine the democratically elected civilian government,'' the spokeswoman said. ``The United States government condemns these acts in the strongest terms and reiterates its fundamental support for the government of Guatemala and for the peaceful transition through open and free elections to a new civilian government next year,'' she said. The violence in Guatemala has dimmed hopes that a working democracy can take root in the central American country. Guatemala returned to civilian government in 1986 after three decades of military rule in which an estimated 100,000 people died and 40,000 disappeared. The country's previous experience with democracy ended in 1954 with a CIA-backed coup against reformist President Jacobo Arbenz. ``The Guatemalan people deserve nothing less than what so many other nations of the hemisphere have achieved: an open, democratic system in which the rule of law is enforced and the rights and liberties of all Guatemalans are protected,'' Ms. Tutwiler said.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6 a.m. EST _ time set by source
DOC.HEAD: Lenders to Offer Cross Between Fixed-Rate and ARM Mortgages
DOC.TEXT: Many lenders will soon offer a new type of mortgage designed to appeal to home buyers who expect to move within seven years but want the security of a fixed-rate mortgage in case they don't. The loans, called two-step mortgages, are a cross between an adjustable-rate loan, where the rate can change every one, three or five years, and a traditional 30-year mortgage, where the interest rate does not change for the life of the loan. In the first step of the new mortgage, borrowers pay an interest rate up to three-eighths of a percentage point lower than on a 30-year, fixed-rate loan. After seven years, the rate is reset at 2.25 to 2.5 percentage points higher than the rate on 10-year Treasury notes. On a typical mortgage of $83,000, home buyers currently would save $23 a month, or $1,932 over the first seven years. However, the rate for the remaining 23 years of the mortgage likely would be somewhat higher than on a new 30-year loan taken out at readjustment time. For instance, if the rate on a 7-year-old, two-step loan were readjusted now, it would be 10.75 percent to 11 percent _ one-half to three-quarters of a percentage point higher than fixed 30-year mortgages. But in this case, unlike a refinancing, the borrower would pay no additional fees or charges at readjustment time. The Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, said it would begin buying two-step mortgages from a handful of lenders today. It said it expected them to be widely available later in the spring. ``It's a mortgage designed for the 1990s,'' said Fannie Mae President Roger E. Birk. ``In this mobile society, homeowners move and, therefore, repay their mortgages about every seven years.'' Birk said two-step mortgages are aimed at military families, people transferred regularly by corporations and first-time home buyers who expect to buy a better home within seven years. ``Very clearly this is marketed at people who expect to move but want to be protected in case they don't,'' Fannie Mae spokesman Gene Eisman said. The loans likely will be particularly popular in California, where people move frequently and home prices are among the highest in the nation, Eisman said. Fannie Mae is a congressionally chartered, but shareholder owned, company that helps finance about one of every eight home mortgages in the nation. It buys mortgages from lenders. It packages some into securities for resale to investors and buys and holds others.

DOC.HEAD: Things Looking Up for Hog Producers, USDA Says
DOC.TEXT: Hog producers are enjoying some relatively good times and further improvement may be on the way, says an Agriculture Department analysis. ``Returns have been on the upswing since last summer and could rise further during the second quarter as hog prices approach their seasonal peak,'' the department's Economic Research Service said. Market prices of slaughter hogs ``may reach the middle to upper $50s per hundredweight before the end of June, the highest in nearly three years,'' the agency said in the March issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. ``So far, prices in the first quarter have mostly been in the high $40s.'' On Monday, top barrows and gilts were quoted at $50.50 to $51 per 100 pounds, with some heavier weights ranging down to $46 and $47. ``A relatively low rate of hog slaughter this spring is expected to support prices,'' the report said. ``Based on the size of last fall's pig crop, second-quarter slaughter could be down 7 percent from a year earlier, the smallest for the spring quarter since 1987.'' Most hogs grow to market weights in five to seven months, so pigs farrowed in the fall usually make up most of the marketings in the second quarter. ``The reduced supply of market hogs this spring could create difficulties for the packing industry,'' the report said. ``Last year, while hog producers were paring herds, pork packers were expanding their slaughter capacity.'' Consequently, the spread between hog prices and fresh pork prices narrowed in 1989, and these packer margins will narrow further through the first half of this year. Looking at cattle, the report said Choice-grade steers at Omaha _ quoted at $76.50 to $77 on Monday _ ``may continue in the upper $70s per hundredweight through late winter but drop to the low-to-middle $70s in the spring'' as fed cattle marketings rise from year-earlier levels. Analysts said Choice retail beef prices set a record all-cut mark of $2.74 per pound in December, typically a month of low beef demand. ``The retail price for Choice beef will continue strong through the first quarter of 1990 despite beef price features in February, the national meat month,'' the report said. Meanwhile, with outdoor cooking just around the corner, broiler producers will probably boost production about 7 percent this year. As a result, wholesale and retail prices broiler prices ``will likely decline considerably'' this year, the report said. On an annual average, wholesale prices may be in the range of 49 to 55 cents per pound, compared with 59 cents in 1989. Wholesale turkey prices have dropped since December, and producer returns ``are currently below break-even,'' the report said. ``However, lower feed costs this year have compensated for some of the price weakness.''

Nine of the top 10 foreign markets for U.S. agricultural products spent more last year than they did in 1988, says the Agriculture Department. The exception was the European Economic Community. Japan, the perennial leader, imported $8.15 billion worth of U.S. products in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, up 12 percent from 1988. The EEC followed at $6.54 billion, down 13 percent from the previous year, according to AgExporter magazine. ``New export records were set for seven of the top 10 export markets for U.S. products _ Japan, Canada, Mexico, the Soviet Union, Iraq, South Korea and Taiwan,'' the report said. Overall, 1988-89 exports were valued at $39.7 billion, up 12 percent from the previous year. A number of factors contributed to the gain. ``Drought sharply reduced yields for most major bulk commodities in the United States and Canada in 1988, which resulted in a drawdown in stocks and higher prices,'' the report said. ``In addition, Asian economic affluence and growing demand for Western-style foods has pushed this region to the top spot as a market for U.S. agricultural exports,'' it added. Others in the top 10 included: Soviet Union, $3.19 billion, up 71 percent; Mexico, $2.77 billion, up 60 percent; South Korea, $2.45 billion, up 9 percent; Canada, $2.19 billion, up 11 percent; Taiwan, $1.59 billion, up 1 percent; China, $1.48 billion, up 142 percent; Egypt, $930 million, up 20 percent; and Iraq, $770 million, up 6 percent.

The Agriculture Department has announced that flue-cured tobacco farmers and buyers each will be assessed one cent per pound for the 1990 crop. The total of two cents per pound will be assessed, down slightly from last year's total of 2.24 cents. The No-Net-Cost Tobacco Program Act of 1982 requires that the program operate at no net costs to taxpayers. Officials said Monday they consulted with the Flue-cured Tobacco Cooperative Stabilization Corp., the producer-owned association that handles the support program, before determining the 1990 assessment.

DOC.HEAD: House Chairman Rebuffs Pentagon Request to Shift Funds
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon isn't getting much sympathy in the House for its request to avert an expected massive layoff of military personnel by taking $852 million from other accounts.
