The Defense Department made the request after deciding last year not to ask President Bush to exclude personnel from Gramm-Rudman budget cuts and after the administration chose not to seek an exemption as it had done previously. But House Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., with the backing of House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., declined to bring the request up before his panel, dooming the Pentagon's appeal. Such reprogramming of funds must be approved by the House and Senate armed services committees and the House and Senate appropriations panels. ``This is a disaster about to happen,'' Vice Adm. J.M. Boorda, deputy chief of naval operations for manpower, personnel and training, told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee. Boorda predicted that without the ability to transfer funds, the Navy will again be a hollow force. ``You'll have a Navy that looks like 1979 and you'll have it by September,'' he said. Other personnel service chiefs said they will be forced to lay off people, freeze promotions and take other drastic management steps if Congress fails to give them the authority to move the funds. The Defense Department has said it faces the dismissal of tens of thousands of men and women by October. The Bush administration could have exempted the military personnel accounts from the across-the-board cuts. Last week, Aspin said, ``Putting weapons before people was their decision and now they're stuck with it.'' On Monday, Aspin indicated that he won't back down from his decision. ``Reprogramming is going to be a useful exercise,'' Aspin told Army officials who appeared before his Armed Services panel. Democrats on the House committee warned Army Chief of Staff Gen. Carl Vuono and Army Secretary Michael P.W. Stone that Congress is looking at slashing $8 billion from Bush's $292 billion fiscal 1991 defense budget and they should draw up contingency plans for troop reductions. Earlier Monday, the assistant secretary of defense for force management and personnel told a Senate subcommittee that the Pentagon did not recommend to the president that military personnel be excluded from across-the-board cuts. Christopher Jehn said the Pentagon realized that excluding military personnel would have left the armed services with ``a full complement of people but not enough money to allow them to train and to exercise at the levels we thought appropriate.'' ``The tradeoff was whether we should protect personnel accounts and wind up with what amounted to an imbalanced budget,'' Jehn told the Senate Armed Services subcommittee on manpower and personnel. Questioned by Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, the panel's chairman, about the type of imbalances, Jehn said there would be ``extreme shortages of things like spare parts, fuel to support flying hours and steaming hours.'' ``We made the sacrifice of people for spare parts,'' Glenn interrupted. ``We did not make the sacrifice of people,'' Jehn answered.

DOC.HEAD: `Red October' Sails Off With $17.2 Million at Box Office
DOC.TEXT: ``The Hunt for Red October'' surfaced with a huge $17.2 million at the box office, making it the No. 1 film in the nation. According to figures released Monday, the high-tech submarine thriller starring Sean Connery and Alec Baldwin averaged $14,010 per screen over the weekend, an impressive take for a film playing in more than 1,200 theaters. Paramount Pictures said the film had the biggest opening weekend outside of the summer or Thanksgiving season. In the film based on Tom Clancy's best-selling novel, officers of a Soviet nuclear missile-firing sub piloted by Connery plan to defect. Baldwin plays a CIA agent who wants to bring the Soviet captain in from the cold. Sme had feared that glasnost would torpedo the film, with its Cold War theme. In second place was the Academy Award favorite ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' which netted $5.1 million, according to figures compiled by Exhibitor Relations Co. Third with receipts of $4.2 million was the Steven Seagal movie ``Hard to Kill.'' ``Madhouse,'' with John Larroquette and Kirstie Alley as a couple entertaining impossible house guests, landed in fourth with ticket sales of $3.1 million. Fifth was director Oliver Stone's ``Born on the Fourth of July'' with $2.1 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $17.2 million, 1,225 screens, $14,010 per screen, $17.2 million, one week. 2. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $5.1 million, 1,432 screens, $3,554 per screen, $60.3 million, 12 weeks. 3. ``Hard to Kill,'' Warner Bros., $4.2 million, 1,508 screens, $2,798 per screen, $33.3 million, four weeks. 4. ``Madhouse,'' Orion, $3.1 million, 1,555 screens, $1,989 per screen, $13.4 million, three weeks. 5. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $2.1 million, 1,434 screens, $1,470 per screen, $59.7 million, 11 weeks. 6. ``Revenge,'' Columbia, $2 million, 1,335 screens, $1,463 per screen, $12.9 million, three weeks. 7. ``Men Don't Leave,'' Warner Bros., $1.4 million, 802 screens, $1,760 per screen, $4.3 million, five weeks. 8. ``Glory,'' Tri-Star, $1.33 million, 811 screens, $1,645 per screen, $20.2 million, 12 weeks. 9. ``Stella,'' Disney, $1.28 million, 1,087 screens, $1,174 per screen, $17.4 million, five weeks. 10. ``Steel Magnolias,'' Tri-Star, $1.2 million, 1,173 screens, $1,005 per screen, $74.4 million, 16 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, PTA Want Parents in Schools
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is convinced _ along with national PTA President Ann Lynch and Chrysler Chairman Lee Iaccoca _ that parents hold the key to greater student achievement. ``Education is a national mission that must include parents,'' Bush told about 250 Parent Teacher Association leaders who met at the White House for a briefing Monday on the national education goals. ``After all, a school program won't kiss away the pain from an injured knee. A school program won't calm the fears of a child about to get a first shot. And a school program alone cannot instill a lifelong love of learning. But parents can spark the flame of curiosity by reading to their children, every night,'' the president said. Before the White House meeting, Lynch released a survey showing that most parents are not getting involved in their children's schools. ``Many parents are doing only half their job when it comes to getting a good education for their children,'' she said. ``I'm convinced if we get more adults dropping into the schools, the kids will stop dropping out,'' Iacocca said in a message accompanying the survey. The survey found that fewer than half of the parents, about 44 percent, had visited their children's schools to participate in a back-to-school night while 46 percent attended parent-organization meetings during fall 1989. ``Too many (parents) sit at home and complain about the schools without ever setting foot through the doors to find out how they can help,'' said Ms. Lynch. The most common reasons for visiting schools included attending a scheduled parent-teacher conference, which 71 percent had attended, or class or school program, which 64 percent had attended. The survey, commissioned by Newsweek Inc. for the national PTA and Chrysler's Dodge Division, was based on a national sample of parents in 538 households with children enrolled in kindergarten through 12th grade. Ninety percent of the children were in public school with 10 percent in either private or parochial schools. Dr. Ernest Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, suggested that parents be given at least a day or two off from work, with pay, to consult with teachers and spend time with their child at school. ``If society sees value in giving employees release time for jury duty and to vote, surely allowing parents time to be engaged in the education of their children is in the public interest,'' said Boyer. While the survey showed that parents' school involvement often was low, most parents said they were very active in their children's education at home. Two of every three, 69 percent, said they discussed school topics with their children nearly every school day. More than half, 58 percent, helped with homework at least two to three times a week, and 52 percent read to or with their children at least once a week. More than half, 57 percent, said their own role was ``extremely influential'' in their children's learning. However, 53 percent of the parents surveyed were not involved in any kind of parent group. Many of those parents cited lack of time or work commitments. Among parents who are involved in parent groups, a large majority are more likely to help with fund raising, 80 percent, and extracurricular events, 72 percent, than to volunteer in classrooms, 52 percent, or participate in curriculum or policy making, 33 percent. The survey was conducted by ICR Survey Research Group in Media, Pa. between Dec. 29 and Jan. 7. The margin of error is plus or minus 4.5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Donny Osmond flashed his perfect teeth, autographed pictures and even sang a little for an Arizona Senate committee. But the lawmakers weren't singing his song when they voted to require warning labels on risque records. The Judiciary Committee approved the measure 8-1 Monday. The recording industry opposes the bill, and Osmond, who acknowledged his ``goody-goody'' image, was the industry's star witness. Osmond, wearing a black leather jacket and cowboy boots, said he always had strict morals but had written lyrics that probably would qualify for the warning labels, especially if sung with a different intonation. The committee's audience included teen-agers with T-shirts promoting controversial groups, and many groaned at first when the pop singer got up to testify. But they laughed when he said, ``I'm a little out of my element.'' And they applauded when he finished testifying for their side after breaking into song. The bill's supporters countered with Steve Clifford, an insurance executive who said he had founded the heavy metal group Icon. Heavy metal ``is a destructive lifestyle,'' Clifford said, testifying in businessman's suit and neat haircut. ``It got me into drug abuse, alcoholism. I thought about suicide. I tampered with Satanism.''

A scriptwriter became the second man in a week to file a lawsuit accusing actor Eddie Murphy and Paramount Pictures of stealing the screenplay for ``Harlem Nights.'' Hafiz Farid of Newark, in a lawsuit filed in federal court Monday, claimed he sent copies of a screenplay titled ``Going Straight'' to Murphy, Paramount and actor Richard Pryor as early as 1989. Farid said many of his ideas were used in the 1989 ``Harlem Nights,'' starring Murphy and Pryor, but he received no credit or payment. Paramount spokeswoman Deborah Rosen rejected the claim. ``We have never heard of Mr. Farid,'' she said. ``We know of no similarity to anything Mr. Farid may have written.'' Last week, Michael Greene of Hempstead, N.Y., claimed his screenplay, ``A Halloween to Remember,'' was the real source of the movie. Greene said he submitted his script to Murphy last year but was told it had been rejected.

A woman who said she was romantically linked with Ben Vereen asked for a restraining order against the song-and-dance man after he allegedly broke into her apartment and assaulted her. Christine Rich filed a petition in Superior Court on Friday, alleging that Vereen, shouting profanities, kicked in her apartment door Thursday, grabbed her arm, neck and clothing and threw her to the ground. Ms. Rich said she dialed 911 and police arrived. Police Sgt. Roger Belding confirmed Monday that Vereen was arrested for investigation of a misdemeanor assault and released on his own recognizance after about two hours. A hearing on the restraining order was set for March 19. Michelle Marx, a spokeswoman for Vereen, said the entertainer had no comment about the allegations. Vereen battled alcohol and drug problems after the death of a 16-year-old daughter in 1987 and has become an anti-drug activist.

Bob Hope, unable to attend a charity event, bought five raffle tickets at $1,000 apiece to help out _ and one of them won him the grand prize, including a $50,000 car. When host Jimmy Stewart picked Hope's name Sunday, he said, ``You're not going to believe this. It's Bob Hope.'' The prize was a luxury BMW, a set of luggage and a trip to Germany. ``Isn't that amazing? I never win a thing,'' Hope said from his desert home Monday. Hope was performing Friday night in Texas and couldn't appear at the Beverly Hilton Hotel's ``An Evening of Elegance.'' He bought five of the 100 tickets sold for the benefit for abused and neglected children. It would seem the globe-trotting entertainer wouldn't need luggage or a free trip to Munich. He's made dozens of overseas trips to entertain U.S. troops over Christmas, including visits to Germany. ``You think you're kidding, don't you? I can use the luggage,'' Hope said. But he said he didn't know what he would do with the car.

Authors Studs Terkel and Kurt Vonnegut were among about 350 authors, editors, literary agents and sympathizers who staged a noisy protest accusing Random House of wrecking a key subsidiary for financial reasons. The protesters Monday charged that Random House owner Samuel I. Newhouse had effectively killed the subsidiary, Pantheon Books, by forcing the resignation Wednesday of its longtime editorial director, Andre Schiffrin. Terkel, clutching a plastic coffee cup in near-freezing weather, was among a number of Pantheon-published writers who turned out for the demonstration. Vonnegut, although not a Pantheon client, said he was ``disturbed that a great American institution like this should be destroyed.'' Random House chairman Alberto Vitale said he was ``absolutely puzzled'' by the reaction to Schiffrin's resignation. ``It's not Random House who is hurting anything,'' Vitale said in a telephone interview. ``Random House has kept Pantheon going all these years.''

DOC.NOTE: For release at 3 a.m. EST _ set by source
DOC.HEAD: World Bank to Double Lending for Education
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank, biggest source of loans to the Third World, said today it is planning to double its lending on education to $1.5 billion a year. Bank President Barber B. Conable announced the plan in a speech prepared for a week-long world conference on education being held at Jomtien, a seaside resort in Thailand. Copies of the speech were made available by World Bank headquarters in Washington. Conable estimated that 100 million Third World children are not enrolled in school. ``Education... is an indispensable segment of the bridge over which the poor can cross the gulf from misery to hope,'' he said. ``It is crucial to the empowerment of people.'' The World Bank, owned by 152 countries, lends more than $21 billion a year. Conable said that since 1963 it has lent about $10 billion for education, more than $2 billion of it for basic education, in 100 countries. Conable said that less than 50 cents of every $100 of international aid now goes to primary education. ``Clearly, the donor community cannot expect to be an effective partner in the efforts which flow from this conference unless there is a dramatic change in aid flows to basic education,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: George Washington could not tell a lie, but he apparently could leave behind a whopping debt. An ancestor of Jacob DeHaven, who lent Washington $450,000 worth of gold and supplies in 1777, is looking for repayment of the loan. With interest, the bill comes to $105.3 billion. ``If I owed the government this money, I would be expected to pay the principal, interest and any penalties that might have been incurred,'' said Carolyn Cokerham of San Antonio. Ms. Cokerham is one of nearly 2,000 living descendants of DeHaven, who made the loan to Washington to help defeat the British in the Revolutionary War. After the war, the government offered to repay DeHaven's loan in continentals, the then-worthless currency of the fledging country. But DeHaven refused and later died penniless. Ms. Cokerham and his other descendants have tried unsuccessfully to get the money repaid throughout the years. Jo Beth Kloecker, an attorney handling the case, said the U.S. Claims Court in Washington last month dismissed the lawsuit because the debt is more than 6 years old. She appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals. Ms. Cokerham claims her grandmother once had a contract signed by Washington promising repayment and 6 percent interest compounded annually. She said she'd like to receive some money, but she really wants her day in court. ``I want the government to admit that this was a debt of honor made by a patriotic man,'' she said. ``I hope it will be addressed in my lifetime, but it has been 213 years.''

News flash: Walt Disney doesn't operate in Florida. That's what Walt Disney Co. lawyers say in response to a lawsuit by Mary Costa, the voice of Sleeping Beauty. She wants a cut of the $29 million she says the entertainment giant has earned on the 1986 videotape version of the tale. ``The Walt Disney Co. is not qualified to do business in Florida and does not do business in Florida,'' said Disney Vice President Doris Smith said in papers filed in state court. But what about Walt Disney World near Orlando, which has been in operation since 1971 and draws millions of visitors every year? ``Of course (Walt Disney Co.) owns subsidiaries that are present and do business in Florida,'' Disney lawyer Luis Bustamante said in court papers. But he said, ``To uphold this (state court) order would be to declare that (Walt Disney Co.) can be sued in any state where people can buy Disney videocassettes or Mickey Mouse sweatshirts.'' The company wants the case heard in California. The argument didn't sway the Palm Beach County Circuit Court, which ruled in favor of Ms. Costa, a Palm Beach opera singer. But Disney isn't giving up: It will try to persuade an appeals court in West Palm Beach that Walt Disney doesn't operate in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,791.08, down 54.12 points, or 0.16 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Plans Trip to Namibia
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will attend independence ceremonies this month in Namibia on an African trip that could thrust him into negotiations to dismantle racial segregation in South Africa. So far, the State Department is giving few details on what could turn out to be a nine-day trip to a half-dozen countries. Spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler announced on Monday only his stop in Windhoek, the capital of Namibia. But preparations were under way for possible visits to Senegal, Zaire, Botswana, Zambia, Ivory Coast and South Africa, where the white minority government last month ended a 30-year ban on the African National Congress and released black leader Nelson Mandela from prison. Baker is going to Windhoek to join with other world leaders as the former South African colony gains independence and Sam Nujoma, a former guerrilla leader who spent 30 years in exile, is sworn in as president. Nujoma helped found the South-West Africa People's Organization in 1960 and led it through a 23-year bush war against South African rule of Africa's last colony. While representing President Bush at the ceremonies, Baker will have a chance to meet with South African President F.W. de Klerk and Mandela, but he is unlikely to turn the occasion into a substantive session about dismantling apartheid in South Africa, said a U.S. official, who spoke on condition on anonymity. Rather, the official told The Associated Press, it is ``highly likely'' that Baker would have those discussions in Cape Town and Johannesburg, South Africa, where he would meet with a wide range of government and opposition leaders. The Bush administration has praised de Klerk for the steps he has taken toward racial reconciliation, while urging him to move faster. Meanwhile, U.S. sanctions designed to punish South Africa for apartheid remain in place. Spokeswoman Tutwiler said the Windhoek stop was the only one scheduled so far. She said she did know when Baker would leave Washington or return home. ``We don't know anything other than the announcement I just made,'' she said. ``It could be the only stop he makes, it could be that other steps are added.''

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Debate Going Public
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain; Senate debate not expected to resume until mid-afternoon EST
DOC.TEXT: The Senate debate over cleaning up the nation's air is moving from behind closed doors to the Senate floor with consideration of compromise legislation that is endorsed by the White House. As the bill, representing the first tightening of federal air-pollution laws in 13 years, came up for discussions late Monday, it promptly came under attack as being too expensive and burdensome to industry. But Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he does not intend to see the legislation languish. He called it the best package that could be fashioned in nearly three weeks of closed-door talks with the Bush administration. ``We're going to stay with this bill until we complete it, sooner or later,'' said Mitchell. He said Congress has grappled with clean air legislation for a decade and ``rarely has there been legislation so thoroughly considered, so long debated, so much discussed.'' The way for floor action was cleared last week when Senate leaders and the White House agreed on curbs on toxic industrial chemicals released into the air, smog-causing pollutants from automobiles and the compounds that cause acid rain. It's uncertain how long the debate over the compromise legislation might last. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, last week urged Mitchell to allow ample time for discussions and amendments that might be brought up. After brief opening remarks by Mitchell and several senators Monday, the discussions were recessed and were not expected to resume until later today. But even before the revised legislation was brought to the floor, the compromise came under attack from both critics who said it was too tough on industry and senators who called it too weak to clean the dirty skies over the nation's cities. Sen. Steve Symms, R-Idaho, who was the only member of the Environment and Public Works Committee to vote against an earlier version of the legislation last November, said the compromise represented little improvement over the committee bill. It's the ``big long arm of the federal government intruding into the lives of the American people,'' said Symms. ``I'm not sure we need this bill right now.'' Mitchell snapped back that Symms ``has opposed every effort to improve the quality of America's air in the past 10 years.'' At a news conference, Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., said the legislation fails to require the auto emission controls needed to clean the air in seriously polluted areas such as the major metropolitan areas of the Northeast. ``Americans are choking on dirty air, and the clean air bill coming to the Senate floor just won't get the job done,'' said Lautenberg. He promised to seek some changes to the bill in the coming days. But the two floor managers of the bill _ Sens. Max Baucus, D-Mont., and John Chafee, R-R.I., _ said the bill represented a significant step forward in achieving cleaner air, including new controls on sulfur dioxide emissions from power plant and other boilers, a major precursor of acid rain. Among other provisions, the bill calls for annual sulfur dioxide emissions to be cut by 10 million tons or a bit less than half by the year 2000; tougher auto tailpipe controls and new curbs on industrial pollution to reduce urban smog in urban areas; and a requirement that industry use the best available technology to reduce toxic chemical releases. While the legislation moves to floor debate in the Senate, a similar clean air bill remains in a House committee.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Clean Air
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of the key provisions of the compromise clean air bill being considered by the Senate.

_Local communities must attain federal air quality standards within five, 10 or 15 years, depending on the severity of the problem. The Los Angeles area is allowed 20 years. _Areas must show annual progress, ozone reductions of 4 percent a year for the first six years and 3 percent annually thereafter. A waiver may be granted if the costs of the annual reductions exceed $5,000 per ton of ozone-forming pollutants. Reductions are to be attained through cuts in automobile emissions and smog-causing releases from industrial plants. Small business emitting less than 100 tons are exempt.

_Automakers must reduce tailpipe emissions of smog-causing pollutants with all cars covered by new emission controls by 1995. Hydrocarbons _ unburned fuel _ would have to be cut by 22 percent to 0.25 grams per mile and nitrogen oxides by 60 percent to 0.4 grams. A second round of tailpipe controls would go into effect in 2003 cutting emissions another 50 percent if 11 cities now with ``serious'' pollution problems fail to meet air quality standards. Cities with even more serious problems would have to use cleaner-burning fuels such as methanol or specially formulated gasoline.

_Utilities must reduce in two phases annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the year 2000 and cap emissions at 1980 levels at that time. First phase begins in 1995, but utilities using clean coal technology may delay initial compliance until 1997. Dirty plants, primarily in the Midwest, also received extra pollution control allowances, which may be sold to recoup some of control costs. Western states also receive additional bonus allowances to provide cushion for growth. _Nitrogen oxide emissions by utilities must be reduced 4 million tons by year 2005.

_Industry must install by 1997 the ``best available technology'' to reduce releases of 191 toxic chemicals by up to 90 percent. _The National Academy of Sciences will recommend methods for assessing remaining health risks, especially from cancer. The Environmental Protection Agency must implement health-based standards to deal with those risks after study is completed.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Study Finds Pop Quizzes Improve Learning
DOC.TEXT: College students prefer periodic tests or term papers to big final exams and learn more from teachers who give them substantial, immediate feedback, a Harvard University study found. For example, a ``one-minute, low-tech, no-cost'' technique is to ask students at the end of each class for a quick, one-paragraph summary of what they learned, said Richard J. Light, author of the three-year study issued Monday. The study concludes that modest shifts in academic policies can create major improvements in college classrooms. Light, a professor at Harvard's Graduate School of Education and Kennedy School of Government, based the study on in-depth interviews with 360 Harvard undergraduates _ conducted by their fellow students _ and seminars that included faculty and administrators from Harvard and about 20 other institutions. Among the conclusions of ``Explorations with Students and Faculty about Teaching, Learning and Student Life'': _Students said they learned the most in classes with periodic tests, oral presentations and papers that let them know how they were doing ``mid-course,'' rather than a big exam at the end of the course. In particular, students indicated they preferred opportunities to rewrite term papers after ``red-penciling'' by faculty. ``Students said they learned more from doing the fourth draft than by doing the first draft,'' Light said. _Students found small study groups of up to six people meeting outside the classroom particularly effective. Light said teachers should encourage formation of such groups. _Students in outside activities such as athletics or clubs, jobs or volunteer work for up to 35 hours a week ``are by far the happiest students,'' Light said. He said teachers should urge students to ``get involved.'' While only Harvard students were involved in the study, Light said the in-depth questionnaires and the information from the seminars made the results applicable to other institutions, including high school and graduate school. Light said he was surprised by some of the differences found between male and female students. For example, although there is no substantial difference between the grades of male and female students, 39 percent of the females said they were not happy with their academic performance, compared with 19 percent of men, he said. Also, although both groups indicated that study groups were effective, males were more likely to join one or form one, Light said. Twelve undergraduate and graduate students were trained by Light and other colleagues before they conducted interviews with the 360 randomly selected Harvard students. They used a 23-page questionnaire that included many open-ended questions. Follow-up interviews were done five to six months later. R. Eugene Rice, senior fellow at the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, said the Harvard study ``confirms a lot that we know about learning, in fact, just about human work in general _ the importance of feedback, its regulation and its timing.'' Rice said he hoped that faculty heeds the study's recommendations, but he noted that universities must then ``reward faculty for putting their time into this kind of teaching which take away time for work on research.''

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Representatives Seek US Aid for Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua is shopping for international aid for its incoming democratic government, and U.S. officials say they'll have a proposal ready to send President Bush within two weeks. Representatives of President-elect Violeta Chamorro, declaring their intention to seek aid from Japan and Western Europe, said Monday the Soviet Union has agreed to continue the economic assistance it gave to the Sandinista regime of President Daniel Ortega. Pedro Chamorro, son of the newly elected Nicaraguan leader, told reporters at the State Department: ``The Soviets assure us that they are going to help Nicaragua; they are going to honor their commitments.'' Commenting after a meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and other ranking officials, Chamorro said that while Soviet arms are no longer needed or wanted, continued imports of Soviet oil are vital to Nicaragua's recovery. Chamorro and other political and economic advisers to Mrs. Chamorro plan further talks with government officials and with representatives of international lending institutions. Bernard Aronson, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs, said a package of recommendations will be sent to Bush within the next two weeks, spelling out what the United States can do to help. The U.S. economic embargo imposed against the Sandinista regime likely will be lifted before Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration as president on April 25, Aronson said. A senior State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that to clear the way for U.S. aid to Nicaragua, Congress must agree to waive a law barring new assistance to a nation already in debt to the United States. He said there will be concerns about setting a precedent but added: ``I think there is a general recognition in both houses of Congress and in both parties that Nicaragua needs some immediate help.'' Chamorro and two other advisers to the new government _ Alfredo Cesar and Francisco Mayorga _ said no requests were made for a specific level of U.S. aid. Dollar figures will be discussed later, they said. Chamorro and Mayargo said the situation is complicated by the fact that the Sandinista government held economic data as a state secret. As a result, the full dimensions of Nicaragua's needs may not be known for some time, they said. Mayorga said, however, that ``hundreds of millions of dollars'' will be sought from all sources, including the United States. ``We expect the entire international community to contribute,'' he said. The Bush administration made clear that it also expects substantial help for Nicaragua from the international community, including Japan and Europe. ``The aid question is being worked on currently,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``We have optimism that the European allies, as well as the Soviet Union and Japan, are willing to help.'' Mrs. Chamorro's government _ which defeated Ortega and his leftists at the polls on Feb. 25 _ will replace the Sandinistas, whose overthrow the United States was unable to accomplish with military support for Contra rebels. Although the administration has pledged meaningful U.S. aid levels for Nicaragua, the final scope of the assistance package likely will be dictated by budget constraints and the needs of other fledgling democracies emerging in Eastern Europe. Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee that handles foreign aid, told reporters: ``There is a long line forming outside the door on that score. ... We need to be cautious about the kind of direct financial investments we are going to be asked to make at a time when we have limited resources.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother of Child Given Alcohol Charged in Boy's Death
DOC.TEXT: A woman was charged in the death of her 5-year-old son, who allegedly was given 10 ounces of bourbon and told to ``drink it like a man'' by a friend of his mother's. Patricia Griffin, 31, was jailed on $10,000 bail on charges of causing injury to a child by gross negligence in the death Wednesday of Raymond Thomas Griffin II. Anthony Jimerson, 21, was previously jailed on $100,000 bail on a charge of injury to a child. Witnesses have told police that Jimerson wanted the boy to go to sleep at a neighborhood gathering March 2 so he could be alone with Mrs. Griffin, said Police Chief Roger Larm. Larm said Monday that Ms. Griffin was negligent because the boy did not receive immediate medical attention. The offense carries 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $10,000. ``An ambulance wasn't called until 16 hours after the original consumption of alcohol, and 12 hours after he started being seriously ill,'' Larm said. Doctors said the boy suffered irreversible brain damage after drinking the bourbon and some beer and had a blood alcohol level of .55 percent, five times the legal definition of intoxication in Texas. He died at a hospital. A hearing was scheduled today to decide whether to keep the boy's 2-year-old brother in a foster home.

DOC.HEAD: US Officials Warn of US Retaliation Against Japanese Trade Policy
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is pressuring Japan to buy more American products or face the threat that ``festering frictions'' over Japan's huge trade surplus could result in U.S. retaliatory actions. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Monday the Japanese ``risk having our market closed or at least gravely limited'' if they fail to dismantle their barriers to U.S. goods. She said President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu agreed during a weekend summit that there was considerable urgency in reducing America's $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. But at a congressional hearing Monday, two key senators expressed disappointment that the summit produced no trade breakthroughs. Administration witnesses were questioned closely on why there has been no progress despite six months of talks aimed at removing Japanese trade barriers. ``Anti-Japanese sentiment in the United States is rising fast,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. ``Japan has a choice. It can either follow the lead of the rest of the world and open its markets or it can keep its markets closed and have the rest of the world follow its lead.'' In a pointed reference to the expanded retaliatory tools Congress gave the administration two years ago, Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said, ``If we didn't go far enough in 1988, believe me, we can go further.'' Hills, answering questions following a speech, said there would be ``tremendous political pressure'' in the United States to retaliate if the Kaifu government does not move promptly to attack the trade imbalance. ``There's no question that Japan has gained its economic well-being from worldwide trade and worldwide investment,'' she said. ``If it fails to open its markets to the same extent to our entrepreneurs, they risk having our market closed or at least gravely limited and therein risk killing the goose that laid their golden egg as well as ours.'' In Tokyo, Kaifu defended his summit meeting with Bush against critics who demanded to know what types of commitments Kaifu had made in response to U.S. pressure. ``The United States is willing to have a dialogue with us. Do you really believe dialogue is bad?'' Kaifu asked during parliamentary debate. The dispute between the two nations involves so-called structural impediment talks aimed at attacking economic shortcomings in both nations that have been blamed for the trade imbalance. American negotiators have demanded that the Japanese reform their distribution system to allow the sale of more imported goods and tighten enforcement of anti-monopoly laws to prevent Japanese companies from freezing out foreign firms. Following the two-day summit, Bush said the United States would do its part by reducing the federal budget deficit, improving education and worker training and increasing savings and investment. At Monday's hearing by the Senate Finance subcommittee on trade, Undersecretary of State Richard McCormack said U.S. negotiators will be looking for significant progress at the fourth round of negotiations, scheduled for April 2-3 in Washington. But administration officials conceded they have no assurance of any breakthrough either in April or before a final report is due in July. ``The basic question is whether the Japanese side sees this as a damage control exercise _ public relations _ or whether they see it as one requiring substantive effort,'' said Deputy U.S. Trade Representative S. Linn Williams. ``On that point the jury is still out.'' J. Michael Farren, the Commerce Department's undersecretary for trade, said the U.S. trade deficit, which totaled $108.6 billion last year, has improved with Japan by only 15 percent since 1987. During the same period, the U.S. deficit with Germany was cut in half and it was reduced by 29 percent with Korea, Taiwan and other East Asian countries. ``There is an all-but-explicit underlying assumption that the Japanese surplus must be maintained ... as a hedge against anticipated oil price increases,'' Farren said. ``American workers will continue paying the insurance premium with the price being American jobs and a diminishing U.S. standard of living.''

DOC.HEAD: Burt Sues CBS Over `West 57th' Show
DOC.TEXT: A former gynecologist accused of performing genital surgery on women without their knowledge to enhance their sexual responsiveness is suing CBS for $250 million over a ``West 57th Street'' broadcast. CBS said it stands by the story on James C. Burt, who alleged in the lawsuit filed Monday in federal court that he was defamed by the program. Burt, 68, faces about 50 malpractice suits for his self-described ``love surgery,'' in which he altered the genitals of his patients, allegedly without their consent. He said the surgery was designed to enhance their responsiveness. Burt sued over a 1988 broadcast of the news show that contained interviews with several former patients. The program is no longer on the air. The show's ``ludicrous and horrendous programming of the segment concerning `The Love Doctor and his Love Surgery' started a chain reaction of talk shows, magazine articles, media reports that have since totally destroyed my personal life, my profession as physician, loss of property, loss of income, my family,'' Burt said in a statement. Also named as defendants were two past or present CBS employees, a patient and another doctor. ``We believe the report was entirely fair and accurate, and CBS News stands by it,'' said CBS spokesman Tom Goodman. In 1989, Burt surrendered his medical license just days before a disciplinary hearing. The board had charged that the surgery caused sexual dysfunction, emotional distress, infection, chronic pain and the need for corrective surgery in some patients. ``This has been the biggest hoax that TV has ever seen,'' Burt said. ``I have never operated on anybody without informed consent.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopia's Leader Wants Capitalism, Says Marxism Failed
DOC.TEXT: President Mengistu Haile Mariam has declared a failure the Marxist economic system he and fellow army officers imposed after overthrowing the late Emperor Haile Selassie in 1974. In a speech Monday to the Central Committee of the ruling Marxist Workers' Party, Mengistu said he wants a return to capitalism. The embattled president is fighting two bitter guerrilla wars simultaneously and facing cuts in aid from his principal benefactor, the Soviet Union. He appears to be wooing foreign investment. The Central Committee must approve Mengistu's recommendations, but there appeared to be little chance that it would not go along with his plans for a drastic overhaul of the country's shattered economy. In recent months, Mengistu has taken many small, seemingly half-hearted steps to attract foreign investment and encourage domestic production, but his speech Monday appeared a near total capitulation to capitalism. He conceded that economic central planning had been a failure. Among the specific reforms Mengistu mentioned were: _ Allowing the private sector to take part in all sectors of the economy with no limit on capital investment. Ethiopia has had a $250,000 ceiling on all types of private investment. _ Giving government-owned land on a concessional basis to private commercial firms for construction of industries, hotels and a wide range of other enterprises. _ Allowing developers to build houses, apartments and office buildings for rent or sale. At present, all land and commercial deeds are held by the government. _ Putting the government's myriad of state-owned industries and businesses on a profit basis, with those continuing to lose money to be sold or closed. _ Giving peasant farmers legal ownership of the land they till and the right to sell their produce to private wholesale and retail outlets. Ownership of the land has been held by the state, with purchase of crops handled by government marketing boards. Mengistu also told the Central Committee that Ethiopia's strategic Red Sea port of Massawa has been ``paralyzed'' by renewed fighting between the government and the secessionist Eritrean People's Liberation Front. He did not, however, acknowledge a rebel claim that the port had been captured. The Eritrean rebels have been fighting the government for 28 years for independence for Ethiopia's northernmost province, a former Italian colony. They launched a new offensive in February after an almost year-long, de facto cease-fire. Mengistu did say another major rebel group, the Tigre People's Liberation Front, had recaptured the vital garrison town of Debre Tabor, cutting off government access to much of Gondor Province. The town fell to the Tigrean rebels shortly after they also ended a long cease-fire with an offensive in August. The government managed to take it back in January, but the rebels claimed to have captured it once again last month. The Tigrean rebels seek the overthrow of Mengistu and the replacement of his government with one patterned after that of Albania, the last hard-line Stalinist regime in Eastern Europe. In recent years, Ethiopia has been the Soviet Union's staunchest ally in Africa. The Soviets, however, have been pressing Mengistu to negotiate with rebels and end the costly war in an effort to cut Soviet aid to Ethiopia. Moscow sent $600 million in arms to Ethiopia last year.

DOC.HEAD: White Surges as Richards Stumbles on Drug Question
With PM-Ill Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ann Richards just won't say no _ or yes _ to whether she's ever misused drugs, jeopardizing her run for governor. With the Democratic primary election a week away, the state treasurer Monday blasted her opponents _ former Gov. Mark White and Attorney General Jim Mattox _ saying they have ducked questions about their personal finances. But Ms. Richards wouldn't say whether she's ever used an illegal drug, a question raised at two debates, the first of them two weeks ago. The question has dogged her ever since. At a news conference, Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, said she never knowingly committed a felony and repeated a statement she has made before: ``I haven't had a mood-altering chemical for 10 years.'' On the Republican side, three contenders are trying to keep multimillionaire oilman Clayton Williams from winning the nomination outright without a runoff. After pumping more than $4 million of his own into a slick TV campaign, the colorful Williams stood at 45 percent in a Dallas Morning News-Houston Chronicle poll published Feb. 25. If he wins 50 percent in the March 13 balloting, he avoids a runoff election for the GOP nomination to succeed retiring Republican Gov. Bill Clements. Among the Democrats, Ms. Richards had been front-runner since entering the race in June, until White pulled ahead in the Feb. 25 poll, which showed him with 34 percent to Ms. Richards' 31 percent. Mattox was third at 17 percent. Richards, who captured national attention at the Democratic National Convention two years ago by describing George Bush as having been born with ``a silver foot in his mouth,'' hasn't displayed a silver tongue on the drug issue, observers have said. Her tack Monday was to attack her opponents. ``I have been sober for 10 years,'' Ms. Richards said. ``Have Jim Mattox and Mark White been honest for 10 years?'' White and Mattox have said they never used illegal drugs, and both on Monday denied any financial improprieties. They said her charges reflect Ms. Richards' fall in recent opinion polls after being the front-runner for months. ``I feel sorry for Ann. Sorry that she is so desperate that she feels she has to lash out this way with such ridiculous and outrageous charges,'' White said. ``She's desperate. Her campaign's in a tailspin,'' said Kelly Fero, press secretary for Mattox's campaign. On the drug issue, Ms. Richards said, ``I feel very sincerely that the continuing dialogue is very destructive. It is destructive for me. It is destructive for other people out there who might seek treatment. The important thing in this time is to put principle above politics.'' Ms. Richards, who has made public income tax returns for all years she has been treasurer, criticized White for releasing only his 1988 return and Mattox for keeping all of his confidential.

DOC.BYLINE: Rise in Student Cheating: Sign of the Times? ^With PM-Harvard Study, Bjt ^By LESLIE DREYFOUS
DOC.TEXT: Cheating appears to be on the rise among college students, according to researchers who say the trend may be a sign of today's ``make it'' mentality. Studies indicate about 20 percent to 30 percent of students cheat. Some copy from classmates' work, others plagiarize term papers or use crib sheets during exams, while others take advantage of computer technology. ``One student who was caught couldn't understand what he'd done that was so wrong,'' said Arthur Levine, chairman of Harvard University's Institute for Educational Management. ``His argument amounted to: `Everyone cheats and as long as I do it well, I won't get caught and will succeed in society.''' Forty-three percent of 5,000 professors nationwide responded ``yes'' when the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching asked: ``Are today's undergraduates more willing to cheat in order to get good grades?'' ``Perhaps the most discouraging side of the survey data is the portrait faculty paint of students, both in the classroom and beyond,'' the Princeton-based foundation's president, Ernest L. Boyer, wrote on releasing the study in November. Getting ahead any way you know how is sometimes perceived as part of playing the game of survival, college administrators said Monday. ``Students read the newspaper and look at television and see plenty of examples of dishonesty in society,'' said Timothy F. Brooks, dean of students at the University of Delaware in Newark, Del. ``It's a massive problem and a disturbing reflection of our society.''

DOC.HEAD: Carlos Kleiber Conducts Met `Otello'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Carlos Kleiber conducted Verdi's ``Otello'' at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time. The audience heard something much different from the usual ``Otello.'' The emphasis Monday was on the entire evening as one piece of music, telling a story. Met audiences probably have never heard so much soft singing in ``Otello.'' Arias weren't done as set pieces that stopped at the end for applause. Understatement ruled, and when a loud outburst came, it was very dramatic. Placido Domingo sang Otello, Katia Ricciarelli was Desdemona and Justino Diaz was Iago. Miss Ricciarelli, who hasn't been at the Met since 1982, probably came off best singing softly. She floated some lovely pianissimos. Her voice sounds right for the part, secure but sweet. Domingo was splendid, continuing to display more dept in his characterization and in his dramatic tenor the more he sings Otello. Diaz has a wonderful tone and, as a bass instead of a baritone Iago, can insinuate even more of that low, evil sound as Iago infects Otello with jealousy. With a boyish haircut and singing softly much of the time, Diaz took more a snake-in-the-grass approach than rough or devilish one. This production, new in 1972, has always had Iago carrying books hither and yon while singing his ``Credo.'' That's one aria we'd like to have the singer stand and deliver. On Monday, there were several solos instead of all choral singing when people bring flowers to Desdemona in Act 2. And there have been changes in staging. Instead of climbing the stairs to their castle while singing love music, with bright stars behind them, at the end of Act 1, Otello and Desdemona nestle down, singing, on the Cyprus dock, with only a few subdued stars. This is a subtle and subdued reading of ``Otello,'' with dynamic range and great musical beauty.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Recalling Microwave Soup
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. is recalling 24,000 packages of its Microwave Chunky Beef Soup because it could contain harmful organisms. The soup was made in the company's Maxton, N.C., facility and distributed to retail stores in Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Wisconsin. Some of the 24,000 packages also were distributed to the military. The soup was packaged in paper cartons, each containing one 9{-ounce microwavable plastic bowl with a ``metallized sealed lid,'' an Agriculture Department announcement said Monday. The suspected product is identified by a three-line code stamped on the side panel of the package. Only packages with the code ``Dec90, Est4R, CO9J'' are being recalled. The problem was reported to USDA after company officials discovered that one day's production was not sterile and ``could allow the growth of organisms that cause illness, if those organisms were present,'' the agency said. Consumers with questions about the recall may call the toll-free USDA hotline at 1-800-535-4555 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EST, Monday through Friday. In the Washington metropolitan area, the number if 447-3333.
DOC.HEAD: Chicago Teen-ager Wins $20,000 Science Award
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old Chicago youth has won a $20,000 college scholarship for a project on molecular genetics he believes may advance understanding of the conversion of nitrogen from air into ammonia. Matthew Peter Headrick won first place in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the nation's oldest high school science competition. His selection was announced Monday night at an awards banquet attended by more than 500 leaders from science, government, education and business. The next two top winners were David Ruchien Liu, 16, of Riverside, Calif., who entered a neuroscience project, and David Michael Shull, 17, of Tacoma, Wash., who developed a method of placing the genetic coding for production of a molecule into white blood cells. They each received $15,000 awards. The fourth through 10th place winners and scholarship amounts were: _Soojin Ryu, 18, Bronx, N.Y., $10,000; _Joshua Fischman, 17, Bethesda, Md., $10,000; _Royce Yung-Tze Peng, 17, Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., $10,000; _Laura Andrea Ascenzi, 17, Sunnyside, N.Y., $7,500; _Andrew M. Lines, 17, Arlington, Va., $7,500; _Mina Kim Yu, 17, of Fairfax, Va., $7,500; _Bianca Denise Santomasso, 17, New York City, $7,500.
DOC.HEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Ordered to Pay More Than $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: An arbitration panel has ordered Shearson Lehman Hutton to pay damages totaling more than $1 million to three Oklahomans who claimed their broker made unauthorized trades and churned their accounts. An arbitration panel of the National Association of Securities Dealers ordered Shearson to pay $994,766 in compensatory and punitive damages and lawyers' fees to Temple, Okla. farmer Walter Earl Cox and his wife, Ardenia F. Cox. In a decision late last month, disclosed Monday, the panel also awarded separately a total of $60,694 in damages and fees to Mrs. Cox and her mother, Cuba E. Read, of Comanche, Okla. The treble compensatory damages stemmed from claims made by the Coxes under the civil provisions of the federal racketeering laws. Both awards came in response to claims made against one-time Shearson registered representative Lindy Kent Ridinger of Wichita Falls, Texas. The Coxes' lawyer, Frank Lewis, of Phoenix, Ariz., said the decision was the first he knew of where both punitive and treble damages were awarded as well as attorney's fees. Shearson denied the accusations and Ridinger, who was fired June 2, 1986, never responded to the charges, according to documents of the NASD. Ridinger was formally censured by the NASD, barred from associating with its members ``in any capacity'' and fined $50,000. He was not reachable for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended lower against the Japanese yen today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index fell back after early gains. The dollar closed at 149.50 yen, down 0.45 yen from Monday's 149.95-yen finish. It opened at 148.97 yen and ranged between 148.50 yen and 149.55 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,791.08, down 54.12 points, or 0.16 percent. It had lost 212.36 points Monday. Dealers said the index started falling in the afternoon session as market players sold electrical issues following a rumor that the business performance of some electrical companies, including Fanuc Ltd. and Amada Co., had deteriorated. The rumors turned out to be false, said Kazuyuki Suzuki of Daiwa Securities. Government bond prices edged up as market players were reassured by the yen's recovery against the dollar. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bond rose to 87.08 in late afternoon, up 0.08 from Monday's close of 87.00. Its yield fell to 7.105 percent, down 0.025 from Monday's 7.13 percent. The dollar's lower opening in Tokyo followed its fall against almost all major currencies overnight as central banks engaged in coordinated dollar-selling. The central banks of Japan, the United States, Britain, France and West Germany bought their own currencies in an effort to push the dollar down, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. But the dollar strengthened slightly after the release of the Bank of Japan's quarterly economic report, which market players interpreted as indicating there would be no increase soon in the bank's official discount rate, the interest it charges for loans to commercial banks. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told reporters today that the framework of international cooperation remains strong and coordinated action will continue to ensure stability in foreign exchange markets. He said U.S. concern over current dollar-yen exchange rates was made clear at the weekend summit between President Bush and Japanese Prime Minster Toshiki Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif. In recent days, the dollar has been at its highest level since mid-June last year. With a few pauses, it had gained 5.43 yen since Feb. 19 before today's fall. The Bank of Japan was seen selling ``a couple billion dollars'' in today's trading to check the dollar's rise, traders said. The central bank does not comment on its exchange market activities. Kanai said many market players reduced their dollar-holding positions in case the Bank of Japan raises its discount rate Wednesday. The bank's governor, Yasushi Mieno, leaves for Europe Wednesday and there had been speculation the bank would raise the rate before he leaves. Japanese market players had been expecting a discount rate increase since after nationwide elections last month, to stem inflationary pressure. After three increases last year, the nation's key lending rate stands at 4.25 percent, still the lowest among the group of seven advanced industrial nations. Growing uncertainties about the interest rate began discouraging stock investment and yen-buying, and on Feb. 26 the Nikkei took its second-largest plunge one-day ever, 1,569.10 points.

DOC.HEAD: Whitney Museum Board Fires Director
DOC.TEXT: The 15-year director of the Whitney Museum of American Art has been fired amid complaints about his leadership, a proposed expansion project and exhibitions a scholar derided as contemporary schlock. The board's dismissal Monday of Thomas N. Armstrong III was announced by museum president William Woodside. Woodside, in a statement, commended the director for having ``enlivened and invigorated'' the museum but said the board saw a need for new leadership appropriate to the ``changing climate'' facing private cultural institutions. Armstrong declined to comment Monday. His dismissal came after months of speculation that the board was dissatisfied with him. His critics said the museum lacked direction under him and cited what they saw as trendy exhibitions, his failure to hire a strong chief curator and his alienation of some donors. Woodside had asked Armstrong to resign late last year but Armstrong refused and sought support from board members, art dealers and donors. Supporters praised him in a petition signed last week by more than 200 people. Some reports said he had made some anti-Semitic remarks, but one board member, Robert W. Wilson, told The New York Times last month the alleged remarks were being excluded from any consideration of Armstrong's future. A scholar in American art told the Times in December that the museum had exhibited ``too much contemporary schlock and too many superficial exhibitions of meaningful American artists.'' The scholar declined to be identified. Another problem concerned a proposed $37.5 million addition that would double the museum's size. The plan, unveiled in 1985, drew criticism because it proposed to wrap the new structure around the original museum, which was designed by modernist architect Marcel Breuer. The plans were revised. Woodside said a search committee will choose a new director.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois GOP Fights Over Abortion, Taxes in Primary for Governor
LaserPhoto CX2
DOC.TEXT: Abortion and taxes are dividing Republicans in a primary battle as the party desperately seeks to hold onto its last major political bastion in Illinois _ the governor's mansion. The embattled front-runner in the March 20 Republican primary is Secretary of State Jim Edgar, a pro-choice moderate who is the near-unanimous choice of the state GOP hierarchy to succeed retiring four-term Gov. James R. Thompson. His chief opponent is Steven Baer, a 30-year-old conservative political organizer who is attacking Edgar as a ``tax-and-spend liberal'' and pro-abortion extremist. The contest has conservative stalwarts like Phyllis Schlafly and Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., in opposing camps, and puts the national party in the position of backing a candidate whose stand on abortion and taxes bears little resemblance to its 1988 platform. But many elected Republicans and party leaders say victory is more important than ideology in this race. ``We just can't afford to lose a governorship in a state like Illinois in an off-year election,'' said Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater. ``It's absolutely critical that we have the strongest candidate, and that's Jim Edgar.'' Edgar, 43, has been a rising star of the state GOP for nearly a decade. Appointed by Thompson in 1981 to fill a vacancy in the patronage-rich secretary of state's office, he won re-election twice. He seemed to have scared off potential gubernatorial opposition within his party last summer with a long list of endorsements and a campaign bankroll that now stands at $3.2 million. Edgar declared that the state should make permanent a two-year, 20 percent state income tax increase approved by the Legislature in June. He also bluntly stated his support for abortion rights, including lifting the state's near-total ban on Medicaid-funded abortions. Those stands brought to a boil the conservative discontent that had simmered under Thompson, a moderate who vetoed anti-abortion legislation on constitutional grounds and spent much of his current term pushing for tax increases. ``Thompson was pro-abortion, but he wasn't as up-front about it as Edgar,'' said Mrs. Schlafly, who is supporting Baer. ``Edgar starts out his speech by saying he's pro-abortion.'' Baer pledges to be ``a governor who can read our president's lips'' and oppose higher taxes. He has put that message on thousands of videotapes mailed to grass-roots Republicans, church groups and anti-abortion activists. Baer argues that his anti-tax stance is an effective strategy against the likely Democratic gubernatorial nominee, Attorney General Neil Hartigan, who is pro-choice but has taken a wait-and-see stance on extension of the tax increase. ``The Republican Party in Illinois can have its cake and eat it, too,'' Baer said. ``We can win and still be able to sleep at night.'' Edgar said his views on abortion coincide with those of most Illinoisans and added that his party should have learned a lesson from the victories of pro-choice Democrats in recent New Jersey and Virginia gubernatorial races. He said he has moved to win broad support within his party by calling for curbs on government spending and assembling a Conservatives for Edgar committee headed by Hyde, who acknowledges that politics took precedence over philosophy in his endorsement. With Democrats likely to retain control of the Legislature in the fall election, the gubernatorial race is the GOP's best hope for gaining leverage in the legislative and congressional reapportionment that begins in 1991. ``We don't control the Legislature, we don't control the mayor's office in Chicago, we don't control a United States Senate seat,'' Edgar said. ``If we lose the governor's office, the Republican Party is going to be a very distinct minority in Illinois.''

DOC.HEAD: Reality of Rare Ritual Cloaked in Mystery
DOC.TEXT: The rare ritual of exorcism, practiced twice by the New York Archdiocese in a year, is cloaked in mystery even for those most familiar with it. But priests say the movie ``The Exorcist'' depicted it pretty well. ``A lot of people think they know the answer, but my experience is nobody really does,'' said the Rev. John Nicola, a priest with the Washington Archdiocese who assisted at four exorcisms in Rome from 1973 to 1975. He added, ``Even psychiatrists who have no belief in the supernatural will tell you about cases.'' Catholic theologians expressed surprise Monday that Cardinal John J. O'Connor reported the two New York exorcisms. He made the disclosure during a Sunday sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral in which he said, ``Diabolically instigated violence is on the rise.'' The cardinal said the exorcisms were approved by the archdiocese's vicar general and appeared to be successful, but he gave no details. He also said the novel ``The Exorcist'' is a ``gruesomely authentic'' portrayal of demonic possession. Nicola agreed. Being there, Nicola said, ``is quite scary.'' Typically, said the Rev. James T. Burtchaell, theology professor at Notre Dame University, an exorcist must be a ``very self-possessed, consistently holy man'' to survive the experience. ``It involves a great deal of self-abuse, bodies being flung around the room, excrement, assumed voices _ it's pretty vile stuff,'' he said. ``The darn movie is going to be the image everybody has. But, I must say, events in the movie are very faithful to stories I've read'' about real exorcisms. Exorcisms are confidential; no figures are kept on the number performed in the United States, said Bill Ryan, spokesman for the U.S. Catholic Conference in Washington. But Nicola estimated investigations result in only one exorcism every two years in this country. In Europe, some dioceses might have five or 10 a year. In parts of Asia, Africa, South America and Mexico, ``it might be an everyday thing.'' Pope John Paul II recently increased the number of exorcists in Rome and in Turin, where there are a reported 40,000 devil worshipers, the San Francisco Chronicle reported in December. The Rev. Simon Harak, a Catholic priest and theology professor at Fairfield University in Connecticut, said the church's book of rituals recognizes exorcisms for people ``who are no longer in charge of their own will.'' Exorcism existed before the time of Christ, and Harak said it may gain prevalence in times or places of satanic worship. ``In the gospels, there's quite a bit of reference to Jesus not only healing people of diseases but freeing them from diabolical possession,'' said Burtchaell. ``Ever since then, there have been outbreaks of similar behavior.'' Besides the most radical form of exorcism, there are ceremonies dealing with evil spirits, including a baptismal prayer, more common in the Roman Catholic Church. ``It's not like, `Oh, my goodness, William Peter Blatty's ``The Exorcist.''' It's a recognition that there are good spirits, angels, and bad spirits, devils,'' Harak said.

DOC.HEAD: Bar Examiners Won't Grade Earthquake-Interrupted Portion
DOC.TEXT: State bar examiners decided not to grade the afternoon session of the bar exam taken Feb. 28 in fairness to Southern California applicants who were forced out of the test center by an earthquake. The quake, measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale, forced about 800 law students to evacate two buildings at the Ponoma fairgrounds test site. The would-be lawyers had about one hour and 15 minutes left in testing time when the quake struck. It caused minor damage and injuries in the region. An estimated 4,100 California applicants took the Multistate Bar Examination last month, about 2,800 of them in Southern California. The Committee of Bar Examiners decided in emergency session it would be unfair to grade the afternoon session for any of the applicants. They said they will score each applicant based on the morning session and then use a national sample of those who took the Multistate to come up with an overall score.

DOC.HEAD: South African Troops Try To Restore Order In Tribal Homeland
By BARRY RENFREW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: South African paratroopers attempted today to end massive rioting and looting in the Ciskei homeland that left at least 20 people dead and more than 550 injured in the wake of a military coup. South African forces set up road blocks around the Ciskei capital of Bisho and sent out patrols as senior officers planned the deployment of more troops, officials said. There were no reports of any clashes involving South African forces, but looting was continuing in some areas, they said. Doctors at hospitals in Ciskei and nearby East London in South Africa said at least 20 people had been killed and more than 550 injured in two days of rioting and looting. They said most had suffered gunshot and stabbing wounds. Rioting erupted after the Ciskei army ousted the nominally independent homeland's authoritarian president in a bloodless coup. Sunday's coup was widely acclaimed by most Ciskeians, who opposed the old government because of its authoritarian rule and repression of anti-apartheid activists. President Lennox Sebe, 63, was on a trade mission in Hong Kong when the military seized power. He had been in power since 1981. The coup leaders said they favor returning Ciskei to South Africa. Many blacks accuse South Africa's white minority government of creating such homelands to try to restrict blacks to the most isolated and underdeveloped parts of the country. Ciskei, a 3,600-square-mile territory of about one million people on the southeast coast, is one of 10 black homelands. None is recognized as sovereign by any country other than South Africa. The jubilation over the coup turned to horror Monday when thousands of people began looting and burning stores and factories. More than 50 factories, many of them owned by Israeli and Taiwanese firms, were burned as drunken mobs went on the rampage in several towns. ``It was a drunken orgy of violence. It looks like a war zone. Dozens of buildings were gutted,'' said local journalist Louise Flanagan. South Africa sent in the troops at the request of Brig. Gen. Oupa Gqozo, the coup leader and head of the new military government. The Ciskei army, cheered by the rioters, made no attempt to stop the lawlessness, eyewitnesses said. ``We didn't expect the jubilation of the people to turn into such turmoil, but seeing that has happened we have asked for further reinforcements from South Africa, and they have responded positively,'' Gqozo told reporters. South Africa initially declined to intervene, but sent troops into Ciskei after angry crowds menaced government buildings in Bisho. Protesters initially attacked and looted shops belonging to officials of the ousted Ciskei government. But the crowds began attacking all businesses and hundreds of buildings, shops, factories and vehicles were torched, witnesses said. Rioters, many of them drunk, broke into shops, removed goods then set buildings ablaze with firebombs, the witnesses said. Looters used wheelbarrows to haul away stoves, refrigerators and other items, officials said. Foreign-owned factories were burned because the old government attracted overseas investment by providing workers at wages of $50 a month or less. Working conditions reportedly were very harsh. Gqozo received a rousing cheer Monday when he told thousands of people at a stadium in Bisho that the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups would be free to engage in political activity in Ciskei. The ANC is the main black group fighting the South African government. President F.W. de Klerk legalized the ANC last month, but some homeland leaders do not allow the group to operate in the territories they control. Gqozo made the announcement following meetings Monday with the ANC-aligned United Democratic Front. South Africa established the homelands in the 1960s in an attempt to create separate, tribal-based states for blacks while whites would retain control of national politics and the economy. Gqozo said he would like to see Ciskei relinquish its nominal independence and return to South Africa. The Transkei homeland is considering a similar plan. The South African government has not taken a position on homelands that want to return to South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Report: $1 Million Runaway Fund Used for Loans to Board Members
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Bruce Ritter denied any wrongdoing in setting up a trust fund of nearly $1 million for runaways that also was used to make loans to two Covenant House board members and Ritter's sister, The New York Times said today. Officials of Covenant House, built by Ritter into the nation's biggest network of shelters for runaways, told the newspaper the loans from the tax-exempt fund were made without the knowledge of most members of the board. It was not known whether the loans were illegal, the newspaper said; that would depend partly on what information was provided to the Internal Revenue Service and the state attorney general. Ritter, who resigned last week as president of Covenant House amid allegations of sexual misconduct involving young runaways, confirmed the loans and said he did nothing wrong. ``I thought I was doing a good thing to take care of the kids,'' the Roman Catholic priest said. Ritter said he created the fund in 1983 out of his salary to support Covenant House programs that the charity otherwise could not afford. Covenant House later made contributions directly to the fund, the newspaper said. The fund received tax-exempt status in 1984, said Edmund J. Burns, its trustee. ``It was my salary,'' Ritter said. ``God help me, I earned it, seven days a week, year-round.'' Two board members who benefited from trust loans _ James J. Maguire and Dr. James T. Kennedy _ recently resigned, the Times said. Maguire in 1988 borrowed $100,000, which is still outstanding. Separately, in 1986, Maguire sold the trust five acres of undeveloped land for $80,000. In 1989, the trust sold the land to Kennedy for $120,000. Kennedy paid $30,000 cash and the trust gave him a 10 percent mortgage on the balance, the Times said. In another instance, the trust made a 1987 loan of $131,000 to Ritter's sister, Cassie Wallace, of Trenton, N.J., who was moving to North Carolina and was having trouble selling her house, the Times said. The next year she repaid $107,781 and Ritter himself paid the rest, $23,319, out of personal funds, the Times said. The interest also was paid.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Soldiers Were Carrying Cocaine Out of Panama
DOC.TEXT: U.S. soldiers took payoffs of up to $10,000 from Colombian drug suppliers to smuggle cocaine in their duffel bags aboard military flights to the United States, CBS reported. The smuggling ring was broken up recently in Panama, the network said Monday. Citing unidentified military sources, CBS said at least seven Colombians and two Americans were arrested. One serviceman confessed that he recruited soldiers to smuggle cocaine aboard the flights home, CBS said. The Pentagon referred questions about the report to the U.S. Southern Command in Panama City. A spokesman there, Marjorie A. Boggs, said, ``We are coordinating with investigative agencies to see if there is anything to'' the report. The network said officials investigating Friday's grenade attack on a Panama City discotheque in which a U.S. soldier was killed are looking into the possibility the bombing was connected to the breakup of the smuggling ring. The attack wounded 15 other American servicemen and 12 Panamanians. It was the first such attack on U.S. soldiers in Panama since the Dec. 20 invasion that ousted dictator Manuel Noriega. Military officials checked for drugs in the baggage of the 13,000 soldiers returning from the invasion, but the deployment was so large it was almost impossible to conduct thorough searches, officers told CBS. Witnesses to the bombing said two men yelling ``Long live Noriega!'' threw a grenade through a glass wall of the disco, then sped away in a car. There was no immediate claim of responsibility. Noriega is awaiting trial on drug charges in Miami, where he was taken after the U.S. invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Urges Top Priority For Reform To Fight Trade Deficit
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today told Parliament that land prices must be driven down and government spending increased if Japan is to reduce its huge trade surplus with the United States. Low wages and expensive housing have kept Japanese from buying more imports, making it difficult to cut into the $49 billion surplus. ``Our corporations are wealthy and strong, but this wealth has come at the expense of long working hours and a low standard of living. It is time to redress this imbalance,'' he said. ``We intend realistic efforts to carry out structural reforms. That means we must carry out reforms of our land use policies and improve the standard of living,'' Kaifu said during questioning by opposition legislators in the upper house of Parliament. Kaifu's opponents, led by the Socialists, the No. 1 opposition party, dominate the upper house and are likely to obstruct action on a number of trade-related issues facing Parliament. These include plans to provide more land for housing and cut inflated real estate prices; and to spend more on roads, parks and sewers to improve the general quality of life. Washington says such changes are needed to eliminate ``structural'' trade barriers behind the chronic U.S. trade deficit with Japan. A key barrier U.S. officials have targeted is a law that they say tends to prevent foreign firms from expanding their sales in Japan. Today, trade ministry officials said they were considering changing or abolishing that law. Minister of International Trade and Industry Kabun Muto, reversing himself on the issue, told Japanese reporters bolder steps might have to be taken if the United States is not satisfied with plans to ease the law's enforcement. U.S. trade negotiators contend it hinders foreign retailers who are trying to open stories in Japan as well as discourages the opening of large Japanese stores that are more likely to sell foreign-made goods than traditional mom-and-pop shops. Kaifu promised President Bush to do his best to carry out substantial reforms during a California summit last week. But he is fighting his government's tendency to become bogged down in domestic disputes. Japan's Parliament was embroiled in battles over a bribery scandal and over a controversial sales tax and has accomplished few trade-related reforms during the past year. Parliament must first deal with a revised version of the 3 percent sales tax and a national budget by the end of this month. A revision of the sales tax exempting food, school entrance fees and welfare in response to widespread criticism was scheduled to go before Parliament today. Kaifu is urging Japan Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi and other opposition leaders to abandon their attacks on the sales tax, given the comfortable majority his party won in Feb. 18 parliamentary elections. Opposition parties unsuccessfully based their campaigns in last month's lower house election on calls to abolish the sales tax, which along with a series of sex and money scandals eroded public support for the governing party and contributed to its loss of control of Parliament's upper house in July elections. While analysts are skeptical about Kaifu's chances of following through on his promises to Bush, the reforms are widely supported by major business organizations and the media. Joining other business groups, the Kansai Economic Federation in western Japan urged the government Monday to raise taxes on farmland in major cities to the same level as residential taxes to encourage development of suburban farmland. It also called for measures to narrow the gap between prices in Japan and overseas. Japanese officials, however, have expressed concern that Kaifu, who lacks clout in his own party, will have problems gathering support for reforms soon enough to satisfy the United States.
