Tokyo is under pressure to show it will implement promised reforms before early April, when trade negotiators are to issue an interim report on the U.S.-Japanese talks. A final report is due in July. Also today, a top Japanese defense official said Japan is ready to consider increasing funds for maintaining U.S. forces in Japan, if such a request is officially made by the United States. ``If the U.S. side makes a request in concrete terms, we will consider'' increasing expenses for U.S. troops in Japan, Yozo Ishikawa, director general of the Defense Agency, told a news conference. But Ishikawa, who assumed the agency's top post Feb. 28, said he has heard nothing ``official'' about the request yet. Ishikawa was referring to a statement by U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney during a television interview Sunday that he wants Japan to assume ``100 percent'' of the cost of maintaining U.S. military bases in Japan. Japan is currently paying $2.4 billion of the $6 billion annual cost of maintaining U.S. forces in Japan, a defense agency official said. Such costs include the salaries of the 22,240 Japanese employees at U.S. miltary facilities across Japan. About 50,000 U.S. military personnel are based in Japan and their salaries and other costs are not included in the maintainance equation.

DOC.HEAD: Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger's Will Leaves the Times to Her Children
DOC.TEXT: Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, the newspaper heiress who died last week, left controlling interest of The New York Times to her four children. Her 19-page will was filed Monday for probate. Mrs. Sulzberger, who died Feb. 26 at age 97 in Stamford, Conn., executed the will Jan. 24. The terms of her father's will had required that her controlling interest in the Times pass to her children after her death. A part owner of the Times, Mrs. Sulzberger left all of her stock in the newspaper and the Times Printing Co. equally to three daughters and a son: Marian S. Heiskell of New York; Ruth Holmberg of Chattanooga, Tenn.; Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger of New York, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of New York, the Times' publisher. ``They will, I am confident, continue to carry out the policy which was initiated by my father and strengthened by my husband,'' Mrs. Sulzberger said in her will. ``By doing so they will be preserving and advancing the best interests and the finest traditions of the great property which they will inherit.'' Mrs. Sulzberger's will provides numerous cash bequests of varying amounts to many relatives, including grandsons and granddaughters. Several organizations were left $100,000 each, including Barnard College, Columbia University, the New York Botanical Gardens and the New York Public Library. Among other bequests, the United Negro College Fund got $50,000.

DOC.HEAD: Man Receives Four-Year Sentence for Burning Black Church
DOC.TEXT: A man was sentenced to four years in prison for setting a fire that destroyed a historic black church founded by escaped slaves during the Civil War. Circuit Judge Edward C. Ferguson imposed the sentence Monday on James Russell Calvin, 21, of Alton, who had pleaded guilty to arson in the 1988 fire. The attack was the second in a year against the New Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Godfrey. It was rebuilt a second time after Calvin's arson attack. The congregation's 25 members are descendants of the escaped slaves who founded the church in 1864. Calvin, who is white, maintained that the attack was not racially motivated but resulted from his alcoholism and stress caused by personal problems. At the time, he told police he believed the church was used for devil worship. Defense attorney Jim Wallis said his client has ``suffered the fire of hell in his remorse.'' The prosecution had called for the maximum, seven years in prison. ``He did that with malice in his heart,'' said State's Attorney Bill Haine. ``This was an attack on an entire church congregation.''

DOC.HEAD: Teens Loot, Vandalize in Protest of Principal's Departure
DOC.TEXT: Scores of police officers in riot gear helped calm hundreds of teen-agers who hurled bottles, looted a store and vandalized cars during a protest against what they said were racist school hiring policies. Six teen-agers were arrested and one minor injury was reported Monday, said police Sgt. John Beerling. The demonstration was held in support of Hawthorne High School Principal Ken Crowe, who recently announced his resignation because he was going to be reassigned. Crowe, who is black, has accused the school board of failing to support his attempts to rid the school of racial harassment. A racially mixed crowd of about 400 students from Leuzinger High School in Lawndale left classes in the morning and marched more than a mile to Hawthorne High School, 15 miles from downtown Los Angeles. The schools are in the same district. ``During the march, the students became unruly and began rioting,'' Beerling said. He added that damage was confined to a few broken windows and dented fenders. ``We went there peacefully to try to stop the racism,'' said Monica Fritsch, a 16-year-old Leuzinger student. ``Then the gangs started fighting. ... We know the schools are cross-town rivals, but we were trying to forget about that.'' About 100 police officers herded many of the protesters onto the school football field, where officials heard their complaints of discriminatory hiring practices, Sgt. Mike Effler said. The students were later bused back to their school. Officer Kathy Burnett said the students were arrested on misdemeanor violations that included disorderly conduct and were released to their parents. One merchant along the march route complained that students had vandalized his shop. Ted Shin said more than 100 teen-agers rushed into his convenience store and stole merchandise.

DOC.HEAD: Gloria Carter Spann
DOC.TEXT: Gloria Carter Spann, the last surviving sibling of former President Carter, died Monday of the type of cancer that killed three other family members. She was 63. Mrs. Spann had been diagnosed in December as having pancreatic cancer, which killed her father, James Earl Carter; her sister, Ruth Carter Stapleton; and her other brother, Billy Carter. Her mother, Lillian Carter, had breast cancer that had spread to other organs, including her pancreas, when she died in 1983. Mrs. Spann was with the former president and his wife, Rosalynn, and her husband, Walter Spann, when she died at Sumter Regional Hospital. Mrs. Spann, an avid motorcyclist, was to be buried today at a graveside service at Lebanon Cemetery in Plains following a funeral procession led by fellow motorcyclists. All but Mrs. Stapleton are buried in the cemetery. Mrs. Spann belonged to the Georgia Motorcycle Rights organization and was named Most Outstanding Female Motorcyclist in the nation in 1978. Besides her brother and husband, Mrs. Spann is survived by a son, William C. Spann.
DOC.HEAD: Harold Glendon Scheie
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Harold Glendon Scheie, a pioneering eye surgeon for whom many instruments and procedures are named, died of cancer Monday at age 80. The founder and former director of the Scheie Eye Institute of Philadelphia developed important techniques for treatment of cataracts and glaucoma. He also helped develop the diagnostic test for myasthenia gravis with Dr. George Gammon in the 1930s and was the first to describe in detail a rare inherited disease that can cloud the cornea, now called Scheie's syndrome. Among the developments that bear his his name is the Scheie procedure used in glaucoma surgery. Surivers include his wife, Mary Ann Tallman; a son, and a daughter. Services for Scheie were scheduled for March 13 at Arlington National Cemetery.
DOC.HEAD: Gary Merrill
DOC.TEXT: Gary Merrill, who had supporting roles in ``Twelve O'Clock High'' and ``All About Eve'' and a stormy 10-year marriage to Bette Davis, died of cancer Monday at his home. He was 74. Merrill appeared in 42 films during a four-decade career. His first movie role was in ``Winged Victory'' in 1944. He went on to ``Twelve O'Clock High'' in 1949 and had parts in ``Phone Call from a Stranger,'' 1953; ``Blueprint for Murder,'' 1953; ``Bermuda Affair,'' 1956, and ``Around the World Under the Sea,'' 1966. On television, he played the gruff but understanding Dr. Gillespie in the ``Young Dr. Kildare'' series. He met Miss Davis in ``All About Eve,'' winner of the best-picture Academy Award that starred Miss Davis in 1950. He played her lover and they married in July of that year, the day his divorce from his first wife became final. Their marriage ended in divorce in 1960. It wasn't until 1985 that she ended a 15-year silence by sending a note to Merrill after he urged people not to buy ``My Mother's Keeper,'' a critical biography of the actress written by her daughter. Merrill said he didn't want Miss Davis to be ridiculed by a daughter he called ``greedy.'' Funeral arrangements were incomplete.
DOC.HEAD: Vito Marzullo
DOC.TEXT: Former Alderman Vito Marzullo, an Italian immigrant who ran his West Side ward virtually unchallenged for more than 30 years, died Monday of respiratory problems. He was 92. Marzullo had been hospitalized for more than a month with pneumonia at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center. Marzullo was an ardent supporter of the late Mayor Richard J. Daley, whom he once called ``the best mayor Chicago ever had.'' He was elected to the Legislature for the first of seven terms in 1941. In 1953, he was elected to the City Council, serving nine terms. He retired in 1985. Marzullo is survived by his wife, Letizia; two sons; four daughters; 19 grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. A funeral Mass was scheduled for Thursday.
DOC.HEAD: Elsie Wood
DOC.TEXT: Elsie Wood, a longtime member of the Legislative Correspondents Association, died Monday. She was 91. Wood worked in journalism at the state Capitol for more than 50 years. She began transmitting news as a telegrapher in 1928 for the Postal Telegraph and Western Union until 1956. She went to work for Cuyler News Service that year. Wood was one of the first two women to be admitted to the journalists association when it allowed women to enter in 1968. Wood was born in Oswego, N.Y., and graduated from what was then the Oswego State Normal School.

DOC.HEAD: Reformists Claiming Victories In Urban Areas, Favored By Heavy Turnout
DOC.TEXT: In cities of the Slavic heartland, voters supported pro-democracy candidates who promise accountability over Communist bosses who have long controlled municipal machines through patronage, activists said. Even in Leningrad, traditionally a bastion of hard-line Communists, pro-democracy candidates dominated Sunday's local and republic-wide elections, said editor Yelena Velinksaya of the official youth news agency IMA Press. Most of the 1,800 contests for seats in the legislatures of the Russian federation, the Ukraine and Byleorussia remained undecided and will have to be settled by runoffs expected in two weeks. But unofficial returns suggested that progressives made substantial gains as voters rejected conservative Communist candidates they associated with corruption and economic mismanagement. Advocates of democracy could secure control several major city councils. Heavy turnout appeared to favor reformers in the Ukraine and Byelorussia, where 80 percent of registered voters went to the polls, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today. The newspaper said, however, that only 64 percent of registered voters turned out in Moscow, capital of the huge Russian federation. Turnout figures for the federation as a whole were not yet available. Reformer Boris N. Yeltsin had no trouble winning a legislative seat in the Russian federation, taking 72 percent of the vote in his district of Sverdlovsk in the Ural Mountains. He defeated 11 other candidates, said Anatoly Moiseyev of the Russian Federation Election Commission. Yeltsin has said he will seek the presidency of the republic, which traditionally means a place on the Communist Party's ruling Politburo. That could return the Communist maverick to the membership he lost in February 1988 for advocating speedier change. Other reformers in the Russian federation also appeared headed for victory, as did leaders of nationalist movements in the Ukraine and Byelorussia, an outspoken television commentator in Leningrad and a defiant editor in Moscow. ``We're so happy! Such success!'' said Irina Rozhenko of the Ukrainian pro-democracy movement Narodny Rukh. Activists said strong showings in this round nearly guaranteed victories in runoff elections for candidates who want to step up the pace of reforms begun by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In Washington, State Department spokesman Margaret Tutweiler said Monday that, ``While, for the most part, these were not multiparty elections, there were, nonetheless, many hotly contested, competitive regional and local races, offering voters a clear choice of candidates and ideologies. ``This represents an important and, indeed, historic step forward in the process of democratization in the Soviet Union,'' she said. In fact, the Communist Party is still the only legal political party in the Soviet Union despite its agreement last month to end its political monopoly and compete with other parties. So pro-reform candidates either had to run as Communists or on slates of grass-roots movements. Defeat of old guard local Communist leaders probably would help Gorbachev's liberalization. He has railed against functionaries who hamper reform, and people hoping to exercise new economic freedoms have told of crippling obstacles erected by local party officials. Zyanon Paznyak, leader of the Byelorussian People's Front, got 59 percent of the vote in his Minsk district, said spokesman Victor Ivashkevich. He said activist candidates appeared to have carried cities but that party apparatchiks, including Byelorussian party chief Yefrem Sokolov, won rural districts. In Leningrad, Bella Kurkova, controversial commentator from the public affairs program ``Fifth Wheel,'' appeared to be the only first-round winner, said IMA Press. Ms. Velinskaya said pro-democracy candidates dominated the elections in Leningrad and that just two of about 150 candidates supported by the ultra-right nationalist group Pamyat survived the first round. Vladislav Starkov, editor of the country's most popular newspaper, Arguments and Facts, was reported the winner of a seat to the Russian republic's parliament. Starkov ignored a strong suggestion from Gorbachev that he quit last year after the paper printed results of a poll implying that the late human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov was more popular than Gorbachev. Unofficial reports said well-known dissident Sergei Kovalyov also won a seat in the Russian parliament. Ukraine party chief Vladimir A. Ivashko, considered a moderate protege of Gorbachev, qualified for a runoff against an opponent backed by Narodny Rukh. Vitaly I. Vorotnikov, president of the Russian republic, defeated a lone opponent in the city of Krasnodar, winning 71.3 percent of the votes cast. Both are Politburo members. Narodny Rukh members said the movement's leader, poet Ivan Drach, was elected in the first round along with several other prominent activists. Official reports said 86 percent of the candidates in the Russian elections and 80 percent in the Ukraine were members of the Communist Party. Political tension has increased in some regions as direct control from the Kremlin decreases. In recent weeks, Gorbachev has prodded the Communist Party into giving up its monopoly on power and pressed for a new, more powerful presidency. In Lithuania, candidates of the pro-independence Sajudis movement swept earlier legislative elections and won more seats in runoffs Sunday. Of the 25 candidates elected Sunday, 18 were from Sajudis, according to reports from activists and the official news agency Tass. Some activists in the Baltic republic want the legislature to vote on secession from the Soviet Union before Gorbachev gets his new powers, which would include the right to suspend the legislature of a republic and send in troops.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Union Seizes Homes in Philadelphia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `In October ...' to RESTORE first reference to Kemp.
DOC.TEXT: Homeless people seized and moved into federally-owned vacant houses in three cities, threatening to stay until the government does more to provide affordable housing for the poor. Activists with the Philadelphia-based Union of the Homeless on Monday took over five houses in Philadelphia and one each in Alexandria, Va., and Detroit, leaders said. Police in New York City thwarted an attempt there to move into a house. Ronald Darnaby of the Philadelphia union said the coalition checked with HUD's inventory to identify houses for sale, then discussed the proposed seizures with community leaders. The two-story homes would house two families each. None of the houses had utilities, Darnaby said. Inside one of the houses, protesters and homeless people wearing coats huddled around kerosene heaters and sipped hot drinks while about 20 other members picketed outside. ``We'll stay as long as it takes,'' said Charles Thompson. Craig Gaskin, a spokesman for the homeless union, said the squatters would stay until their demands are met or they are removed by police. The coordinator for the homeless for HUD's regional office in Philadelphia, Pat Mulligan, said his agency considered the seizures trespassing but that officials had not decided how to respond. City officials sent in building inspectors but no police officers. Lt. Ed Kachigian said the city would not act against the homeless unless HUD requested it. In October, HUD Secretary Jack Kemp said HUD would take 10 percent of its single-family inventory for affordable housing for homeless people. But the union said it wants action immediately. ``We are sick and tired of empty promises,'' union President Leona Smith said. ``The government is more committed to bailing out mismanaged savings and loans banks than to saving and restoring the lives of people who are homeless, chronically unemployed and who are being pressed into a permanent underclass status.'' The organization wants more money earmarked for remodeling or construction of low-income housing and for rent subsidies. In Manhattan, about 30 members of the union were thwarted by police in an attempt to take a house, said union member Renaldo Casanova. He said two members of the group were arrested. Casanova said Monday's activities were a prelude to a May Day event in which the union plans to have activists in 40 states simultaneously occupy vacant, HUD-owned houses. Philadelphia Housing Commissioner Ed Schwartz offered to act as a mediator between the homeless and HUD, a role he played two years ago when the group seized several houses. HUD later sold those houses to the homeless group. Mulligan said the agency gives priority to shelter groups when selling houses and offers leases for $1 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Anti-Japanese sentiment in the United States is rising fast. ... Japan has a choice. It can either follow the lead of the rest of the world and open its markets or it can keep its markets closed and have the rest of the world follow its lead.'' _ Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., testifying at a congressional hearing on trade relations with Japan.

``It involves a great deal of self-abuse, bodies being flung around the room, excrement, assumed voices _ it's pretty vile stuff.'' _ the Rev. James T. Burtchaell, theology professor at Notre Dame University, describing exorcism after Cardinal John J. O'Connor said two were performed in the New York Archdiocese last year.

``One student who was caught couldn't understand what he'd done that was so wrong. ... His argument amounted to: `Everyone cheats and as long as I do it well, I won't get caught and will succeed in society.''' _ Arthur Levine, chairman of Harvard University's Institute for Educational Management, on the apparent rise in cheating among college students.

DOC.HEAD: Mojave Desert Winds Slow Shuttle Maintenance Work
DOC.TEXT: Stiff desert winds slowed efforts to prepare space shuttle Atlantis for a piggyback jet ride back to Florida. Gusts to 45 mph also delayed an investigation into an apparent leak of hydraulic fluid discovered before the shuttle landed here Sunday from a secret, 4{-day mission during which it put a $500 million spy satellite in orbit. ``As far as the landing, it was not a safety issue,'' Conrad Nagel, Atlantis processing director for NASA, said of the leak. Meanwhile, Discovery was towed Monday to an assembly building at Kennedy Space Center in Florida, NASA spokeswoman Pat Phillips said. Inside, booster rockets and the external fuel tank will be attached to Discovery, which is scheduled for launch April 12 on a mission to put the $1.55 billion Hubble Space Telescope in orbit. Atlantis was towed off its dry lakebed landing strip and into a 100-foot steel maintenance structure. But the wind prevented NASA from hoisting the shuttle as planned Monday morning, slowing work by about 16 hours, Nagel said. Nagel said the delay forced officials to postpone the trip atop a modified Boeing 747 to Florida from Friday to Saturday. The possible leak of bright red hydraulic fluid was discovered as Atlantis approached landing. Sensors showed a brief pressure drop in the main hydraulic system. The system operates control surfaces that steer the spacecraft under computer orders during re-entry, Nagel said. Overall, he said, the shuttle was in excellent condition. Only one heat-shield tile may need replacement. About 20 other tiles sustained ``dings'' up to an inch in size, while about 40 others had nicks of a half inch or less. Atlantis is scheduled to fly again July 9 on another secret mission.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Moves Into Plains; Rain Follows in Southern Plains
DOC.TEXT: A storm that dumped heavy snow in the upper Rockies threatened to blanket the northern Plains today, and rain was to follow the storm in the central Plains. Along a stationary front Monday, rain was scattered from northern Texas to Nebraska and from the mid-Mississippi Valley to the upper Ohio Valley. Moline, Ill., received a third of an inch of rain, and snow extended from northern Illinois to the lower Great Lakes region. Dry weather prevailed across much of the nation Monday, with fair skies covering most of a southern band running from the South to the West. Calm skies also covered New England and upstate New York. The storm crossing the Rockies left in its wake strong winds in the mountains and desert areas of Southern California. Gusts of 55 mph were reported Monday at the Mojave Airport. Up to 8 inches of snow fell in Snowbird and Alta by midafternoon Monday, as a winter storm left parts of Montana, Wyoming and Utah covered in white. Snow was predicted today for much of the Rockies, from the northern highlands and mountains of New Mexico up through the ranges of Colorado and into central and south central Montana. The storm was expected to enter western Nebraska and southwest and south central South Dakota today. Temperatures in the Great Lakes and northern New England stayed in the 20s and upper teens, while the northeast and north central United States received highs in the 30s and 40s. Temperatures were in the 60s and 70s from the south central Plains to the Southeast. Southern Florida and the lower Rio Grande valley were in the 80s. Afternoon highs in the Southwest were mostly in the 60s. The high for the nation Monday was 88 degrees at Presidio, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against most other major currencies in European trading today. Gold prices were up. Dealers said the dollar still was smarting from Monday's heavy central bank interventions to stem the dollar's rise. Despite the interventions, dealers said, the dollar still was very well supported. ``The only people really selling the dollar are the central banks,'' said Graham Leverton, corporate adviser at Bank of America in London. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.45 yen to a closing 149.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 149.70 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _ 1.6975 West German marks, down from 1.7035 _ 1.4969 Swiss francs, down from 1.4985 _ 5.7395 French francs, up from 5.5715 _ 1.9095 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9155 _ 1,253.00 Italian lire, down from 1,255.00 _ 1.1885 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1904 In London, British pound rose to $1.6530 from $1.6390 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $404.50 a troy ounce, up from $403.75 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $404.80. In Zurich, the bid price was $405.00, up from bid $403.25 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.29 to close at a bid $404.73. Silver was unchanged in London at a bid price of $5.13 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Kohl Agrees On Parliament Treaty Resolution, No Concessions Asked From Poles
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has agreed to formally state support for a treaty on Poland's western border without asking for concessions from the Poles, his chief of staff said today. The announcement followed a crucial meeting of Kohl's coalition government, which was seriously divided over the chancellor's previous handling of the border issue. Rudolf Seiters, Kohl's chief of staff, said the coalition partners had agreed to introduce a resolution in Parliament on Thursday favoring a treaty recognizing the current borders with Poland. Seiters said the resolution would not include Kohl's demands, made Friday, that any such treaty be linked with assurances by Poland to honor its 1953 decision not to seek war reparations from Germany, and its pledge last year to guarantee the ethnic rights of its German minority. It was not clear whether the resolution would state _ as Kohl has many times insisted _ that only the government of a united Germany can have final say on the border issue. Kohl's previous pronouncements on the border issue have angered the Poles and resulted in severe criticism at home, even from his junior coalition partners, the Free Democrats of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. Genscher and Kohl failed to settle their differences in a meeting on Monday. Leaders of Kohl's coalition government met again today to try to reach a compromise. Seiters made the announcement following that meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Unification Uncertainties Stir Nervousness in East, Strife in West
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl dropping condition on reparations. Picks up 13th pvs, `Kohl's conservative...'
DOC.TEXT: The uncertainties looming ahead with the prospect of German reunification have given East Germans cold feet and touched off a new political crisis in West Germany. East Germany's leading politicians on Monday called for a new social charter to be adopted in both Germanys that would preserve the protections they have enjoyed under socialism, like guaranteed employment and affordable rent and food prices. The proposed social charter adopted at weekly negotiations between the Communists and 15 other parties reflects just how hesitant many East Germans are about plunging ahead with a merger with capitalist West Germany and abandoning the life they've known for 40 years. In Bonn, Chancellor Helmut Kohl fueled the controversy raging over his refusal to unequivocally recognize Germany's border with Poland. He told reporters Monday that Germans should be wary of Poland's 1953 pledge not to seek World War II reparations, contending Polish officials have been pressing claims for the past three years for compensation of forced labor by Poles under the Third Reich. But Kohl backed off the reparations issue today. His chief of staff, Rudolf Seiters, said Kohl agreed to formally state support for a treaty on Poland's western border without asking for concessions from the Poles. The announcement followed a crucial meeting of Kohl's coalition government, which has been seriously divided over the chancellor's handling of the border issue. Seiters said the coalition partners agreed to introduce a resolution in Parliament Thursday favoring a treaty recognizing the current borders with Poland. It was not clear whether the resolution would state _ as Kohl has many times insisted _ that only the government of a united Germany can have final say on the border issue. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland has called on the two Germanys to begin talks aimed at a treaty recognizing the current border _ formed by the Oder and Neisse rivers _ as the permanent boundary between Poland and a united Germany. About a third of modern-day Poland was German territory prior to World War II, and Warsaw fears a united Germany might seek to recover the regions. The chancellor's obstinance angered Poles, opposition Social Democrats in West Germany, the World War II Allies who retain control of Berlin, and even members of his own center-right coalition government. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher had distanced himself from Kohl on the border issue and warned him that reopening the issue of war reparations for Poland could backfire. Kohl's conservative Christian Democratic Union governs in partnership with Genscher's liberal Free Democrats and with the arch-conservative Christian Social Union of Bavaria. The Christian Social Union's chairman, Theo Waigel, last year called for unification within the 1937 borders of Germany, which would include the huge territorities of Silesia and East Prussia lost to Poland and the Soviet Union after the Nazi defeat in 1945. The Christian Democrats and Free Democrats also appear to be at odds over how unification should be accomplished, with Kohl's party urging a unilateral decision by East German states to merge with West Germany. A leading parliamentarian of the Free Democratic Party, Burkhard Hirsch, contends no right of secession exists for that East German states. The opposition Social Democrats oppose an immediate vote by a newly seated East German Parliament to merge with West Germany, calling instead for a convention to draft a joint constitution. The social charter adopted at the East German political talks demands that the right to work and the right to housing be enshrined in a new constitution for a united Germany. If adopted by the East German Parliament chosen in the March 18 election, the charter should serve as the basis for negotiations with West Germany on monetary and social union, opposition minister Gerhard Poppe said. The charter proposal illustrates the strong social democratic leaning of East Germany's political forces. The country's Social Democrats are expected to poll a majority in the election. East Germans have traditionally viewed their social security programs as the paramount achievement of over 40 years of Communist rule and are nervous about the prospects of a headlong plunge into capitalism's cold waters. Once efficient Western methods are introduced to East Germany's government-controlled industry, for example, the now-negligible unemployment rate among the country's 9 million-strong workforce could jump to as much as 15 percent. Rent prices are also likely to surge. East Germans in general know little about West Germany's social security system, viewed as one of Western Europe's most generous. The conservative Alliance for Germany, the East German political grouping backed by Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, has appealed to voters not to fear the switch to capitalism. Social Minister Norbert Bluem of West Germany appeared at a news conference with leaders of the East German Christian Democrats and noted that the Bonn government already spends about $410 billion per year on social services, or more than $6,500 per capita.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Group Signs Unprecedented Pact With Shopping Mall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents 12th graf, `In an ...'
DOC.TEXT: Racial tensions at a shopping mall should be eased by an agreement to hire more blacks, promote black-owned businesses and end racial harassment, officials say. ``I think when you hire people and give them economic opportunity, it has a tendency to cut down on some of the racial strife,'' state Sen. Kay Patterson, said Monday. The agreement calls for hiring and promoting more blacks by the Columbia Mall management and encouraging stores to do the same, and using more black contractors and suppliers. Management would also would no longer use a segregation-era trespassing law to detain blacks. Patterson, who led other black officials in calling for the resignation of a sheriff who allegedly used a racial slur in describing how crime at the mall could be reduced, said the pact with the mall was ``long, long overdue.'' Dr. William F. Gibson, national chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said the agreement was the first of its kind, but the problems at Columbia Mall were not unique. He urged other NAACP chapters to negotiate similar agreements. Informal studies show blacks make up 30 percent to 40 percent of the mall's 150,000 weekly customers, Gibson said. The agreement was reached in the ``spirit of cooperation'' but is not legally binding on the mall, said George Forbes, an attorney for the mall's owner, Jacobs, Visconi and Jacobs of Cleveland. ``The Columbia Mall does not, it has not and it will not discriminate as regards to race, creed or color,'' added Forbes, a longtime member of the NAACP. The pact stemmed from allegations that about 50 black teen-agers had been detained last summer by mall security officers under a 1960s anti-trespassing law designed to maintain segregation. In most cases, no criminal charges were ever filed. In December, two black teen-agers were shot inside the mall, the latest of four such incidents. The mall discontinued its practice of detaining black youths under the trespass law about a month ago, Jacobs said.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Gary Merrill Dies of Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Gary Merrill spent his final years on the Maine coast doing very little _ which suited the actor who died at his home of lung cancer. He was 74. ``I've spent my life doing as little as possible ... And I intend to keep doing exactly the same thing,'' Merrill told an interviewer in 1981. He said he enjoyed being ``a hermit.'' Merrill, who moved to Maine in 1965 and spent most of his time playing golf and reading poetry in schools, died Monday at his small cottage overlooking the ocean in the wealthy Portland suburb of Falmouth Foreside. Merrill was best known for his supporting roles in the movies ``Twelve O'Clock High'' and ``All About Eve'' and for his stormy marriage to actress Bette Davis. He also was a long time escort of actress Rita Hayworth. His first movie role was in ``Winged Victory'' in 1944. The colorful, spirited actor, whose penchant for skirts on hot days was known in the Portland area, appeared in 42 films over more than 40 years. He first appeared on stage in 1937 and went on to play the gruff but understanding Dr. Gillespie in the ``Young Dr. Kildare'' television series and he narrated ``The Valliant Years'' series about Winston Churchill. His last stage appearance was on Broadway in 1980 in a revival of ``Mornings at Seven'' with Maureen O'Sullivan. Merrill's other movie roles included ``Phone Call from a Stranger,'' 1953; ``Blueprint for Murder,'' 1953; ``Bermuda Affair,'' 1956, and ``Around the World Under the Sea,'' 1966. His trademark, a deep, rich voice, was heard in commercials after he quit acting, including eight years as the voice for a beer company's ads. Merrill met Davis in ``All About Eve'' in 1950 and married her in July of that year, the same day his divorce from his first wife became final. The marriage with Davis ended in divorce in 1960. Davis ended a 15-year silence in 1985 by writing a note to Merrill after he paraded outside a bookstore with a sign urging shoppers not to buy ``My Mother's Keeper,'' a critical biography of Davis by her daughter. A native of Hartford, Conn., Merrill spent many childhood summers in Maine, and he and Davis spent much of their 10-year marriage in Cape Elizabeth, just outside Portland. In his 1988 autobiography, ``Bette, Rita and the Rest of My Life,'' Merrill said his best times were spent with Davis and their children in Cape Elizabeth. He insisted he had been only an ``adequate actor'' because he ``never worked at it. I had no drive, really. I just like to get by and have fun,'' he said. The unabashed free spirit, when asked why he was wearing a skirt in downtown Portland one summer day in 1984, said, ``I believe in wearing no clothes at all, and this is the closest you can get to it in public.'' Merrill is survived by a son, Michael; a daughter, Margot; a brother and two grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: 1990 Year of Hostage Release; Syria's Assad To Visit Tehran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Beirut report, EDITS to trim. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `In Washington...'
DOC.TEXT: A Tehran newspaper close to Iran's president said today that 1990 will be the last year of captivity for the hostages in Lebanon, and resumption of U.S.-Iranian ties is not a precondition for their release. In a second editorial, the English-language Tehran Times said Syrian President Hafez Assad would visit Tehran soon, after an expected trip by his foreign minister, Farouk Al-Sharaa. It also denied reports that a trip by the brother of President Hashemi Rafsanjani to the Syrian capital of Damascus last week was related to the hostage question. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon, with 40,000 troops there. Both editorials in the government newspaper were excerpted by the official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia. Recent statements from Iranian newspapers saying the hostages should be released, along with optimistic assessments by Syrian and other officials, have fueled reports that a hostage release is imminent. In Beirut today, the respected An-Nahar daily ruled out any release soon, but quoted unidentified Lebanese fundamentalist sources as saying Iran was prepared to tackle the hostage issue. The sources were quoted as saying there had been no direct contacts between Iran and the United States, but both were scouting for what was described as a mechanism for releasing the hostages. The report did not elaborate. An Assad visit to Iran was expected. Syria was Persian Iran's only staunch Arab backer in its 1980-88 war against Iraq, the arch foe of Damascus. Iran and Syria are also in frequent contact over Lebanon, where they back rival Shiite Moslem militias. The Tehran Times statement said visits between capitals was ``a very normal thing,'' noting that the sensation on the hostage issue created by the Western media over such visits was ``much too fancied.'' For the second time in as many weeks, the newspaper said the 18 Westerners in Lebanon, believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions, should go free without preconditions. In the past, the paper has reflected the thinking of President Hashemi Rafsanjani. ``Our own assessment indicates that this thorny issue can be sorted out in the near future in a sincere spirit by sincere people,'' the paper said, adding, ``1990 can and will be the last year of the captivity of these hostages.'' It said an effort was under way to free the hostages because ``Islam in no way allows or condones the idea that people should be taken or held hostage.'' In Washington on Monday, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said there were no grounds for expecting an imminent release, but said many people outside the U.S. government were involved in talks to win their freedom. The longest-held hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who will mark his 5th anniversary in captivity on March 16. Anderson is one of the eight Americans in captivity along with four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Rafsanjani has indicated the desire to separate Iran from the hostage issue as he seeks Western technology and financing to rebuild Iran's troubled economy. But the factions holding the hostages are said to be more loyal to radicals in the Tehran government who oppose Rafsanjani. They viewing confrontation with the West as the wellspring of the Islamic revolution. The Tehran Times said today that there were no direct talks between Tehran and Washington on resuming relations, according to the IRNA report, which was monitored in Nicosia. ``At this hour, Iran-U.S. relations are not under discussion and such a move is also not supported by the leader of the Islamic Republic and its top officials,'' said the paper. It reiterated its ground-breaking Feb. 22 statement that the hostage ordeal should be solved without any preconditions, and should not be related to resuming ties with Washington. Ties were broken following the 1979 attack on the U.S. Embassy in Tehran that resulted in 52 Americans being held hostage for 444 days. The paper said the visit to Damascus by Mahmoud Hashemi had nothing to do with freedom for the hostages. A Syrian source, who refused to be identified further, said Sunday that the meeting between Hashemi, a foreign ministry official, and Syria's Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa was to coordinate efforts to gain the release of all the hostages. The source said Hashemi had arrived from Beirut, where he met with senior Shiite Moslem figures on the hostage issue.

DOC.HEAD: Actor David Rappaport Hospitalized After Suicide Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES spelling of resuscitation in 3rd graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY60
DOC.TEXT: David Rappaport, a dwarf who starred in the series ``The Wizard'' and played a wily lawyer on ``L.A. Law,'' was in stable condition today after trying to kill himself by inhaling car exhaust, authorities said. Police officers said the 3-foot, 11-inch actor had stopped breathing when they found him inside a car on Sunday night. The engine was running and a hose connected to the exhaust pipe ran inside the car, said Sgt. Albert Dravidzius. Officers used cardiopulmonary resuscitation to revive him, the sergeant said. Rappaport, 38, was taken to Queen of Angels-Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center. No other information was released at the family's request. In CBS's ``The Wizard,'' which was broadcast from 1986-87, Rappaport starred as Simon Mckay, a good-willed inventor. The actor appeared on NBC's ``L.A. Law'' as a lawyer who bests his opponents by playing up his short stature. He also appeared in the 1981 movie ``Time Bandits.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Claims Job Discrimination Against Former Communists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to clarify 3rd graf. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `The return...'
DOC.TEXT: Many of the 20,000 Communist Party employees who lost their jobs when the party was dissolved are having a hard time finding new work, some because of discrimination, a newspaper reported. The provincial and local party secretaries, instructors, drivers, clerical workers, porters and others employed by the party were fired when the discredited Communist Party dissolved itself in January. Trybuna, the newspaper of the Social Democracy party which replaced the former ruling party, said Monday that most of those dismissed have reported to labor offices in need of new jobs. ``The return to normal work is sometimes difficult,'' the newspaper said. It implied that part of the problem was an ``anti-Communist'' bias fueled by local Solidarity leaders. ``A director of an enterprise, uncertain of his own future, is not that eager to hire former employees of the party apparatus,'' the Trybuna article said. ``He is simply afraid that at some point somebody might accuse him of maintaining contacts with the former Communist Party.'' ``As we can see, anti-Communist pressure is big. There are enterprises ... where they say that in case of workforce reductions, the first to be fired will be former Communist Party members,'' the newspaper said. ``Such an attitude doesn't have much in common with the government's promise that the only criterion will be skill.'' Discrimination against Communists would be a reversal of decades of bias against opposition activists. After the 1981 martial-law crackdown to repress Solidarity, for example, thousands of workers had to ``verify'' their loyalty to the Communist government, and those considered politically suspect lost their jobs. Former Communist bosses also often held significiant power in the assignment of jobs and privileges on the local level, where the party and the government were intertwined. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, taking charge of the East bloc's first non-Communist government last fall, said there should be no vengeful purge of party loyalists from central or local governments, institutions or businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Rulings Will Make It More Difficult for Criminals to Get Federal Court Help
DOC.TEXT: Two new Supreme Court rulings will make it much more difficult for convicted criminals, including many of the nation's 2,200 death row inmates, to get help in federal courts. The rulings generally bar defendants from invoking new constitutional decisions to attack their state court convictions after they have exhausted their initial round of appeals. That means prisoners may not base their appeals on favorable court rulings issued in other cases after their own convictions become final in state appellate courts. By identical 5-4 splits, the court Monday upheld death sentences for two men on death row in South Carolina and Oklahoma. In each case, the court's conservative bloc _ Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy _ joined to form the majority. In each, the court's liberals _ Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens _ dissented. The court's new and stringent rule was announced in the case of South Carolina death row inmate Horace Butler. It evoked a sharp dissenting opinion by Brennan. ``After today,'' he wrote for the four dissenters, ``despite constitutional defects in the state process leading to their conviction or sentencing, state prisoners will languish in jail _ or others like Butler will die _ because state courts were reasonable, even though wrong.'' Brennan said that with the ruling in Butler's case, ``the court has finally succeeded in its thinly veiled crusade to eviscerate'' federal laws passed by Congress to protect criminal defendants' rights. Writing for the majority, Rehnquist said federal courts should not review ``reasonable good-faith interpretations of existing precedents made by state courts even though they are shown to be contrary to later decisions.'' In the Oklahoma case of Robyn Leroy Parks, the court said he is barred from contending that a jury wrongly was told to ignore ``sympathy'' before it sentenced him to death. The court said Parks should not have been allowed to raise such a constitutional argument in a federal court challenge after having exhausted his direct appeals in state courts. The presiding judge told Parks' sentencing jury, ``You must avoid any influence of sympathy, sentiment, passion, prejudice or other arbitrary factor when imposing sentence.'' The justices left unanswered whether such a jury instruction is constitutional. In another death penalty ruling, the court struck down a key portion of North Carolina's death penalty law, invalidating the death sentences of most of the state's 84 death row inmates. And in a separate decision, the court upheld a California killer's death sentence by ruling that the instructions given to his sentencing jury were valid.

DOC.HEAD: Afghanistan at a Glance
With PM-Soviet-Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT:
Afghanistan at a glance:
LOCATION _ Southwest Asia, bordered by Pakistan, Iran and the Soviet Union. GEOGRAPHY _ 245,600 square miles, roughly the size of Texas. Rugged Hindu Kush Mountains in the northeast, steppe and desert to the west. POPULATION _ Approximately 15 million, of which 5 million have fled the war. Inhabitants include Moslems of more than a dozen tribes, among the largest are the Pathans, Tajiks, Baluchis and Hazaras. GOVERNMENT _ Marxists of the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan, backed by the Soviet Union. Locked in civil war with Moslem insurgents since it seized power in a 1978 military coup. Soviet forces intervened in 1979 and are to leave by Feb. 15 under a U.N. accord.
ECONOMY _ Traditonally agriculture and mining.
EXPORTS _ Natural gas, minerals, textiles, hand-woven carpets and crafts. HISTORY _ Locally autonomous tribes and militias. Repulsed British colonialism three times in the 19th and early 20th centuries.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Witness Surrenders in Ohio
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and last graf to CORRECT that only four of seven defendants were scheduled for trial Monday. ^By RONALD POWERS
DOC.TEXT: A key prosecution witness whose disappearance forced a postponement in the trial of four young whites accused of killing a black teen-ager surfaced later in the day in Ohio after three months on the run. John S. Vento turned himself in Monday night to FBI agents in Dayton, Ohio. Vento is a witness in the slaying of Yusuf Hawkins, 16, who was surrounded by a gang of about 30 whites and shot Aug. 23 after he and three friends, all black, went to Brooklyn's Bensonhurst neighborhood to look at a used car. Earlier Monday, the judge in the case reluctantly agreed to delay the trial one month to give prosecutors time to find Vento, who had vanished in December. The FBI last week issued an arrest warrant for him as a material witness. ``He walked up to the door, came in and identified himself,'' said Bob Siller, the senior FBI agent in Dayton. ``He was alone and unarmed and surrendered without incident.'' The prosecution will have Vento ready to testify at the April 2 trial ordered by Judge Thaddeus Owens, said Pat Clark, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney. The slaying inflamed racial tensions in the city. For several days after the slaying, hundreds of blacks marched in Bensonhurst to protest the killing. Seven young men were charged in the attack. The remaining defendants are to be tried later. Joseph Fama, 19, accused of firing the fatal shot, is in custody; the other defendants are free on bail.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Takes Stand, Denies Charges In Racketeering Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge accused of using his office to do favors for convicted felons testified that he called another judge to ask to be a character witness in a case, not to sway the judge's decision. In his first day on the stand Monday, U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar contradicted numerous prosecution witnesses _ and in one case, apparently his own previous tape-recorded conversation _ in fighting charges that could cost him his career and his freedom. He said he was unaware that his former legal secretary, Vera Hoff, was a fugitive from a tax evasion sentence when he visited her in Mexico in 1981 and 1982, or when he told deputy marshals in 1980 that he did not know her address. He also denied knowing about a wiretap that he is accused of twice disclosing to its target, Abe Chapman, a co-defendant in the case and a former relative of Aguilar by marriage. Aguilar appeared to acknowledge knowing about a Chapman wiretap in a conversation that was secretly tape-recorded and played for the jury last week. Aguilar, 58, of San Jose, is charged with eight felonies, punishable by 55 years in prison and $2 million in fines. He also could be removed from office by Congress, regardless of the verdict. Accusations that he tried to influence two fellow judges, aided a fugitive and devised a coverup are combined in a charge that he used his office as a ``racketeering enterprise'' to obstruct justice. It is the first such charge against a federal judge. Aguilar testified Monday that he intended nothing improper in January 1987 when he phoned U.S. District Judge Samuel Conti about the case of Ronald Cloud, Aguilar's longtime friend and former law client. Cloud, a former Nevada casino owner, was later convicted of bank fraud in a jury trial before Conti. Aguilar said his only purpose was ``to ask him if he had any objection to my testifying in his court as a character witness.'' He said he began by telling Conti that Cloud was ``a very sick man, a very old man, and he's a friend of mine,'' and was about to ask about appearing as a witness when Conti changed the subject. He also said he ``did not think it was improper'' when he later wrote down several suggestions to pass along to Cloud's lawyer for his appeal. The prosecution contended Aguilar was trying to use his influence with Conti to aid Cloud's case, and showed his intention by trying to aid Cloud's appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Ozzy to Cardinal: You've Got It All Wrong
DOC.TEXT: Rock singer Ozzy Osbourne, who's been known to bite the heads off bats and pigeons, chose to send a telegram when faced with a righteous cardinal. ``You are ignorant about the true meaning of my songs,'' Osbourne wrote Monday to Cardinal John J. O'Connor, who in a sermon singled out the heavy-metal musician as especially satanic. ``You have also insulted the intelligence of rock fans all over the world, and I recommend you do a little research before making your opinions in the future,'' Osbourne said. The former lead singer of Black Sabbath took offense when O'Connor singled out Osbourne's ``Suicide Solution'' as typifying the songs that lead to demonic possession and even suicide. ``If you want to discuss this matter with me personally, you can call me any time and I will only be too happy to discuss this with you in private. God bless you,'' Osbourne wrote. Osbourne was sued in 1987 by parents of a 19-year-old who committed suicide while listening to another Osbourne song. The lawsuit was later dismissed. The thrash rocker says that ``Suicide Solution'' was really about the dangers of alcohol, which caused the death of his friend, Bon Scott, lead singer of AC-DC. The song, Osbourne told The Associated Press in 1987, ``was nothing more than a warning to people on the dangers of drinking too much alcohol. ... The song was a warning to me as well as everyone else. If I hear it enough maybe it will have an effect.'' Osbourne acknowledges he still has a drinking problem.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests Man Who Allegedly Threatened Stephanie Zimbalist
DOC.TEXT: A man who allegedly sent 212 mostly threatening letters and cards to ``Remington Steele'' star Stephanie Zimbalist was arrested at a hotel after he arrived in Southern California, the FBI said. Michael Lawrence Shields, 43, of Plymouth, Mich., was scheduled to appear at a bail hearing today on three counts of mailing threatening communications contained in an FBI complaint. He was arrested Friday. Most of the letters sent to the 33-year-old actress were threatening, authorities said Monday. ``In your efforts to avoid me, Miss Zimbalist, you'll win a few,'' said an April letter. ``You'll perform in some small town, and I won't know about it. But you must win every time! I only have to win once, and I've got you again.'' A Feb. 16, 1990, letter reads, ``Dear Stephanie, You can run but you can't hide. Your Secret Admirer.'' FBI agents found Shields because his last letter said he would be coming to Southern California and gave his flight number and the name of the hotel, said FBI agent Lawrence Lawler. Philip Minges, a spokesman for the actress, said she was ``obviously relieved'' that Shields was in custody. Miss Zimbalist played sleuth Laura Holt on NBC's ``Remington Steele'' TV detective series which ran from 1982 through 1986. U.S. Magistrate Joseph Reichmann refused Monday to throw out the complaint. Shields' lawyer contended the letters contained no explicit threats.

DOC.HEAD: Human Testing of Potential AIDS Vaccine to Begin
DOC.TEXT: Human testing of a potential AIDS vaccine, the first to be approved by a state board without going through the federal process, is scheduled to begin soon at two California hospitals. The California Department of Health Services Food and Drug Branch announced Monday that clinical tests of HGP-30 will start in two or three months at San Francisco General Hospital and the University of Southern Califorer in Los Angeles. Researchers are seeking 24 healthy volunteers who test negative for exposure to the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. This initial test is to nia Medical Centdetermine the vaccine's safety. But scientists also will watch to see if the volunteers' bodies make protective antibodies against the vaccine, a hint that it might someday provide protection against acquired immune deficiency syndrome. ``It is a very limited, small study _ the first step in vaccine development in humans,'' said Dr. James Kahn, who will conduct the testing in San Francisco. ``It's not something that's going to cure AIDS, and it is not intended as a cure or treatment for AIDS.'' If it is proven safe, the next step would be to see if it can prevent AIDS, and researchers say that only after safety and effectiveness are proven, a process that could take many years, would the vaccine be distributp. of Alexandria, Va. Researchers hope the body, when exposed to the synthetic protein, will be tricked into thinking it has been exposed to the true HIV protein and will launch an immune response against it. ``Once successful immunization with HGP-30 is achieved, an individual should be protected from all the various strains of the AIDS virus,'' said Dr. Allan L. Goldstein of the George Washington University School of Medicine, who led the team that discovered HGP-30. Its manufacturer became impatient with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval process and began giving the vaccine to British men last May. No results are yet available from this study. Under a new state law, a drug or vaccine can be tested in California if it is made and approved in the state. This law was designed to circumvent the lengthy FDA approval process, speeding up availability of anti-AIDS agents. By the end of last month, the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta had recorded 121,645 cases of AIDS in the United States, with 72,580 deaths, or 60 percent of all cases.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Legislator Faces Recall Over Indian Spearfishing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th graf, `The turnout...' to UPDATE with polls open. Picks up 5th graf, `The vote...'.
DOC.TEXT: A state legislator said turnout today holds the key to whether he survives a recall election forced by opponents of spearfishing rights for Wisconsin's Chippewa Indians. Rep. James Holperin, a four-term Democrat, is Wisconsin's first state legislator to face a recall since 1932. He was challenged by Sayner businessman Gene Ahlborn in today's Democratic race. The winner meets Republican Brian Sherren in the April 3 election for Holperin's Assembly seat. ``The turnout will be critical,'' Holperin said Monday. ``The turnout in special elections have generally not been that good. If turnout is low, I believe I will not do as well and will be beaten.'' The polls opened at 8 a.m. and Oneida County Clerk Dick MacDonald said today that clerks are expecting a big turnout because of the controversy. The vote to remove the 39-year-old legislator comes after years of turmoil over the Chippewas' rights to catch walleye with spears in northern Wisconsin. In 1983, a federal court ruled the Chippewas had the right to spearfish, hunt, cut timber and gather food off the reservation under 19th century treaties that ceded northern Wisconsin to the U.S. government. The ruling is under appeal. Vilas and Oneida counties, which Holperin represents, have been the scene of angry confrontations between non-Indians and Chippewa spearfishermen in recent years. Organizers of the recall claimed Holperin lost touch with his constituents over the issue. Opponents were especially critical of his support for Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson's negotiated plan to pay the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa band $50 million in cash and other aid over 10 years if they curtailed exercise of their treaty rights. Tribal members voted down the plan last fall. Recall backers noted that surveys indicated 70 percent of Holperin's constituents opposed the plan. Stop Treaty Abuse-Wisconsin, a group that objects to allowing Indians to spearfish _ something non-Indians cannot do _ gathered more than 6,000 signatures to force the recall. ``These people ... are crying for representation,'' said Ahlborn, 50. ``I will listen to the people. It is just that plain and simple.'' Holperin repeatedly has said he does not support court rulings that upheld the Indians' treaty rights. He said the lease settlement was a way to defuse the confrontations while the appeals weaved through the courts. ``If (Holperin) loses, it is going to be a threat to anyone who does anything that a special interest groups disagrees with,'' said Gary Greenland, a professor of history and political science at nearby Nicolet College.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Chairman Recuperating From Fainting Spell
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 7 grafs new to update with latest medical statement. Picks up 6th graf pvs, Atwater collapsed.
DOC.TEXT: Lee Atwater, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was undergoing additional hospital tests today as doctors tried to come up with a diagnosis for his collapse during a speech. ``He is in great spirits and spent the day yesterday with family and friends,'' said RNC spokeswoman Leslie Goodman. One source, who asked not to be identified, said Atwater received calls at the hospital from President Bush and former Presidents Ronald Reagan and Richard Nixon. The Republican chairman was taken by ambulance to Holy Cross Hospital in suburban Silver Spring, Md., on Monday night for a special exam called magnetic resonance imaging, which provides computer analysis of internal organs and structures. After the test, Atwater was seen propped up on a stretcher, chatting with family members and aides and appeared in good spirits. Goodman said early tests ``were not definitive.'' Atwater, 39 and a regular exerciser, fainted as he was speaking to a group of GOP contributors Monday morning and was rushed to George Washington University Hospital. He remained in the hospital overnight. Atwater collapsed about 10 minutes into a breakfast talk to about 100 longtime contributors to Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, at a Washington hotel. An aide to Gramm, Larry Neal, said two doctors were in the room and both came forward immediately. Ms. Goodman said Atwater regained consciousness before an ambulance arrived at the hotel, and was out only briefly. Neal said paramedics arrived in two or three minutes. Atwater, who was President Bush's 1988 campaign manager, accompanied Bush late last week to several GOP fundraising events in California and had been in Puerto Rico over the weekend on party business. Earlier this year, the chairman went on a liquid diet in hopes of losing a few pounds. He told a reporter last week, however, that he had given up the diet and had actually gained, rather than lost, weight. Strict liquid diets have been associated with a variety of side effects, including fainting. However, aides said Atwater had been off the diet for several weeks and had not followed the regime closely when he was on it. Atwater exercises up to 90 minutes daily and runs several times a week, often for six miles, aides said.

DOC.HEAD: Reports of Coup Attempt in Afghanistan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with curfew imposed, guerrilla leader saying rebels are broadcasting on army frequency. Pick up 6th pvs, `Najib has...' Defense minister's name is pronounced shah na-WAHZ tah-NYE.
DOC.TEXT: The Afghan defense minister and Moslem guerrillas attempted to overthrow the Kremlin-backed government in Kabul today but failed, Kabul radio said. Pakistan-based guerrillas and diplomats said they had reports of widespread fighting in Kabul. In Moscow, official Soviet sources said the palace of President Najib was bombed by unidentified planes, and that there was fighting around the Defense Ministry. Official Kabul radio, monitored in Islamabad, said Defense Minister Shah Nawaz Tanai had plotted with guerrilla leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar and his fighters to overthrow the government. But the attempted coup was crushed, it said, and Tanai had escaped. Security forces were searching for him and his backers. The radio appealed to Afghans to join the military and help capture Tanai ``dead or alive.'' A curfew was imposed at 7 p.m. in Kabul, the radio said. Hekmatyar, leader of Hezb-i-Islami, one of the most fundamentalist of the seven resistance groups based in Pakistan, said the guerrillas were broadcasting appeals on the Afghan army's military frequency urging soldiers to help oust Najib and his government. ``Now is the time for all Afghan people to join hands, topple this regime and finish the fighting,'' Hekmatyar said at a news conference in Islamabad. Najib has been president of Afghanistan since 1986. He has made various offers to the guerrillas, known as mujahedeen or Islamic holy warriors, to try to end the civil war that started when his Marxist party seized power in a 1978 coup. Tanai is considered a party hardliner who opposes the peace overtures. He was implicated in a December coup attempt but never charged. Guerrilla sources based in Pakistan said they had reports from their commanders of widespread fighting in Kabul. ``If Kabul radio says it (the coup) has been crushed, it doesn't mean it has,'' said a guerrilla source. Tanai, one of the leaders of the revolution that installed the Soviet-backed government, has reportedly had contacts recently with the Moslem guerrillas. Guerrillas in the Pakistan frontier city of Peshawar indicated they would give the general sanctuary. ``Probably,'' said one guerrilla source when asked if the rebels would help Tanai evade Afghan troops. The Soviet news agency Tass, quoting eyewitnesses, said ``unidentified planes bombed the presidential palace,'' and that anti-aircraft guns returned fire. Shooting also was heard in the vicinity of the airport and near the Defense Ministry, Tass said. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov told reporters earlier in a news briefing that a coup attempt possibly was under way. ``There is fighting at the airport. The situation is unclear, it may be a coup attempt,'' he said. ``We must wait for information, we don't know who is fighting who.'' He said it was too early to say what action the Soviet Union would take in the event Najib was overthrown. Western diplomats in Islamabad also reported street fighting, aerial bombardments by the Afghan air force, tank movement around the Soviet Embassy and fighting around the presidential palace. They did not know if the tanks were being moved to defend the embassy or to attack it. The diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they had received their information from numerous sources but declined to elaborate. Radio Kabul said Aslam Watanjar, the country's interior minister, will replace Tanai. Tanai has been involved in at least three of five known coup attempts since Najib became president in December 1986, Afghan sources in New Delhi said. The most recent was in December, when at least 100 members of the Khalqi faction of the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan were detained, the sources said on condition of anonymity. Similar accounts were given by Kabul residents. Tanai, thought to be in his mid 40s, has a reputation as an ultra hard-liner, especially when it comes to making any concessions to the mujahedeen or modifying the stand of his party. Although its origins are Marxist, the party under Najib has sought to portray itself as a defender of Islam and champion of a free-market economy. Tanai is a member of the party's Politburo, which currently has 14 members, according to senior party members. Soviet troops pulled out of Afghanistan in February 1989 after 10 years of waging war against rebels trying to oust successive Soviet-backed regimes. Guerrilla attacks intensified after the pullout and some observers predicted Najib's days were numbered, but the guerrillas were unable to secure major cities. Government troops repelled attacks on such cities as Jalalabad and Khost. International operators in Moscow reported that telephone lines to Kabul were damaged.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Will Appeal Flag-Burning Ruling
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 8 grafs new to UPDATE with Justice Department saying it will appeal decision, picks up 9th graf pvs, In Monday's.
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said today it will ask the Supreme Court to review a second federal judge's ruling that a new law making it a crime to burn the American flag is unconstitutional. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said government attorneys intend to appeal Monday's ruling here by U.S. District Judge June Green. The Justice Department has already filed a notice of its intention to ask the Supreme Court to review a similar ruling Feb. 21 by a federal judge in Seattle. Both judges struck down the Flag Protection Act of 1989 and dismissed criminal charges against defendants accused of flag burning. The judges said the statute violates the First Amendment's protection of free speech. ``It would be our expectation the court would consolidate those cases,'' Runkel said. The law provides for direct appeal of district-court rulings to the Supreme Court. Such rulings have legal effect only in the geographical area covered by the district court. The ruling Monday gave opponents of the law their second victory in less than two weeks. But it also gives proponents of a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning more political ammunition for their cause. President Bush endorsed the amendment route to undo last year's Supreme Court ruling that struck down a Texas flag-burning law, saying he was unsure that the statute Congress passed instead would survive court challenges. In Monday's decision, Green held that flag burning is a form of political speech protected by the First Amendment. She rejected the Justice Department's contention that the law was enacted to protect the flag, not regulate speech. ``However compelling the government may see its interests, they cannot justify restrictions on speech which shake the very cornerstone of the First Amendment,'' the judge wrote. ``For in protecting the flag for those who wish to wave it in support of these causes, but preventing the defendants from burning it in opposition, the government has created a regulation which cannot be justified without reference to the content of the defendants' message,'' she wrote. Green dismissed flag-burning charges against Shawn D. Eichmann, David G. Blalock and Scott W. Tyler. The three were arrested last Oct. 30 after they set several flags on fire during a protest outside the U.S. Capitol. Conviction under the law carries a one-year sentence. ``The right to dissent is sometimes an albatross which burdens our society with its offensive sounds. Yet, political dissent lies at the heart of the First Amendment's protection,'' Green wrote. It ``would not be needed if the persons who exercise their right of free expression by word and action were all pleasing, lovable persons with whom the rest of the citizens agreed,'' she said. ``The First Amendment, of course, makes no invidious exceptions. It provides protection for everyone, including the defendants.'' William Kunstler, a New York attorney who handled both the Washington and Seattle cases for the Center for Constitutional Rights, hailed the ruling, saying: ``We have knocked out an offensive statute in the area of the First Amendment.'' But Kunstler predicted that there would be a long fight over passage of a constitutional amendment if both the Washington and Seattle rulings are upheld by the Supreme Court. ``We passed phase one, we are going into phase two,'' Kunstler said. ``If we win, we go into phase three, which is this horrible amendment, which the president is sitting back and licking his chops over.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union, East Germany Say No to Nato Membership for Germany
DOC.TEXT: The leaders of the Soviet Union and East Germany said today that NATO membership for a unified Germany is not acceptable and proposed a staged approach for the merger of the two countries. At a Kremlin meeting, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and East German Premier Hans Modrow also urged that Poland be included in discussions between the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union on unification. After the meeting, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said Gorbachev ``dismissed the idea of a united Germany remaining in NATO.'' ``It is clear to us that it does make a difference if a united Germany is to be a NATO member,'' Gerasimov quoted Gorbachev as saying. President Bush and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl have said a unified Germany should remain a full member of NATO. In talks in Washington late last month, Kohl said a neutral unified Germany would be ``a false solution.'' East German spokesman Wolfgang Meyer said the leaders agreed NATO membership for a unified Germany would be ``a continuation of the Cold War in the present era.'' Modrow came to Moscow to discuss German unification, economic cooperation, Polish borders, and Soviet security after East Germany's free elections on March 18. He returned to Berlin this afternoon. Until the hard-line Communist regime of Erich Honecker crumbled last fall, East Germany was the Soviet Union's firmest ally in Eastern Europe, and it remains the Kremlin's chief trading partner. Gerasimov said Gorbachev saw a bright future for trade with unified Germany. ``He was very optimistic about our future relations if unification proceeded as it should, that is stage-by-stage,'' Gerasimov said. He said both sides wanted a meeting of the four World War II victors _ the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain _ before the East German elections. ``All countries, except the United States, have given the go-ahead,'' Gerasimov said. Gorbachev and Modrow agreed Poland should be included in the unification process, spokesmen for the leaders said. ``The two sides are of the opinion that not a single question concerning Poland can be considered without it (Poland),'' Mayer said. ``The same applies to all neighbors of East Germany and West Germany.'' Germany's attack on Poland on Sept. 1, 1939, started World War II. Poland lost territory to the Soviet Union but gained land from Germany at the war's end and Poland has asked the German states for a treaty that guarantees the Oder-Neisse river border as the permanent frontier.

DOC.HEAD: ``60 Minutes'' Fourth In National Ratings
DOC.TEXT: With Andy Rooney back after his controversial suspension, CBS' ``60 Minutes'' was fourth in last week's national Nielsen ratings and had its fourth highest rating this season, CBS estimates showed today. Sunday's broadcast, in which Rooney discussed his abbreviated suspension and denied he was a bigot, had a 22 rating and a 37 percent share of the national audience, easily beating ABC's competing ``Life Goes On.'' That series had an 8.9 rating and a 15 percent audience share, trailed by NBC's Disney movie hour, which averaged an 8.3 rating and a 14 percent share. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. On Feb. 8, Rooney was suspended for three months without pay after a gay magazine quoted him as making a racial slur. He denied he said it. CBS News president David Burke lifted Rooney's suspension Thursday. The ratings of ``60 Minutes'' slipped during Rooney's three-week absence, and the program on Feb. 25 dropped to 18th place in ratings. Network analysts said the slippage was due primarily to ABC's repeat broadcast of the premiere of its hit ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' That special, shown in the time period normally held by ``Life Goes On,'' beat ``60 Minutes'' in the ratings.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Begins Resupply of Sparkling Water
DOC.TEXT: The producers of Perrier began resupplying their distributors today, three weeks after ordering the worldwide recall of 160 million bottles because traces of cancer-causing chemicals were found in the sparkling water. The company said the new bottles _ marked ``New Production'' _ would be available Wednesday in French stores and in most of Europe, Canada and the eastern United States by early April. They will be available in the western United States by April 22, Perrier said. The recall was announced Feb. 14 after traces of benzene, a cancer-causing chemical, were found in Perrier samples in several countries, including the United States, Canada, West Germany, the Netherlands and Denmark. Benzene, a naturally occurring chemical used in cleaning solvents, entered Perrier's bottling line after workers failed to replace a filter, the company said. A spokesman for Perrier said an international team of experts would ensure that the mineral water is now pure. The company said it has not yet been able to calculate the cost of the resupply program. In France, unlike in other countries, the recall was voluntary. Some supermarket chains cleared their shelves of the product, while other shopowners continued to sell it.

DOC.HEAD: Date Of Elections Announced
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's first free elections in more than four decades will be held on June 8 and 9, Parliament announced today. The balloting for both houses of Parliament will be based on the principle of proportional representation, said a parliament statement carried by the official CTK news agency. Parties will need 10,000 signatures to run a candidate and at least 5 percent of the national vote for a mandate, CTK said. Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution late last year toppled the hard-line Communist leadership of Milos Jakes, ending more than 40 years of Communist rule and paving the way for the first free elections since 1946. In keeping with a decision to streamline the country's legislative body, the number of seats in the House of People, one of Parliament's two chambers, has been reduced from 200 to 150 seats. Of those, 101 will go to candidates in the Czech lands, while 49 will be allocated to deputies from the country's smaller republic, Slovakia, CTK said. In the second chamber, the House of Nations, the 150 seats were divided evenly between representatives from the two republics. The decision to cut the number of seats came under a move to transform the parliament into a less unwieldy, full-time legislature. Under Communist rule the parliament was largely a rubber-stamp institution for party policy that met only a few days a year. In another development, the Czech National Council, the regional Parliament, approved an amendment to the republic's constitution Monday dropping the ``Socialist,'' from its name, ``Czech Socicalist Republic,'' CTK reported. The Slovak National Council passed an identical law on Friday. Deputies of the Czech council also supported a proposal by Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel to drop the word ``Socialist'' from the country's formal name, making it the ``Czechoslovak Republic.'' The Czech and Slovak lands were united in Czechoslovakia in 1918 after the dissolution of the Austrian Habsburg monarchy in World War I. The country was named the Czechoslovak Republic from 1918 until 1960, when the Communists added the definition Socialist.

DOC.HEAD: Military Says Senior PLO Officer Captured in Boat Seizure
