DOC.TEXT: The Israeli navy captured a senior PLO officer and an alleged ``terrorist'' collaborator when it seized a boat off the Lebanese coast last month, the military announced Tuesday. The PLO officer was identified as Said Sanouna, and was about to be appointed to a senior post with PLO Chief Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction in Lebanon. The second person was not identified. The Farah 7, en route from Cyprus to Lebanon, was stopped by the navy during a routine patrol Feb. 23, and it was brought to Israel, the military said. The boat and all those aboard except two _ Sanouna and a ``wanted collaborator with terrorists'' _ were freed Tuesday, the military said. The Farah 7 had been stopped by the navy near Lebanon in April 1989 and several Fatah men were captured, according to a military spokesman. The military did not say how many people were aboard the vessel or where it had been registered.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed in Fight Between Farmers, Ranchers
DOC.TEXT: A range war has erupted in northern Nigeria for the second time in four months, claiming 11 lives, newspapers reported Tuesday. Fulani cattle herders clashed with Hausa farmers in Sokoto state last weekend, the newspapers said. The farmers accuse the herdsmen of letting their cattle graze on the farmers' crops. The latest fighting followed the release from jail of two cattle herders who had been charged with killing a farmer. Angered by the release of the two herders, relatives of the dead farmer attacked the ranchers, the newspapers said. Fighting between the farmers and ranchers claimed nine lives in Sokoto state since November.

DOC.HEAD: Anchors of German Battleship Bluecher Salvaged
DOC.TEXT: Two rusty 10-ton anchors of Nazi Germany's cruiser Bluecher were salvaged from 230 feet of water in the Oslofiord, a newspaper reported. The anchors will be turned into memorials to mark the German attack on Norway 50 years ago, the newspaper Aftenposten reported Monday. The Bluecher sank April 9, 1940, off Oscarsborg Fortress, under torpedo and gun attack by Norwegian forces. Of the 2,400 men aboard, about 1,000 died. The salvage vessel Oslokrana raised the anchors. One will be unveiled as a memorial in a park in Droebak and the other will be given to the fortress. The cruiser remains on the bottom.

DOC.HEAD: Old Pearl Discovery Rivets Bahrain
DOC.TEXT: Archaeologists have unearthed a pink pearl, believed to be 4,000 years old, stirring excitement on this Persian Gulf island whose oil riches overshadow its former glory as the land of the pearls. ``This is an excellent find, the most romantic find of the decade,'' said Robert Killick, director of the joint London-Bahrain Archaeological Expedition. Unlike gold or silver trinkets, ancient pearls are extremely rare finds because their surfaces peel and they disintegrate, he said. Killick said the pearl, which was four millimeters in diameter, was from the Dilmun era _ 45 to 50 centuries ago when the island thrived as a major trading center between Mesopotamia, now Iraq, and the Indus Valley of west Asia. Killick said the pearl was believed 4,000 years old because his expedition, which involves Bahrain's Ministry of Information and the British Academy, was digging through an ancient town dating to that time. Bahrain's pearling industry thrived in the past three centuries, but tapered off with the advent of Japan's artificial pearl industry and the vast wealth earned from oil.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Team Attempts Winter Ascent of Mount McKinley
DOC.TEXT: Four Japanese mountain climbers attempting a winter ascent of Mount McKinley's dangerous West Buttress haven't been seen in nearly two weeks. Four other climbers have died on North America's highest mountain during winter. At high elevations in winter, McKinley often has white-out conditions with wind that can exceed 200 mph. The mountain is in Denali National Park, the native American name for the mountain. The climbers and their equipment, including a 35-day supply of food, were flown to a camp on the southeast fork of the Kahiltna Glacier on Feb. 11, said Park Service mountaineering ranger Bob Seibert. Since then, the weather on the 20,320-foot mountain generally has been bad. Cliff Hudson, a bush pilot who flew the group onto the mountain, said he was scheduled to check on them last week. But he said he could not because visibility on the mountain has been close to zero. Hudson and Seibert said the group was last seen Feb. 22 at about the 11,000-foot level by a plane flying overhead. There were no apparent problems. Hudson said he would try to fly over the mountain as soon as weather permitted. ``They have priority,'' he said. When the group left Talkeetna, outside the park, they gave March 15 as the ``last due out'' date, Seibert said. That is the day a search would begin if they don't return. Hiroshi Oda, 37 of Osaka, is leading the 1990 Japan Winter McKinley Expedition. With him are Takeyoshi Takatsuka, 47, of Toyama; Osamu Tagaya, 34, of Akita; and Junji Saito, 25, also of Osaka. All four are experienced mountaineers, Seibert said. Oda has successfully climbed Mount Everest and McKinley's West Buttress during summer, and Takatsuka has scaled Everest and K2, the two highest peaks in the world, Seibert said. If successful, they would be the first Japanese to successfully scale the West Buttress in winter. Last March, three Japanese climbers were lost in a storm on their way up the mountain during a storm that featured 200-plus mph wind. A fourth member of that group returned to camp alone before his fellow climbers were lost. In 1984, solo adventurer Naomi Uemura died on his way down the mountain after planting his flag at the top. It is believed he also died in a winter storm, Seibert said.

DOC.HEAD: Delivery Company Loses Precious Einstein Film
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 4,000 feet of film on Albert Einstein that was part of the University of South Carolina's Movietonews collection fell out of a delivery truck and has been missing for a week, officials say. ``From a historical standpoint, it is absolutely irreplaceable,'' said Don McCallister, assistant archivist for the university's News Film Library. ``I can't really put a dollar value on it. How do you put a dollar value on something that cannot be replaced?'' The film, which has historical value to researchers, shows Einstein appearing at various events during the 1930s. The university was sending the film, which was packed in a 1-foot-square fiberboard carton, to Audio Plus Video International in Northvale, N.J., so it could be copied onto videotape for a French filmmaker, McCallister said. On Feb. 27, a delivery truck carrying the film left the Federal Express office in Columbia. A few blocks down the road, the driver realized the back door had opened. Federal Express workers searched the route but did not find the package. ``We are doing everything we can to try to find this package,'' Sandra Munoz, a spokeswoman for Federal Express in Memphis, Tenn., said Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: SR-71 Lands in Attempt for Record Cross-Continent Flight
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New lead to say flight time was for crossing the continent. picks up 2nd graf pvs, The aircraft.
DOC.TEXT: The SR-71 Blackbird spy plane ended its last flight today, apparently shattering at least three air-speed standards as it crossed the continent on its way to museum display. Initial calculations put its flight time at 68 minutes and 32 seconds. The aircraft, to be displayed by the Smithsonian Institution, touched down at Washington Dulles International Airport at 10:50 a.m. EST, said Jack Weir of the airport operations office. The aircraft had taken off in a fiery blast from its Mojave Desert airfield at Air Force Plant 42 at 4:30 a.m. PST, or 7:30 a.m. EST. After flying over California for a time, it took on fuel before officially beginning its flight, and landed at the airport some 20 miles outside Washington, D.C. Weir said officials were still determining whether the spy plane, which is being mothballed because of budget cuts, broke four records as intended. ``They're still computing all that,'' said Weir just after the landing. ``Unofficially, it set at least three records,'' Weir said. One was fastest transcontinental flight, he said. It was not immediately known what the other two were. Weir said the flight time was initially determined to be 68 minutes, 32 seconds. ``It was awesome,'' said Air Force Col. Tom Hornung of the liftoff. ``It was a fitting end to a great Air Force program.'' Flying the ominous-looking black plane were pilot Lt. Col. Raymond E. Yeilding and his reconnaissance systems officer, Lt. Col. J. D. Vida. At speeds exceeding Mach 3, or three times the speed of sound, the crew planned to attempt four speed records on the way. The crew was trying to best a world record from Los Angeles to Washington, a world record from Kansas City to Washington, a world record from St. Louis to Cincinnati and a national record from the West Coast to the East Coast. Any records must be certified by the Federation Aeronautique International. The Blackbird spy plane was a successor aircraft to the U-2 spy plane, one of which was shot down on a spying mission over the Soviet Union during the Eisenhower administration. The Blackbird, the world's fastest operational aircraft, has never been shot down, although it has collected virtually tons of raw intelligence data from world hot spots during its 25-year service life. Pilots flying SR-71s already hold the world absolute records for speed, 2,193 mph, and altitude, 85,069 feet. After congressional debate late last year, Congress decided to go along with an Air Force request to mothball the Blackbird fleet. The Air Force contended that the program was too expensive compared to other budget priorities, such as the B-2 stealth bomber. It also hopes to develop a new generation of fighter aircraft for the 21st century. The Blackbird planes remained popular with congressional intelligence committees and with other consumers of intelligence such as the CIA and the State Department. The spy plane program has been carried as part of the Air Force budget.

DOC.HEAD: 7,000 U.S. Troops May be Withdrawn from South Korea
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials said Tuesday they are considering withdrawing 7,000 troops from South Korea by 1994, a number that would reduce U.S. forces on the peninsula to the lowest level since the Korean War. Also on Tuesday, South Korean President Roh Tae-woo warned North Korea that the discovery of what Seoul officials describe as an invasion tunnel across the 2{-mile Demilitarized Zone could lead to the communist nation's ``self-destruction.'' A reduction of 7,000 troops would leave roughly 36,000 U.S. servicemen in South Korea. It was reported earlier that the United States would be withdrawing about 5,000 troops. In the new proposal, about 2,000 air support personnel and 5,000 other troops would be evacuated, officials said. It has not been decided whether units of the 2nd Infantry Division, key U.S. ground troops deployed near the border, would be affected, they said. As part of a series of defense reductions Washington has asked Seoul to increase the money it pays toward the upkeep of U.S. troops stationed in South Korea, officials said. Other changes being considered could include the appointment of a Korean to replace an American admiral as head of the United Nations Command delegation to the Military Armistice Commission. The U.S.-led command represents the 16 nations that fought alongside South Korea during the 1950-53 Korean War and help police the armistice that ended the conflict. The 155-mile border separating North Korea from South Korea is one of the most heavily fortified in the world and is sealed to prevent communication, visits, mail or telephone calls from one side to the other. Despite sporatic dialogue aimed at easing tensions, the two nations remain enemies. The sweeping changes that have created new political allignments in Eastern Europe show no sign of affecting North Korea, one of the last hard-line communist states. The tunnel discovered Saturday was found 145 yards below the surface, and is 2 yards wide and 2 yards high, large enough for three fully armed soldiers to run abreast, officials said. They said a regiment-size army could pass through in an hour. ``The North Korean leaders must know that they could face a self-destructive, suicidal situation if they continue such anti-national acts,'' Roh said in a speech at the Korea Military Academy. Officials said the tunnel, which begins in the northern sector of the neutral zone, crosses about 1,000 yards into South Korean territory.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Faced with Jail Takes Pill Overdose in Court
DOC.TEXT: A woman who told a judge, ``I will not go to jail,'' swallowed a handful of pills as she was led away, and was hospitalized Tuesday in critical condition. Carol Krzyzaniak of Spring Hill was in court Monday under orders to come up with $2,000 or spend 179 days in jail in a guardianship mismanagement case, said Circuit Judge Richard Tombrink Jr. When she said she could not pay and was led off to jail, she started taking the pills. ``She took a large number of pills. But I don't know what kind,'' said Tim Mossgrove of the city fire-rescue department, which took her to Lykes Memorial Hospital, where she was in intensive care. Ms. Krzyzaniak was found in contempt of court Jan. 25 for failing to uphold her duties as legal guardian of the $130,000 estate of an 84-year-old man who died in June. Brooksville is in Hernando County, about 50 miles north of Tampa.

DOC.HEAD: Cruising Capital May Put Brakes On National Pastime
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Generations of tires have rolled along the two-mile strip of McHenry Avenue where cruising has resisted fading into nostalgia with sock hops, 45 rpm records and poodle skirts. It was a world shown in the reminiscences of native son George Lucas in his 1973 movie ``American Graffiti.'' But like rock 'n' roll, cruising has evolved into something wilder, argue police and some business owners who want to curb the steady parade of teen-agers and cars. ``When people cruise McHenry, we see an increase in gang activity, in alcohol and substance abuse, vandalism to businesses and disrespect in the neighborhoods,'' said Mayor Carol Whiteside. ``We're not willing to be a magnet for everyone in northern California who doesn't have anywhere else to go on Friday night.'' Business owners, tired of removing trash and graffiti from their property before opening Monday mornings, and police, concerned they can't adequately patrol the car-clogged avenue, are pushing a pair of anti-cruising ordinances to be considered March 27 by City Council. Under the proposals, motorists would face fines if they pass designated checkpoints more than twice in a four-hour period. Pedestrians would risk loitering citations. Modestans may deny that cruising is a source of identity for the central California city dwarfed by the San Francisco Bay area 90 miles to the west. But it's hard to find business owners or customers along McHenry Avenue who didn't at some time cruise along some thoroughfare. Perhaps it's the legacy of ``American Graffiti,'' along with the annual Graffiti Night, which honors the cruising tradition in grand proportions, that draws teen-agers to McHenry Avenue most Friday and Saturday nights, sometimes 5,000 vehicles strong. ``We're not here to look for trouble. We're here to have a good time. This is what gathers all different people,'' said 17-year-old Robert Bennett, who drove 15 miles from Manteca. ``A lot of people do bring cars for show,'' said his companion, Matt Meza, 19. Joe Hudson, 19, drove 30 miles from Tracy to find a group of girls he'd met the week before. Not that the evening would be lost if they didn't show _ ``There goes a Mustang with a blonde and a brunette,'' he pointed out to two friends. Today's cruisers may have the same motives as their parents and grandparents, but as car clubs give way to gangs, pranks to violence and staticky radios to blaring stereo systems, some residents wonder if it's time to let cruising pass into legend. ``Modesto is maturing. There is nothing wrong with cruising, but it's not a part of the way of life anymore,'' said Kyle Barker, a music store owner. ``I think we accepted it 10 years ago, one, because I think it was more wholesome and, two, I think we were more naive about the consequences.'' In Lucas' day, a well-aimed water balloon may have gotten the perpetrator's windshield smeared with shaving cream, but probably wouldn't have drawn a knuckle sandwich. The consequences today may be far more serious, said police Sgt. Gene Wilkinson. ``We may get somebody beat over the head with a baseball bat because he hit someone with a water balloon,'' he said. Now, during a typical weekend along McHenry Avenue, 50-odd citations are issued and half dozen arrests are made, Wilkinson said. ``It's a different world than you had 25 or 30 years ago. We have to address the problems of today,'' Wilkinson said. ``I can understand the complaints of nostalgia buffs. Maybe 30 years ago, it would have been an overreaction, but today all we're trying to do is protect those we can.'' McHenry Avenue today is the address of hundreds of businesses, and some owners say they lose customers when the daytime commuter corridor becomes overrun by low riders with rattling mufflers, detailed pickup trucks and pastel colored VWs. ``Commerce is America. We have to earn a living. If it's in our way, we have to stop it,'' said Raj Jariya, night clerk at the Capri Inn.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: Nation's Population Reaches 250 Million
DOC.TEXT: There are now a quarter-billion Americans. This nation started life with just under 4 million people, about as many as now live in metropolitan Boston. On Tuesday it reached 250,000,000, according to estimates by the Census Bureau. A more detailed total will be calculated following the national head count to be taken April 1. The 250 million estimate represents a 10.4 percent increase from the 226.5 million Americans counted in 1980. The U.S. population reached 50 million in 1880, doubled to 100 million by 1915, was 150 million in 1949 and climbed to the 200 million mark in 1967. Projections done by the Census Bureau indicate that the nation could reach 300 million within 30 years. Current population growth is estimated at one new person every 14 seconds in the United States. That is based on a birth every 8 seconds and a new immigrant arriving every 35 seconds, balanced by a death every 14 seconds and a departure every 3 minutes. The United States ranks fourth in the world in population, following China, at 1.1 billion; India, at 833 million, and the Soviet Union, at 289 million. Following the United States are Indonesia, 188 million; Brazil, 151 million; Japan, 123 million; Nigeria, 115 million; Bangladesh, 115 million and Pakistan, 110 million.

DOC.HEAD: December and January, The Winter of Our Dissimilarity
DOC.TEXT: Two more unlike months you could hardly find in a single season. It was the warmest January on record in the United States, following one of the coldest Decembers. The average temperature in January was 37.2 degrees Fahranheit in the 48 contiguous states, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported Monday. That's the warmest January since uniform record collection was started in 1895, according to NOAA's National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C. The relative warmth was felt most strongly in the region that includes parts of Montana, the Dakotas, Wyoming and Nebraska, the agency said. But readings were above normal across nearly all of the nation Mx}ept the Southwest. That warmth came hard on the heels of the fourth coldest December on record, a month when bitter cold was felt even in Florida, the agency noted.

DOC.HEAD: Billboards Will Tell Youths ``Addiction is Slavery''
DOC.TEXT: A black hand grips several vials of crack cocaine. The message is simple _ ``Addiction is slavery.'' The billboard, unveiled Tuesday by NAACP Executive Director Benjamin L. Hooks, will soon appear in several thousand locations nationwide, as will a companion anti-drug billboard aimed at white youths. ``If anything today is slavery, it is drug addiction,'' Hooks said. ``It determines when you wake up, when you go to bed, what kind of job you have, what you think, what you do. ``It destroys lives, will, and purpose and nothing has been deadlier, more dangerous, more damaging to this America than the addiction to illegal substances,'' he said. The Outdoor Advertising Association of America is donating the 5,000 billboards in conjunction with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America. The Eight-Sheet Outdoor Advertising Association, which represents smaller billboards found mainly in urban areas, is working with the OAAA on the anti-drug effort. ``I hope that it will help to wipe out the drug scourge in America, and that young men and women can lift up their heads, their eyes, their hearts and be able to walk down the street knowing they are not slaves but that they are in control and in charge of their lives,'' Hooks said. The ``Addiction is Slavery'' billboard targets the black community. A companion billboard called ``cocaine gun'' shows a young white boy with a gun pointed up his nose and is labeled simply, ``Cocaine.'' The ``Addiction is Slavery'' billboard was created by the Harlem-based Patrick Agency and the ``Cocaine Gun'' billboard was created by DDB Needham Worldwide. Kippy Burns, a spokeswoman for the Outdoor Advertising Association of America, said the number of billboards being devoted to the message has not been determined. The OAAA, which represents more than 80 percent of the billboard industry, estimates the value of the advertising effort at $5 million, Burns said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Jews Hope to Raise $420 Million to Resettle Soviets in Israel
DOC.TEXT: American Jews intend to raise $420 million this year for ``Operation Exodus'' to help settle a flood of Soviet Jews in Israel, fund-raisers announced Tuesday. The money will be used to transport immigrants from the Soviet Union, to refurbuish absorption centers in Israel and to help in the initial costs of the resettlement. The campaign, begun last week, is the largest special fund-raising drive undertaken by the United Jewish Appeal, which raises money for Israel and for Jewish communities in the United States and elsewhere, said spokesman Raphael Rothstein. So far, more than $60 million have been pledged by wealthy Jewish donors, he said at a news conference. The rest of the money is expected to be pledged this year but contributors will have three years to pay up, he said. Soviet reforms have opened the doors to an unprecedented wave of Jewish emigration, most of it heading for Israel. In the first 15 days of February, some 4,600 Soviet Jews arrived in Israel _ more than twice the number that came to Israel in all of 1988, the appeal said. The Jews' departure has been speeded by fears of escalating anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. ``There's an urgency that may become an emergency,'' Rothstein said. But the pace of emigration has been slowed by the Kremlin's refusal to implement an agreement for direct flights from Moscow to Tel Aviv. Rothstein said Jewish leaders are not hopeful that direct flights will be allowed any time soon because of intense pressure from the Arab world, which opposes the Jewish immigration to Israel. He said discussions were underway for ships to carry some of the emigres from the Black Sea port of Odessa to Israel. Such a journey would last 2{ days and would augment the flights from Bucharest, Budapest and other transit points now used by Soviet Jews to reach Israel. The fund raising is based on projections that 200,000 Soviet Jews will arrive in Israel in the next few years, although Israeli officials say the figures could fluctuate with changing circumstances. The Israeli government will provide $3 billion for the absorption of the immigrants, with the rest to be raised by world Jewry. Israel has also asked the Bush administration to guarantee $400 million to build housing for the immigrants. The administration has said it would support the guarantees if Israel promised not to use the money for housing in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel has declined to provide such an outright pledge. The disagreement has raised tensions between Washington and Israel, already exacerbated by Israeli stalling on a proposal by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for advancing peace talks with Palestinians from the occupied territories. Rothstein said the political conflict has not spilled over into the fund-raising campaign. ``There is no indication that political considerations will affect people's generosity,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Election Returns Trickle in, Show Wins for Reformers, Officials
With AM-Soviet-Property, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Official election returns trickling in Tuesday appeared to bear out pro-democracy movements' claims of widespread victories in the country's Slavic heartland, but they also showed Soviet officialdom winning several key races. Communist Party and government officials who won seats in Sunday's local elections included the Ukraine's prime minister, Vitaly Masol, several chiefs of the Ukraine's Communist Party, and the president and prime minister of Byelorussia, the state-run news agency Tass reported. Among prominent pro-reform candidates named as winners by the official press Tuesday were Tatyana Koryagina, a radical economist who has warned of a conservative conspiracy against reform, and Victor Shinkaretsky, a crusading consumer reporter on Soviet TV. The vast majority of the 1,800 parliament seats up for grabs in the Ukraine, Byelorussia and the Russian republic parliaments must be decided in run-off elections. Candidates were required to win 50 percent of the vote. Almost 450 out of 497 races for local councils will go to run-off elections in Moscow, 330 out of 450 districts in the Ukraine; and 43 out of 48 districts in the Byelorussian capital of Minsk, Soviet media reported. The run-off elections are expected within two weeks. Activists from the Ukraine's Narodny Rukh, Byelorussian People's Front and various other progressive movements have said strong showings in this round nearly guaranteed victories in run-off elections for candidates who want to step up the pace of reforms begun by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Gorbachev has railed against functionaries who hamper reform, and people hoping to exercise new economic freedoms have told of crippling obstacles erected by local party officials. Deputies elected in Byelorussia included an unusually high number of doctors, particularly in areas affected by radiation from the Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident, Tass said. Voter turnout was as high as 80 percent in the Ukraine and Byelorussia, but only 64 percent of registered voters turned out in Moscow, the newspaper Pravda said Tuesday. Byelorussia, the Ukraine and the vast Russian republic account for 80 percent of the Soviet Union and more than two-thirds of its 290 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Put Out Tanker Fire After 12 Days
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters on Tuesday finally extinguished a blaze aboard the U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tanker Surf City after a 12-day battle, the owners said. The vessel, in the Gulf of Oman 100 miles off Fujairah, will be left to cool for 24 hours before being removed, according to a statement issued by Chesapeake Shipping Inc. in the United Arab Emirates port city of Dubai. A Feb. 22 blast and fire aboard the 81,283-ton oil products tanker killed two of the 25-member U.S. crew. Four suffered injuries. The Surf City was one of 11 tankers Kuwait registered in the United States during the Iraq-Iran war to entitle them to U.S. Navy protection. Kuwaiti officials, who established the U.S.-registered Chesapeake company to operate the reflagged vessels, said an electrical short circuit caused the explosion. The vessel will be towed to a safe position to conduct a ship-to-ship transfer of the remaining cargo, the company said. Eighty percent of the original gas-oil cargo and 60 percent of the original naphtha cargo remained intact, it said. The blast, which occurred off the U.A.E. southern emirate of Sharjah, started a fire that gutted the living quarters of the 700-foot vessel. A fleet of tugboats fought the fire, which repeatedly reignited. The ship was towed from the gulf after four days because Sharjah authorities feared new explosions.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Confirms Thomas as Federal Judge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today confirmed conservative civil rights official Clarence Thomas as a federal appeals judge, brushing aside complaints about his record from some liberal and senior citizens groups. The Senate had planned to take a roll call on the nomination but changed course at the last minute and confirmed Thomas on a voice vote. Thomas, 41, will be a judge on the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia. As chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission over the last eight years, he has been one of the most visible black officials in the Reagan and Bush administrations. Thomas, a critic of quotas and affirmative action to fight hiring discrimination, has been highly praised by conservatives. But liberals have criticized his record. It became clear Monday night that Thomas' critics had failed to muster enough support to defeat his nomination. ``I am prepared to concede that Mr. Thomas is going to be confirmed,'' said Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, a leading critic. The only other opponent to materialize in the debate was Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, who complained that the statute of limitations on 15,000 age-discrimination cases before the EEOC ran out without any action being taken while Thomas was in charge. ``Those cases might as well have been sent to Beijing,'' Pryor said. ``They might as well have been sent to Bulgaria. They might as well have been sent to Romania. ... It's too much to overlook.'' Pryor said, however, that Thomas was virtually guaranteed to win confirmation and added that he wished the nominee well in his new post. Danforth, Thomas' chief Senate supporter and former employer, said he could vouch for the nominee's abilities as a lawyer. ``I hired him twice,'' Danforth said. ``People say, 'Don't you ever make a mistake?' Well, yeah, but not twice.'' Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., dismissed complaints that Thomas had failed to cooperate with the Aging Committee several years ago when former Sen. John Melcher, D-Mont., was chairman. Simpson said the panel's investigation of the employment commission was flawed to begin with. ``They wasted a lot of time trying to nail Clarence Thomas,'' he said. Thomas was born in poverty in rural Georgia, worked his way through college and is a graduate of Yale Law School. Before becoming chairman of the commission, he worked under Danforth in the Missouri attorney general's office and in the Senate as well for the Monsanto Corp. Civil rights forces have been divided over the nomination. The Alliance for Justice, a liberal court-watcher group based in Washington, and several senior citizens groups have been critical. But the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People did not take a stand on the issue.

DOC.HEAD: Andreotti Sees Bush About Larger Role on German Unification
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after 4th graf pvs bgng, Responding, Adreotti ... to UPDATE with two-plus-four meeting planned in Bonn; picks up 5th graf pvs, Andreotti technically ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti to the White House today for discussions on giving Italy a larger role in shaping a reunified Germany. ``We agree on the foundations of a new Europe,'' Bush said in a speech on the South Lawn welcoming Andreotti to the White House. The president stressed the ties between the United States and Italy, to which 12 million Americans trace their descent. ``Our dialogue is constant, it is substantive, it is productive,'' Bush said. Responding, Andreotti said Italy welcomed ``the dawn of democracy'' in Eastern Europe. But without elaboration, he said the new world that is emerging was ``fraught with problems'' and challenges. Meanwhile, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater announced later that the United States has accepted a West German proposal for ``a two-plus-four meeting of sub-Cabinet officials on March 14 in Bonn.'' Fitzwater said the officials would ``discuss the procedures for future substantive meetings'' on German unification. The two-plus-four are the two Germanys and the four powers that defeated Nazi Germany in World War II, the United States, Great Britain, France and the Soviet Union. Fitzwater said later meetings will be held only after the March 18 elections in East Germany and after discussions between the two Germanys themselves. The State Department said the two-plus-four formula would not be expanded to give a seat at the table to Italy, Poland or any of the other smaller countries. Spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said the formula ``is designed with the four because the four have special legal rights and responsibilities since World War II. ... We have said as far as the others, that we have definitely and are aware of all of their concerns, and will listen to their concerns.'' Andreotti technically speaks only for Italy as he asks Bush to guarantee Rome a place in the U.S. formula for merging East Germany with West Germany. But Denmark, Norway, and other small countries _ as well as Poland and other victims of German aggression in Eastern Europe in World War II _ have a stake in the outcome of Andreotti's talks with Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``It's not a problem which belongs to Italy,'' Andreotti said as he opened talks with Bush in the Oval Office. ``I think that all the member countries of the Atlantic alliance must handle together these problems,'' he said. Andreotti made an exception only of Berlin, the former German capital which is under the control of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. ``The specific problems related to Berlin must be handled by the four countries,'' he said. He stressed that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the 16-member alliance between the United States, Canada and 14 European countries, and the European Security Conference, a grouping of 35 East, West and neutral nations, should be updated to deal with changing circumstances. ``The Western alliance is ever more vital and necessary,'' Andreotti said. The ``two plus four'' formula would have the two Germanys make most of the basic arrangements for unification. Afterward, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ the Big Four allies of World War II _ would move into the planning to consider security issues and the new Germany's place in Europe. Baker gained Soviet, British and French acceptance of the approach at an ``Open Skies'' conference last month in Ottawa, Canada. Last week, visiting Irish Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey worked out an agreement with Bush for additional consultations with the 12 nations of the European Community. Still, Andreotti, who heads Italy's 49th postwar government and is in his sixth non-consecutive term as prime minister, is uneasy. Last week in Rome, he called for closer cooperation between Europe and North America and urged Washington not to overlook its allies in negotiating German unification and other important political and security issues. Andreotti was quoted as saying that any breakdown in the U.S.-Western European relationship at the close of the Cold War would be ``truly absurd.'' The prime minister said he did not fear a united Germany would turn belligerent. But he registered concern that interest rates could be driven up when West Germany tries to help East German development. A senior U.S. official, in a White House session Monday with reporters, said: ``From our perspective, Italy is a very key player in European events. We have made clear that while we think the `two plus four' mechanism is a very important mechanism, it is only a first step, a step in this larger process of German unification.'' The official, whose name could not be disclosed under rules of the briefing, added: ``We believe that there should be full alliance consultation on this process. And there should be full involvement of all European nations concerned. And that, of course, includes Italy.'' At another point, the official described Italy as ``a very key ally'' and said ``we attach a lot of importance to these regular consultations.'' After the meeting with Bush and lunch with Baker at the State Department, Andreottiplanned separate sessions with U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. He will be guest at a black-tie dinner tonight at the White House.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Opens Berlin Bureau
DOC.TEXT: ABC News has opened a Berlin news bureau with offices in East and West Berlin, the network said Tuesday. It said the bureau may become ABC's primary news bureau for coverage of Eastern Europe. The Berlin bureau chief will be Pat Sullivan. His brother, Robert, is the New York bureau chief for Worldwide Television News, a London-based television news agency partly owned by ABC.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Shelves Resolutions on German Border, Unification
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday shelved a resolution that would have called on Germany to stick to its present borders, saying the rush of events made the proposal unnecessary. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., withdrew his resolution after West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government indicated in Bonn it would not lay claim to Polish land. ``I believe international pressure, including the pressure generated by prospective action on my resolution, contributed to Chancellor Kohl's decision to provide the necesary assurances on the Polish-German border,'' Pell said at a committee hearing. Kohl's government agreed to introduce a resolution in Parliament saying that a united Germany should sign a treaty promising it will never seek to recover Polish land lost after the 1945 defeat of the Third Reich. The Senate panel also postponed action on a separate resolution that would have called for the leaders of Poland and Czechoslovakia to be included in talks about German reunification. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., said it would be premature to vote on the measure before a group of senators had a first-hand look at the tumultuous German situation. Lugar and members of an arms control observer group will travel next week to East and West Germany and meet with Kohl. But Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., who with Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., introduced the second resolution, pushed unsuccessfully for a vote. ``It's simply saying let's consult,'' he said. ``In fact, we are sending the wrong signal by objecting,'' said Simon. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., sided with Lugar, saying the Senate shouldn't be dabbling in ``things that we don't know anything about.'' Simon said he assumed Lugar was acting on behalf of the Bush administration in holding up a vote on the measure. An aide to Lugar, speaking on condition he not be identified, said State Department officials told Lugar late Monday they hadn't studied the resolution closely enough to have a final opinion.

DOC.HEAD: Musher Kills Attacking Moose
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to update with racer killing moose, picking up at the 8th graf previous, ``Swenson is.''
DOC.TEXT: One musher in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race and his dogs were safe today after he had to kill an attacking moose with five pistol shots. Defending champion Joe Runyan held the lead today after passing four-time winner Rick Swenson in the 1,160-mile race. Lorren Weaver, holding 44th place among the 68 racers still in the race and 78 miles behind Runyan, killed a moose that attacked his dogs on the trail between Skwentna and Finger Lake, race officials said. Searchers had set out on snowmobiles Monday after two bush pilots reported seeing the moose attack a team of dogs. One dog was gashed across the head, but Weaver, 50, a physician fron Knik, and his team were otherwise unhurt. They continued into Finger Lake, checkpoint No. 7 and 193 miles from the start of the race from Anchorage to Nome that started Saturday. Race spokeswoman Debbie Croutch said the moose was without antlers, but there was no report on whether it was a bull or a cow. Bulls often have dropped their racks this by time of year. Attacks by hungry moose plagued racers during training this year, and some mushers carried rifles for protection. The animals, which weigh up to 1,800 pounds, have become aggressive because deep snow has made it hard to graze. Runyan and five other veteran racers overtook Swenson during the sprint Monday from Rainy Pass to Rohn, 271 miles into the race. The group passing Swenson included his archrival, Susan Butcher. Swenson is the only person to have won the race four times. Butcher won in 1986, 1987 and 1988, and took second place last year. The Iditarod race runs from Anchorage to Nome, on the Bering Sea coast, and crosses frozen rivers, treeless tundra and huge mountain passes. Usually the race lasts 11 to 18 days or longer, depending on weather and other conditions. Seventy mushers and dog teams left Anchorage on Saturday. The Iditarod, named after a ghost town along the trail, commemorates the delivery by sled dog teams of a life-saving diphtheria serum to Nome in 1925.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Central Committee Headquarters to Go to University
DOC.TEXT: The successor to the now-dissolved Polish Communist Party is ready to turn over to Warsaw University the massive building that was party headquarters for four decades. The imposing building in central Warsaw, derisively dubbed the ``White House,'' has been at the heart of a nationwide debate over regaining for the state treasury the vast holdings accumulated by the Communists when they controlled the government. During a weekend meeting, the Social Democracy party, which inherited the assets of the Communist Party when it disbanded in January, agreed to hand over the Central Committee headquarters to a government commission with the recommendation it be given to the university, said Marek Siwiec. ``I don't have to hide our great joy,'' said Wlodzimierz Siwinski, deputy rector of the university, which plans to use the building as a library. The Social Democracy Party's Supreme Council made the decision Saturday and representatives met Sunday with the commission established by the Solidarity-led government to review the legal status of Communist Party property. The turnover of the building must be approved by all sides. ``Many of those who supported erection of the building wrote or called us demanding that it should remain in the hands of the Polish left wing,'' said Siwiec, editor of the Social Democracy newspaper Trybuna. ``But we hope that the needs of culture and science will get dominating respect and the building will go to the university,'' Siwiec said. Since the East bloc's first non-Communist-led government took power last fall, the Communists have been under intense pressure to return property no longer supported by membership or power. On Monday, General Secretary Leszek Miller reported the Social Democracy Party had signed up 47,000 members and said he was satisfied with its growth. The Communist Party claimed a membership of 2 million. The government commission, set up by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki to defuse public clamor to simply nationalize the Communist holdings, has found that many buildings were not actually owned by the party but had been loaned by city officials or other organizations. During negotiations, party leaders have have agreed to turn over 1,600 buildings and offices nationwide. Not without glee, the newly independent press has devoted space in recent weeks to speculation over new uses for the headquarters, with a McDonald's restaurant one favored possibility. But the six-floor building, with 490 rooms and three conference halls, appears well suited for the university library, woefully short of funds, space and special facilities required to preserve rare books, Siwinski said. The Social Democracy party will move its headquarters to one of the buildings it retains following the talks with the government, Siwiec said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Opens Junior College, Seen as Test for Universities
DOC.TEXT: Facing international pressure to reopen Palestinian universities, Israel's army on Tuesday allowed classes to resume at a West Bank teacher's college. The peaceful resumption of classes at the Arub Academy and the planned reopening of other two-year schools were seen as tests for a possible restart of universities that have been shut almost since the start of the 26-month-old Palestinian uprising. But the army said soldiers closed two elementary schools and a middle school Tuesday in the West Bank city of Nablus, raising to 27 the number of primary and secondary schools shut so far this year for disturbances. Arab education officials were told the latest closures were because pupils had stoned West Bank military commander Yitzhak Mordechai's military jeep. The Arub Academy, a men's college that trains students to teach English, Arabic, Islamic studies and geography, was the scene of jubilant reunions Tuesday, with students kissing each other on the cheeks in a traditional Arab greeting. ``It's one of the happiest days we have had,'' said Hamad Sarsur, the headmaster. Hurrying for class with a notebook in hand, Yousef Asafreh said that because of army closures, he has spent more than four years trying to get a teaching certificate in Arabic that normally takes two years. He and other students said the hillside campus, located near the Arub refugee camp on the road to Hebron, would not be used for political protests. ``It is our central demand that we be educated,'' said Asafreh, 25. ``Students understand that they cannot receive education with riots. Riots and education cannot go together.'' Arub had 82 students and 12 teachers before the uprising began in December 1987, but only 55 students showed up for class Tuesday. Sarsur said he did not yet know if any students were in jail for anti-Israeli activism. He predicted unrest would not start on the Arub campus, adding: ``The students are eager to return to their desks.'' Army officials said if there was no trouble at the Arub college, where classes were held peacefully Tuesday, then officials would open the other 15 community colleges. ``It is going to be gradual,'' said one official who demanded anonymity. ``If there is no incitement or security violations, we will see all of them open and functioning in a short time.'' He and other officials declined to make specific pledges but suggested a peaceful reopening of junior colleges would pave the way for universities to resume operation. The army has kept six Palestinian universities with about 21,000 students and 16 junior colleges and vocational schools with about 5,000 students shut for 26 months. Officials say the campuses are potential rallying points for anti-Israeli violence, but Palestinians contend the closures are an unjustified collective punishment. A leaflet issued by the pro-PLO underground leadership of the uprising Tuesday called for rallies near college campuses Saturday to demand the opening of universities and the freeing of jailed students. Israel is being urged by European countries and the United States to allow universities to resume. In January, the European Parliament imposed a freeze on scientific cooperation with Israel until the universities were reopened. There was also a call by the Israeli Parliament's education committee to open one campus to test whether it was safe to resume classes at other institutions. Elsewhere, police spokesman Mordechai Bareket said a 35-year-old Arab woman who had a police record as a prostitute and drug addict was killed in Hebron. Her body was found in the yard of her house with the head smashed and bloodied. Arab reports described her as a collaborator with Israeli authorities, but police said she was not known as a collaborator. The death brought to 192 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs during the uprising, most for alleged collaboration or drug involvement. Some 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis, and 43 Israelis have also died. In Nablus, the army used bulldozers to destroy the home of Mohammed Hawwash, whose son Jaber, 20, was arrested last Nov. 8 and charged with being a member of the Red Eagles, an underground group blamed for killing alleged collaborators. Six people lived in the three-room house. Also Tuesday, the uprising leaders issued an order allowing stores in the occupied territories and Arab east Jerusalem to open for five hours daily, adding two hours to the schedule shops have kept for most of the uprising. A leaflet announced the move, which marked the first easing of the strict discipline that the rebellion's leaders have tried to maintain on Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Will Push Repeal of Income Penalties for Older Americans
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Republicans said Tuesday they will try to force votes this year on a bill allowing some older Americans with higher incomes to work without losing a part of their Social Security pension. ``By penalizing seniors who wish to enhance their income and remain active members of the American work force, current law actually makes it tougher for many seniors to support themselves,'' said Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla. ``Our bill gives senior citizens a choice of whether they want to work or retire,'' said Rep. Dennis Hastert, R-Ill., chief House sponsor of the legislation. The bill has been signed by 181 of the 435 members of the House. ``The Senate ... will act'' on the bill this year, predicted Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas. If the Democratic-controlled Finance Comittee fails to approve the measure, he said, ``we are going to vote on it over and over and over again'' on the Senate floor. Eighteen of the 100 senators have voiced support for the bill. A person who is at least 65 but under 70 may earn $9,360 this year without losing any Social Security benefits. For each $3 earned above that amount, the worker loses $1 of pension. A person 62, 63 or 64 gives up $1 in benefits for each $2 earned above $6,840. There is no earnings limit on those 70 and older. Republicans have tried for a quarter century to repeal the earnings limit, contending it effectively imposes the nation's highest tax burden on older citizens. The Bush administration has not supported repeal. The House approved a significant reduction in the earnings limit last year, as did the Senate Finance Committee. But the measure was dropped in the Senate as part of a deficit-reduction agreement. The House Ways and Means Committee estimates that repealing the earnings limit would benefit only the best-off 10 percent of people between 65 and 70. About one of every five Americans in that age groups earns an income. Hastert cited a study predicting that if the limitation were repealed, 700,000 older people who do not now work would rejoin the labor force, creating $132 billion in economic output. He said repeal would cost the treasury $7.2 billion in federal tax revenues but $3.2 billion of that would be made up in tax collections on the new income.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Thomas Easily Gains Approval as Federal Appeals Judge
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed conservative civil rights official Clarence Thomas as a federal appeals judge, brushing aside criticism from senior citizens and liberal groups. Senate opposition to Thomas, which once appeared powerful, all but dissolved as the vote neared. In the end, the critics did not even request a roll call on the nomination and Thomas was approved on a voice vote. Thomas, 41, becomes a judge of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the nation's capital, sometimes called the nation's second highest court because of the heavily spotlighted cases that come before it. As chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Thomas has been one of the most visible blacks in the Reagan and Bush administrations. He was praised by conservatives for his outspoken criticism of affirmative action programs and quotas as a means of fighting hiring discrimination, but liberals have chafed under his tenure. Born on a poverty ridden farm in rural Georgia, Thomas worked his way through college and graduated from Yale law school. Supporters, led by Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., stressed Thomas' achievement in climbing the ladder the hard way as well as what they called his demonstrated legal ability. Thomas had worked for Danforth both in the Missouri attorney general's office and in the Senate. He also was an attorney with the Monsanto Corp. Despite the criticism from senior citizens and some civil rights leaders, it became clear Monday that opponents had failed to muster anything resembling the forces needed to defeat the nomination. ``I am prepared to concede that Mr. Thomas is going to be confirmed,'' Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, a leading critic, said Monday when the Senate debated the nomination for about 90 minutes. The only other opponent to materialize in the debate was Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging. Both Metzenbaum and Pryor aimed their criticism at Thomas' handling of age discrimination cases at the EEOC. Pryor said the statute of limitations on thousands of such cases lapsed without action while Thomas was in charge, calling it ``too much to overlook.'' Thomas blamed state and local fair-employment commissions for the lapses. ``Mr. Thomas' testimony reveals a fundamental lack of understanding of both the laws he has been charged with enforcing for the past eight years and the regulations and procedures of the agency he has chaired,'' the American Association of Retired Persons said in a letter to top Judiciary Committee lawmakers after that hearing. However, the AARP neither supported nor opposed confirmation. The Alliance for Justice, a liberal court-watcher group based in Washington, campaigned hard to block confirmation.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Lawmakers Legalize Private Ownership, Employment
DOC.TEXT: Beset with a sinking economy and rising discontent, Soviet lawmakers made a drastic break with Communist orthodoxy Tuesday by voting to allow private citizens to own small factories and hire their own workers. Applause swept through the Kremlin chamber as the Supreme Soviet, by a 350-3 vote with 11 abstentions, passed the Property Law, which the official Tass news agency described as ``the main plank'' of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign for economic reform. The law permits Soviets for the first time in nearly seven decades to privately possess ``means of production,'' an approach at odds with classic Marxist thinking, which sees in private ownership the roots of the capitalist exploitation wiped out by the Russian Revolution 72 years ago. Deputy Premier Leonid I. Abalkin said the law, to go into effect July 1, will enable private citizens to own workshops, garages for automotive repairs, farm enterprises and other small-scale ventures to supplement the notoriously ineffective state-run economy. Also, subject to restrictions from legislatures in the 15 Soviet republics, the law permits one citizen to hire another for pay, a practice that currently is illegal and was a key target of the Russian revolutionaries. In the early 1920s, Vladimir I. Lenin and his Bolsheviks temporarily retreated from their drive to implement communism and allowed private ownership of the means of production under the New Economic Policy, or NEP. The policy was ended under Lenin's successor, Josef Stalin. Tuesday's vote was hailed by supporters not as a tactical move backward but as a great advance toward a more just and prosperous society. It again showed Gorbachev's bent for pragmatism, even when it runs counter to policies pursued by his predecessors for decades. Abalkin stressed to reporters that new appoaches were needed to wrench the country from its economic quagmire, which he said was deepening. ``Either we speed up the reforms, or we ship things using military transport,'' he said. He revealed that Soviet economic performance had worsened in the past two months, with industrial production slipping 1 percent. ``There is a crisis of confidence, of confidence in the government,'' he added. Although the Property Law conserves large economic monopolies for the state-run sector, it declares all forms of ownership juridically equal, including property owned by individuals, the government and collectives, and says society gains by competition among them. ``This is an enormous step forward because it lays down the principle of pluralism in the forms of ownership and the basis of their equality and their protection from the government,'' said progressive lawmaker Alexei Yablokov. In another sign of the new economic thinking, a government-sponsored preamble offered by Abalkin proclaiming ``socialist property'' to be the foundation of the country officially named the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics failed to pass the 542-seat legislature. ``The preamble would turn the law into a propaganda slogan,'' objected deputy Konstantin D. Lubenchenko, a senior lecturer in Moscow State University's law faculty. Despite its new stance on property rights, the law continues to skirt the socialist aversion to private property by referring instead to ``the property of citizens.'' ``It's unfortunate that there is no mention of private property, but the principle is there,'' Yablokov said. Soviets long have been permitted to own cars, summer homes and other personal property, and the new law won't change that. Abalkin said a key provision of the 23-page document orders state-owned factories and other businesses to allocate a share of after-tax profits to workers. By providing them with a material stake in their enterprise's profitability, the law will presumably encourage Soviets to work harder, a problem Gorbachev's leadership has said is crucial to raising the often abysmal rate of productivity. Abalkin cautioned that the law was ``just a piece of paper'' and by itself won't bring about an economic miracle. ``We need to change the stereotypes of behavior, and peoples' psychology,'' he said, apparently referring to the widespread Soviet hostility toward any form of private enterprise. Laws on taxation as well as price reforms, long postponed but now promised by Jan. 1, also are necessary for a ``decisive step towards a market economy,'' Abalkin said. The Kremlin keeps the prices of bread, meat and other foodstuffs artificially low at the cost of billions of rubles in subsidies. The Property Law preserves a government monopoly on the main pipelines for natural gas and other products, the electric power grid, space systems, nationwide communications and information networks and defense industries. Neither the law nor a companion bill passed Feb. 28 by the Supreme Soviet allows the unrestricted buying and selling of land, as many progressives had wanted, although the Law on Land allows peasants to bequeath the plots they till to their children. The Supreme Soviet also voted to incorporate traditional Marxist rhetoric into the Property Law outlawing the use of any form of property ``for the exploitation of one man by another,'' over loud objections that such wording was a sneak attack on private property. ``The most basic exploitation of man and man comes from the government,'' said Moscow deputy Mikhail A. Bocharov, director of a pioneering construction materials plant where workers lease the premises from the state. The Supreme Soviet voted separately on each of the bill's six parts, with the private property section passing 354-0 with 13 abstentions, and then on the bill as a whole. The draft, under discussion since fall, came back before the legislature two weeks ago but was returned to committee because of ambiguities. After voting, the legislature adjourned until it parent body, the Congress of People's Deputies, meets Monday. The 2,250-member Congress must give final approval to the Property Law since it will require amending the Constitution, whose Article 10 still declares that ``the foundation of the economic system of the U.S.S.R. is socialist ownership of the means of production.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Again Criticize Bush Budget Proposals
DOC.TEXT: Senior Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday ridiculed President Bush's revenue proposals and said the administration shows little interest in reducing the budget deficit. Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, and Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., goaded Kenneth Gideon, the assistant treasury secretary for tax policy, to offer some alternative tax proposals. Gideon didn't bite. ``I am here to defend our revenue proposals,'' Gideon said. ``It looks to me like they are a mile wide and an inch deep'' and heavy with gimmicks, Bentsen said. He was especially critical of a provision in the Bush budget that, the administration says, would raise $2.5 billion just by improved management of the Internal Revenue Service. ``I find it very hard to accept the idea that ... by rearranging a few desks over there ... you are going to have any serious increase in revenue,'' Bentsen said. ``You ought to come before this committee with respectable proposals,'' Moynihan told Gideon. ``I am embarrassed for your situation and I suspect you are, too.'' Bentsen asked why the administration can propose raising the tax on aviation fuel and defend it as a user fee but oppose a higher tax on gasoline or automobiles. ``We tried to be consistent with our proposals,'' Gideon replied. ``We think a significant increase in gasoline taxes raises real problems'' because of disproportionately high use of fuel in rural states. Moynihan was especially upset because three of the revenue raisers in Bush's budget would further the practice of using Social Security taxes for deficit reduction. ``You don't want to deal with the deficit,'' Moynihan said. ``The deficit is a mode of social discipline.'' The administration, he said, is happy to argue against increased social spending by pointing to the size of the deficit. The administration, while saying it's proposing no tax increase, is asking Congress to vote an additional $15.7 billion in new revenues for the budget year that begins Oct. 1. After subtracting $1.8 billion worth of targeted tax reductions, that would leave a net revenue gain of $13.9 billion. Those proposals range from raising the tax on airline tickets to requiring all state and local government employees to pay for Social Security hospitalization coverage. Bentsen told Gideon that congressional authorities say Bush's proposals would cut the deficit by only $9.4 billion, not $13.9 billion. There is no way to raise $13.9 billion without raising taxes, Bentsen said. Gideon spent a good deal of his time at the hearing defending Bush's proposal to cut taxes on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments. The administration contends a reduction would provide such an incentive to the economy that it would increase tax collections. Congressional leaders reject that point. Their analysts say the capital-gains cut would lose $11.4 billion over five years. However, the Treasury Department says it would gain $12.5 billion _ a difference of $23.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of Fight Against Guerrillas Plotted With Them Instead
With AM-Afghanistan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As Afghanistan's defense minister, Maj. Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai was supposed to lead the fight against Moslem guerrillas. Instead, he may have plotted with them against President Najib. The attempted coup Tuesday illustrated the simultaneous challenges Najib faces in trying to pacify enemies in his own party and end the 12-year-old civil war. Kabul radio said Tanai, who became defense minister about 18 months ago, plotted with fundamentalist guerrilla leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. Such an alliance would one of convenience, not ideology, given Tanai's long advocacy of harsh methods against the guerrillas. By linking Tanai to Hekmatyar, the government may be trying to set the stage for the defense minister's final disgrace. In recent months, Najib increasingly has presented Hekmatyar as the personification of evil while depicting other guerrilla leaders and field commanders as more rational and welcome to join his Soviet-backed government. Hekmatyar has become increasingly estranged from his fellow guerrilla leaders, rejecting their political leadership and killing some of their followers. Najib has promoted Tanai, both in the government and Communist Party, even though the general has a reputation for active opposition. It's become a familiar scenario since the party took control by coup and assassination in April 1978: Give your enemies power in hopes of buying obedience, then try to keep them from overthrowing you. Afghan sources from both sides of the party and civil war say Tanai has been involved in at least the last three of five known coup attempts since Najib became president in December 1986. The two most recent ones occurred in July and December. Tanai is from the party faction called Khalq, or ``masses,'' and Najib represents the Parcham, or ``flag,'' faction. Parcham generally is less hawkish than Khalq, especially when it comes to making political overtures to the guerrillas. Najib loyalists say the president has begun an effort to change the party, even its name, to make it more acceptable to the insurgents, the Afghan people and such foreign critics as the United States. The party's official name is the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. Such overtures generally have been lost on the Islamic fundamentalist guerrillas, who refuse to deal with a ``godless'' party. Tanai, believed to be in his mid-40s, is known as a foe of any concessions to the insurgents or modification of the party's Marxist origins. Najib recently has sought to portray the party as a defender of Islam and champion of a free-market economy. The general comes from the Tanai district near Khost in southern Afghanistan, and takes his surname from his home region. He is a member of the party Politburo, whose membership is said to be 14. Tanai became defense minister sometime in 1988, but as often happens in Afghanistan, his appointment apparently was not announced. When Najib changed his Cabinet in February 1989, after Soviet military forces were withdrawn, Tanai remained in his post. An Afghan source in New Delhi said travelers arriving in the Indian capital Monday reported that Tanai had installed his ministry in the Darulaman palace on Kabul's southwestern outskirts, and that it bristled with big guns and antennas. He said the travelers spoke of widespread rumors in Kabul over the weekend that Tanai was planning a coup. The source, like the others, spoke on condition of anonymity. Najib's official residence and office complex, Arg Palace, is in the heart of Kabul. Both palaces were used by King Zahir Shah, who was overthrown in 1973 by former Prime Minister Mohammad Daoud, his cousin. Daoud was overthrown and killed in the 1978 coup that brought the Communists to power.

DOC.HEAD: Buckey Pleads Innocent in Revived McMartin Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Buckey pleading innocent, defense attorney trying to halt dismissal of one count. Picks up 6th graf, `I don't...'.
DOC.TEXT: Raymond Buckey today pleaded innocent to eight revived charges in the McMartin preschool molestation case during a hearing in which his lawyer made an extraordinary motion to halt dismissal of a sex count. ``I am innocent, your honor, not guilty,'' Buckey told Superior Court Judge Stanley M. Weisberg. The judge formally dismissed four unresolved charges against Buckey and held in abeyance one contested charge. Defense attorney Danny Davis told the judge he wanted to keep in the case the allegation of sexual misconduct involving the son of Judy Johnson, the mother whose complaints triggered the McMartin Pre-School investigation. ``It seems a little strange that the defense would be moving against a dismissal of a count, but I am willing to hear the motion,'' Weisberg said. An afternoon hearing was scheduled on the motion. There were 13 counts unresolved by jurors in the McMartin trial, which lasted nearly three years and cost taxpayers more than $10 million. Jurors were leaning to acquittal on the charges involving the three youngsters in the new trial. ``I don't know why they're doing it,'' Buckey said outside court. ``They've got three of their weakest witnesses. Now I'm facing a mini-McMartin trial.'' The district attorney last month dropped a troublesome conspiracy count against Buckey, 31. Buckey spent nearly five years in jail without being convicted until his release on $1.5 million bail in February 1989. When Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, finally came to trial in 1987, what had originally been hundreds of counts of child molestation was pruned to 64 counts and a shared count of conspiracy, and five other defendants had been dropped from the case. The 41 children once said to have been abused came down to 11 alleged victims.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Editors Protest Censorship of Immigration Data
DOC.TEXT: Editors of four leading daily newspapers on Tuesday criticized military censorship of reports about Soviet immigration, arguing the measure hurt Israel's image and violated press freedom. Their protest came a day after U.S. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler urged Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to reconsider the censorship order he issued Friday. The order, which prohibited publication of how many immigrants arrived in February, was announced last week after officials predicted up to 230,000 Soviets would arrive this year. Israeli officials said the restrictions that barred publication of figures and travel routes taken by Soviet immigrants were needed for security reasons. They cited recent Arab protests about the influx and fears that immigrants might be attacked. The army censor routinely reviews articles pertaining to military affairs before publication, but coverage of immigration has rarely been applied. Editors and legal experts protested in newspaper editorials, saying Israeli leaders, not journalists, were to blame for the Arab anger that followed Shamir's suggestion Israel needed occupied land to settle Soviet immigrants. Moshe Vardi, editor of the mass-circulation Yediot Ahronot daily, accused the government of tarnishing Israel's image at a time when anti-democratic measures were increasingly unpopular. ``In the free world and even beyond, censorship is simply an incomprehensible term in 1990. It is a vestige of the past,'' he wrote. Vardi and other editors sought a meeting with Shamir. They urged the government to seek an understanding with editors rather than impose blanket censorship on the Soviet immigration story. Such an unwritten agreement existed during the 1984 airlift of Ethiopian Jews when self-censorship kept the story secret for months. Other editors and legal experts questioned the government contention that the flow of Soviet immigration was endangered by reports about how many were arriving. ``The Soviet Union has not conditioned giving exit visas to keeping it secret, so publicity to the immigration does not endanger it,'' the liberal daily Haaretz said. The paper said the ban contravened the public's democratic right to know, especially when Israeli leaders have said citizens may have to pay more taxes to handle the influx of immigrants.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Prime Minister Urges Higher Standard of Living
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told Parliament on Tuesday that Japan must improve living standards to help ease trade frictions with the United States. Expensive housing, high savings and poor public facilities have kept Japanese living standards low and limited imports, hindering reduction of the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan, Kaifu said. ``Our corporations are wealthy and strong, but this wealth has come at the expense of long working hours and a low standard of living. It is time to redress this imbalance,'' he said. Responding to opposition questions in Parliament's upper house, Kaifu urged lawmakers to cooperate in changing Japan's economic structure for the sake of the Japanese people as well as to ease growing tension with the United States over trade imbalances. ``We intend realistic efforts to carry out structural reforms. That means we must carry out reforms of our land use policies and improve the standard of living,'' he said. Actions by two Cabinet members Tuesday improved the chances for pledges made by Kaifu at last week's California summit with President Bush. Minister of International Trade and Industry Kabun Muto ended opposition to changing a retail stores law that U.S. officials say tends to prevent foreign firms from increasing sales in Japan. U.S. trade negotiators and domestic business circles say the law hinders foreign retailers from opening outlets and slows the opening of large Japanese stores that would more likely sell foreign-made goods. Ministry officials said they were considering changing or abolishing the law. Muto had told Japanese reporters that bolder steps might have to be taken if easing its enforcement is not enough to satisfy the United States. Washington also says Japan should provide more land for housing, cut inflated real estate prices and spend more on roads, parks and sewers to improve the general quality of life. Such spending is seen as likely to create more demand for foreign products while reducing the dependence of Japan's economy on exports. Meanwhile, Japan's top defense official said Tokyo would consider paying more for the 50,000 U.S. armed forces members in Japan if the United States officially makes such a request. But Yozo Ishikawa, director general of the Defense Agency, said at a news conference that he had heard nothing ``official'' about a statement on the matter by U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney in a television interview Sunday. Cheney said he wants Japan to assume ``100 percent'' of the cost of maintaining U.S. military bases in Japan. Japan pays $2.4 billion of the estimated $6 billion annual cost of basing U.S. forces in Japan, the Defense Agency says. At their summit, Kaifu promised Bush to do his best to carry out substantial reforms and increase Japan's contributions to regional security. But he faces strong opposition from other parties. Kaifu's opponents, led by the Socialists, the No. 1 opposition to his Liberal Democratic Party, dominate the upper house and are likely to obstruct action on trade and defense-related issues. The Socialists and some other opposition parties oppose increasing defense spending and are highly critical of Japan's security relationship with the United States. Parliament also has been bogged down in battles over a bribery scandal and a new sales tax, preventing debate on trade-related reforms in the past year. Kaifu is urging Japan Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi and other opposition leaders to abandon their attacks on the sales tax, given the comfortable majority his party won in Feb. 18 lower house elections, to enable Parliament to act on other pressing issues.

DOC.HEAD: Another Aftershock Rattles Upland; Total Now Over 400
With AM-Spy Plane, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pomona Valley quivered again Tuesday as the number of measurable aftershocks from last week's rumbling earthquake reached an estimated 400 to 500. The aftershock at 10:01 a.m. measured 3.1 on the Richter scale and was centered four miles northwest of Upland, said Bob Finn, spokesman for seismologists at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. ``It was very mild,'' said Michael Guerin, spokesman for the state Office of Emergency Services in Ontario, about five miles from the epicenter. ``We're at the point now where we don't even look up from our computers.'' The Feb. 28 quake, centered three miles northwest of Upland, measured 5.5 on the Richter scale, causing some minor injuries and more than $12 million in damage, Guerin said. Finn said that by midday Tuesday, seismometers had detected 400 to 500 aftershocks, but only about three dozen measured at least magnitude 2.3, large enough to be felt. Many people reported feeling what they thought was another quake early Tuesday, but Finn said it was the sonic boom from an SR-71 Blackbird spy plane looping over northern Los Angeles County. The retired spy jet made a record 68-minute flight from Palmdale to its new home at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Prelate Hopeful of Papal Visit to an Independent Lithuania Soon
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's Roman Catholic cardinal was quoted Tuesday as saying he hopes the Soviet republic will achieve its independence by next year and that Pope John Paul II will be the first visitor to the country. In an interview in Kaunas with the Italian Catholic daily Avvenire, Cardinal Vincentas Sladkevicius suggested the pope could combine the trip with a planned return to his native Poland, which adjoins Lithuania, in June 1991. ``He would be the first and most welcome guest of a free Lithuania,'' the cardinal was quoted as saying. Sladkevicius told the newspaper the church supports the cause of independence for the Baltic republic ``with all its heart'' and urged Western nations to do the same. Lithuania, an independent country before World War II, was occupied by the Soviet Union in 1940. An estimated 2.5 million people, or 80 percent of Lithuania's population, are Roman Catholics. In elections last month, Lithuanians elected a legislature that is expected to push Soviet authorities for independence this year. The Lithuanian Communist Party has also joined the call for independence. John Paul has disclosed that he twice had been barred from visiting Lithuania. At a meeting at the Vatican in September, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev invited the pope to the Soviet Union but John Paul made no commitment. Sladkevicius said if the pope were to go first to Moscow and then to Lithuania ``it would demonstrate that we are part of the Soviet Union. I don't think John Paul will do something like that.'' ``There is another hypothesis,'' the cardinal was quoted as saying. ``If Lithuania becomes independent soon, let's say next year, the pope could come here from Warsaw, combining the visit to Lithuania with that planned for Poland in June 1991.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Company to Build 2 Multiple-Screen Theaters in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Not to be outdone by McDonald's, Time Warner Inc. announced plans Tuesday to open American-style, multiple-screen movie theaters next year in Moscow and Leningrad, where audiences will be allowed to eat popcorn in their seats for the first time. The two ultramodern theaters are expected to open in late 1991 at a cost of $28 million, and will offer the Soviet Union's avid moviegoers a total of 19 new screens and 7,400 new seats to enjoy popular foreign and domestic films, U.S. and Soviet officials said. The theaters will feature state-of-the-art projection and Dolby stereo sound systems, computerized ticket booths, concession stands in marble and neon lobbies, restaurants, souvenir shops and video game arcades _ with parking lots out front.
