American popcorn, a novelty to Soviet audiences, will be sold along with candy and soft drinks. And in a break with Soviet tradition, moviegoers who formerly were required to consume refreshments at buffet counters in theater lobbies will be able to carry them to their seats in the new theaters. ``Hooray for Hollywood and Leningrad and Moscow, too,'' said Time Warner President N.J. Nicholas Jr. at a news conference at the Soviet Embassy where Ambassador Yuri Dubinin toasted ``the healthy future of this Soviet-American child.'' The project is a joint venture between Time Warner, a worldwide publishing and entertainment conglomerate whose Warner Bros. International Theaters Co. subsidiary will own 60 percent of the theaters, and the official Soviet film agency, v@o Sovexportfilm, which will own 40 percent. The announcement came less than two months after McDonald's opened its first fast-food restaurant in the Soviet capital Jan. 31, serving an opening-day record of 30,000 meals to hungry Muscovites. Plans for the two new theaters doubtless will be good news to Soviet moviegoers, who see an average of 14 films a year compared to the four seen by their American counterparts, according to industry estimates. ``They'll have every auditorium completely filled every hour of the day,'' predicted Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America. The largest of Moscow's more than 100 movie theaters, the Russia Theater, contains a 1,200-seat auditorium for feature films and a 500-seat room for documentaries. By contrast, the new Warner multiplex in the Soviet capital will boast 10 screens and 4,000 seats. It will be built on Novokirovsky Prospekt near a major railroad and subway terminal. The Leningrad theater, also near a subway station, will have nine screens and 3,400 seats. Oleg A. Rudnev, the jowly, bushy-browed general director of the Soviet film agency, said the new theaters will be free to show potentially controversial American movies such as ``The Hunt for Red October,'' the newly released, pre-glasnost tale of a Soviet submarine commander who defects to the United States. ``There is no censorship anymore,'' Rudnev said through an interpreter. ``It is probably not possible to surprise the Soviet viewer any longer.'' Time Warner officials said ticket prices won't be decided until American films are test-marketed in Moscow and Leningrad to determine what Soviet viewers are willing to pay. Embassy officials said movie tickets in Moscow average about 50 kopeks, or eight cents, under the unofficial exchange rate for foreign visitors. Prices are cheaper for matinees and more costly _ about 25 cents _ for lengthy, popular feature films in more luxurious theaters.

DOC.HEAD: All Sides Talk about Peace, But Not To Each Other
DOC.TEXT: All sides in Northern Ireland, from the IRA to Ian Paisley, are talking about peace, but not to each other as yet. With Catholics and Protestants both unhappy with the status quo, feelers sprout from many directions: from Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey, the Protestant leaders of the Unionist parties, the main Roman Catholic parties, and the British government. The contacts continued Tuesday as Peter Brooke, the top British official in the province, met with three Unionists. ``We didn't expect there would be any startling development,'' said Ken Maginnis, a member of Parliament from the Ulster Unionist Party. Maginnis, whose goal is the creation of a provincial government to end 18 years of direct rule from London, said no one should expect a sudden breakthrough. ``I want to see a devolved government ... but I want to see something that people will feel confident with, not something that becomes just another millstone around our necks,'' Maginnis said. The ``millstone,'' as Unionists see it, is the Anglo-Irish Agreement signed by Britain and Ireland in the Northern Ireland village of Hillsborough in 1985. The treaty guaranteed Ireland an advisory role in Northern Ireland affairs and pledged the two governments to cooperate against terroEW YORK (AP) _ Foreign Exchange, New York prices. DOC.BYLINE: Mandela Arrives to Tumultuous Greeting in Tanzania ^By CHEGE MBITIRU
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela on Tuesday brought his crusade for black majority rule in South Africa to Tanzania, the home of thousands of exiled black compatriots. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, was met by former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere, the first African leader to offer the ANC guerrilla training camps outside of South Africa. ``How are you, teacher?'' Mandela asked Nyerere in Swahili as he stepped off a special Air Zimbabwe flight from Harare. Mandela and Nyerere last met in early 1962, when Mandela came to Tanzania to ask the former president to establish training camps in this East African country. Thousands turned out at Dar es Salaam's international airport and waited through an hour-long rainstorm to greet the 71-year-old Mandela, who was freed from a South African prison four weeks ago. As Mandela emerged from his plane, the crowd raised a roar of ``Viva ANC!'' After inspecting an honor guard, Mandela was escorted to a group of exiled ANC members. ``I am so glad I have seen him at last,'' said a bearded South African who refused to give his name but said he had fled his country in 1964. Mandela was to address a rally in Dar es Salaam and fly to Zanzibar, an island republic of Tanzania, on Wednesday, and visit the ANC camps about 100 miles west of Dar es Salaam on Thursday. He planned to address many of the 3,000 ANC exiles who live in Tanzania. Most are due to return home by the end of this year. Before ending his three-day stay in Zimbabwe, Mandela said he had learned a lesson. ``Zimbabwe's reconciliation is an experience from which we want to profit,'' Mandela said, referring to President Robert Mugabe's policy of reconciliation between whites and blacks. Until independence from Britain 10 years ago, Zimbabwe was the white-ruled colony of Rhodesia. But after a seven-year guerrilla war the black majority assumed power under Mugabe. Mandela views Zimbabwe as a role model for his own country, where 5 million whites wield economic and political power over 28 million voteless blacks. The ANC leader said he wanted to discuss ways of steering the country towards black majority rule with all political movements in South Africa, including the rival Pan-Africanist Congress. On whites' demands for guarantees for their future, Mandela said the ANC was still examining the question but hoped to allay the minority's fears. Mandela was freed from 27 years imprisonment on Feb. 11 by President F.W. de Klerk after the ANC, the PAC and the South African Communist Party were legitimized for the first time in 30 years. The release heralded the beginning of negotiations between the white-run government and anti-apartheid movements towards a new political framework. Mandela is expected to hold his first talks with de Klerk this month after returning from Sweden.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Successfully Tests Advanced Rocket Engine
DOC.TEXT: Japan successfully tested one of the world's most advanced rocket engines Tuesday and officials said the engine will have the capability to launch large, sophisticated satellites. The LE-7 engine ``burned normally'' during a four-second firing test, the National Space Development Agency said. The sophisticated engine is to power the first stage of a new Japanese rocket, the H-2, on which Japan has pinned many of its hopes for future space exploration. The current mainstay of the Japanese space program, the H-1 rocket, can lift only 1,210 pounds into geostationary orbit, making it incapable of launching large, sophisticated communications satellites. Development of the Japanese-designed H-2 also will also free Japan from U.S. veto power over commercial launches of third-country satellites, imposed as a licensing condition for U.S. technology used in previous Japanese rockets. The H-2 is slated to go into service in March 1992 and will match the two-ton geostationary payload capabilities of current U.S., Soviet and European rockets. The LE-7 engine, powered by liquid hydrogen and oxygen, uses a high-technology propulsion system similar to that on the U.S. space shuttle. Tuesday's success followed a string of development problems that technicians attributed to the extremely high stresses inside the high-performance engine. The first stage of the current H-1 rocket is based on 25-year-old U.S. Delta rocket technology licensed from McDonnell Douglas, but the second stage is designed in Japan and also will be used as the second stage of the H-2. McDonnell Douglas officials recently asked Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to supply it with the new second stage to update the Delta rocket, Japanese officials say. On Feb. 22, a European Ariane 44-L rocket carrying two Japanese communications satellites exploded shortly after liftoff, destroying both satellites, reportedly worth $600 million. Analysts say the accident is likely to further encourage Japan to develop its own space capabilities. Despite a late start, due in part to a post-World War II ban by U.S. occupation authorities and low budgets, Japan's space program has progressed steadily and achieved an enviable success record. A Japanese satellite, Muses-A, is due to reach the moon on March 18, making Japan the third nation after the Soviet Union and the United States to reach Earth's closest neighbor.

DOC.HEAD: SEC, Soviet Bloc Officials Discuss Emerging East European Stock Markets
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street's watchdog, the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Tuesday that it wants to help advise the emerging free economies of Eastern Europe on how to keep their infant stock markets orderly and honest. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, who met recently with high-level financial officials from the Soviet Union, Hungary and Poland, said the agency would form an Advisory Committee on Emerging Securities Markets in Eastern Europe. ``The SEC's expertise in this area hopefully can assist in a successful transition to efficient private capital markets with necessary oversight and supervision,'' Breeden said. The committee will recommend what action the SEC and the financial industry can take to help create organized securities markets in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Breeden said there ``is no more fitting manner'' for the United States ``to aid the process of economic development in Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union than by assisting in the creation of free capital markets in these countries.'' Breeden and other SEC officials met Feb. 21 with a high-level delegation from the Soviet government that was reviewing the operation of U.S. banking and securities markets. Breeden has held similar meetings with delegations from Poland and Hungary, including one with President Bush and the leader of an effort to expand the small Hungarian securities exchange. The SEC anticipates eventually receiving additional requests for assistance from several other governments in creating securities markets. No one has been named to the panel, but SEC officials hope to include leaders of U.S. securities companies, other financial firms and senior representatives of self-regulatory organizations such as securities exchanges. Breeden said he hoped the advisory committee's first meeting could be held in April.

DOC.HEAD: Will the Pentagon Disappear Under Its Mountain of Supplies?
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon increased its stockpile of unrequired spare parts and supplies by $4 billion over three years, creating a system that ``is like opening the door to Imelda Marcos' closet,'' a lawmaker said Tuesday. The General Accounting Office released three reports describing widespread problems in the Defense Department's management of its $103 billion supply system, including excessive purchases of unnecessary items and storage space devoted to obsolete items. Officials from the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee that in 1987 the department had a $30 billion inventory of unrequired items. Three years later, the stockpile costs $34 billion. The GAO said it based its report on Pentagon estimates. ``Although we found no dominant reason that caused inventory growth, we believe the growth results from a tendency to stock far into the future,'' said Frank C. Conahan, assistant comptroller general. ``This is fostered by a management philosophy that rewards obligating funds and filling orders. ``There is no corresponding emphasis on economy or efficiency,'' he said. Deputy Defense Secretary Donald J. Atwood told the Senate panel the Pentagon has moved to implement reforms proposed in last year's Defense Management Review. If the Eastern bloc nations could turn toward democracy in a single year, said Atwood, ``I don't see why we can't reform the Defense Department.'' According to the GAO, the Navy had 53 reactor assemblies for a sonar system. But 51 of them, totaling $160,000, were not needed. The agency said neither the Navy's item manager nor the branch chief had records or knew why the items were unrequired. By definition, required items are supplies for future wars and two years or more of peacetime operations. Unrequired are those beyond the necessary stockpile. The GAO also found an inventory manager increased the requirement for shirts from a six-month supply to a five-year supply. The Defense Logistics Agency later found itself with 379,000 shirts and 1,078,000 on order when the requirement only called for 424,000. The excess totaled a seven-year supply for $8.7 million. The reports prompted outrage from members of the Senate panel. ``Looking into the Pentagon supply system is like opening the door to Imelda Marcos' closet. You see excess _ staggering excess,'' said Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., referring to the former first lady of the Philippines known for her buying sprees. ``The Defense Department's tens of billions of dollars in unrequired inventories, unwisely purchased during the Reagan years, continue to grow,'' said Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate panel. ``It's warehouses are gorged with the overflow and are filled beyond capacity.'' The GAO also warned the problem may be worse than their estimates because it found a number of cases where the Pentagon added or planned to add unnecessary requirements for supplies.

DOC.HEAD: State of Emergency Declared in Homeland to Stop Rioting
DOC.TEXT: The new military rulers of the Ciskei homeland declared a state of emergency Tuesday in a bid to end looting and rioting following their coup that has left 27 people dead and 550 injured. There were reports of more looting despite the presence of South African troops, who were sent in to quell the violence at the request of the new rulers in Ciskei. Dissident army officers led by Brig. Gen. Oupa Gqozo staged a bloodless coup Sunday that ousted Ciskei's President Lennox Sebe while he was in Hong Kong on a trade mission. Ciskei, a 3,600-square-mile territory of about 1 million people on the Indian Ocean coast, is one of 10 black homelands in South Africa. They are recognized only by the Pretoria government. South Africa established the homelands in the 1960s to try to create separate, tribal-based states for blacks while whites retain control of national politics and the economy. Looting and rioting erupted Sunday evening, and more than 50 stores and factories, many owned by Israelis and Taiwanese, have been destroyed. Doctors at hospitals in Ciskei and nearby East London in South Africa said 27 people had been killed and more than 550 injured in violence following the coup. Most of the dead and injured suffered gunshot and stabbing wounds, the doctors said. The military rulers announced the state of emergency Tuesday evening. Gqozo told the state-run South African Broadcasting Corp. that his government had begun to release political prisoners held by Sebe, and he said the new government would investigate charges of corruption against the ousted president. Human rights groups say Sebe's government detained hundreds of dissidents. South African Foreign Minister Pik Botha, speaking to Parliament in Cape Town, said additional South African troops had been moved into the area as a reserve force. South Africa's pro-apartheid Conservative Party criticized the South African government for not intervening sooner in Ciskei to prevent the chaos. ``These little stone-throwing, looting arsonist (criminals) are probably a precursor to the new South Africa,'' said Tom Langley, a member of Parliament for the Conservatives. Botha said he was informed Friday of a possible coup attempt in Ciskei and passed the information on to Sebe, who ignored it and left for Hong Kong the same day. The deposed president apparently did not inform his wife, who remained at the official residence in Ciskei. She was taken from the residence Tuesday in a car bearing South African diplomatic license plates. Sebe, meanwhile, was expected to return Wednesday to South Africa. His plans were unclear, but it appeared doubtful he would try to return to Ciskei. South Africa has neither formally recognized the new military rulers nor given any indication that it opposes them. The South Africans recognize the military government in the neighboring Transkei homeland that came to power in a 1987 coup. The coup appears to have wide support in Ciskei. Many residents opposed Sebe and considered his rule oppressive and corrupt. But the jubilation over the coup quickly turned violent as drunken mobs rampaged in several towns. ``It was a drunken orgy of violence. ... Dozens of buildings were gutted,'' said journalist Louise Flanagan. Gqozo received a rousing cheer Monday when he told thousands of people at a stadium in Bisho that the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups would be free to engage in political activity in Ciskei. The ANC is the main black group fighting South Africa's white-run government. South African President F.W. de Klerk legalized the ANC last month, but some homeland leaders do not allow the group to operate in the territories they control. Gqozo said he would like to see Ciskei relinquish its nominal independence and return to South Africa. The Transkei homeland is considering a similar plan. The South African government has not taken a position on homelands that want to return to South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Alleges Detentions, Torture
Embargoed For Release 7:01 p.m. EST _ Time Set by Source
DOC.TEXT: The government of Chad continues to detain, torture and summarily execute political prisoners despite the adoption of a new Constitution guaranteeing human rights, Amnesty International said Wednesday. President Hissene Habre has direct knowledge of some of the abuses, and many of the several hundred political detainees had been held within 50 yards of the presidential office, the human rights organization said. Chad has been ``a catalogue of horror'' since Habre gained power in 1982, said Amnesty International representative Jamal Benomar, speaking at a news conference Tuesday. He said Habre's government had refused to respond to Amnesty International's allegations and refused to disclose any information about the fate of political prisoners. ``The authorities have never admitted that these detainees exist,'' Benomar said. According to the Amnesty International report, some prisoners were arbitrarily detained because they belonged to a particular ethnic group suspected of anti-government activities. Others were detained solely because of relatives' activities, the report said. In December, the government adopted a new constitution that guarantees basic individual rights, as well as freedom of speech and assembly. But Amnesty International said there had been no perceptible change in the government's treatment of political prisoners. Benomar said torture of political prisoners in Chad has become routine, with increasing use of electric shocks. Women prisoners have been forced by soldiers to serve as slaves and prostitutes, the report said. ``Prisoners are held incommunicado and denied medical attention,'' the report said. ``No one sees the detainees except the security personnel guarding and interrogating them.'' Habre became president in 1982 after driving a Libyan-backed rival out of the capital, N'Djamena, during a civil war. In December, his government claimed voters in a referendum gave overwhelming approval to the new constitution and to a new, seven-year term for Habre. He said the election introduced Chad to ``an era of democracy,'' but has allowed no opposition political activity. Benomar said some opponents of the government have crossed the border into Sudan and are taking up arms against Habre.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Commission Renews Call For Release of Hostages
With AM-US-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Human Rights Commission on Tuesday demanded the immediate release of all hostages worldwide and issued a special appeal to respect the work of the International Committee of the Red Cross. In Beirut, the Red Cross appealed to captors holding two of its workers to release them or let them write to their families. The resolution adopted by the 43-nation commission censured the actions of all hostage-takers, ``whatever their motives'' and expressed alarm at the number of kidnappings worldwide. ``As long as there is one hostage left in the world, the international community must state and restate its disapproval,'' a French delegate said, introducing the U.N. resolution. The text was similar to measures approved by the commission in previous years but added the special appeal to respect International Red Cross workers. Elio Erriquez, 23, and Emmanuel Christen, 32, orthopedic technicians at a Red Cross artificial limb center in south Lebanon's port city of Sidon, were abducted five months ago. No group has claimed responsibility and international appeals have drawn no response. ``We will spare no effort to ... find a solution to this problem,'' said Angelo Gnaedinger, a Red Cross official, in his message to the captors. He said that over the past five months the Red Cross has contacted political and military leaders in Lebanon who pledged support in trying to win their release. Christian and Erriquez are among 18 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon. The others are eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian. Held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The U.N. resolution was sponsored by France, Belgium, Britain, Colombia, France, Ireland, Italy, Japan, the Soviet Union and West Germany. Switzerland and Togo joined as non-voting observers.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Ducks Question on Baseball Dispute
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS ``coach'' to ``captain'' in 5th graf: ``The president,''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, an avid baseball fan and father of a major-league team owner, checked his swing Tuesday when pitched a question on baseball's labor dispute. ``I was tempted,'' he allowed. Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said later that the administration would not get involved the three-week owners' lockout that's threatening the 1990 season. ``He's concerned about the fans and the game of baseball. He would like to see the issue resolved. But he has no intentions to intervene,'' Fitzwater said. The president, who was first baseman and captain of his 1948 Yale University baseball team and whose son, George W. Bush, is part owner of the Texas Rangers, fielded the baseball question during a picture-taking session with Italian Prime Minister Giulo Andreotti in the Oval Office. ``Do you think anything should be done about the baseball strike?'' a reporter asked. Bush laughed and told Andreotti: ``There's a strike on, and our son owns one of the teams or is the managing owner or managing partner of one of the baseball teams. ``She's asking me about the strike knowing that I won't take questions at a photo opportunity. However, she got close to something I might answer. She got very close there. I was tempted,'' Bush said. Although the president and reporter both called it a ``strike,'' Bush's son and the rest of the baseball owners actually have locked the players out of spring training in the dispute over major league baseball's basic bargaining agreement. The dispute has already forced cancellation of half of the scheduled pre-season exhibition games and was threatening the April 2 opening day. Fitzwater was asked if Bush had spoken to his son about the walkout. ``I don't know whether he's talked to George privately about it or not. He doesn't have any plans to weigh in publicly,'' Fitzwater said. Asked about whether the president would deal with ``economic dislocations'' to spring-training states such as Florida and Arizona, Fitzwater laughed and said: ``Well, there's a bargaining process set up to resolve this issue and that's the appropriate forum.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration, Congressmen Back Selma Trail
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration and fellow congressmen on Tuesday lauded a plan by Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., to designate the route of the 1965 Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march as a national historic trail. Three weeks before the March 1965 protest, Lewis led a group of 525 demonstrators onto the Edmund Pettys Bridge in Selma, Ala., for a planned march to Montgomery. The group was attacked by state troopers; Lewis was severely beaten. Television accounts of the attack brought thousands of people to Selma for the subsequent march, which resulted in congressional passage of the Voting Rights Act. Testifying for the bill, Herbert Cables, deputy director of the National Park Service, told the House interior subcommittee on national parks and public lands, ``The fact that citizens shed their blood to demonstrate their right to vote should never be orgotten.'' Cables told Lewis the nation owes him ``a debt of gratitude ... for what you did 25 years ago.'' The park service official said the adminstration supports Lewis' bill to authorize a one-year study to determine if the march route qualifies for designation as a national historic trail. Edwin Bearss, chief historian of the park service, said the agency normally will not consider a historic designation until 50 years after an event. But the Selma to Montgomery march, he said, is ``transcendental.'' Lewis said designation of the march route as a national historic trail would ``serve as a reminder of the right and responsibility to vote'' and will recognize the sacrifices of those who fought to ensure that right for all Americans. ``Congress may have passed the Voting Rights Act,'' he said, ``but the law was written by the marchers on the road from Selma to Montgomery.''

DOC.HEAD: Testimony: South African Military Approved ANC Disruption Plans
DOC.TEXT: The military approved plans in 1985 for undercover agents to go abroad to disrupt operations of the exiled African National Congress guerrilla movement, an army general testified Tuesday. Maj. Gen. Joep Joubert said the proposal was approved by Magnus Malan, who has been defense minister since 1980. However, Joubert did not specify any actions that have been carried out in the past five years. Several prominent ANC officials outside South Africa have been assassinated or have had attempts on their lives in recent years. The ANC, the main group fighting the white-run government, was legalized last month by President F.W. de Klerk. It has offices in more than 30 countries, but most of its estimated 15,000 exiled members are expected to begin returning to South Africa shortly. Joubert testified on the second day of a judicial inquiry into allegations that the military and police participated in death squads. Much of the testimony has focused on a shadowy military unit known as the Civil Cooperation Bureau, which South African Police say they suspect of involvement in the killing of government opponents. The bureau, which employed former police officers and other civilians, was set up to carry out operations that could not be traced to the military or the government, according to other generals who testified Tuesday. Malan said Monday he didn't know until November 1989 that the bureau existed. Activists, meanwhile, have alleged that the police and military have been involved in the unsolved killings of some 60 activists in the past decade. Maj. Gen. Jan Klopper testified that the Civil Cooperation Bureau grew out of other covert units and was formally established in 1986. The military has said the secret bureau had 139 members, an annual budget of $ 11 million and was engaged in highly sensitive intelligence gathering operations in South Africa and abroad. Yet top military and government officials have claimed they had no knowledge of the bureau until recently. De Klerk and Deputy Defense Minister Wynand Breytenbach have said they learned of the unit's existence in January. Meanwhile, Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu responded with humor Tuesday following revelations that the bureau had planned to send him a baboon fetus. ``We used to think (soldiers in the bush) were looking for so-called terrorists,'' said Tutu. But, he added, ``all they were looking for was pregnant baboons.'' Gen. Rudolph Badenhorst, head of Military Intelligence, testified Monday about the baboon plot, but said he didn't know the reason for the plan, which was never carried out. Badenhorst acknowledged that the Civil Cooperation Bureau blew up a Pretoria store owned by an anti-apartheid activist and bombed a community hall in a mixed-race township near Cape Town. No military officers have been charged in connections with the activities of the bureau, but two men have been detained for questioning and police are searching for several others.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Chief Going to North Korea for First Foreign Trip
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin will travel to North Korea in mid-March in his first trip outside China since assuming his office in June, it was reported Tuesday. Jiang will make the goodwill visit at the invitation of North Korean President Kim Il Sung, according to the official Xinhua News Agency. Jiang's visit accentuates the close ties between the two hard-line Communist states, particularly at a time when North Korean relations with its other main ally, the Soviet Union, have been strained by Soviet reforms and ideological changes. North Korea also needs to bolster its ties with China as East European nations and the Soviet Union move toward official relations with South Korea. China does 3 billion U.S. dollars worth of annual trade with the South and sanctions non-official ties, but insists it will not normalize relations with the Seoul government and continues to support the North on all Korean issues. Jiang's trip follows an unannounced three-day visit to Beijing by Kim in November. The 77-year-old Korean leader reportedly sought to reaffirm the two countries' longstanding socialist ties amid upheaval in Eastern Europe and head off any tendency toward increased China-South Korean contacts. Jiang's predecessor, Zhao Ziyang, also visited Pyongyang last April, when student-led pro-democracy demonstrations were filling the streets of Beijing and conservatives such as Premier Li Peng were consolidating a hard-line position toward the students. On June 24, three weeks after the military crushed the democracy campaign, the party accused Zhao of supporting the demonstrators and ousted him from all his posts. It named Jiang, then party chief of Shanghai, to head the 48 million-member party.

DOC.HEAD: Brown Named Lubbock Correspondent
DOC.TEXT: Arthur ``Chip'' Brown III, a newsman in the Dallas bureau of The Associated Press, has been named the correspondent in Lubbock. The appointment was announced Tuesday by Dallas Chief of Bureau John Lumpkin. Brown, 22, joined the AP as a part-time news clerk in 1988. Following graduation from Southern Methodist University, he began working full-time and later became a newsman on the Dallas staff. Brown is a native of Kalamazoo, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Geagea: Christian Truce Will Hold
LaserPhoto BEI4
DOC.TEXT: Christian warlord Samir Geagea said Tuesday he believes the latest truce in his confrontation with renegade Gen. Michel Aoun will endure. ``Nothing can be solved by war. I think this cease-fire will hold,'' said Geagea, who was interviewed at a forward militia command post in Jounieh, north of Beirut. The truce began Friday and ended more than a month of fighting between Lebanon's two top Christian leaders that left 750 dead and 2,088 wounded. Geagea said the Vatican and France were instrumental in convincing Aoun to accept the truce. He said French and Vatican officials said they would not hinder a Syrian military intervention if Aoun did not end the intra-Christian fighting. ``They told Gen. Aoun if you want to continue the war in east Beirut, we shall consider ourselves unconcerned (with what's happening) and we believe big events could happen as a result,'' Geagea said. The cease-fire was called by Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir. Sfeir had threatened to excommunicate Aoun, Geagea and their followers if they did not stop the shooting. Aoun and Geagea are Maronites, the Christian sect that has dominated Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Aoun initiated the intra-Christian confrontation by demanding the disbanding of Geagea's Lebanese Forces, the main military challenge to his claim as sole authority in the Christian enclave. But Tuesday, Geagea again said merging his Lebanese Forces with Aoun's army ``is out of the question.'' ``Only when the civil war ends and a strong state based on certain foundations emerges will that happen. We shall then be the first to disband our militia,'' he added. Geagea said his forces have had contacts with U.S. officials and that Iraq helped mediate between his militia and Aoun's army through its embassy in East Beirut. Iraq, Syria's main Arab foe, was Aoun's primary backer during the general's failed six-month war of liberation to evict the Syrians last year. It was also a major arms supplier for the militia. Geagea refused to clearly state whether he recognized the Syrian-allied government of President Elias Hrawi. Hrawi was elected in November in line with an Arab-brokered peace accord to end Lebanon's 15-year-old war civil war. Aoun has rejected the peace pact and the government of Hrawi, which dismissed Aoun as army commander. Aoun has criticized the peace plan for not laying out a timetable for a complete withdrawal of Syrian forces. Syria has 40,000 troops in about 70 percent of Lebanon. Geagea refused to take a clear position on the Lebanese peace pact. ``There are good things in it and bad things,'' he said without elaboration. Hrawi is on a tour of Arab states for talks on ending the bloody intra-Christian dispute and to push through the Lebanese peace pact. He left Saudi Arabia for Algeria Monday, ending two days of talks with King Fahd, who promised military aid, sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Treasury Official to Top Thrift Regulatory Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday named Assistant Treasury Secretary Salvatore R. Martoche as acting director of the the Office of Thrift Supervision, the agency that regulates the nation's savings and loan institutions. Martoche immediately promised to ``provide stability and leadership'' to the government's oversight of the troubled S&L industry. The interim appointment fills the vacancy created by the resignation last December of M. Danny Wall, who quit under criticism from members of Congress for his handling of the S&L crisis in his 2{-year tenure. Martoche, a former U.S. attorney from Buffalo, was named by Bush to serve ``until a new director is in place.'' Administration officials said the search for a permanent successor to Wall is continuing. Sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Treasury Department planned to forward its recommendation within several days. Congressional Democrats have been pointing to the Bush administration's failure to recruit a permanent successor to Wall as evidence that the S&L bailout was falling into disarray. Because the Martoche appointment is an interim one, it does not require Senate confirmation. When speculation surfaced that Jonathan Fiechter, senior deputy in charge of policy at the agency, might be named as interim director, S&L industry officials raised questions over the legality of any actions taken by an acting director who was not confirmed by the Senate. Martoche's appointment was expected to alleviate that problem because he has already been through the confirmation process in his current Treasury post. Martoche said in a statement he would ``seek to provide stability and leadership to the agency during the transition.'' He also said he would appoint Fiechter as his principal deputy director. Martoche takes over the reins of the agency overseeing the restructuring of the troubled S&L industry, and will preside over a growing list of lawsuits against savings industry executives accused of illegal lending practices. Wall, criticized in Congress for underestimating the S&L crisis and acting slowly against the California-based Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, announced Dec. 4 he would resign as soon as the administration found a replacement. However, as the months passed, Wall indicated he was anxious to leave soon. Martoche is currently assistant secretary of the Treasury for enforcement, overseeing the Secret Service, the Customs Service and the agency's drug-intervention programs. The Office of Thrift Supervision, formerly known as the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, was extensively overhauled last year as part of the 10-year, $150 billion S&L rescue legislation. The measure placed the agency under the control of the Treasury Department and removed many of its previous powers. Under the legislation, a new agency, the Resolution Trust Corp., is charged with selling or closing hundreds of insolving S&L associations. At the time of his resignation, Wall denounced a ``steady stream of one-sided information'' from congressional hearings on the collapse of Lincoln. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, wrapped up his investigation of Lincoln Tuesday. Gonzalez, in a statement, said he was encouraged Bush had named an acting director but criticized him for waiting so long and for leaving other regulatory positions vacant. ``Leaving a resigned and discredited ... director in office in a lame-duck status for three months has been extremely poor public policy that has struck at the heart of the agency's morale,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Soviets May Violate Treaty With Missiles in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The United States wants early talks with the Soviet Union on reports that Soviet medium-range missiles remain in East Germany in apparent violation of the 1987 treaty banning such weapons, the State Department said Monday. Margaret Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said the United States wants to learn if the weapons sighted in East Germany last week were prohibited SS-23 missiles and missile launchers. ``At this point we do not want to speculate on what we may or may not find,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``We expect to discuss this subject with the Soviets at a very early date,'' she said, adding the time and place have yet to be set. The Washington Times in its Tuesday editions quoted unnamed Bush administration officials as saying U.S. Army officers traveling through East Germany photographed six SS-23 launchers and a dozen missiles. The newspaper quoted administration missiles as saying existence of SS-23 missiles in East Germany would violate the Intermediate Nuclear Forces, or INF, treaty. They said presence of the missiles in East Germany would complicate negotiations to reduce U.S. and Soviet strategic intercontinental missiles because new doubts would be raised about verifying Soviet compliance. Under the terms of the treaty the Soviet Union was to dismantle all of its declared 239 SS-23 launchers and 108 SS-23 missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Protest Army Killing of Schoolgirl
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Thousands of students marched through the northern port city of Gonaives on Tuesday to protest the army's killing of an 11-year-old girl during unrest in another town, radio stations said. Most schools were closed in Gonaives, 100 miles north of Port-au-Prince, according to independent Radio Haiti Inter. According to a resident who spoke on condition of anonymity, more than 5,000 students marched to demand the ouster of Haitian ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, chanting ``Avril murderer!'' and ``We're fed up with Avril!'' Roseline Vaval was fatally wounded by a stray bullet Monday as she sat on her front porch in Petit Goave, about 30 miles southwest of Port-au-Prince. The bullet was fired by soldiers dispersing a protest, Haiti Inter said. Seven prominent critics of Avril were arrested and forced into exile in January during a government crackdown on political opposition. Fifty activists were arrested and allegedly beaten. Opposition to Avril has been building since the crackdown. On Monday, 18 political parties and civic groups joined to demand his resignation and the establishment of a provisional civilian government headed by a Supreme Court justice. The leftist Confederation of Democratic Unity and five other small radical groups threatened a ``popular uprising'' unless Avril resigned. Radio Metropole, another independent station, said the Petit Goave demonstration was to protest the arrest of a youth, but gave no further details. The town's schools and shops closed during Monday's protest, in which three people were wounded. Avril, who came to power in a September 1988 soldiers' revolt that ousted Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, has pledged to turn over power to a civilian government in elections this year. Virtually all parties and unions have vowed to boycott any elections held under Avril. Namphy had assumed power after a popular uprising forced former dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier to flee to exile in France in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: TMI Officials Begin Plant Shutdown After Leak Detected
DOC.TEXT: Workers at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant began shutting down the Unit 1 reactor Tuesday after plant monitors detected higher-than-normal amounts of radioactivity being vented into the atmosphere. State, federal and plant officials said there was no danger to the public. The releases were not detected by radiation monitors located off the island, which is about 10 miles south of Harrisburg. Also Tuesday, the Unit 3 reactor at the Peach Bottom nuclear power plant in York County, near the Maryland border, was shut down because of a mechanical problem with the system's generator, officials said. Unit 2 had been shut down last week for maintenance. GPU Nuclear Corp., which operates TMI, said officials believe the problem stemmed from a small water leak between the nuclear and non-nuclear sides of the plant. Under federal license requirements, TMI must shut down if there is a confirmed leak of more than 6 gallons per hour. Although the leak appeared to be at a rate of 1 gallon per minute, GPU officials said they decided to immediately shut down the plant instead of going through a process to confirm the actual rate. The plant could have continued to operate until the leak was confirmed to be 6 gallons per hour, they said. ``The shutdown is a precautionary measure and no emergency condition exists,'' said Mary Wells, a GPU spokeswoman. The higher-than-normal levels of radiation were detected by a monitor in the plant's steam system. Radiation left the plant through a vent on that system. Doug Bedell, a GPU spokesman, said only a fraction of one millirem of radiation was released over a three-hour period. He said a chest X-ray would equal about 10 millirems of radiation. A millirem is a unit of measurement. Karl Abraham, a spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said the leak at TMI, at a rate of about 1 gallon per minute, was detected shortly before 8:30 a.m. Workers began shutting the reactor down shortly after 9 a.m., plant officials said. Susan Woods, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Resources, said the agency had not detected any above-normal radiation levels off-site. ``The plant is going into normal shutdown; they are doing it manually,'' she said. ``If there was a serious problem, it would have automatically shut down.'' The plant had been operating at 75 percent capacity. It was recently out of service for two months for maintenance and to replenish its nuclear fuel. ``We don't know when it will be up again,'' Bedell said. ``We need to determine the nature and source of these leaks before we would consider starting up the plant.'' TMI 1's sister plant, Unit 2, was the site of the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident, in 1979. A combination of human and mechanical errors led to the draining of protective cooling water from the plant's radioactive gases were released into the atmosphere. Unit 1 was undamaged in the accident. A spokesman for Philadelphia Electric Co., which owns Peach Bottom, did not immediately return a phone call for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Wheat Prospects Still Good
DOC.TEXT: Rain and above-normal temperatures continued to boost winter wheat prospects in the central and southern Great Plains, but dry conditions remained in northern areas, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday. ``In Kansas, crop condition was good except in the central and north-central area, where soil moisture was still short,'' the facility said in its report for Feb. 26-March 4. ``Insect and disease problems were very light.'' The facility is operated by the departments of Agriculture and Commerce. Weekly reports cover wheat and crop conditions but don't include production forecasts. Relatively warm weather and ample moisture supplies hastened wheat growth in Oklahoma, while the crop's condition was reported good in Arkansas and fair-to-good in Missouri. Rain also helped the Texas crop. But the report added: ``The northern Great Plains remained dry. In Nebraska, winter wheat was fair-to-poor. Wind damaged fields in the northern and western areas.'' Wheat was ``breaking dormancy'' in eastern and southeastern areas of Nebraska but were under stress from lack of moisture. ``In Montana, winter wheat was fair-to-good,'' the report said. ``Growth was good in California,'' although the numbers of Russian wheat aphids continued to increase in the Sacramento Valley. Crop conditions were reported good-to-fair in Washington, while in Oregon winter wheat was said to be fair in the east and good-to-excellent in the western part of the state. ``In the Corn Belt and Southeast, winter wheat was fair-to-good, with adequate moisture supplies,'' the report said. ``The crop was breaking dormancy in portions of the Corn Belt.''

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Tells Dubcek International Accord Needed on Border
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand on Monday told Czechoslovakia's leading lawmaker, Alexander Dubcek, that an international accord is needed to assure that a unified Germany would not seek to regain prewar land. A French official briefing reporters on condition of anonymity said the French president would repeat the position Friday when Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelkski and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki make a one-day visit to discuss the issue. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl is being criticized increasingly for refusing to guarantee that the current border between Poland and East Germany, known as the Oder-Neisse line, would be kept by a united Germany. Kohl says such a commitment can only be made by a united German parliament, but he appears to be under pressure from rightists who want to reclaim territory lost to Poland after World War II. Dubcek was Czechoslovakia's Communist leader during the ``Prague Spring'' reform movement of 1968, which Soviet troops crushed. He returned to public life as speaker of the Federal Assembly late last year after the peaceful revolution that forced the Communists to give up their monopoly on power. The country replaced its hard-line Communist government with one acceptable to the opposition and elected former dissident playwright Vaclav Havel as president. Dubcek's two-day visit to Paris continues Tuesday with meetings with Premier Michel Rocard and National Assembly Speaker Laurent Fabius and a news conference. The French official briefing reporters said Dubcek told Mitterrand that Czechoslovakia does not oppose German reunification so long as it takes place in a European framework, and that Czechoslovakia supports Poland's position on the Oder-Neisse line. Polish leaders say they want to be included in international talks on German reunification that deal with Poland's border. Current plans for what are known as ``two-plus-four'' talks call for East Germany and West Germany to make plans for reunification, with the victorious World War II powers _ France, Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union _ taking part on issues with international consequences. Foreign affairs officials from the Germanys will meet next week to start discussions on reunification, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dieter Genscher told his European Community colleagues Monday in Brussels, Belgium. Irish Foreign Minister Gerard Collins, chairman of the EC council of ministers, relayed Genscher's announcement to reporters. The German minister gave no dates nor locations for the meetings, Collins said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition to Receive Media Time During Election Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The opposition will have access to state broadcast media during election campaigns, the National Assembly announced Tuesday, amid preparations for the first free balloting in more than four decades. Lawmakers adopted a new statute for radio and television, which is responsible to the legislature and no longer to the government. But it was unclear whether the measure would grant the broadcast media more independence. In a marked departure from the past, when state radio and television reflected the official view, the statute specified ``commentaries on radio and television represent the personal opinion of the commentators.'' Communists in Bulgaria, unlike those in other Soviet bloc countries, have retained much of their clout in national politics. Legislative elections are scheduled for June _ the first after 45 years of hard-line Communist rule. The duration of the election messages and other details were to be included in an electoral law, which was among key legislation held up by the suspension on Feb. 12 of talks between the ruling Communists and the opposition. The talks broke down over the Communists' refusal to agree on key political reforms. On Monday, the legislature enacted a law restoring the names of the 1.5 million ethnic Turks and other Moslems forced to adopt Bulgarian names in an assimilation campaign authored by the Communists. Legislators said the media statute was modeled after similar legislation in several West European countries. It stipulates that ``radio and television must be objective. They must not serve one party or group.'' According to the new law, the broadcast media will be controlled by a committee of eight legislators and seven other leaders. The heads of state radio and television will be proposed by the government and elected by the legislature. They cannot hold senior posts within political parties. Workers in the media are not entitled to engage in political activity, the statute said. The law also stipulated the state council president, the head of the legislature and the prime minister should be given ``immediate access to radio and TV on demand.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Clean Air
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of the key provisions of the compromise clean air bill being considered by the Senate.

_Local communities must attain federal air quality standards within five, 10 or 15 years, depending on the severity of the problem. The Los Angeles area is allowed 20 years. _Areas must show annual progress, ozone reductions of 4 percent a year for the first six years and 3 percent annually thereafter. A waiver may be granted if the costs of the annual reductions exceed $5,000 per ton of ozone-forming pollutants. Reductions are to be attained through cuts in automobile emissions and smog-causing releases from industrial plants. Small business emitting less than 100 tons are exempt.

_Automakers must reduce tailpipe emissions of smog-causing pollutants with all cars covered by new emission controls by 1995. Hydrocarbons _ unburned fuel _ would have to be cut by 22 percent to 0.25 grams per mile and nitrogen oxides by 60 percent to 0.4 grams. A second round of tailpipe controls would go into effect in 2003 cutting emissions another 50 percent if 11 cities now with ``serious'' pollution problems fail to meet air quality standards. Cities with even more serious problems would have to use cleaner-burning fuels such as methanol or specially formulated gasoline.

_Utilities must reduce in two phases annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the year 2000 and cap emissions at 1980 levels at that time. First phase begins in 1995, but utilities using clean coal technology may delay initial compliance until 1997. Dirty plants, primarily in the Midwest, also received extra pollution control allowances, which may be sold to recoup some of control costs. Western states also receive additional bonus allowances to provide cushion for growth. _Nitrogen oxide emissions by utilities must be reduced 4 million tons by year 2005.

_Industry must install by 1997 the ``best available technology'' to reduce releases of 191 toxic chemicals by up to 90 percent. _The National Academy of Sciences will recommend methods for assessing remaining health risks, especially from cancer. The Environmental Protection Agency must implement health-based standards to deal with those risks after study is completed.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Fronts Wreak Havoc On Southern Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: A storm moving out of the Rockies and onto the Plains blasted Wyoming and Colorado with heavy, wet snow Tuesday, closing schools and hundreds of miles of highway and shutting down the Wyoming Legislature. Wyoming's Laramie Range near Granite Mountain had picked up 3 to 4 feet of snow and some mountain areas in Colorado got up to 2 feet overnight. Earlier, the storm left 22 inches at Snowbird, Utah. Ahead of the advancing snow, freezing rain brought down power lines in western Nebraska. New Mexico and western South Dakota got snow and Kansas had strong thunderstorms. Jack Daseler, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service in Cheyenne, Wyo., described the conditions responsible for the storm as ``a classic,'' combining an upper level weather system near the Four Corners area, where Colorado, Utah, Arizona and New Mexico meet, and a surface system in southeastern Colorado. He said that during the night ``the upper and lower system will coincide over east-central Colorado and sit there for 12 hours.'' He predicted total accumulations of 15 to 18 inches in Wyoming's lower elevations. Cheyenne had more than a foot by noon and Wheatland had 18 inches. Pinewood Springs, Colo., in the foothills seven miles southwest of Loveland reported 24 inches of fresh snow and Buckhorn Mountain west of Fort Collins received 22 inches. In New Mexico, 9 inches of snow had fallen by late morning at Chama and Brazos Lodge. Heavy snow hampered rescue efforts after a bank explosion at Crested Butte, Colo., and delayed the arrival of ambulances from Gunnison, officials said. Wyoming legislators decided to take a day off from their budget session as the snow deepened outside and blowing snow made buildings just a block away in Cheyenne start to fade out. About 4,000 state employees were told to stay home and at least 400 miles of interstate highways were closed. ``Getting people home tonight is the concern,''said Senate Majority Leader Diemer True. ``We could get staff and legislators here, but getting them home tonight is the problem.'' Neither House Speaker Bill McIlvain, with 18 years in the Legislature, nor Senate President Russell Zimmer, a 16-year member, could remember the Legislature ever closing because of the weather. Children in Cheyenne and Laramie got the day off, and the University of Wyoming in Laramie canceled classes at 11 a.m. ``They're calling for another foot,'' university spokesman Bill Young said. The University of Wyoming's Cowboys were stranded in Laramie by road closures that kept them from making their flight from Denver to the Western Athletic Conference basketball tournament in El Paso, Texas. Rodney Barkell, manager at a 7-Eleven store in Cheyenne, said he had almost no business. ``What we mostly get right now is walk-ins _ people that are close enough to where they can walk'' to the store. And some of those who did take their cars may have regretted it. ``We've had a bunch of people stuck in our parking lot,'' he said. Barkell added that he was 1{ hours late for work himself and he only lives a mile away. ``I got stuck trying to get out of my house, and a friend of mine tried to pull me out and he got stuck, too,'' Barkell explained. The Wyoming Highway Patrol closed some 200 miles of Interstate 80 from the Nebraska line west to Walcott Junction, and about 150 miles of Interstate 25 from the Colorado line north to Orin Junction. The closures piled up business at truck stops in Cheyenne. ``We're jammed,'' said Richard Fox, general manager of Little America in Cheyenne. ``Everything is full. The truck parking lot is jammed with trucks and all of our motel rooms are rented. We probably have a couple of hundred people waiting around the coffee shop and lobby.'' In northern Colorado, Interstate 25 was closed by heavy snow from north of Wellington to the Wyoming line. The Colorado State Patrol also closed Highway 287 from Fort Collins to Laramie, Wyo. Denver's Stapleton International Airport reported delays in arrivals and departures because of visibility problems. Spokesman Richard Boulware said visibility was reduced to 1,000 feet at one point in the morning. Colorado's Poudre Valley Rural Electric Association spokesman Larry Graff said a major transmission line and five substations were down, affecting 3,000 customers north of Fort Collins. Fort Collins Light and Power also reported some outages in the city, including radio station KIIX, which was temporarily off the air.

DOC.HEAD: Graffiti Attacks on London Subway Decline after Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: An experiment on the London subway to remove graffiti quickly from trains, stations and other buildings is producing good results, the system said Tuesday. ``We found that attacks increased for a time when the vandals were faced day after day with clean surfaces, but then the number of attacks fell away,'' said spokesman John Reed of London Underground. ``We think the vandals get tired of seeing their individual trademarks cleaned off and can't be bothered to keep going back to renew their scribbles,'' he said. London Underground operates the 237-mile system and its 268 stations which Londoners call the Tube. Removing graffiti from trains, stations and other buildings on the subway costs more than $3.2 million a year and some stations suffer as many as 700 attacks a month. A cleaning company specializing in graffiti removal was hired in August on a $656,000, one-year contract to work on a group of 15 stations at the northern end of the Metropolitan Line. Its cleaners aimed to get rid of the daubing within 10 hours of staff reporting attacks. The cleaned surfaces are then treated with easy-to-clean paint and lacquer. Reed said vandals travel from all over Britain and even from overseas to daub the subway. ``Some of them like to show they diced with death by crossing electrified tracks and climbing up to bridges and other structures to leave their personal logos,'' Reed said. The experiment includes photographing each graffiti attack and passing details to the Transport Police in an attempt to identify individual vandals, but that aspect has only just been publicized. ``Staff morale at the cleaned-up stations has improved and some of the staff have asked to restart gardens which used to brighten up our surface stations. We are also getting letters of thanks from passengers,'' Reed said. Mike Scanes, managing director of the firm with the cleanup contract, Graffiti Management, said: ``Graffiti is a social problem which should be tackled by schools and parents. It amazes me that any parent can let a child play on a Tube line carrying 650 volts.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP Lawmakers Urge Renewal of Drive for Flag-Burning Amendment
DOC.TEXT: Six Republican lawmakers on Tuesday urged renewal of the drive for a constitutional amendment to outlaw burning the American flag, saying the statutory ban passed last year appears certain to be overturned in the courts. ``Maybe it doesn't bother people around here a lot ... but out there in the real world they're ready for a constitutional amendment,`` Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., told a news conference. A U.S. district court in the nation's capital ruled Monday that the statutory ban on burning the American flag approved by Congress last year is not a constitutional way to limit free speech. A federal court in Seattle issued a similar ruling last month. The Justice Department said Tuesday that it would appeal the rulings. But the Republican lawmakers said it appeared probable that the Supreme Court would uphold the decisions and throw out the statutory ban. Congressional sponsors of the measure offered it last year as an alternative to a constitutional amendment. They said that imposing the ban with a statute was better than adding restrictions through changes in the document that guarantees Americans freedom of speech. The sponsors sought to avoid language that singled out protesters. Instead, they fashioned what they called a simple, ``content neutral'' ban on destruction of the flag, which they said had nothing to do with freedom of speech. They hoped in this way to survive a court challenge to the legislation. The Republican lawmakers reminded the news conference that some of them had warned last year that the courts would not uphold the statutory ban. They said Americans will demand a constitutional amendment to settle the issue once and for all. ``I don't think there's anything that's going to get our American people more excited than a bunch of jerks out there trampling on the American flag and stamping on it,'' declared Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., said support within the Senate is now sufficient to pass an amendment. Also at the session were Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., and Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, as well as Rep. Chuck Douglas, R-N.H.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Call for Unity of Czechs, Slovaks
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Czechs and Slovaks rallied to show anger at purported attempts by Communists to sow discord among the country's two main ethnic factions. ``Some people would like to see Slovaks fighting the Czechs as another source of conflict,'' Slovak Interior Minister Vladimir Meciar told the demonstrators in a nationally televised speech. ``Gentlemen, your times have gone, and you should go too,'' Meciar said in urging Communist deputies in the Slovak parliament to resign. Slovakia, the eastern part of Czechoslovakia, has traditionally been a stronghold of orthodox communism, and the new reform movement that broke the Marxist's hold on the country appears stronger in the Czech lands and particularly in Prague. Czechs outnumber Slovaks approximately two-to-one in the country, which has a population of about 15.5 million people. The National Council, Slovakia's parliament, recently passed a controversial proposal that would change the country's name to the ``Federation Czecho-Slovakia,'' an attempt to stress the equal status of both nations within the country. The proposal would have to be approved by the federal Parliament, and passage is unlikely. The move was considered by many moderate Slovaks to be an unnecessary challenge to the Czech part of the country that could inflame passions between the two groups. There have been charges that Communist deputies _ a minority in the 150-member National Council _ had actively lobbied the majority independent legislators to support the proposal. Jan Buday, leader of the Public Against Violence opposition group that played the key role in Slovakia's peaceful uprising against Communist rule, accused Communists of attempting to spread discord in Slovakia by inflaming historic tensions between Slovaks and the ethnic Hungarian minority. Buday, whose name sounds Hungarian but who says he is a Slovak, accused the Communists of spreading rumors that he was Hungarian and trying to impose that group's ethnic interests on Slovaks. ``I am first of all a citizen and also a Slovak of the kind who does not have to be racist or chauvinist,'' Buday said.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard: Gasoline Barge Explodes in Arthur Kill Off Linden
LaserPhoto NY31
DOC.TEXT: A barge carrying more than 4.2 million gallons of fuel exploded in flames Tuesday on a waterway plagued by oil spills this year, and at least one man was injured, the Coast Guard said. The barge, anchored at a Citgo petroleum facility at Linden, broke into two parts after the explosion and drifted across the Arthur Kill waterway toward Staten Island, N.Y., officials said. Coast Guard officials said the fuel aboard the barge Cibro Savannah was unleaded gasoline, but Citgo spokesman Kent Young said the vessel had just finished taking on heating oil. It was unclear if both materials were on board. Young, speaking from the company's headquarters in Tulsa, Okla., said the loaded barge had pulled about 150 feet away from the dock when it exploded shortly before 1 p.m. He said there was a second explosion about 15 minutes later. There was no damage to Citgo land facilities, he said. Linden Mayor Paul Werkmeister said two men on board jumped off when the explosion hit. ``The man who jumped off the portside was taken to the hospital and we know he's in shock,'' the mayor said. Donald Wright, the barge's captain, was treated for smoke inhalation at Rahway Hospital and will be released, said hospital spokeswoman Nancy Jackson. An unidentified woman who answered the telephone at Cibro Petroleum Inc. in New York confirmed that the barge belonged to the company, but said she had no details. Police blocked off the road to the plant while tugboats and firefighters on land poured water and foam onto the barge, which carried 100,500 barrels of gasoline. Each barrel carries 42 gallons, he said. ``It shook the world,'' John McCabe, who works at Auchter Industrial, said as he watched the smoke rise thousands of feet into the air. Ben Francesco, 59, of Staten Island, owner of an auto wrecking yard about 1,000 yards from the scene, said he and his colleagues felt the blast. The explosion forced the closing of the water channel for the second time in two months. The Arthur Kill and connecting Kill Van Kull separate Staten Island from New Jersey. This year it has been the scene of oil spills from a broken pipeline, a punctured barge and broken barge-loading equipment. The heavily industrialized waterway connects to New York Harbor.

DOC.HEAD: President Urges Community Service
DOC.TEXT: President Bush quoted from slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. and the biblical Good Samaritan story on Tuesday as he urged people to have the courage it takes to serve their communities. Bush told a meeting of the Society of Association Executives that they should set a goal of 100 percent participation in community service among their employees and members. Expanding on one of his favorite themes, Bush recalled a speech by King who said serving others often requires courage. The Good Samaritan, King told his listeners, helped a stranger on the road after two other travelers passed him by. ``They didn't stop because they were afraid,'' of being ambushed by robbers, Bush recounted. The Good Samaritan asked himself what would happen to the man if he didn't help him, while the other two focused on what would happen to them if they stopped. ``Which question do we ask ourselves,'' Bush said. ``About going down to the soup kitchen in that dangerous neighborhhod. About stopping on a dark street to help a homeless man. About reaching out to those desperate kids ... who have no home life, who're hooked on drugs, who live a nightmare we can't begin to imagine. ``Doing any of these things isn't easy. Every one takes an act of courage,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Student Musicians to Make 2nd Tour
DOC.TEXT: The American Soviet Youth Orchestra, made up of 100 talented student musicians from both countries, will make its second tour of the United States and the Soviet Union this summer with concert debuts planned in Western Europe. The orchestra, a joint venture of the Oberlin College music conservatory in Ohio and the Moscow State Conservatory, will give 24 concerts in 17 cities in the Soviet Union, Europe and the United States in July and August. The conductors will be Leonard Slatkin, music director of the St. Louis Symphony, and Alexander Lazarev, artistic director of the Bolshoi Theater Orchestra in Moscow. Violinist Joshua Bell will accompany the tour as American soloist. S. Frederick Starr, the Oberlin president and founder of the orchestra, said the $1.3 million cost of the tour will be split between U.S. and Soviet sponsors. The U.S. share will be financed mostly by private contributions, he said. The orchestra, which made its first tour in 1988, is composed of 50 American and 50 Soviet music students who are selected after rigorous competitions in both countries. The 1990 tour was announced during a reception Monday night at the Soviet Embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Backs Down on Polish Border Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to include Polish, Gorbachev reax; picks up 4th `Kohl had' and SUBS 17-18 `President Mikhail ... serious consequences' to conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BON1
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl dropped his demand for Polish concessions on a border treaty and moved closer Tuesday to guaranteeing a united Germany would not claim land ceded to Poland after World War II. His government proposed a parliamentary resolution, to be introduced Thursday, saying a united Germany should sign a treaty with Poland declaring that the right of Poles ``to live in secure borders will not now or in the future be questioned by us Germans.'' After a Cabinet meeting where ministers discussed disagreements over his handling of the border issue, Kohl said: ``The things that burdened us are cleared away.'' In Warsaw, the Polish Foreign Ministry said there had been ``clear progress,'' but talks were needed about a border treaty. Mikhail S. Gorbachev welcomed the ``corrections'' in Kohl's position, the Soviet news agency Tass quoted the Soviet president as saying after meeting in Moscow with Hans Modrow, the Communist premier of East Germany. Kohl had been criticized for his reluctance to state clearly, presumably in an effort to preserve the conservative vote in ecember elections, that a reunified Germany would not question Poland's western border. He had insisted repeatedly that only the leadership of a united Germany could make such a promise about Polish territory, roughly one-third of which was part of Germany before the war. The chancellor's pronouncements caused unease in Poland, the Soviet Union, United States and elsewhere as Kohl sought international support for bringing East and West Germany together into a single nation. His statements also created trouble at home. The Free Democrats, his coalition partners, joined the opposition Social Democrats in saying his position jeopardized the chances of unification. On Friday, he exacerbated the problem by demanding that any treaty recognizing Poland's current borders be linked to pledges by the Poles to honor a 1953 decision to waive any war reparations, and to a renewal of Poland's 1989 promise to guarantee the rights of its German minority. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and his Free Democrats agreed with Poland that Kohl must clarify his position on the sensitive border issue. After a meeting Tuesday between Kohl and Genscher, their second in two days, Free Democrat official Torsten Wolfgramm said the chancellor had abandoned his demand that Polish assurances accompany a border treaty. ``It is completely clear,'' he said. ``A treaty would contain only the border question.'' Rudolf Seiters, Kohl's chief of staff, also indicated a treaty would concern only the border. Silesia and East Prussia were awarded to Poland and the Soviet Union, respectively, at the Potsdam conference of 1945. That led to the expulsion of 12 million Germans, and at least 2 million died in the process. Genscher was born in what now is East Germany. The foreign minister has made clear he and his party are willing, in return for reunification, to give up all claims to the territory lost to Poland. Seiters said the parliamentary resolution would recommend declarations of respect for Poland's western border by the parliaments of both Germanys, to be made after the East German elections March 18. Once Germany was united, he said, the government would make a treaty with Poland guaranteeing its borders. Gorbachev warned against any attempt by a reunited Germany to change borders drawn at the end of World War II. ``Naturally, the inviolability of postwar borders is the main issue in this respect,'' he said in Moscow. ``To use German reunification to reanimate revanchist plans would be to pursue an irresponsible policy fraught with very serious consequences.'' The Bonn newspaper Die Welt quoted President Wojciech Jaruzelski of Poland as saying prolonging the border debate could ``create an atmosphere which overshadows everything, and which can complicate everything positive for our relations.'' It quoted Jaruzelelski as saying, when asked whether he feared German reunification: ``Yes and no. I worry as a Pole and European because of historical experiences. The position of a mighty power, a dominance, could lead to this position being somehow used at the cost of others.'' On the other hand, Jaruzelski said, he believes ``the Germans themselves, the big powers and all European peoples, especially the Poles, will do everything so that a united Germany will be a constructive element in Europe.'' Germany's invasion of Poland on Sept. 1, 1939, began World War II. The newspaper telexed excerpts of the interview to other news organizations in advance of publication, scheduled for Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Symbol of Cold War Retires on Record-Setting Run to Museum
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS penultimate graf, The Blackbird ... Dulles crowd, to CORRECT Adams' rank
DOC.TEXT: America's premier spy plane _ the SR-71 Blackbird _ came in from the Cold War after a quarter century of supersonic snooping, setting a transcontinental speed record Tuesday before retiring to a museum home. In a final fling for the history books, one of the black, dagger-shaped aircraft flashed from coast to coast in 68 minutes, 17 seconds, arriving at Washington Dulles International Airport outside the nation's capital to the cheers of hundreds of onlookers. The old record was 3 hours, 38 minutes, set in 1963 by a Boeing 707. The Blackbird took a running start, refueling over the Pacific Ocean at 60,000 feet before heading east from the California coastline and crossing its finish line near Salisbury, Md., said Malvern Gross, president of the National Aeronatics Association. The Blackbird then refueled before cruising in to Dulles Airport. The flight also set three other speed records certified by the National Aeronautic Association. ``It's bittersweet,'' said Air Force Lt. Col. Bruce Liebman, who flew Blackbirds for the 9th Strategic Reconnaissance Wing at Beale Air Force Base, Calif., in the 1970s. ``I'm happy it set the record but sad that it has been put to bed.'' ``Bye-bye, Blackbird,'' said Ben Rich, the Lockheed Aeronautical System Co. executive who helped design the Blackbird: ``I cannot honestly say this is a happy day for me.'' The Blackbird model No. 17972 was donated to the Smithsonian Institution, which plans to display it at a Dulles Airport wing of the National Air and Space Museum. Against overcast skies, the spy plane ended its flight by dipping as low as 200 feet above the runway as it whistled past an official greeting gate, balls of fire trailing its huge engines as the pilot suddenly pointed the pencil-shaped fuselage toward the heavens. It was one of the few public displays of a Blackbird. And despite the rush to publicize this final run, most details of the plane's design and capabilities are still top secret. The Air Force won't even say how many of the planes exist. Maj. Suzanne Randle of the Strategic Air Command's headquarters at Offutt Air Force Base, Neb., said nine Blackbirds are going to museums, three are being mothballed at Palmdale, Calif., and three will be used by NASA for research. Ms. Randle said she could not say whether that accounted for all the planes. The first flight of a Blackbird was in December 1964. It regularly flew missions over heavily defended North Vietnam and provided intelligence in many other regions, including the Middle East and China. In 1982 its photographs revealed the presence of Soviet MiG fighters in Nicaragua, touching off an international dispute. The Air Force officially retired the Blackbird fleet in January, saying they were too expensive to keep in the air despite their technological prowess. Technological advances also enable satellites to do similar work more cheaply. Critics argue, however, the planes should be kept in service because they are more versatile than satellites, which are locked into specific orbits and can take longer to pass over a trouble spot. The Blackbird can outrun the fastest fighters and has never been shot down in 25 years of spying. It remains the fastest and highest-flying jet aircraft in the world. Built to withstand temperatures of more than 800 degrees Fahrenheit, its skin is a titanium alloy instead of the aluminum used on most airplanes. Powered by two Pratt & Whitney turbojet engines, it can sustain a speed of Mach 3, or three times the speed of sound. Its maximum speed is classified. On Tuesday's flight, the plane set separate speed records of 2,153.24 mph between Los Angeles and Washington; 2,242.48 mph between St. Louis and Cincinnati and 2,200.94 mph between Kansas City, Mo., and Washington. Sonic booms were reported in various communities along the flight path as the plane completed its race across the continent. The pilot was Lt. Col. Ed Yeilding, and Lt. Col. J.T. Vida was the reconnaissance systems officer. The decision to scrap the Blackbirds still worries some members of Congress and clearly irks airmen who flew the secret aircraft on its 65 million miles of spying. ``You might ask, `Why retire it'''? said Sen. John Warner, R-Va., at the Dulles arrival ceremony. ``This is a very vivid example of what America will go through to scale back defense spending.'' Later he added, ``This is one of the first victims'' of the rush to reduce the military as a result of lessened East-West tensions. The Blackbird's retirement has special meaning for the pilots. Brig. Gen.
