Harold ``Buck'' Adams, who flew the same Blackbird on a record-setting speed run from London to Los Angeles in September 1971, appeared to be fighting back tears as he stood several yards from the plane in addressing the Dulles crowd. ``She is a truly magnificent machine, and she's retiring a winner,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: UNO Meets Contras, No Demobilization Deadline Set
With AM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: An aide to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua said Tuesday that Contra rebels based in Honduras told him they are willing to disband, but that no deadline has been set. ``All sides have the good will to achieve demoblization. ... But we have not come here to demand anything of anybody. We're just beginning a dialogue,'' said Jaime Cuadra, a representative of Mrs. Chamorro. Cuadra talked with reporters at the Presidential Palace here after meeting with President Rafael Callejas. Mrs. Chamorro, who defeated President Daniel Ortega's leftist Sandinista party in Nicaragua's national elections Feb. 25, will take office April 25 for a six-year term. The date for demobilization of the U.S.-supported Contra rebels, estimated at 10,000 in Honduran camps along the Nicaraguan border, has emerged as a major stumbling block on the way to a peaceful transfer of power in Nicaragua. The Sandinistas, who lost the elections to Chamorros's 14-party United National Opposition coalition, have demanded the Contras demobilize before they hand over power to the new administration, saying that otherwise the ruling party cannot assure a peaceful transition. Contra rebel commanders have insisted they will not disarm or demobilize until after the transfer of the presidency, the Sandinista-run army and the Interior Ministry, which controls the police. ``If the Sandinistas don't hand over the army and the Interior Ministry, they aren't handing over anything. The people rejected the Sandinistas on Feb. 25, and we will not lay down our arms until the people's will is respected,'' said a top Contra commander who called himself only Wilmer. Wilmer, who refused to disclose his real name, made the statement Monday in an interview with The Associated Press at Yamales, the main Contra camp, 85 miles east of Tegucigalpa. Asked about a specific plan for demoblization and a deadline, he said: ``There is no plan and no established deadline.'' The United States, which helped form the Contras in the early 1980s and sustained them financially through the decade, said last week that immediate measures should be taken to achieve the Contras' demobilization. But the State Department also said the rebels must enjoy ``full guarantees'' regarding personal and economic security at home before disbanding. Honduras has been a reluctant host to the Contras in recent years. Callejas said last week the rebels should leave as soon as possible.

DOC.HEAD: Three Held in Drug Scheme Linked to Alleged Soldiers' Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: Three people linked to a scheme to use U.S. soldiers to smuggle cocaine from Panama to this country were ordered held after appearing before a magistrate, authorities said Tuesday. The soldiers allegedly were hired by Colombian smugglers to bring cocaine in duffel bags aboard military flights to the United States, CBS News reported Monday night. CBS reported on a smuggling ring broken up recently in Panama. The network, quoting unidentified military sources, reported that at least nine people, including two Americans, were arrested. The three who appeared before the federal magistrate in Fort Lauderdale on Monday are charged with conspiracy to import cocaine. The three, identified only as John Doe III, John Doe VII and Jane Doe II, are linked to an investigation of the soldiers, government sources said on condition of anonymity. Federal documents said the cocaine smuggling involving the three went on from Oct. 1, 1989, to Feb. 19, 1990. If convicted, the three could be sentenced to at least 10 years in prison. Documents related to their court appearance before U.S. Magistrate Lurana Snow were ordered sealed by the U.S. attorney in Miami. Diane Cossin, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney's office, said that several sparse documents released Tuesday were the only information being released. A federal official familiar with court policy said it is allowable in some circumstances to seal documents related to a court appearance to prevent the release of details of an ongoing investigation. Doug Tillett, a Justice Department spokesman, referred all questions to the U.S. attorney's office in Miami. A Pentagon spokesman also declined comment on the case. The CBS report said U.S. soldiers took payoffs of up to $10,000 from Colombian drug suppliers to bring cocaine home. One serviceman confessed that he recruited soldiers to smuggle cocaine aboard the flights home, CBS said.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Reported in Jamaican Local Elections
DOC.TEXT: Beatings, ballot-box thefts at gunpoint and other irregularities marred local elections in urban areas Tuesday, but voting was peaceful in the countryside, police and state radio said. Police said a Kingston voter, 32-year-old Robert Anglin, was attacked by several men and stabbed repeatedly. He was hospitalized in serious condition. Witnesses and the state-owned Jamaican Broacasting Corp. said thugs beat up a polling station chairwoman at a Kingston grade school and splashed her with ink, and reported several cases of hoodlums and gunmen stealing ballot boxes. Elsewhere in the capital, toughs invaded polling stations, intimidated voting officials, marked ballots and stuffed them in the boxes, witnesses said. No reports of irregularities or violence came from rural areas. The government deployed 6,500 police and 4,000 soldiers across this Caribbean island to prevent violence. The elections were for 13 city mayors and parish councils. Ten of the city governments now are controlled by the governing center-left People's National Party and three by the opposition Jamaica Labor Party. Witnesses and state radio said all ballot boxes were stolen at the Chetolah Park Primary School and Kingston Parish Church voting stations in Kingston and ballot boxes were also stolen at three voting stations in St. Catherine Parish. Prime Minister Michael Manley on Monday night urged Jamaicans to refrain from violence. Elections here traditionally have been marred by clashes between militants from the two main parties. Businesses closed and government offices worked half the day to allow employees to vote, but polling officials reported a low turnout. Results will be announced this week. Polling hours for the 6,000 voting stations were 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. Manley's party campaigned on the platform of decentralization by promising to turn over certain powers from the central government to local authorities. Manley defeated Labor Party leader Edward Seaga in a lopsided electoral victory in February 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Dinkins Calls Census `Political,' Threatens Suit
DOC.TEXT: The draft guidelines for conducting the U.S. Census are ``a cruel joke on American cities,'' New York Mayor David N. Dinkins said Tuesday in threatening to sue the Commerce Department. ``By issuing these draft guidelines, the Commerce Department has sent a signal to the Census Bureau that it wants a political census, not an honest one,'' Dinkins said at a news conference. ``But the draft guidelines are a joke _ a cruel joke on America's cities that depend upon a fair census for political representation, for a fair share of federal funding, for our constitutional right to equal protection under the law.'' If the department has not made some changes when it issues the final guidelines March 10, ``we'll see them in court,'' Dinkins said. The city is seeking an adjustment to the 1980 census, which it says undercounted the population by 6 percent, or 450,000 people. The undercount, it said, lost the city hundreds of millions of dollars in state and federal aid, based on a population formula, and curtailed its political representation in Washington and Albany. Dinkins' major complaint with the draft guidelines was that there will be no adjustment unless there is ``overwhelming'' evidence of an undercount. ``Even if that evidence is produced, an adjustment would occur only if it would not be too politically disruptive and the explanation for it could be `clearly and simply stated in a way that is understandable to the general public,''' Dinkins said. Plus, he said, the draft guidelines make the assumption that the 1990 undercount won't be any worse than the 1980 undercount. ``This to me is as bad as the early days of our country when the government said we will count African-Americans _ slaves _ as three-fifths of a human being,'' Dinkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says He Can't Judge Hostage Situation
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday he was unable to judge reports suggesting that American hostages in Lebanon will be freed soon but added that the existence of such speculation is encouraging. Baker, asked if the administration had reason for optimism about the hostages, replied, ``I don't know. I mean, you're asking me if all the smoke out there means there is a fire.'' He added, ``We certainly hope that the hostages will be released. We'd like to see anybody that could have influence in that regard weigh in.'' Baker commented at the State Department about the latest in a string of reports in Iranian newspapers, as well as optimistic assessments by Syrian officials, suggesting that the long hostage ordeal may be ending. The Tehran Times, a newspaper close to Iran's president, said in an editorial that 1990 would be the last year of captivity for the hostages. The report also said resumption of U.S.-Iranian ties was not a precondition for the hostages' release. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler, commenting on speculation about the hostages, said, ``I don't know why this many rumors are out here. I don't have an explanation for that.'' Baker, asked by reporters if he were encouraged by statements from Iran, said, ``We don't have any better way of judging that right now, frankly, than you do. We see what is coming across here, and we are encouraged by the fact there is speculation. Let's see if that speculation proves out.'' A senior administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``We see a lot of stuff going on. ``It's kind of like watching a lot of action under a blanket,'' the official added. ``We're not quite sure who's doing what to whom.'' The official said, ``We're hopeful. We don't know enough to be optimistic.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, asked about the latest Tehran Times report, said, ``It's just pretty hard to judge it. We certainly hope it's true.'' Iran is believed to exert considerable influence over Hezbollah, the umbrella group for radical Shiite Moslems believed to be holding some of the hostages. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon, with 40,000 troops there. While saying there is nothing to suggest an imminent release of the hostages, the administration says there are a lot of talks going on behind the scenes by officials outside the U.S. government. Eighteen Westerners, including eight Americans, are being held capitive in Lebanon. The longest-held hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who will mark his fifth anniversary in captivity on March 16. The Tehran Times, in a second editorial, said said Syrian President Hafez Assad would visit Tehran soon, after an expected trip by his foreign minister, Farouk Al-Sharaa. It also denied reports that a trip by the brother of Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani to the Syrian capital of Damascus last week was related to the hostage question. In Beirut, the respected An-Nahar daily ruled out any hostage release soon but quoted unidentified Lebanese fundamentalist sources as saying Iran was prepared to tackle the hostage issue. The sources were quoted as saying there had been no direct contacts between Iran and the United States, but both were scouting for what was described as a mechanism for releasing the hostages. The report did not elaborate. The Tehran Times, for the second time in as many weeks, said the hostages should go free without preconditions. In the past, the paper has reflected the thinking of President Hashemi Rafsanjani. ``Our own assessment indicates that this thorny issue can be sorted out in the near future in a sincere spirit by sincere people,'' the paper said, adding, ``1990 can and will be the last year of the captivity of these hostages.'' It said an effort was under way to free the hostages because ``Islam in no way allows or condones the idea that people should be taken or held hostage.''

DOC.HEAD: Junk Dealer Appears Before Federal Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: A junk dealer appeared Tuesday before a federal grand jury investigating a series of mail bombings in the South that killed two people. Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, of Enterprise, and his attorney, Paul Harden of Evergreen, did not disclose the nature or extent of any testimony. The federal grand jury that convened in Birmingham last week is investigating the mail bombings that killed federal appeals court Judge Robert S. Vance of Birmingham and lawyer Robert Robinson of Savannah, Ga., in December. Vance was killed by an exploding package at his home on Dec. 16. Two days later, a similar mail bomb killed Robert Robinson, an NAACP attorney who served as a city councilman in Savannah, Ga. Two other bombs were spotted and defused, one at 11th Circuit offices in Atltanta, the other at NAACP offices in Jacksonville, Fla. A source familiar with the case told The Associated Press that the grand jury may not be conducting a full investigation but may compile testimony for use later, possibly by another grand jury. O'Ferrell said Monday he had not been subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury, but that he had discussed testifying with his attorney. FBI special agent Tom Moore said he was prohibited from commenting on any grand jury proceedings concerning O'Ferrell. The special grand jury handles cases investigated by the Organized Crime-Drug Enforcement Task Force, and federal prosecutors assigned to the task force in Birmingham have been working the mail-bomb investigation, officials have said. O'Ferrell came under scrutiny after investigators discovered that the type in letters he wrote years ago to Vance's court, the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta, appeared to match the type in letters linked to the mail bombs. More than 100 investigators flocked into Coffee County and began searches of O'Ferrell's New Brockton home and Enterprise business on Jan. 22. They dug up his septic tank and sent divers into a nearby lake to look for possible evidence. Investigators found several typewriters in the salvage store but none that had type matching the letters, according to federal agents. O'Ferrell speculated he could have had the typewriter and used it to type his letters but then sold it to an unknown buyer.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Urges Israel To Accept Proposal For Talks With Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III urged the Israeli government on Tuesday to approve his terms for talks with Palestinian Arabs or run the risk of a dead end in Mideast peace efforts. ``Without a dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians we can never move forward to peace,'' Baker said as the two leading political parties in Israel clashed over his formula for talks. ``They are trying to resolve some fairly thorny problems that they have within their government,'' Baker told reporters. ``I think they are working hard and in good faith to resolve those problems and we certainly hope they are successful.'' Baker stopped just short of involving himself in the political dispute in Israel over his terms for the talks. But he left no doubt about the outcome he seeks from Jerusalem. ``What we would like to see is for them to give us a positive answer so that we can move forward toward a dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians,'' Baker said. The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, meanwhile stressed that Baker would continue to press for Israelis and Palestinians to meet in Cairo. ``He will stay engaged as long as there is hope, as long as there are genuine efforts on the part of all parties,'' she said. ``And he today sees no reason to give up that hope or to disengage.'' On Monday in Jerusalem, leaders of the Likud coalition, headed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, voted to send an Israeli team to Cairo for talks with Palestinian delegates, but only if East Jerusalem Arabs were excluded from negotiations. Also, the Likud leaders said they would quit the talks if the Palestine Liberation Organization tried to direct the discussions. This raised the possibility of a breakup of the government's ruling Likud-Labor coalition. Labor, the junior member, had threatened to walk out unless U.S. terms for negotiations were accepted by Wednesday. The Bush administration sought to avoid involvement in the dispute. ``We are not going to have a comment on that,'' spokeswoman Tutwiler said of the Likud moves. ``That is an area which we have refrained from getting into.'' The U.S. official read from a prepared statement that skirted the current political dispute by saying the Bush administration wanted a decision from the Israeli government itself. ``We posed questions to the government of Israel, and we have not yet received an answer from the Israeli government,'' spokeswoman Tutwiler said. ``Positive answers to the questions will make it possible to go forward.'' She acknowledged Israel was facing a dilemma. The U.S. proposal is known to call for placing on the delegation at least one Palestinian deported from the West Bank during the insurrection against Israeli control. ``We have said these are very difficult decisions,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``We understand that.'' But in expressing U.S. pressure, she said `'the ball is in Israel's court'' and ``the time to act is now.''

DOC.HEAD: House Panels Ends Lincoln Probe
DOC.TEXT: The House Banking Committee closed its investigation of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and mapped plans Tuesday to broaden its probe to include spectacular thrift failures in Texas, Colorado and Florida. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, promised anew to examine the failure of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. President Bush's son, Neil, served on the thrift's board. Regulators have said the younger Bush had questionable business ties to Silverado borrowers. The committee will hold a March 26 hearing on the failure of CenTrust Savings Bank of Miami. A month ago, CenTrust became the first S&L to fail because of junk bond losses. It was also known for spending deposits on a museum-quality art collection, lavish salaries, a yacht and limousines. On May 2-3, the committee will look at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and what Gonzalez called a ``daisy chain'' operation in which junk bonds were shuffled around the country among institutions _ including Lincoln, Silverado and CenTrust. Gonzalez plans field hearings April 11-12 in Dallas to examine thrift collapses in Texas. He said he hoped to subpoena the former executives of Vernon Savings and Loan Association and Sunbelt Federal Savings and Loan Association. The panel will also look at the government's 1988 bailout sale of American Savings and Loan Association, Stockton, Calif., to Texas financier Robert Bass, Gonzalez said. Tuesday's hearing, the seventh by the committee focusing on Lincoln, scrutinized the web of interlocking land deals involving Hidden Valley and Estrella, which were to be a massive residential developments in the desert 20 miles southwest of Phoenix. Chris Seefer, an examiner in the Office of Thrift Supervision's San Francisco office, complained that political appointees in the agency's Washington headquarters blocked field examiners from scrutinizing the projects, after meeting with Lincoln owner Charles Keating Jr. in September 1987. He estimated that caused $200 million of Lincoln's $2 billion loss. Gonzalez had invited Charles H. Keating III, son of Lincoln's owner, to testify, but he did not appear. The younger Keating, while still in his 20s, drew a $1 million annual salary from Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp., for handling many of his father's real estate ventures. ``The absence says much about the cavalier attitude'' of the Keatings, Gonzalez said. He had intended to subpoena the younger Keating, but had not been able to gather the majority of his 51-member committee needed to vote on the action. For the most part, the hearing covered old ground, examining a land deal between Lincoln and Ernest C. Garcia, a Tucson developer and stockbroker. Lincoln was able to manufacture profits by lending Garcia $19.6 million, which was never repaid. Garcia used the money to buy the Hidden Valley land through a straw buyer, Fernando R. Acosta. The transaction has been examined in detail in public hearings before U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin, who is to decide on a motion to dismiss Keating's lawsuit seeking to reclaim Lincoln. The S&L was seized by the government in April. Garcia, who had been subpoenaed by the committee, appeared but refused to answer questions, asserting his constitutional right to avoid self-incrimination. Acosta testified briefly, saying he acted as a straw buyer in the Hidden Valley sale as a favor to Garcia and did not consider his actions improper. He disclosed he had been questioned by the FBI and Securities and Exchange Commission about the transaction. Gonzalez told reporters his committee would release its report on the Lincoln failure soon, possibly in a week.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Tass Report on Afghanistan
With AM-Afghanistan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In addition to regular news reports on Tuesday's events in Afghanistan, the English-language service of the official news agency Tass carried this dispatch, which was not presented as a commentary: Serious concern is caused by fighting between separate units of the government forces, also with the use of aviation, that broke out in Kabul on March 6. At a time when national reconciliation is gaining momentum and the prospects for a political settlement to the Afghan conflict have become more tangible, an attempt has been made to stage an armed coup against Afghanistan's lawful government. These actions can blight the hopes for an early establishment of peace in Afghanistan. Soviet people who are sincerely interested in the well-being of the Afghan people and who wish that there should be no more loss of life in neighboring Afghanistan, our friend, cannot remain indifferent to the events in Afghanistan. It is noted with satisfaction that the government takes vigorous steps to normalize the situation. What is needed above all in this hour of trial for the Afghan people is unity of all patriotic forces to protect Afghanistan's national interests and the resolve to prevent developments that may lead to tragedy. People in the Soviet Union are confident that the road to a future peaceful and prosperous Afghan state is through national reconciliation and the ensurance of Afghanistan's independence and sovereignty. This road is favored in the Soviet Union and throughout the world.

DOC.HEAD: Rupert Residents Vote On Banning Sale Of Alcohol
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be updated with results of vote, after 7 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The town meeting had all the makings of a low-budget soap opera: a bitter, 12-year feud between families, a battle over selling booze and a question about who should govern. First and foremost, voters went to the polls Tuesday to decide whether the town's only general store, M.H. Sherman's _ owned by Marion and John Pelton _ should be allowed to continue selling beer and wine. A rejection could force residents to travel six miles or more to buy beer and wine, making Rupert one of only six dry towns in Vermont. Rupert, which borders New York in southern Vermont, was a dry town until voters narrowly approved the sale of beer and wine in 1981. Rupert is not the only New England community grappling with change. In Vernon, neighbors of Vermont's only nuclear power plant voted Monday to support a low-level radioactive waste site near the plant. Vermont is the only state with a nuclear power plant that has no place to put its low-level radiactive nuclear waste. In addition, voters in many Vermont towns were asked whether they support asking the state's congressional delegation to back a 5 percent cut in defense spending and redirect it to domestic needs. In the coastal Maine town of Penobscot, residents considered a plan Tuesday to abolish local property taxes and finance town services instead through voluntary payments and user fees. The town's budget is $1.2 million a year. In Rupert, with a population just over 600, many feel the real issue on the ballot has more to do with the local family feud than the issue of wet versus dry. ``It's really just a grudge match,'' said Rupert Selectman Jay Wilson, Jr., adding that the feud began about 12 years ago when John Pelton charged that Wilson's son, now town road commissioner, and several of his friends were taking gasoline from the town garage for personal use. Wilson, who has served on the board of selectmen for 32 years, and some of his family have reportedly not been in Pelton's store since then. Wilson also is struggling to keep his seat on the Board of Select. He is being challenged by Dan Nardi, who supports keeping the alcohol laws intact. The battle over alcohol sales in town has been contentious, with Wilson accusing Pelton of selling alcohol to minors (which Pelton denies), and a recent selectmen's meeting erupting into a fist fight over the issue. ``It's Wilson again Pelton,'' said one resident, who asked not to be identified. Added another, ``We've got a lot of `family' problems around here.'' Pelton is not the only one feuding with the Wilson clan. Edward Lewis says his road is the last to get plowed by the road commissioner, Wilson's son, after every snowstorm because he has challenged the elder Wilson for the selectman's seat several times. Rev. Paul Mychack, of the Church of Christ, says some residents have ``been against me mindlessly'' because he took another of Wilson's sons to court 11 years ago. ``It's unbelievable how divided the town is,'' said Mychack. ``I'm so upset about the violence. Before this is over, I'm afraid someone will get hurt.'' M.H. Sherman's, located two doors down from the post office, is an unlikely battle field. The small store is crammed with everything from Blue Seal livestock feed to disposable diapers and displays a bulletin board touting an upcoming chicken and biscuit dinner to benefit the fire department. ``This is a nice store ... it's almost like a community center here,'' said Andrea Lenhardt, a clerk at Sherman's. ``When the power goes out in town, the first place people come to is this place.'' Lenhardt echoes her bosses' denials that they sell beer and wine to minors. ``We are very careful, especially if it is someone we don't know. Sometimes we tell people don't even take it (beer or wine) out of the cabinet unless they have i.d.'' But some residents, including Wilson's daughter-in-law Lisa, complain that too often residents gather at the store not to mingle with neighbors, but to get drunk. ``You get more obnoxious people,'' said Lisa Wilson. ``They sit at the store and get drunk and hassle people.'' Traditionally the first Tuesday in March, Rupert's town meeting allows residents to decide issues crucial _ often whether to buy a new snow plow or raise selectmen's salaries _ with a show of hands. State offices and schools are closed for the day.

DOC.HEAD: East German Parliament Approves Strike Right
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Tuesday adopted a labor law that recognizes the right to strike for the first time in East Germany's 40-year history, while forbidding employers from locking out workers. The embrace of one capitalist tactic and rejection of another highlights the indecision gripping East Germans as they begin considering how to merge their nation with West Germany. Members of Parliament praised the new labor code that mixes market-style reforms with traditional socialist protections, but conceded it probably will stir protest among West German investors and employers eyeing unification. The labor law easily won approval from the 385 lawmakers present for what is expected to be the last session of the 500-member People's Chamber prior to the nation's first competitive elections on March 18. Only six voted against the measure, with 53 abstentions. Debate was minimal. The future of the new labor law may rest with the new, 400-member Parliament. Many labor principles embodied in the law require implementing legislation that will have to be tackled after the new legislative body is seated. The strike clause, however, is among changes to take effect next week. Lawmakers hailed the no-lockout clause as a workers' right not enjoyed in West Germany. Because the law is likely to be seen as imbalanced by West German industries seeking to build plants or engage in joint production operations in East Germany, it may serve to slow the investment considered essential to turning around the flagging economy. The law comes in the form of a constitutional change. It permits unions to call strikes if arbitration fails to resolve labor-management differences in negotiations. Strikes have been forbidden in East Germany and most socialist states. Labor unions traditionally were powerless to challenge policies handed down by Communist authorities, who dominated all social and economic matters until last fall. The government now will have the right to intercede and stop a strike only if the walkout is deemed a threat to public well-being. The law provides that ``no one can reduce or hinder unions in their rightful occupation.'' Communist lawmaker Kaethe Niederkirchner said such a broad protection was likely to disturb the capitalists next door. He quoted West German employers association president Klaus Murmann as describing the law as a ``hindrance'' to inter-German economic cooperation. Parliament also adopted additional measures on election procedures, including extending voting rights to foreigners who have lived in East Germany for two years or more.

DOC.HEAD: Gourmet Brownie Company Sues Bakery Goliath
DOC.TEXT: A gourmet brownie maker is claiming in a federal lawsuit it was burned by a 71-year-old baking giant in Minnesota that allegedly stole a recipe and sold it under a new name. The Boston Brownie Co. alleges McGlynn Bakeries of Eden Prairie, Minn., took the batter recipes for Boston Brownies and marketed them, with a few minor changes, under the name Classic Brownie Batter. McGlynn denies the allegations. The U.S. District Court lawsuit filed last last month cites an agreement between the two companies in which McGlynn would manufacture the batter for Boston Brownie, and for its own store in Minneapolis. The agreement said the recipes were a trade secret and that McGlynn would protect them, the lawsuit contends. Boston Brownies, which has one store in the Faneuil Hall marketplace, makes ``gourmet brownies'' in 20 flavors. In addition to the traditional fudge and fudge nut varieties, offerings include rocky road, mint, toffee, amaretto, kahlua, white chocolate macadamia nut and chocolate chip. ``It's my recipe, my process, my logo, and all of that,'' said Laura J. Katleman, the owner and inventor of Boston Brownie, which has sales of about $400,000 annually. The Classic Brownie Batters, which McGlynn has marketed for about two years, also come in flavors such as rocky road, toffee, mint and amaretto, as well as chocolate, chocolate pecan, cherry, white chocolate chunk, and blond chocolate chip. ``Have you ever heard of amaretto brownies? Where did he get those flavors?'' Katleman asked Monday. What's more, she said, ``the fudginess, the ingredients, they read the same as mine. My chemist says for McGlynn to have come up with these formulas it would have been a miracle.'' Katleman said she was appalled by what she called McGlynn's lack of honor in allegedly fudging things so her brownies were sold under his name. McGlynn Bakeries is run by Michael J. McGlynn. What made her particularly angry, she said, was ``the way he wooed me. He invited me to his home, I met his family. He was so warm and sweet, and to find out he was doing this. ``Maybe I am naive about the workings of big business, but his conduct in this whole matter was just appalling to me.'' Sales at McGlynn, which has retail bakeries and manufactures frozen dough and pre-baked foods, totaled about $100 million in 1989, McGlynn said in a telephone interview. He said the sales from Classic Batter Brownies comprised ``less than one-quarter of one percent'' of total business. McGlynn declined to comment on any aspect of the suit, but a lawyer for McGlynn Bakeries, Jim Harlow, said the company denied all of the suit's allegations. ``We think the allegations of the complaint are groundless and the company intends to vigorously defend against them,'' said Harlow, who declined further comment. Katleman said McGlynn first approached her after he had sampled some of her brownies on a pass through Faneuil Hall. ``He was just enamored of the whole concept of gourmet brownies,'' said Katleman. McGlynn wanted to lease the Boston Brownies recipe for franchise stores, but they could not agree on terms, Katleman said. Instead, they agreed to have him manufacture her batter, of which she needs ``a couple of thousand pounds a week,'' she said. Last December, Katleman discovered the Classic Brownie Batters in a McGlynn catalogue, which she saw in the offices of another batter maker. ``The guy started to read down the list, Chocolate Amaretto, Rocky Road, and he asked me `Are you sure he hasn't ripped you off?' I was just blown away,'' Katleman said. The lawsuit seeks to restrain McGlynn from any use of Boston Brownies batter, recipes, products, formulas and processes. It also seeks damages, but Katleman said she could not name a specific amount.

DOC.HEAD: Gephardt Says It's Time for Direct U.S. Aid to Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `If you're...' to UPDATE with Dole comment. Picks up 7th graf pvs `Gephardt noted ...'
DOC.TEXT: House Democratic Leader Richard Gephardt said Tuesday the United States should offer direct aid to the Soviet Union to ensure that its reforms succeed. ``We should be investing in our own self-interest,'' Gephardt said. ``And stability, democracy and a market economy in the Soviet Union are in America's strong self-interest.'' The proposal brought immediate criticism from some quarters, and a presidential spokesman said the Soviets don't want direct aid. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., also said that the Soviets haven't requested U.S. help and that, if they did, it would be wasted without economic reform. ``Unless they reform the economy, it's going down a rathole,'' Bradley said. Others on Capitol Hill said that while they thought Gephardt's proposal would spark a useful debate, the idea would fall on disapproving public ears. ``If you're going to start giving foreign aid to the hated commies of 70 years' worth, you've got a real sales job to do in the United States,'' said Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo. ``Gorbachev needs us a lot more than we need him,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``We ought to extract a fair price'' for any support, including a requirement that the Soviets stop aiding client states from Cuba to Afghanistan. ``If Gorbachev needs some ready cash, he can ask for a refund from Castro'' and the others, Dole said in a speech released by his office. Gephardt noted an appeal by Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, in a Feb. 21 speech to Congress, to help his country by helping the Soviet Union continue on its reformist road. If Havel, who was imprisoned by the communists, can call for aid to the Soviets, ``the least we can do is listen,'' Gephardt said in a speech that also contained his harshest criticism to date of Bush's policy toward Eastern Europe. He accused Bush of ``a lack of leadership in this most crucial moment,'' throwing billions of dollars into the military budget to defend against ``communists who don't want to be communists any more'' while ignoring their economic needs. ``It's as though George Bush's Pentagon budget were written by someone who hadn't read a newspaper in a year,'' Gephardt said, drawing applause. Indeed, most of the administration's budget was drafted last year, after the opening of the Berlin Wall but before many other dramatic developments in Eastern Europe. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater called the charges ``general old political stuff'' and added, ``The Soviet Union doesn't want direct aid.'' But others, while saying the Soviet Union should have to meet certain conditions before receiving U.S. help, acknowledged that events have moved so rapidly that aid is no longer out of the question. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he agreed with Gephardt. ``It's a dramatically different circumstance from a few months ago,'' Foley said, noting local elections that have taken place in the Soviet Union and the existence of competing political parties. ``Those changes are coming on very fast, and we have a stake in this country in supporting those changes,'' Foley said. Gephardt, a 1988 candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, proposed the idea of direct aid in a speech to the liberal Center for National Policy and acknowledged that it would be difficult politically. ``There are votes to be lost in taking a risk for peace, in appearing insufficiently tough on the Soviets. And there are votes to be lost in calling on the American people to make some changes to adapt to the changing world,'' the Missouri congressman said. Speaking to reporters later, Gephardt added: ``We live in a paradox. We now face the prospect of giving assistance and support to people who've oppressed people for 45 years.'' But he said that during a trip to Eastern Europe two months ago ``I was embarrassed that we are not being as strong and as courageous as they are. Can't we do something to help?'' Specifically, Gephardt called for a ``Food for Freedom'' program to send U.S. food aid to the Soviets; the lifting of trade restrictions, including those on high-technology exports, and guarantees for businesses that want to invest in the Soviet Union. ``A stronger Soviet economy will facilitate the process of peace,'' said Gephardt. ``How can the Soviets pull Red Army troops out of Eastern Europe if they have no jobs and no homes for them to return to in Russia?'' Direct U.S. aid is possible now because ``the Cold War as we have known it for four decades is over,'' Gephardt said. While the possibility remains that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could be ousted or his reforms could fail, superpower competition in arms and influence has changed in fundamental ways, he said. The United States since May 1985 has sold 20 million metric tons of U.S.-grown wheat to the Soviet Union under subsidies worth hundreds of millions of dollars, but has never provided direct aid of the kind Gephardt proposed. Some of Gephardt's colleagues also questioned the propriety of the suggestion and his motives. ``He's got the burning bosom syndrome to be president of the United States,'' Simpson said. ``Of course there's a major question of how we react to the startling developments in the Soviet Union,'' said Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill. ``But Mr. Gorbachev has got to stop subsidizing their imperial designs regionally around the world. Let him tell Mr. Castro he's on his own'' in Cuba. ``Then they might be entitled to look to us for concrete assistance,'' Hyde said. He added, ``I know Mr. Gephardt is anxious to make a mark for himself, but we should speak with one voice on these very delicate questions.''

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Exile Leader Says Chances of Free Elections Are Nil
DOC.TEXT: A Romanian exile leader told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and members of Parliament Tuesday that chances of free elections in Romania are nil because Communists control the government, media and economy. Ion Ratiu said the National Salvation Front has taken over the old Communist Party structure and is using it to help win the May 20 general election. The front took power in the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Ratiu, 72, who arrived from Bucharest Tuesday and planned to return Wednesday, is president of the World Union of Free Romanians. He was granted asylum in Britain in 1940 and became a wealthy businessman. He now hopes to run for Parliament in Romania as a candidate of the National Peasants Party, the largest opposition group. After meeting Mrs. Thatcher, he told an all-party meeting at the House of Commons that the Western news media and Western embassies in Romania were perpetuating the view that the opposition parties ``are incapable of producing a coherent government.'' Ratiu said many of the 47 political parties formed since the revolution ``are phantom parties subservient to the front.'' He said that nonetheless, if free and unfettered elections were held and the result was a plurality for the opposition, a coalition of non-front parties ``would form a government that is very credible and very capable.'' Ratiu said he doubted there will be free elections. ``In the country, at large, the entire structure of the Communist Party, with small exceptions, is now active as the front. The chances of free, fair and unfettered elections are nil under these circumstances,'' he said. ``Effectively, the front still has control of the media, economy and the government infrastructure and all its members have a vested self-interest in victory for the front party.'' Ratiu chided French President Francois Mitterrand and Premier Michel Rocard for receiving Prime Minister Petre Roman and not arranging a single ministerial meeting for Corneliu Coposu, president of the Peasants Party who has been in Paris this week. ``I do not wish to see the front recognized as a legitimate government,'' he said. Ratiu said Romania's interim President Ion Iliescu agreed last week to allow the World Union of Free Romanians to publish an independent newspaper and new radio and television stations. A printing press will be delivered next week and Ratiu said he expects to start publication in two weeks. Equipment for the TV channel is in Bucharest and ``we can start it at once, within two days,'' he said. He said the exile group would send 100 tons of paper to Romania for the election campaign, and it would be offered equally to all parties, including the front.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of 4th item to CORRECT that Rockefeller not grandson of Nelson Rockfeller
DOC.TEXT: Take off the expensive suit, the suspenders, the designer socks, the silk shirt, and what would O. Stillman Rockefeller be? Just another scantily clad millionaire selling underwear. The 30-year-old Rockefeller _ a descendant of William Rockefeller, brother of John D. Rockefeller Sr. _ will soon be seen modeling Jockey brand underwear. It's all for charity. One of his fellow underwear salesmen is Jim Palmer, former Baltimore Oriole and Hall of Fame pitcher. Rockefeller, who normally works with artist Mark Kostabi, will donate his fee for doing the ad to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, publicist Natasha Devli, said Tuesday. The first ad, which will be print only, is set to appear in the next issue of Forbes magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Rules Out NATO Membership for United Germany
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Tuesday the reunification of Germany should proceed slowly and NATO membership for the new nation was ``absolutely out of the question.'' Gorbachev spoke after meeting with Hans Modrow, the Communist premier of East Germany. His remarks were carried by Tass, the official news agency. President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said last week they had agreed a united Germany should be part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Soviet Union, which has more than 300,000 soldiers in East Germany, has said the new country should be neutral. Tass said Gorbachev was asked Tuesday what he thought of a United Germany becoming part of NATO and replied: ``We cannot agree to that. It is absolutely out of the question.'' Modrow's spokesman, Wolfgang Meyer, said East Germany also found NATO membership unacceptable. A ``step-by-step'' approach to reunification is needed, Gorbachev said, and condemned what he called tendencies to treat the process ``high-handedly.'' Modrow's talks in Moscow also concerned future relations. East Germany is the Soviet Union's main trading partner.

DOC.HEAD: All But Romania to Have Trade Agreements With EC by May
DOC.TEXT: All nations in the former Soviet bloc except Romania will have trade agreements with the European Community by the end of April, a senior official of the community said Tuesday. Frans Andriessen, commissioner for trade and foreign affairs, said accords with East Germany, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia would be concluded before the EC summit on Eastern Europe is held April 28 in Dublin, Ireland. Agreements were signed in 1988 and 1989 with Hungary, Poland and the Soviet Union. The scope of an agreement Czechoslovakia signed in 1988 is being widened. Andriessen said the ``first generation'' agreements would be a basis for more extensive commercial relations. He said a pact could not be signed with Romania because its government was more of a caretaker administration than the others. ``Second generation'' agreements to be negotiated later are intended to be ``a model ... we can use for the construction of a greater Europe,'' Andriessen said. The official said those agreements would deal with establishing a free trade zone, political cooperation, common projects in sectors such as transport and the environment and financial deals like a $1.2 billion loan arranged for Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: Study Examines Noise Effects On Pregnant Horses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Capt. Dick...' with 1 to UPDATE with comment from Air Force's project manager. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `LeBlanc said ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force is paying for a $100,000 study to determine how low-flying F-4 Phantom fighter jets may affect the health and behavior of pregnant horses kept near military bases. Simulated bursts of jet noise will reverberate through barns for nine months to determine their effect on eight pregnant, thoroughbred and saddlebred horses, researchers at the University of Florida said Monday. Another control group of eight pregnant mares will not be exposed to the flyover din. ``Heavily pregnant mares may be more susceptible to the stress of aircraft noise,'' said Dr. Michelle LeBlanc, a veterinarian. ``One of the common complaints the Air Force receives is that abortions seem to occur more often in mares subjected to low-flying aircraft.'' LeBlanc, associate professor at the University of Florida's Department of Large Animal Clinical Sciences, said about 50 studies on the effects of aircraft noise on animals have been conducted since the arrival of sonic boom in the 1950s. ``But because many studies weren't considered scientifically valid, the Air Force sought additional research with domestic animals,'' she said. The study is funded by the Air Force's unit of noise and sonic boom impact technology, she said. ``The reason for the research on domestic animals is to provide data on general and potential damage claims incurred by the Air Force as a result of farm or ranch overflights,'' said Maj. Michael Thompson, project manager of Air Force studies on sonic booms. LeBlanc said stress may affect the quantity and quality of antibodies produced in the mares' first milk, or the ability of foals to absorb the antibodies. ``Foals rely on these antibodies for protection against infectious diseases during the first few weeks of life, and they're only capable of absorbing these antibodies during their first 18 hours of life,'' she said. Each randomly timed noise burst will last three seconds, increasing about 50 decibels per second until it peaks at 120 decibels, comparable to the noise of a jackhammer, she said. Ultrasound will be used in monitoring the horses' heart activity and fetal movement, while video cameras record behavioral reactions to the sounds. LeBlanc aims to pinpoint the threshold of noise that prompts a frightened horse to bolt. The Air Force could use that information to determine when their aircraft should fly higher to diffuse the noise, she said. ``The horses in the study might get a little upset over the jet sounds at first, but they should adjust to it quickly,'' LeBlanc said. Next year, with the help of real Air Force jets, LeBlanc will continue the study using authentic flyover experiments, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill Soldier, Wound 9 in Attack on Helicopter
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas opened fire on a military helicopter Tuesday, killing a soldier and wounding nine of the people aboard, including four Salvadoran journalists, the army reported. Solicitor General Mauricio Eduardo Colorado was in the U.S.-made UH1H helicopter but was not hurt, an army news release said. Leftist rebels riddled the chopper with automatic weapons fire in Chalatenango, a northern province. Colorado was returning from Guancorita, a small town 55 miles north of San Salvador, where he investigated allegations that the air force had bombed and strafed the area, killing or wounding many civilians. The helicopter pilot and co-pilot, Capt. Sergio Calix Molina and Lt. Douglas Tochez Artiga, were wounded but managed to land in Guarjilla village and the wounded were taken to a San Salvador hospital, the army said. It did not identify the dead soldier or the other wounded. The journalists were identified as Samuel Arias, a television reporter for TCS Noticias; his cameraman, Manuel Diaz, and sound man, William Madrid, and Antolin de Jesus Herrera, a photographer for the newspaper Diario de Hoy. One of the journalists was in serious condition, the army said, but it did not identify him. Human rights groups say 73,000 people, most of them civilians, have been killed since the civil war began in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: `60 Minutes,' With Andy Rooney Back, Returns to Top 10
DOC.TEXT: Sparked by the return of suspended commentator Andy Rooney, ``60 Minutes'' jumped to fourth place last week in the A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings, according to figures released Tuesday. Helped by Walter Matthau's first appearance in a television movie and the Miss USA beauty pageant, CBS finished in second place for the week. But it was the re-emergence of ``60 Minutes'' _ beaten the week before by an hour's worth of ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' repeats _ that was probably the best news for the struggling network. Sunday's broadcast, in which Rooney discussed his abbreviated suspension and denied he was a bigot, had a 22 rating, easily beating ABC's competing ``Life Goes On.'' That series had an 8.9 rating, trailed by NBC's Disney movie hour, which averaged an 8.3 rating. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. On Feb. 8, Rooney was suspended for three months without pay after a gay-oriented magazine quoted him as making a racial slur. He denied he said it. CBS News president David Burke lifted Rooney's suspension Thursday. The ratings of ``60 Minutes'' slipped during Rooney's three-week absence, and the program on Feb. 25 dropped to 18th place in the ratings. For the week, NBC was first with an average prime-time rating of 14.4 to CBS' 13.1 and ABC's 12.4 Here are the Top 10 shows: ``Roseanne,'' ABC; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC; ``Cheers,'' NBC; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC; ``A Different World,'' NBC; ``CBS Sunday Movie _ The Incident,'' CBS; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC. ``The Incident'' starred Matthau as a small-town lawyer who defends a Nazi prisoner of war charged with murder. ``The 1990 Miss USA Pageant'' was No. 20 for the week with a 15.9 rating. On the other end, ABC's ``H.E.L.P.,'' about an elite rescue squad of New York, premiered at No. 79 for its Saturday, 8 p.m. time slot. ``Nasty Boys,'' in its second week for NBC, was tied for 52nd place with ABC's ``Elvis.'' ABC captured first place among the evening news shows for the eighth week in a row. Peter Jennings' ``World News Tonight'' had an average rating of 11.1, Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News'' was 9.8, and Dan Rather's ``CBS Evening News'' was 9.7. An NBC News special, ``A Day In the Life of the White House,'' featuring interviews with President and first lady Barbara Bush, was No. 62 with a 10.0 rating for Wednesday night. A repeat of ``The Simpsons'' was No. 36 and the highest rated Fox show for last week.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Witness Surrenders in Ohio
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with capture of missing witness, CORRECTS in lead to seven defendants, sted four. No pickup. STANDS for AM-BRF--Racial Attack.
DOC.TEXT: A missing prosecution witness in the trial of seven young whites accused of killing a black teen-ager who ventured into their predominantly white neighborhood surrendered Monday in Ohio. The witness, John S. Vento, gave himself up to FBI agents in Dayton, said Paul Mallett, who heads the bureau's operations in southern Ohio. Vento, who had been missing since December, is a key witness in the slaying of Yusuf Hawkins, 16, who was surrounded by a group of 30 whites and shot to death Aug. 23 when he went to the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to look at a used car. The FBI last week issued an arrest warrant for Vento as a material witness in the case. Earlier Monday, the trial judge reluctantly agreed to delay the start of proceedings until April 2 to give prosecutors time to locate Vento. The prosecution will have Vento held as a material witness and ready to testify in time for the April 2 trial ordered by Judge Thaddeus Owens, said Pat Clark, a spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney. Seven young white men are charged in the slaying _ six with second-degree murder and one with first-degree assault. Joseph Fama, 19, accused of firing the fatal shot, is in custody; the other defendants are free on bail.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd grafs of 2nd item to CORRECT second reference to Simpson to `she,' sted `he'
DOC.TEXT: A pair of pet pigs found themselves in the pokey for promenading down a street and stopping the traffic. Police took four hours to round up the pigs, and a goat that joined them, and took them to the pound Monday after officials at Homestead Elementary School complained they were blocking traffic. Officer Terry Simpson said she decided to rein in the trio because owner Marge Lampert had been ticketed a dozen times for failing to control her animals, and allegedly had not paid up. Lampert, an equipment operator at Elmendorf Air Force Base, said she bought the pigs at a state fair last year and her children named the cute and cuddly things Joseph and Miss Piggy. Now that they're grown, they've become too hard to hold, she said. ``I had hoped to confine them well and let the kids in the neighborhood experience farm animals without offending anyone,'' she said. ``I seem to have offended everyone. ``I'm not a real organized person, so sometimes I get more than I can handle,'' she said. She also owns four dogs, a cat and 15 tropical birds.

DOC.HEAD: Bonner Contends More Died in Nagorno-Karabakh Than in Beijing
DOC.TEXT: Yelena Bonner, widow of Andrei Sakharov, said Tuesday the Soviet action against ethnic unrest in the Caucasus cost more lives than the Chinese army crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in June. She is visiting Rome as a guest of the Socialist Party and commented during a news conference at party headquarters. Mikhail S. Gorbachev will go down in history ``not as the father of perestroika, but as the instigator of genocide,'' Bonner said. Trouble began between the neighboring Caucasus republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan two years ago over Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave in Azerbaijan whose population is predominantly Armenian. Soviet troops stormed Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, on Jan. 13 to stop ethnic fighting, and Soviet officials say more than 170 people died in the crackdown. Bonner did not say how many people she believed were killed. Hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of demonstrators were killed in June when the Chinese army crushed pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. Bonner also criticized Gorbachev's political reforms, suggesting the mass of Soviet people had lost faith in their president. ``I say this with sadness and regret,'' she said. Sakharov, a physicist largely responsible for the Soviet hydrogen bomb, won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1975 because of his long campaign for human rights. He died in December.

DOC.HEAD: State Permits Human Testing For AIDS Vaccine
DOC.TEXT: Human testing of a potential AIDS vaccine was approved Monday by state health officials, but researchers cautioned that development of a true vaccine will take years. The approval was the first for human trials of HGP-30 in the United States, according to the companies that developed the drug. Clinical trials will be held at San Francisco General Hospital and the University of Southern California Medical Center in Los Angeles, said Dr. James Kahn, who will conduct the San Francisco tests. The trials will begin in two to three months, he said. ``This is just a very preliminary stage,'' said Kahn, who called HGP-30 a ``candidate'' vaccine. ``It's the first step, but it's not something that's going to cure AIDS, and it is not intended as a cure or treatment for AIDS.'' The trials were approved by the state Department of Health Services' Food and Drug Branch, said Tom Hazlet of the branch. In the tests, 24 healthy people who test negative for human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, will receive escalating doses of HGP-30 and be monitored for at least a year. Doctors will try to determine the vaccine's toxicity and see if it causes the body to produce antibodies to the virus, Kahn said. Another potential vaccine for the incurable disease is being tested at the National Cancer Institute in Washington, D.C., Kahn said. Experts in the field say tests of a potential vaccine for an AIDS-like disease in monkeys also shows promise for the development of a treatment that could prevent AIDS in humans. HGP-30 targets for destruction a core protein of HIV. The vaccine is designed to trigger antibodies to the protein, which is found in all strains of the AIDS virus, according to Alpha 1 Biomedical Inc. of Washington and CEL-SCI Corp. of Alexandria, Va., which developed the vaccine. HGP-30 is the first potential vaccine to be tested in humans where the active component is a completely synthetic molecule, the companies said in a news release. Because the vaccine lacks live or dead virus, there is no chance that HGP-30 could cause AIDS infection, the companies said. Kahn, assistant professor of medicine at the University of California-San Francisco and a member of the AIDS-Oncology Division at the university-affiliated San Francisco General, said most researchers believe it will be five to 10 years before an effective AIDS vaccine is developed. By the end of last month, the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta had recorded a cumulative total of 121,645 cases of AIDS in the United States, with 72,580 deaths, or 60 percent of all cases.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Walters to Interview Bryant Gumbel
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Walters, co-anchor of ABC's ``20-20,'' will conduct a rare interview of Bryant Gumbel, co-host of NBC's ``Today'' show, for the March 16 edition of her program, ABC News said Tuesday. Walters' interview with Gumbel, whose show has trailed ABC's rival ``Good Morning America'' in the ratings for the past eight weeks, is the latest instance of one network anchor interviewing another. Bob Costas, whose late-night NBC show last month featured his interview with ABC ``Nightline'' anchorman Ted Koppel, himself recently was interviewed by Dick Cavett for the ``The Dick Cavett Show'' on cable television's CNBC. That program is to be shown Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Scores U.S. Efforts at Demobilizing Contras
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Mrs. Chamorro statement, INSERT 2 grafs after 7th `It was'; picks up 8th pvs, `The Sandinistas...' ^By FILADELFO ALEMAN
DOC.TEXT: Outgoing President Daniel Ortega criticized the United States and Honduras on Tuesday for failing to help demobilize the Contra rebels. ``Why has the government of the United States delayed ordering the transfer of humanitarian funds to the United Nations or the Organization of American States to speed up demobilization and repatriation of the Contras?'' Ortega said in a speech. ``Why is Honduras delaying a decision to expel the Contras from its territory?'' he said. There are an estimated 4,000 Contras inside Nicaragua and thousands more in camps in southern Honduras, just across the border from Nicaragua. Ortega, whose leftist Sandinista government has been fighting the U.S.-supported Contra rebels during eight of its 10{ years in power, spoke before U.S. and Latin American publishers at a meeting of the Inter American Press Association. Also on Tuesday, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who defeated Ortega in elections Feb. 25, traveled to the Costa Rican city of Liberia for talks with President Oscar Arias. It was her first trip abroad since she was elected, and she praised Arias for a plan he devised in 1987 that earned him the Nobel Peace Prize and eventually led to the Nicaraguan elections. Mrs. Chamorro asked Arias to endorse her proposal that Central America declared a demilitarized zone. ``I want your valued support, as winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, for my proposal that the presidents of Central America sign an agreement declaring Central America demilitarized, to be signed by the six countries of the isthmus and endorsed by all Latin American countries,'' she said. The Sandinistas have recently taken a harder line against the Contras, saying they will not permit the dismantling of the Sandinista Army unless the Contras are demobilized before Chamorro takes office April 25 for a six-year term. But Contra leaders have balked at the idea of breaking up their forces immediately, saying they will hand over their weapons to Mrs. Chamorro's government only after it takes office to ensure they won't be harassed by the Sandinista military. The government declared a ceasefire following the elections, but Contra groups have been moving among the population in several towns in the interior and there were firefights this week with the Sandinista Army near the northern city of Matagalpa. ``The strengthening of the democratic process in Nicaragua will depend on the maturity of the U.S. government, of those who govern and those who are governed here, and on the attitude of the government of Honduras,'' Ortega said. Ortega urged the United States to assume a ``responsible attitude,'' and accused the Contras of being ``bent on revenge.'' ``They think the time has come to collect dues, to chop heads,'' he said. As one of his last acts in office, Ortega said he was sending a bill to the national assembly abolishing a decade-old news censorship law that will also permit the establishment of private television stations _ both by the Sandinistas and sympathizers of the 14-party coalition headed by Mrs. Chamorro, the United National Opposition. On Monday, Ortega had warned of renewed fighting if Chamorro's government enrolls former guardsmen or Contra rebels in Nicaragua's armed forces, controlled by Sandinista militants. ``A national war will break out,'' said Ortega at a rally of hundreds of students in Managua inaugurating the scholastic year. Both Ortega and Mrs. Chamorros have been calling on the Contras to disband immediately. The United States has also urged such demobilization, saying the little nonlethal aid it now provides them is about to end. In Tegucigalpa, Honduras, Foreign Minister Mario Carias Zapata on Tuesday said repatriation talks were continuing.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says He Lied, Disputes Witnesses
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge accused of using his office to do favors for convicted felons testified Tuesday that he lied when he told a lawyer he had disclosed a wiretap to its target. In his second day on the stand, U.S. District Court Judge Robert Aguilar also accused a series of prosecution witnesses of lying or being mistaken in saying they had held conversations or meetings with him. The witnesses included a former lover, a former secretary, a friend who was secretly cooperating with the FBI and a deputy U.S. marshal. The judge denied every accusation against him: that he had tried to influence criminal cases by approaching fellow judges; that he helped his former secretary remain a fugitive; that he twice disclosed a wiretap to its target; that he lied to the FBI; and that he told a witness to lie to a grand jury. Aguilar, 58, of San Jose, is charged with eight felonies, including a charge that he used his office as a ``racketeering enterprise'' to obstruct justice, the first such accusation against a federal judge. A judge since 1980, he faces a prison sentence of up to 55 years if convicted. He also could be removed from office by Congress, regardless of the verdict. In asserting that he had lied in the past, Aguilar was seeking to defuse potentially damaging prosecution evidence: a secretly made tape recording of a luncheon meeting in which he said he had relayed word to Abe Chapman, an elderly relative by marriage, that he was being wiretapped. Aguilar is charged with twice revealing the tap to Chapman, in August 1987 and February 1988. On Monday, he denied knowing that Chapman was being wiretapped. But in May 1988, attorney Ed Solomon, a friend and former classmate of Aguilar's, agreed with the FBI to wear a tape recorder to two meetings with the judge. On one of the tapes, Aguilar said he had relayed word to Chapman about a wiretap so that he would call on pay phones in the future. That ``was not a true statement,'' Aguilar testified Tuesday. ``I was bragging to Ed Solomon ... trying to make him feel better,'' the judge said, recalling that Solomon had appeared distraught about an FBI investigation. ``What I've said here under oath was absolutely the truth.'' Aguilar also testified about his involvement in the case of Rudy Tham, a former Teamsters leader who was represented by Solomon in seeking a new trial on a 1980 embezzlement conviction. Aguilar testified that he and Solomon had never discussed Tham's case. Aguilar is accused of trying to influence U.S. District Judge Stanley Weigel to rule favorably in the case. The prosecution contends he told Solomon to lie to the grand jury about their discussions on the case, and that he lied when he denied to the FBI that he had discussed the case with Solomon. ``I have never discussed the Tham case with Ed Solomon, never discussed the merits of the case,'' Aguilar said. He said their conversations involved only procedural aspects of the case, such as how to file a motion for a hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Jury Pool Filling Rapidly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs on Watergate-Iran-Contra juror after 10th graf, Reagan's videotaped
DOC.TEXT: The pool of prospective jurors for John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial grew to 35 Tuesday, including a woman who campaigned for Jesse Jackson and another familiar enough with the case to know former President Reagan had refused to turn over his personal diary. Eleven people were disqualified, including a retired CIA research analyst who conceded the agency had made mistakes, ``but not very many.'' On the second day of the jury selection process, U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said, ``I think we can do with 45 people'' before proceeding with choosing a panel of 12 jurors and six alternates. He said he expects to fill the pool by midday Wednesday and have opening statements on Thursday morning. Of the 35 accepted so far, 27 are women and eight men. Under questioning by the judge, the secretary who has campaigned for Jackson said she could be impartial, adding that she had once sent a get-well card to Nancy Reagan when she was sick. An employee at the University of the District of Columbia, she had seen Poindexter aide Oliver North on television testifying about shredding documents. ``I knew he (North) had a secretary and she sneaked out with documents on her person,'' said the woman. But she added that she ``wasn't familiar with Mr. Poindexter.'' A bridal consultant who became part of the jury pool said she recalled that Poindexter was North's boss, but little else. She said she heard that Reagan had refused to turn over to Poindexter his ``diary or private letter book and a video was offered instead.'' Reagan's videotaped testimony taken Feb. 16-17 will be shown at Poindexter's trial, said Richard Beckler, lawyer for Reagan's former national security adviser. Reagan and the Bush administration invoked executive privilege in refusing to turn over 36 of Reagan's diary excerpts to Poindexter. Greene is expected to rule on the question at some point. Also sent into the jury pool was a retired Defense Department employee who got the Watergate scandal mixed up with the Iran-Contra affair. The prospective juror, a woman who worked at the Army Materiel Command in Alexandria, Va., said Oliver North's trial last year was ``abot the tapes. He had so many tapes he did erase, Oliver North and secretary.'' During Watergate, then-President Nixon's secretary Rose Mary Woods said she might have accidentally erased a portion of one taped conversation. The tape in question was of a conversation between Nixon with his chief of staff, H.R. Haldeman, about how to handle the spreading FBI investigation of the Watergate scandal. Disqualified from the pool was a retired CIA research analyst who spent 25 years at the agency and said she didn't want to discuss her work. She said she has ``no firm opinions about'' whether ``right and wrong'' was done in the Iran-Contra affair. Asked whether she could be impartial if there was evidence at the trial that the CIA had done something wrong, the woman said, ``The CIA has made mistakes'' over the years, ``but not very many.'' Another potential juror was disqualified after saying she thought Poindexter had been involved in ``doing something that he shouldn't have done.'' ``I didn't think it was right; in fact, I knew it wasn't,'' said the woman, a retiree who had worked for the U.S. Air Force. Poindexter's low public profile, compared with keen public awareness of North, is making it a relatively simple task to select a jury for Poindexter's trial. It took more than a week to select a jury last year for North's trial because so many prospective jurors were familiar with testimony he had given Congress in 1987 under a grant of immunity from prosecution. Poindexter is under indictment on charges of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. The charges relate to allegations that Poindexter's covered up North's secret resupply network to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua and to allegations that Poindexter's lied concerning a November 1985 shipment of Hawk antiaircraft missiles to Iran.

DOC.HEAD: President Signs Anti-Dropout Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a bill Tuesday to renew funding for model programs to reduce the number of school dropouts. Currently, the graduation rate for 18-year-olds is only about 72 percent. ``This alarming situation can be turned around,'' Bush said in a statement. Together with the nation's governors, Bush has set a goal of increasing the graduation rate to at least 90 percent by the year 2000. The bill appropriates $50 million for each of fiscal 1990 and 1991 for the program.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary, Bulgaria Join West in Rights Votes on Cuba and China
By HANNS NEUERBOURG
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: In votes without precedent in U.N. history, two reform-minded East European countries sided with Western delegations on resolutions dealing with the human rights situation in Cuba and China. A U.S.-initiated measure critical of practices under President Fidel Castro was passed 19-12 in the U.N. Human Rights Commission, with Hungary and Bulgaria among those voting in favor while the Soviet Union cast a dissenting ballot. Poland and Czechoslovakia, attending as non-voting observers, added to the Havana government's isolation by co-sponsoring the text introduced by U.S. chief delegate Armando Valladares, a former Cuban political prisoner, Hungary and Bulgaria also joined the West in opposing a proposal by Pakistan that no action be taken on a mildly worded resolution on China. The resolution included a guarded reference to last June's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing. However, the Pakistani motion narrowly carried, the result of intensive Chinese lobbying among Third World members of the 43-nation organization. The U.S. resolution on Cuba had been gradually softened following consultation with other Western delegations. Valladares hailed its approval as a ``victory for the fight for human rights around the world.'' It expresses ``concern'' at reports that witnesses who testified before commission members visiting Cuba on an unprecedented fact-finding mission in 1988 were subsequently subject to arrest, harassment and other reprisals. Cuba is called upon to honor its guarantees not to take any action against these witnesses and to provide the commission ``with a response to unanswered questions'' put to the Cuban authorities by mission members. The resolution asks U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to provide the commission with results of contacts he promised to maintain with Cuba on the issue. The 1988 mission, which had been invited by Cuba, compiled a largely noncommittal report listing allegations of gross violations together with denials by Havana and claims of a clean record. Cuban Deputy Foreign Minister Raul Roa Kouri, addressing the commission before the rollcall vote, said the resolution was ``totally unacceptable.'' He branded it ``yet another U.S. attempt to obtain through pressure what it could not obtain through aggression by mercenaries, terrorist infiltration, murder attempts on our leaders and economic blockade.'' Valladares told reporters that Cuba now would have to give comprehensive answers to questions on basic freedoms, as well as to allegations of torture and other abuses involving hundreds of people. He said the U.S. move obtained a majority because ``no one wants to be associated with Cuba'' after what happened to Nicolae Ceausescu, the Romanian Communist dictator who was overthrown and executed last December. ``Romania could happen all over again in Cuba, but even worse,'' he said. ``I am very optimistic, I think the days of Latin America's last dictatorship are numbered.'' Czechoslovakia's Zdenek Pagac told the meeting before the vote that some may call his country's support for the resolution a ``historic moment but our position is not surprising.'' He said defense of human rights was ``free of ideological aspects'' under the new Prague government, which is led by non-Communists. The Soviet delegate limited his comment to voicing regret at ``politicizing'' the issue. At Tuesday's session, U.S. Ambassador Morris B. Abram denounced a 15-year-old General Assembly resolution equating Zionism to racism as a ``disgrace'' and urged it be scrapped. He told the commission Zionism ``has been a model for all honorable national liberation movements'' and said Zionism and racism are ``total contradictions.'' Abram, who has held high posts in American Jewish organizations, said the sponsors of the 1975 resolution tried to ``classify ... Jewry and the Jewish state as infected with criminality, and thus to replay Hitler's themes'' that led to the Holocaust. ``The United Nations was founded in the wake of the defeat of Hitler's crimes. It would be an awful twist of history if the United Nations became the executor of Hitler's prophecy,'' Abram said.

DOC.HEAD: OAS Chief Says 50 Observers Will Stay through Changeover
DOC.TEXT: The Organization of American States will keep a team of observers in Nicaragua until Violeta Chamorro takes over as president from Daniel Ortega on April 25, OAS Secretary-General Joao Baena Soares said Tuesday. Baena Soares praised Nicaraguan political parties for their cooperation with OAS observers in the country's Feb. 25 election and reported to the organization that results were ``within what the OAS polls anticipated.'' A preliminary report by Nicaragua's Electoral Council gave Chamorro 55.2 per cent of the votes against 40.8 for President Daniel Ortega, the standardbearer of the Sandinista Front. Baena Soares told the OAS Permanent Council that the 31-nation organization had sent 433 observers to 4,391 polling places as part of a highly sophisticated system of on-the-spot checks and computer tabulation that included an electric power plant to be use in case of a black out in public services. The OAS team, the largest to verify the election, ``received the full cooperation of all the Nicaraguan competing parties and all nations of the hemisphere, which provided us with realiable specialists in each aspect on an electoral process,'' he said. The OAS team is being scaled down to about 50 until the transfer of power, he added. Baena Soares said the information he gave to the OAS Council will be follow up by a more detailed, written report. The OAS, in a joint operation with the United Nations, also is pushing for the dismantling of the U.S.-backed Contras, which have been resisting mobilization. The peace process supported by the OAS called for both free elections and the dismantling of the Contras.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Break Provided Housing For Thousands
DOC.TEXT: A partnership of the nation's largest corporations used an endangered tax credit last year to invest $77 million in low-income housing for 2,000 families, advocates of the tax break said Tuesday. That investment was used by non-profit, community-based corporations as a lever to start providing $200 million in rental housing in 15 cities, the National Equity Fund said. The fund invested the money, which came from 35 corporations. Representatives of the Chicago-based fund were joined at a news conference by Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., and Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y. Mitchell and Danforth have introduced legislation to make the Low Income Housing Tax Credit permanent. Rangel is a sponsor and prime mover behind the original legislation in the House. ``Tax policy has had a negative effect by and large in the 1980s,'' said Danforth, referring to the impact of tax-policy on low-income housing programs. ``It's time to turn it around.'' The credit was made part of the 1986 tax reform. It was extended last year was extended to the end of 1990. The Bush administration has proposed adding another year. NEF is an affiliate of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a private, non-profit group dedicated to community development. The LISC was created by the Ford Foundation in 1979. The first partnership created under the auspices of NEF invested $14.25 million from 13 corporations to create 857 units of housing. NEF said it raised $51 million from 40 corporations last year to develop over 2,000 units of housing worth over $150 million.
