According to NEF, the credit creates 100,000 units of low-income housing each year. The credits are awarded over 10 years. The 1989 fund covers projects in Boston; Cincinnati; Hartford, Conn.; Healdsburg, Ca.; Indianapolis; Kalamazoo, Mich.; Kansas City, Mo.; Los Angeles; Miami; Minneapolis; Newark, N.J.; New York; Philadelphia; Raleigh, N.C.; and St. Paul, Minn. Corporate investors are: AT&T; Aetna Life & Casualty; American Express; Ameritech; Bank of America; Banc One Mortgage Corp.; Bankers Trust New York Corp.; CBS; Capital Cities@ABC; Chase Manhattan Bank; Chemical Bank; City National Bank; Consolidated Edison Company of New York; The Continental Corp.; The Dime Savings Bank of New York; Fannie Mae; Freddie Mac; Great Western Bank; Hallmark Cards; HomeFed Bank; INB National Bank; J.C. Penney; J.P. Morgan and Co.; Kaufman and Broad Home Corp.; Knight-Ridder; National Westminster Bank; New York Life Insurance; Payless Cashways; Pfizer; Prudential Insurance; Republic National Bank of New York; The St. Paul Companies; The Stanley Works; Williamsburgh Savings Bank; and Xerox Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Disrupt Council Meetings in England; 21 Arrests
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 21 anti-tax demonstrators outside a community council meeting in Bristol on Tuesday, and protests brought council business to a halt in Norwich and Maidenhead. Councils deliberating their assessments under the new community tax also were disrupted in Bradford, Birmingham, Exeter and Worcester, according to Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. Four constables were injured during five hours of protests in Bristol, police said. Scuffles broke out as the crowd learned that the council had set one of the highest taxes in England. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government introduced the new tax, which is assessed against every adult, to replace the property tax. The tax is intended to make it clear to voters whether their local council members are frugal spenders. The average English household will pay $280 more under the new tax than under the property tax, an increase from $837 to $1,112, British Broadcasting Corp. radio reported Tuesday. However, the charges vary widely from community to community. ``The lesson will be learned that it is the Labor (opposition party) authorities which are the high spenders and it is the Conservative ones which look after their constituents,'' Mrs. Thatcher told the House of Commons on Tuesday. However, Mrs. Thatcher's popularity has suffered because of the new tax and many people have joined the revolt. The council in Norwich abandoned its meeting when about 200 people in the public gallery shouted abuse, tossed rubbish and tore up council agendas. ``The council chamber looked like it had been covered in snow,'' said council member Chris Wright. An estimated 2,000 demonstrators outside chanted ``No Poll Tax'' and ``Thatcher Out.'' It is called a poll tax after a tax levied on individuals in the Middle Ages. The Maidenhead council also halted its meeting when a crowd of about 700 stormed the building. Police reported two arrests. At least 40 protesters forced their way into a reception area, and television coverage showed them flinging documents out the windows. ``It is a night for the people. We have occupied the council chamber,'' said Graham Roberts, leader of the Maidenhead Against the Poll Tax group. ``The tumbrels of the people are coming to sweep them away.'' In the northern city of Birmingham, a Conservative party council member and two teen-age aides held doors shut to keep demonstrators out, according to Press Association. There were no arrests. Hand-clapping protesters disrupted a hearing in Bradford, where teachers also walked out Tuesday to protest spending cuts made to keep taxes down.

DOC.HEAD: Rain, Snow and Frozen Rain Make for a Cold, Damp Day
DOC.TEXT: Much of the nation was cold and damp Tuesday, with snow covering parts of Wyoming, Colorado, South Dakota, Utah and New Mexico. Snow and rain also drenched the East Coast. By mid-morning Tuesday, there were snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches across southeast Wyoming, with more than 18 inches of new snow across portions of the Laramie Mountains, west of Cheyenne. Overnight snowfalls for New Mexico included 9 inches at Chama and Brazos Lodge, 8 inches at Angel Fire, 6 inches at Taos, 5 inches at Star Lake and 1 inch at Gallup. By Tuesday morning, snowfalls ranged from 1 inch at Stapleton, Colo., to 14 inches at Telluride, Colo. In South Dakota, as much as 6 inches of snow fell Tuesday over and near the central and southern Black Hills. In Utah, the storm left 22 inches at Snowbird, 21 inches at Alta Lifts, 19 inches at Brian Head and 18 inches at Solitude. In the East, there were accumulations Tuesday morning of new snow ranging from 1{ inches at Harrison, N.J., and Newark, N.J., to 4 inches at Greenwood Lake, N.J., and about 3 inches in New York City. Tuesday afternoon, snow fell across southern New England, New York, New Jersey and northeast Maryland. Rain spread over northern Virginia and Maryland. Showers and occasional thunderstorms swept through central and north central Texas. Rain spread across much of Oklahoma, eastern and northern Kansas and southern Nebraska. Western Iowa and northern Nebraska also were hit with freezing rain. Snow extended from southeast Montana across Wyoming, western South Dakota, the Nebraska panhandle, western Kansas and eastern Colorado, and northern New Mexico. Snow was scattered over the mountains of central Washington with snow changing to rain over the northern Pacific Coast. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 14 degrees at both Caribou and Limestone, Maine, to 85 degrees at Sarasota, Fla. The low temperature for the nation Tuesday morning was 22 degrees below zero at Houlton, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Sets Ultimatum for Approval of Baker Proposals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 3 grafs after 6th graf, ``We demand ... UPDATING with Baker comment. Picks up 7th graf, In an ... with minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: Vice Premier Shimon Peres on Tuesday threatened to bring down the government unless Israel's Cabinet gives immediate approval to U.S. proposals for starting a dialogue with Palestinians. The decision-making inner Cabinet is scheduled to meet Wednesday, with Peres' center-left Labor Party and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc still at odds over the U.S. plan. Peres read an ultimatum after a 45-minute meeting of Labor Cabinet ministers at his office in Tel Aviv. He demanded a Cabinet meeting to decide whether to accept the plan, which the parties have been squabbling over since October. ``Labor ministers demand ... a discussion and decision on a positive answer to the questions U.S. Secretary of State (James A. Baker III) presented to Israel,'' it said. Peres told reporters he would consider a tie vote in the inner Cabinet, which has six members of each party, as a negative response that would ``bring an end to the government.'' ``We demand a vote and a decision tomorrow,'' he said. Baker urged Israel to approve his terms for talks or run the risk of coming to a dead end in Mideast peace efforts. He told reporters in Washington on Tuesday, ``Without a dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians we can never move forward to peace.'' Baker said he believed Israel was ``working hard and in good faith to resolve those problems and we certainly hope they are successful.'' In an interview on Israel Television, Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Likud declined to say if the issue would come to a vote Wednesday or even be discussed. But he said in an Israel radio interview, ``I don't see any reason for dismantling the government. I think, I hope and I expect that we can unite around the positions presented by Likud ministers.'' Baker has presented proposals aimed at meeting Palestinian demands that exiled Palestinians and Arabs from east Jerusalem be eligible for the negotiating team sent to Cairo. The key issue is Likud's refusal to accept any Palestinian who lives in Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem, home to 140,000 Palestinians. Shamir claims such respresentation would threaten Israel's claim to sovereignty over the unified city. The PLO has demanded that east Jerusalem be the capital of an independent Palestinian state. On Monday, Likud demanded that Labor approve its call for the exclusion of all east Jerusalem residents. It also insisted on Labor's support in abandoning the talks if the PLO was found to be involved in negotiations in any way. Labor's statement Tuesday reaffirmed the party's commitment to ``the status of Jerusalem as the sovereign and united capital of Israel,'' and stressed that ``in accordance with the government's guidelines, Israel will not conduct negotiations with the PLO.'' But the ministers said they ``completely reject any attempt by Likud'' to deviate from the original May 14, 1989, peace plan, which made no mention of barring East Jerusalem residents. In calling for a showdown, Peres was backed by Labor's No. 2 man, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, whose hawkish views are often closer to Shamir's positions. Labor said it would convene a meeting of its Cabinet ministers immediately after the inner Cabinet session Wednesday. A decision to leave the government would have to be approved by the party's bureau and then by the meeting of its central committee, set for March 15. If the Cabinet approves the Baker proposals, the United States would be expected to invite the foreign ministers of Israel and Egypt for a meeting to prepare for the Cairo talks. Among the outstanding tasks would be naming a Palestinian delegation, a contentious issue since Palestinians insist that the PLO pick the negotiators. The Cairo meeting would discuss Israel's plan for elections in the occupied territories, the scene of the Arab uprising in which 659 Palestinians and 43 Israelis have been killed since December 1987. Palestinians would be elected to negotiate a limited autonomy scheme for their 1.7 million brethren in the occupied lands. Both ideas are a compromise with Palestinian demands for a clear PLO role in peace talks and an independent state in the occupied territories with east Jerusalem as its capital.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Says He, Six Cabinet Ministers Received Recruit Money
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said Tuesday that he and six members of his new Cabinet had received more than $300,000 in donations from Recruit Co., the information service conglomerate at the center of an influence-peddling scandal. ``All of these donations had been received before the Recruit Co. became the target of public criticism,'' Kaifu said during questioning by opposition legislators in Parliament. ``They present no problem in terms of the (governing Liberal Democratic) Party's internal standards, either.'' Last spring, two prime ministers resigned over their ties to the company, and a major election loss by the ruling Liberal Democratics was blamed in part on voters upset with politicians' receipt of funds from Recruit. Three Cabinet members also resigned who were linked to the scandal, and the party's senior leaders were forced to adopt a low profile, clearing the way for the rise of Kaifu, who came to office with a clean image and promises of political reforms. Kaifu told a Socialist Party questioner that seven ministers in his Cabinet, formed last Tuesday, had received a total of $325,300 in donations from Recruit, which has been accused of trying to buy influence, mainly with sales of cut-price stock to influential politicians and businessmen. Kaifu listed himself as the largest recipient, with $96,000, followed by Director General of the National Land Agency Moriyoshi Sato, who had received $93,300. Donations to Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, Labor Minister Shunpei Tsukahara, Transport Minister Akira Oho and Director General of the Hokkaido and Okinawa Development Agencies Tamisuke Sunada ranged from $4,000 to $59,300, he said. Sakamonto told a news conference all the donations were legal. ``Our party decided last year that we did not have to disclose ordinary political donations and the purchase of fund-raising party tickets,'' he said. ``As long as no one was asked to give favors nor has given any, I think they should be treated as ordinary donations.'' Kaifu had sought to keep politicians linked to the Recruit case or other scandals out of his administration. In forming his new Cabinet, after his party's Feb. 18 election victory, he showed unexpected assertiveness in resisting pressure from party elders to give Cabinet posts to two such men. In connection with the stock deals, which involved shares not yet offered for public sale, 12 politicians, public officials and Recruit executives have been indicted on bribery charges.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Italian Minister Discuss Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf, bgng: Andreotti had xxx with 2 grafs to UPDATE with toasts at state dinner. Picks up 18th graf pvs: He was ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti on Tuesday discussed the emerging new order in Europe and reaffirmed that the German-Polish border and all current borders must be respected. Andreotti, who has urged a larger role for all the NATO allies in discussions leading to German unification, hailed what he called ``the dawn of democracy in Eastern Europe.'' ``New balances lie on the horizon, full of promise, yet also fraught with problems,'' the Italian leader said after Bush welcomed him to the White House with military honors. ``By updating and reviving the spirit and the model of NATO and Helsinki, we must all together seize the challenges that are facing us,'' Andreotti said. Bush said the United States and Italy agree ``on the foundations of a new Europe'' and look to the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe ``to play a greater role in Europe's future, particularly in guiding the economic and political transformation of the rising democracies in Eastern Europe.'' Later, the White House announced the United States had accepted a West German proposal for a ``two-plus-four'' meeting of sub-cabinet officials to discuss procedures for more substantive talks on German unification. Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the meeting may be held March 14 in Bonn, but that the date and location were not definite. The two-plus-four are the two Germanys and the four Allied powers that defeated Nazi Germany in World War II _ the United States, Great Britain, France and the Soviet Union. The two-plus-four formula, agreed to by the four powers' ministers in Ottawa last month, has stirred concern in Rome and other capitals left out of the equation. Andreotti told Italian reporters after his White House talks that established institutions such as NATO should not be replaced by what he called a ``directorate.'' He said he favors convening the 16-nation NATO alliance before its customary meeting in May. A spokesman for Andreotti, Pio Mastrobuoni, said Bush assured the prime minister that the aim of the four powers' meeting would be to put an end to their special rights over Germany. Asked by a reporter at the outset of the Oval Office talks with Bush whether the two-plus-four formula gave Italy a sufficient voice in German unification, Andreotti said: ``It's not a problem which belongs to Italy. I think that all the member countries of the Atlantic alliance must handle together these problems. ``The specific problems related to Berlin must be handled by the four countries'' that won World War II, he said. The State Department said the two-plus-four formula would not be expanded to include Italy, Poland or any of the other smaller countries. Raymond Seitz, the assistant secretary of state for European and Canadian affairs, told reporters that Bush and Andreotti ``discusssed the question of borders and the need in an emerging European order that all borders are accepted.'' Seitz said Bush made ``abundantly clear ... that the two-plus-four mechanism is not regarded in any fashion as a substitute for a legitimate discussion of alliance concerns in NATO.'' Andreotti had lunch with Secretary of State James A. Baker III at the State Department and later returned to the White House for a black-tie state dinner, where Bush said, ``I can think of no time in modern history when our strong transatlantic partnership was more crucial.'' Andreotti, toasting Bush in return, called for ``a new solidarity ... between the United States and Europe.'' He reiterated his call for ``a broader framework for cooperation'' based upon the Helsinki formula and NATO to deal with a Europe where ``ideological and military confrontations wane.'' He was to address a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday and receive an honorary degree from Catholic University before departing Thursday for Latin America and stops in the Dominican Republic, Chile, Argentina and Brazil. Andreotti became prime minister in July for the sixth time, leading Italy's 49th postwar government. Italy will assume the presidency of the 12-nation European Community this July. Andreotti said in Rome last week that he did not fear that a united Germany would turn belligerent, but was concerned that interest rates could be driven up when West Germany tries to help East German development. Andreotti also met with U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, shelved a resolution calling on Germany to stick to its present borders, saying the rush of events made it unnecessary. In Bonn, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government moved to still the border controversy by unveiling a proposed parliamentary resolution saying a united Germany should sign a treaty with Poland guaranteeing it would not try to recover territory taken away after the war.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Sets off Legal Debate With Opinion that Ship Could Have Sunk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with testimony Tuesday concerning Hazelwood's sobriety at time of spill. Picks up 6th graf, `Some witnesses ...'
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood probably was drunk when his tanker ran aground and triggered the nation's worst oil spill, a toxicologist testified Tuesday. Richard Prouty, chief forensic toxicologist with the medical examiner's office in Oklahoma, said he calculated that Hazelwood's blood alcohol level would have been .14 percent at 12:05 a.m. on March 24, when the oil tanker ran aground on a reef in Prince William Sound. The legal limit in Alaska for operating a motor vehicle is .10 percent. The U.S. Coast Guard has a limit of .04 for operating a commercial vessel, but jurors were not told of the regulation because federal law is not involved in the state charges against Hazelwood. The question of whether Hazelwood was drunk has been described by his lawyers as the keystone of the case, because it reflects on whether he acted recklessly as captain of the ship. The defense contends Hazelwood wasn't drunk. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole asked whether Prouty would consider a person with a blood alcohol level of .14 to be impaired in reasoning and making decisions. ``It is my opinion they definitely would be impaired,'' Prouty said. Prouty was called as the final witness in the prosecution's case against Hazelwood, but his cross-examination was put off until Wednesday. Earlier, Hazelwoods' attorney suggested that an expert witness designed calculations to show the tanker would capsize, drawing a heated response from the witness. ``I did not contrive the calculations to show the ship would sink,'' said William Vorus, a professor of naval architecture at the University of Michigan. Hazelwood, 43, is charged with criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. The seaman from Huntington, N.Y., faces up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted. The Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude, devastating the rich wildlife in Prince William Sound. The most serious charge against Hazelwood is second degree criminal mischief, which involves acting recklessly in disregarding a known risk. Cole has focused on Hazelwood's behavior after the grounding to prove this charge, with witnesses saying the skipper ordered the engines turned on and the ship pointed forward. Some witnesses have said taking the ship off the rocks would cause it to capsize or sink. But in a brief filed with the judge Monday, defense attorney Dick Madson argued there was no risk that the ship would come off the reef and Hazelwood could not have disregarded a risk that didn't exist. Vorus acknowledged he did not figure into his calculations any actions the crew of the stranded tanker might have taken to prevent sinking if the ship got off a jagged reef that hung it up and ruptured its tanks. ``There was no indication the crew was doing any of the things you indicated,'' he told attorney Michael Chalos. ``And there was no indication the vessel was coming off the reef, either, was there?'' asked Chalos. ``Under a slightly different situation, the vessel could have come off the reef,'' said Vorus. But like other prosecution experts who testified before him, Vorus agreed the ship was stuck solidly on Bligh Reef and the scenario he created in which the ship was refloated and sank was hypothetical. ``Do you agree it couldn't come off the reef?'' asked Chalos. ``Obviously, it didn't come off and that's as good a proof as any that it wouldn't come off,'' Vorus said. Before he concluded his testimony, Vorus attempted to make a strong protest of the defense attorney's implications that the witnesses' calculations were scripted by the prosecution. ``I object to the accusations that are being put forth here,'' declared the witness. ``I think the state conducted itself most properly in this case.'' Chalos objected that ``the witness is making a speech,'' but Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone allowed the comments to stand. Vorus earlier was allowed to give jurors an elaborate account of a computer simulation of the grounding. The witness, who said his engineering firm was being paid $40,000 by the state for its work on the Hazelwood prosecution, gave a scholarly account about how a ship stays afloat. He calculated that the Exxon Valdez would have capsized 75 minutes after grounding if it was freed from the reef in 10 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Ron Kovic Decides Against Congressional Bid, Associate Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Kovic confirming he won't run, picks up 7th graf, ```I'm real ...'
DOC.TEXT: Ron Kovic, the disabled Vietnam veteran whose life was chronicled in the film ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' said Tuesday he will not run for Congress. Kovic gave no explanation for his decision against challenging conservative Republican Rep. Robert Dornan of Garden Grove, saying only in a statement released by an assistant: ``I've decided not to run.'' Kovic, 43, nominated for an Oscar for co-writing the screenplay for the Oliver Stone film, was recruited by Democrats to run for the seat held by conservative Republican Robert Dornan of Garden Grove. The filing deadline for candidacy is Friday afternoon. The first word that Kovic was not running came in a telephone call he made Tuesday morning to Tim Carpenter, an organizer for the group Peace Politics who helped with Kovic's exploratory campaign for the Orange County congressional seat. ``He said, `I'm sorry, but I'm not going to do it,''' said Carpenter. ``I said, `I wish you would. But I look forward to working with you sometime in the future.''' ``I'm real disappointed,'' said county Democratic Chairman Michael Balmages, who had not talked to Kovic but was told by ``two good sources'' that Kovic was not running. Balmages said he would be talking to two or three other possible candidates who had been staying out of the running while Kovic was a possible candidate. Balmages would not offer any names. Dornan, whose strong support of defense projects earned him the nickname ``B-1 Bob,'' was not immediately available for comment. Tom Cruise, who played Kovic in ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' had intended to help Kovic campaign had Kovic decided to seek the position. Dornan took the possible Kovic challenge seriously, sending out 20,000 fund-raising letters that portrayed Kovic as a draft card burning ultra-liberal. Dornan wrote that ``Born on the Fourth of July'' offered a number of reasons to vote against Kovic. The film, based on a book by Kovic, traces his life from being a strong supporter of the Vietnam War to a disillusioned, anti-war activist. ``The movie shows Kovic in a panic and mistakenly shooting his corporal to death in Vietnam, visiting prostitutes, abusing drugs and alcohol and cruelly insulting his parents,'' the letter said. ``And this is a person the liberals want in the U.S. Congress. No way.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Mourn Basketball Star Who Died During Game
With AM-Gathers-Medical Questions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: REVISES crowd estimate in lead. SUBS last 2 grafs to reflect that jersey was giving during the Mass sted at the end, and DELETE reference to crowd applauding another time. Also moved sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA7,LA8
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 friends, family members and classmates gave basketball star Hank Gathers a final, thunderous ovation Tuesday on the same court where he played his last game. ``Every time I pick up a basketball for the rest of my life, Hank will be there with me,'' said Bo Kimble, Gathers' friend and teammate at Loyola Marymount University. Gathers died Sunday after collapsing during a game. ``It's so difficult right now to be here speaking of my beloved friend and brother,'' Kimble said during the memorial and Mass at the Catholic university. ``Hank, I love you so much, you mean the world to me. I know Hank would want to hear one more cheer here in his house.'' The crowd at Loyola Marymount's Albert Gersten Pavilion then rose to their feet, cheered and applauded for several minutes. Gathers' mother, Lucille Gathers, rushed to the front and hugged Kimble. Less than 72 hours earlier, Gathers had collapsed on the court. He was pronounced dead less than two hours later in a nearby hospital. Gathers, who fainted during a game on Dec. 9 and was diagnosed as having an irregular heart beat, was 23. The cause of death has not yet been determined. Gathers was remembered by the Rev. Thomas Higgins as a stirring player who battled to overcome an impoverished and disadvantaged background. After reciting a passage from Hamlet, Higgins turned the words to fit Gathers. ``What a piece of work was Hank,'' Higgins said. ``Hank was a very bright, intelligent man. He didn't have many educational advantages. It took courage to go to class, but Hank was a hero every day.'' Higgins led the crowd in a chant which grew louder and louder, ``We love you Hank, we miss you Hank, we commend you to God.'' The memorial, with Gathers' body in a silver casket draped with red and white flowers, was attended by Gathers' mother, his two brothers, his sister and his aunt. Lucille Gathers sat through much of the service being comforted by the Rev. David Hagan, a family friend who had been Gathers' mentor as a youngster in Philadelphia. Hagan said he hoped a memorial would be set up for Gathers' family and that the gym would someday bear Gathers' name. ``He broke his body and gave his blood for this university,'' Hagan said. Said Loyola coach Paul Westhead: ``For all of us to go on, that is the task. For Hank, the decision would be simple. `Clear the floor.' He would play today.'' During the Mass, Gathers' teammates presented the player's family with his scarlet and white jersey, No. 44, and a photograph of him making a slam dunk. After receiving the jersey, Gather's brother Derrick walked slowly up the aisle holding the jersey aloft.

DOC.HEAD: Philippines Court Frees Enrile, Accused in Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Enrile comment Wednesday, SUB 8th graf pvs, `After a...' with 3 grafs; pickup 9th graf pvs, `Rebellion is...'
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Tuesday granted bail to Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile, the opposition leader who was arrested in connection with December's bloody coup attempt, but it delayed ruling on the validity of a charge against him. The decision appeared to be a setback for President Corazon Aquino's government, which accused Enrile last week of ``rebellion with murder.'' The court said bail was granted because the chances were ``fairly remote'' that Enrile would flee the country. But the panel said it made no determination on whether rebellion and murder could be charged together. Enrile's lawyers argued that a 1956 Supreme Court decision nullified the joint charge. One justice, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the court would meet in a few weeks to review the 1956 ruling. Lawyers for Enrile said they expect the court to decide on the dual charge within the month. Late Tuesday, Enrile's lawyers presented his release order to authorities and he walked out of the suburban Northern Police headquarters, where he has been jailed since last week. ``Like a jailed bird that has just been set free, I'll fly away happily,'' Enrile said while signing autographs for police officers before boarding his bulletproof van. In a radio interview Wednesday, Enrile called the case against him ``unbelievable.'' He said the court's decision to release him without deciding the merits of the charge was done so as not to embarrass the government. ``I am praying for our president for enlightenment,'' Enrile said. ``She is in a very difficult situation because ... she does not know everything that is happening around her.'' After a three-hour hearing Tuesday, 10 justices voted in favor of granting $4,650 bail each to Enrile and two co-defendants, hotel owner Rebecco Panlilio and his wife. Four other justices voted to deny bail and one abstained. Rebellion is punishable by six to 12 years in prison, and defendants are eligible for bail. Murder carries a life sentence and bail is not allowed. Enrile and six others were indicted Feb. 27 in the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, in which at least 113 people were killed and more than 600 injured. Enrile denies any role. Some of Enrile's colleagues in the Senate criticized how the government handled the case. Sen. Ernesto Maceda, a lawyer, said Enrile should have been charged only with rebellion. ``Then maybe there would not have been any problems in turning Enrile into a martyr and a hero. The result of the administration's decision to file a complex case is really bad,'' Maceda said. Enrile was charged after witnesses claimed they saw former Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, a rebellion leader, at Enrile's home on the first day of the coup attempt. The Panlilios were also allegedly at the Enrile home on Dec. 1. During the hearing, about 200 Enrile sympathizers gathered outside the courthouse carrying signs reading ``Justice for Enrile.'' A group of anti-Enrile demonstrators rallied at another gate, and hundreds of armed police stood guard in the building and nearby streets. Inside, one of Enrile's lawyers, former Supreme Court Justice Serafin Cuevas, argued that the detention of the opposition senator is illegal and unconstitutional. ``We say so because the information under which he was charged and sought to be prosecuted is for an offense that does not exist in our law books,'' Cuevas added. Solicitor Gen. Francisco Chavez argued that the law does allow for a dual charge ``if a single act involves two or more grave or less grave felonies.'' He recommended that the court reconsider the 1956 ruling. ``What we have here is ... disgruntled members of the armed forces, military adventurists, plain and simply power grabbers.'' As defense minister, Enrile led the February 1986 mutiny that precipitated the ``people power'' revolution that swept Mrs. Aquino to power. He was fired nine months later after a failed coup by his followers. Among those indicted with Enrile was suspended provincial Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo. On Sunday, officials tried to arrest Aguinaldo in Tuguegarao, 250 miles north of Manila. But Aguinaldo's forces seized a hotel, taking government representative Brig. Gen. Oscar Florendo hostage and trapping several officials on the upper floors. Florendo was slain during fighting to retake the hotel and Aguinaldo fled during the clash. Military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa ordered troops to capture Aguinaldo ``at all costs.''

DOC.HEAD: IRS Summons Lawyers Over Naming of Clients Who Pay Large Amounts in Cash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to CORRECT in 2nd graf name of Sonnett's organization and in 5th graf letter sent in October sted November; UPDATES with confirmation in lead, comments from IRS official in Detroit; picks up 13th graf, ``It's very ...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service has served summonses on criminal defense attorneys around the country demanding that they reveal the names of clients who paid large lawyer fees with cash, an IRS official confirmed Tuesday. Lawyers argue that such disclosures would violate the fundamental right of attorney-client privilege. The attorneys were told to bring their financial records to IRS offices, according to Miami attorney Neal Sonnett, president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers. One lawyer served said an IRS agent told him that 900 lawyers were to receive summonses. ``We have heard from enough lawyers around the country to recognize that it appears to be a nationwide assault upon criminal defense lawyers,'' said Sonnett, whose organization knows of 12 lawyers who were served. ``... I think there's hundreds of attorneys who will go to jail for this.'' In October, the IRS sent letters to about 940 criminal defense attorneys requesting information on clients who paid them more than $10,000 in cash, Sonnett said. The letter, signed by Christopher J. Lezovich, an IRS official in Detroit, was sent to attorneys around the country giving them 30 days to identify the clients. It also included a warning that non-compliance would result in summonses. Tax collectors are acting under a disclosure law passed by Congress in 1985. The law, initially widely ignored, was aimed at exposing tax evaders, including major drug dealers who often transact business in cash. The original penalties for failure to disclose were only misdemeanors. But a year ago, Congress reclassified violations as felonies punishable by up to 10 years in prison. The summonses received by lawyers on Tuesday were signed by local IRS agents, Sonnett said. Lezovich said Tuesday night that the Detroit IRS office within the past 10 days wrote to field offices to advise them that agents might want to serve summonses against the lawyers who received the letters in October. ``We got some back, some provided the information, some didn't. Of those, some were selected for the first wave'' of summonses, he said. The Detroit IRS office is one of the agency's main computer centers, and it processes Form 8300, which among other things requests that filers list cash sums of at least $10,000 they have received. ``We anticipate that was just a first cut. This isn't going to be the end of it,'' Lezovich said of the summonses. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said his department took part in discussions last year with the IRS and lawyers' groups on the issue. ``It's very clear what the issue is here ... it grows out of concerns about drug payments,'' Runkel said. Sonnett said the summonses request that attorneys bring all their financial records, including bank statements and payment records, and not just bookkeeping related to the federal 8300 forms. ``I cannot conceive of a summons that is more blatantly a fishing expedition, which in effect asks the lawyer to turn over all his financial records to the IRS to roam through,'' he said. John Wesley Hall, a criminal defense lawyer in Little Rock, said revenue agent John W. Prather Jr. of Little Rock indicated that a nationwide move by the IRS was under way against 900 lawyers who refused to reveal the names of clients. Hall said he would not comply with the demand of the summons. The summons served on Hall directed him to bring all his bank records from 1987 to 1989 to the IRS office in Little Rock on March 27. ``Talk about over-reaching,'' Hall said, adding that he has had two clients pay him more than $10,000 each during the last three years. The summons involves one of them, he said. The privilege of the lawyer-client relationship is not only granted in state law, but also is a constitutional privilege, Hall said. ``I believe I am duty-bound not to provide the requested information,'' Hall said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Big Saudi Contributions Provided Most of Mrs. Reagan's Fund
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabians gave $2 million in two donations to Nancy Reagan's war on drugs, providing more than half of the money raised for her anti-drug fund, according to a report published Wednesday. Saudi King Fahd gave $1 million in 1985 and another $1 million came later from Mouaffak al Midani, a Syrian-Saudi businessman, The Washington Post said in its Wednesday editions. The newspaper said its report was based on documents and interviews with the people involved. The donations came at the same time the Saudi royal family was helping to finance the contras in their war against the Sandinistas in Nicaragua and as the administration was considering a weapons sale to the Saudis, the newspaper said. The Saudis were permitted to buy some, but not all, of the weapons they wanted. James Rosebush, who was chief of staff to the first lade at the time, said the Saudi donations were not intended to influence her or President Reagan. ``That it why we set up this arms's length fund,'' he was quoted as saying. Mrs. Reagan's fund raised another $1.6 million from smaller contributions and some tennis tournaments.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Jury Convicts Parliament Hill Bus Hijacker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details on Yacoub, quotes. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Tuesday convicted Lebanese-born Charles Yacoub on two charges arising from his hijacking of a New York-bound bus to Parliament Hill last April and holding police at bay for eight hours before surrendering. All 10 hostages on the bus eventually were released unharmed. After more than 17 hours of deliberations, the jury convicted Yacoub, 33, of forcible confinement, which carries a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison, and use of a weapon to commit an offense, which carries a minimum sentence of one year in prison and a maximum of 10 years. He was acquitted of charges of hostage-taking, which could have brought a sentence of life in prison; intimidation of Parliament and aggravated assault. Yacoub, who sat without emotion in court while the jury rendered the verdict, was held in custody to await sentencing. In his closing arguments in the Supreme Court of Ontario Monday, defense lawyer Michael Kastner contended that while Yacoub was responsible for the incident, he had no criminal intent because of his mental state. Psychiatrists described Yacoub as suffering from hypomania, a reaction to depression in which people are driven by uncontrollable thoughts to do irrational things. Justice Jean-Charles Sirois reminded jurors that some passengers testified they were terrified during the incident. ``I suggest to you that acts of violence were committed and that all passengers were traumatized by their confinement,'' Sirois said. Yacoub, who came to Canada from Lebanon in 1976 and lived in Repentigny, Quebec, near Montreal, used a .45-caliber pistol to pull off the hijacking. Kastner said that while he would have preferred a complete acquittal, the verdict was a victory because Yacoub was acquitted of the most serious charges. The lawyer indicated he will appeal the verdict and will also request bail. ``He's not a terrorist, '' Kastner said outside the courtroom. ``He's a jeweler from Montreal and was in a state of irresistible impulse when he committed this.'' The court was told Yacoub hijacked the Greyhound bus to bring attention to the fighting in war-torn Lebanon, his homeland. He commandeered a bus bound for New York City from Montreal at about noon on April 7 and forced the driver to take it to Ottawa, where it wound up on the front lawn of Parliament Hill. Initially nine passengers and the driver were held as hostages. Yacoub was demanding withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon, the court was told. Crown attorney Julianne Parfett said Yacoub was a terrorist and should have been convicted of all charges against him.

Many lenders will soon offer a new type of mortgage designed to appeal to home buyers who expect to move within seven years but want the security of a fixed-rate mortgage in case they don't. The loans, called two-step mortgages, are a cross between an adjustable-rate loan, where the rate can change every one, three or five years, and a traditional 30-year mortgage, where the interest rate does not change for the life of the loan. In the first step of the new mortgage, borrowers pay an interest rate up to three-eighths of a percentage point lower than on a 30-year, fixed-rate loan. After seven years, the rate is reset at 2.25 to 2.5 percentage points higher than the rate on 10-year Treasury notes. On a typical mortgage of $83,000, home buyers currently would save $23 a month, or $1,932 over the first seven years. However, the rate for the remaining 23 yearsof the mortgage likely would be somewhat higher than on a new 30-year loan taken out at readjustment time.

Opponents of a new federal law making it a crime to burn the American flag scored another victory when a second federal judge ruled that the statute runs afoul of the Constitution. But Monday's ruling by U.S. District Judge June Green here also gives proponents of a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning more political ammunition for their cause. President Bush endorsed the amendment route to undo last year's Supreme Court ruling that struck down a Texas flag-burning law, saying he was unsure that the statute Congress passed instead would survive court challenges. So far, Bush and other supporters of a constitutional amendment have been proven correct.

College students prefer periodic tests or term papers to big final exams and learn more from teachers who give them substantial, immediate feedback, a Harvard University study found. For example, a ``one-minute, low-tech, no-cost'' technique is to ask students at the end of each class for a quick, one-paragraph summary of what they learned, said Richard J. Light, author of the three-year study issued Monday. The study concludes that modest shifts in academic policies can create major improvements in college classrooms. Light, a professor at Harvard's Graduate School of Education and Kennedy School of Government, based the study on in-depth interviews with 360 Harvard undergraduates _ conducted by their fellow students _ and seminars that included faculty and administrators from Harvard and about 20 other institutions.

The rare ritual of exorcism, practiced twice by the New York Archdiocese in a year, is cloaked in mystery even for those most familiar with it. But priests say the movie ``The Exorcist'' depicted it pretty well. ``A lot of people think they know the answer, but my experience is nobody really does,'' said the Rev. John Nicola, a priest with the Washington Archdiocese who assisted at four exorcisms in Rome from 1973 to 1975. He added, ``Even psychiatrists who have no belief in the supernatural will tell you about cases.'' Catholic theologians expressed surprise Monday that Cardinal John J. O'Connor reported the two New York exorcisms. He made the disclosure during a Sunday sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral in which he said, ``Diabolically instigated violence is on the rise.''

Under different circumstances, Rosalinda Caoili would have been cleaning hotel rooms for tourists who provide Hawaii with its No. 1 industry and help sustain her family of six. ``I love working for the people,'' said Caoili, a housekeeper at the Sheraton Waikiki hotel for the past 14 years. Instead, she walked a picket line Monday while tourists at 11 hotels dealt with making their own beds and doing without prompt room service during the biggest hotel strike in Hawaii history. Up to 7,500 workers are on strike for better pay and benefits. ``We have to make a living,'' said Caoili, who makes about $8.50 an hour. ``If we don't do something, there will be a time when these people cannot afford to live here.''

DOC.HEAD: Celebrating Opera Sponsorship on Radio and TV
DOC.TEXT: Texaco's 50-year love affair with the Metropolitan Opera is being celebrated on both radio and television in concerts highlighting memorable moments from past performances. On radio, a live gala will take the place of the regular Saturday afternoon opera broadcast March 10 on the Texaco-Metropolitan Opera Radio Network. More than a dozen singers and six conductors will perform arias, ensembles and overtures that have been favorites during the 50 years of Texaco sponsorship. On television, the Public Broadcasting Service is offering ``Great Moments from the Met,'' culled from the nearly 50 operas televised since 1977, thanks to funding from Texaco. The show is being made available to PBS stations for use anytime during the March 1990 pledge drive. ``Great Moments'' is packed with as much vocal talent as anyone could ask for: Luciano Pavarotti and Placido Domingo are represented (twice each) and so are Kathleen Battle, Jessye Norman and Samuel Ramey. All are in excellent voice as they perform arias or duets from favorite roles. But, somehow, the whole adds up to considerably less than the sum of its parts. Part of the problem is that we can't appreciate these artists fully just hearing snippets of their work. Worse, even the snippets are interrupted by voice-overs as the performers give us their mostly superfluous views on what the characters they are portraying are all about. ``I'm going to do this opera until I can't,'' Pavarotti tells us eagerly, but uninformatively, about Donizetti's ``L'Elisir d'Amore.'' Miss Norman, discussing the title role of Strauss' ``Ariadne auf Naxos,'' discloses the surprising news that ``I always empathize with all of the characters that I sing.'' The unquestionable highlight of the telecast is Leontyne Price's farewell performance in 1984 of Aida's third act aria ``O patria mia.'' Not only was the soprano in unusually fine voice, her comments about the occasion, made in an interview during the last year, are deeply moving. ``For the rest of my life, whenever I view the tape of that final performance, I can't possibly be unhappy,'' the soprano says, tears welling in her eyes. ``... I really get goose pimples just thinking of it now.'' The other singer who comes off well is Teresa Stratas, heard in two wildly differing roles _ the gentle, tragic Mimi of Puccini's ``La Boheme'' and the hardbitten prostitute Jenny in the Kurt Weill-Bertolt Brecht ``Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny.'' Miss Stratas is worth listening to even when she's not singing. She brings a rare insight and intensity to her discussion of the operas. The program ends with another maddeningly incomplete excerpt, part of the farewell scene from Act Three of Wagner's ``Die Walkuere,'' sung by Hildegard Behrens and James Morris. This, as host F. Murray Abraham reminds us, is but a tease for the upcoming complete telecast of the Met's Ring Cycle on four consecutive nights in June. The Texaco radio concert can't match the TV production's star power, but it will have the advantage of being live and spontaneous. It's so spontaneous, in fact, that the final program was being nailed down a week before the broadcast. ``Originally, we were going to have recorded highlights and interviews, but as the anniversary season became more and more important, we decided to have the live concert,'' explained Charles Sheek, the Met's associate press representative. So what was printed on the season schedule as a performance of Gounod's ``Faust'' instead became a special event. The cast was assembled mostly from singers already in town for performances or rehearsals. ``We tried to choose artists in roles they became well known for, and some operas that have an important broadcast history,'' Sheek said. The concert will open with Met artistic director James Levine conducting the overture to Mozart's ``Le Nozze di Figaro,'' the very first Met opera broadcast under Texaco sponsorship in 1940. Other likely highlights: _ Marilyn Horne singing from Rosina's aria from Rossini's ``Il Barbiere di Siviglia,'' an opera the great mezzo is retiring from her repertory. _ Carol Vanness singing Fiordiligi's aria ``Come scoglio'' from Mozart's ``Cosi fan tutte.'' _ Dolores Ziegler, a recent Met debutante, singing the composer's aria from Strauss' ``Ariadne auf Naxos.'' _ Kurl Moll in Daland's ``Lobst du mein Kind'' from Wagner's ``Der Fliegende Hollaender.'' _ Ashley Putnam, Francisco Araiza and Samuel Ramey in the final trio from ``Faust.'' _ Dawn Upshaw singing ``No word from Tom,'' from Stravinsky's ``The Rake's Progress.'' The ever-present Placido Domingo will be taking part in this concert too _ but not as a singer. He's one of the six conductors who will take turns leading the Met orchestra.

Elsewhere in television ... CRITICS TAKE OVER SHOW: With Oscar-time looming in Hollywood, film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert will be the guest hosts of the March 23 ``Pat Sajak Show'' on CBS. The two also have taped a pre-Oscar special that will be syndicated to stations for broadcast starting Monday, says a spokeswoman for Buena Vista Television, their syndicator. The main event, the Oscar ceremonies, will be broadcast March 26 by ABC.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed PMs, March 7

For Release Thursday PMs, March 8, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Cable, ``Santa Barbara'' and Coproductions Part of New Effort
DOC.TEXT: In television ratings talk, the numbers are down _ way down _ for communism in the East bloc, and liberated audiences are ready for their first glimpse of ``Santa Barbara'' and other bourgeois decadence. Expatriate Soviets, American television executives _ including ``Garfield's'' animator _ and a cable company headed by a Polish concentration camp escapee are among those trying to grab a piece of the new marketplace. Others aren't sure Eastern European and Soviet audiences are worth the stretch for commercial television. ``They have no money, so it will be quite some time before it approaches a meaningful market,'' warned Colin Davis, the head of MCA Television International. ``Some have taken the approach of giving them a show and then sharing in advertising revenue. But there isn't much advertising because there isn't much in the way of consumer goods.'' Conduit Internationale Films has offered ``The Wonder Years'' and the soap opera ``Santa Barbara'' to newly established Polish commercial television Channel 2. The shows will begin airing this month, while Conduit tries to drum up international advertising. One prime-time minute on Polish television sells for $6,500, with the revenue to be split between Conduit, the program supplier and the Polish television firm. Conduit claims 10,000 television households in Poland. Robert Spinner, head of Conduit's advertising push, said he believes the television and consumer markets will grow simultaneously in Poland. ``I don't see it as a great market for BMWs, but for low-cost items such as cosmetics, soap, cold remedies and soft drinks, its a good market,'' Spinner said. While Conduit will seek to program standard airwave channels, another American company, Chase Enterprises of Hartford, Conn., is installing television cable lines in Poland and Hungary. Headed by Polish-born David Chase, who survived four World War II concentration camps including Auschwitz before escaping, the media company recently signed a deal giving it 70 percent of the Polish cable franchise, with 30 percent under control by a government consortium. ``In all likelihood, there will not be an immediate gold mine,'' conceded Arnold Chase, David's son. ``There are still problems to be overcome, and there are still changes going on, but the changes are for the positive.'' The son estimated the cost for cabling Poland at $900 million. The company last week also entered into a similar cable agreement with Hungary roughly estimated to cost $250 million. Soviet television has had a few experimental broadcasts of American programming, and Russian media experts in the United States predict there will someday be a market for commercial American shows in their country. But the current effort to establish Western television in the Soviet Union involves co-productions bringing American and West European cash in exchange for low-cost Soviet talent and studios. Film Roman, the Burbank, Calif.-based animation studio that turns out the ``Garfield'' cartoon series and specials, has signed an agreement with the Soviets establishing a 10,000-square foot studio outside Moscow. The move is the latest quest by American animation studios to find cheaper labor outside the country. In recent years, said Film Roman chief executive officer Phil Roman, film animation contracting has traveled from Japan to Korea to Taiwan. The Soviet animation artists will do backgrounds, ink, paint and camera work, with post-production, such as adding character voices and sound effects, handled back in the United States. ``They offer very high animation at a very reasonable price. They get paid two or three times what they are normally making and the cost is still below what it is for us in the Far East,'' said Roman. ``They want to be recognized outside the Soviet Union, and their country needs the hard currency.'' Television movies and miniseries planned for filming in the Soviet Union by American companies such as MGM@UA Television and Fries Entertainment are coordinated by a recently established USSR Film Service in Los Angeles. Efforts targeted for this year include a production on the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster and a miniseries on a joint U.S.-Soviet space flight to Mars. Yuri Spilny, who left the Soviet Union in 1972, heads the USSR Film Service office, making sure American producers get what they need from the Soviet Union's 39 studios. He believes American shows will find a way to Soviet viewers. ```Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous' _ now, that would be like a fantasy night for Soviet television,'' Spilny joked. ``It's just a question of time. They have a huge audience there ... An American film could be seen there by 200 million television viewers,'' said Ilmar Taska, who will produce the presentation of the best foreign film Oscar from Moscow for the 62nd annual Academy Awards. ``The same way as McDonald's has crossed over, American television will come to the Soviet network as well.''

The network will broadcast 17 prime-time games next season and 18 for each of the three seasons after that.

DOC.HEAD: Inventors Often Find Uphill Battle in Marketing Ideas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation.
DOC.TEXT: Entrepreneur Chris Graff wants the world to know he can build a better bedframe. But his trademarked Bedfellows, at first glance a collection of oddly twisted metal tubes, doesn't look like a bedframe. He believes that's his problem. Graff finds that largely indifferent manufacturers, sales reps and customers are suggesting he give the idea a rest. The path to his office door at Geste Corp. hasn't been beaten smooth. ``It's been pretty cold all across the board,'' he says. So it often goes when inventors and business venturers attempt to sell the public a new twist on an old idea, say patent attorneys and marketing experts. Customers are reluctant to change. Marketers are slow to see the new product's brilliance _ at least from the inventor's point of view. Those whose fortunes are tied to conventional products may battle the upstart competition. ``With a lot of innovative products, regardless of their performance and the benefits they provide, that is the wall the innovator keeps running up against,'' says Scott Jessup, who teaches entrepreneurship at the University of Notre Dame. In the world of sponsored research, each patentable idea may cost at least $5 million, Purdue University figures show. A corporate portfolio containing hundreds of patents may include only a few that actually make money. It's tough for the big fish, and even harder for the small fry. More than 40 years ago, Preston Tucker introduced an automobile that bore his name and offered motorists a four-door fastback with a rear engine and headlights that turned with the steering wheel. Only 51 cars were produced and Tucker's dream died, mired in Securities and Exchange Commission fraud charges that ended in an acquittal. Detroit inventor Robert W. Kearns developed intermittent windshield wipers in the 1960s only to discover automakers weren't interested. He went to court in the 1980s after the wipers became standard equipment and recently won a judgment against Ford Motor Co. Graff bought the patent rights to Bedfellows last year, and so far has sold little more than 250 sets for under $30. His chief competition is the standard Hollywood bedframe that sells for about the same price. There the similarities end. The bedframe doesn't look remotely like one. It more resembles sets of bicycle handlebars put together and fastened to the underside of a box spring mattress. Its advantages over a conventional frame, says Graff, are considerable. Bedfellows for a full-size boxspring weighs about six pounds, one-fourth the weight of a standard frame. That cuts into the considerable costs of shipping, and eases the chores of storage and store display, says Graff. Customers get a break, too. The assembled frame is easier to move, even with mattress and box springs, because the weight is distributed on eight points, instead of four. Its odd configuration eliminates exposed rails and legs _ ending the age-old menace of stubbed toes and barked shins. ``I've bumped my toe enough times in the middle of the night to realize there some merit there,'' Graff says. Jessup, president of an investment banking firm, concedes he's nearly lost a few toes on conventional bedframes himself. ``But would I go out and buy that? It would take a pretty significant experience to take that leap of faith.'' Disappointed expectations arise sometimes from unrealistic hopes, say patent and marketing experts. Some inventors wildly inflate the value of an idea that makes a product only marginally more salable. But Graff persists, looking for new marketing outlets. ``I've lost money so far, but you don't plan on making money this far into the project,'' he says. ``I'm convinced it's a good product. And once the consumer gets ahold of it...''

DOC.HEAD: Moneychangers Thrive in Post-Revolutionary Bucharest
DOC.TEXT: Foreigners tell of the tourist who visited Dracula's castle in Transylvania and was awakened the first night by a caped figure. He was terrified. He trembled as the figure approached, its mouth open, fangs dripping blood. It spoke: ``Change money?'' Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu imposed harsh penalties on money-changers, but they thrive on the flood of journalists and other foreigenrs who have arrived since he was overthrown and executed in December. One dollar buys 20 lei at the official rate, but 70 on the black market, and rates of up to 160 have been reported from the countryside. Most foreigners stay at the Intercontinental Hotel, which used to be off-limits to the average Romanian and crawling with agents of the Securitate, Ceausescu's hated secret police. Now it crawls with money-changers, who have a much easier time of it than during Ceausecu's 24 years in power. All Romanians were required to report contacts with foreigners and strict limits were put on possession of hard currency. They had to deposit all hard currency in special accounts and explain where they got it. Since the revolution, money-changers appear wherever there is a demand. The unofficial exchange of currency remains illegal, but the authorities are choosing to ignore it, at least for the moment. Money-changers seem a sign of the new times, like Bucharest's first privately owned businesses _ a clothing store and photography shop that opened in February. They pursue their trade in hotels, taxis, restaurants, on the street, and occasionally diversify. One approached a Canadian reporter in a hotel lobby and offered to sell an antique Russian icon. Later, he offered an American a gold French cigarette lighter. Two others tried to peddle a gold watch they claimed had been Ceausescu's. ``You have to make a living,'' said one, who identified himself as Velentin. ``Around here, where a manager makes maybe 4,200 lei a month ($60 at the black market rate), you starve if you don't find all kinds of ways to make money.'' There have been reports of money-changers trying to cheat foreigners by offering what appear to be large rolls of money _ 100-lei notes on the outside and toilet paper on the inside. Another common trick is for the money-changer to stop a transaction suddenly, explaining that the rate has changed or someone is watching, then try to return a $1 bill instead of the $50 or $100 the foreigner was exchanging. One Sunday, protesters forced their way into the government headquarters in Victory Square, ransacked it and trapped Gelu Voican, the deputy prime minister, in his office for several hours. Several foreign reporters and about 20 soldiers were in a group that joined Voican in the office. A photographer pointed to a tall, dark man and said, ``He's familiar.'' In a few minutes, the man edged up to a reporter and said: ``Change money?''

At the Movies: `Bad Influence'
DOC.TEXT: A few decades ago, Errol Flynn was charged with the rape of a pair of teen-age girls (he was acquitted), and Robert Mitchum was busted for smoking marijuana (he served time). The scandals seemed capable of destroying the stars' careers, but their studios put them in heroic roles and Flynn and Mitchum became more popular than before. That brings us to ``Bad Influence,'' starring Rob Lowe. Yes, the Rob Lowe who got in a jam by videotaping sex between a couple of young women in an Atlanta hotel room. Far from being a hero in ``Bad Influence,'' Lowe plays a totally immoral figure capable of deceit, robbery and murder. In the film he videotapes sex between two of the other protagonists and uses the tape for a shocking purpose. In a later scene he lands in bed with two nubile and eager beauties. Exploitive? Some may think so. A new furor may arise, perhaps obscuring the fact that ``Bad Influence'' is a crackerjack suspense movie. The great Hitchock comes to mind. He loved outlandish situations, such as the chase across Mount Rushmore in ``North by Northwest.'' In ``Bad Influence,'' two brothers try to dispose of a body in Los Angeles' famed La Brea tar pits. The film's theme is basic Hitchcock: Normal citizen finds himself enmeshed in a deadly game. James Spader is a marketing analyst successful in his work and engaged to the rich, beautiful Kathleen Wilhoite. His life is well-ordered until an encounter in a beach bar with Lowe, a ruthless charmer who takes over Spader's life, teaching him to outfox his office rivals and introducing him to a dangerous beauty, Lisa Zane. Lowe introduces Spader to fast living, drugs and Los Angeles' undergound nightlife, then to criminal acts. Spader restores his senses and tries to escape, but to his horror he becomes involved in murder. ``Bad Influence'' might have been just another exercise in the destructive fast-lane life of Los Angeles. But David Koepp has fashioned a screenplay filled with unexpected turns and shocks, and Curtis Hanson directed in taut style, aided immeasurably by Robert Elswit's stunning photography. Spader (``sex, lies and videotape'') draws an impressive characterization of a man in a quagmire. Lowe, whose previous work has seemed vapid and colorless, corrects that impression this time out. He is profoundly evil as the protean drifter. Steve Tisch directed the Epic Production, which bears a well-deserved R for nudity, sex, violence, drugs and language. Running time: 110 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``25 x 5: The Continuing Adventures of the Rolling Stones'' (CBS Music Video. VHS, $19.98. No Rating)
``It was image that counted,'' Keith Richards recalls in the video documentary ``25 x 5: The Continuing Adventures of the Rolling Stones.'' ``We were very hip to image and how to manipulate the press.'' Richards was referring to the mid-1960s, when the Stones were presented as the dangerous alternative to the lovable Beatles, even though, as Mick Jagger points out, ``They were just as cynical as we were.'' Visits to children's hospitals were kept secret, such headlines as ``Would You Let Your Daughter Marry a Rolling Stone?'' encouraged hostility. ``What mood do we have today?'' Richards says of those times, speaking like a seasoned campaign manager. Image still counts. Call this video ``Beat the Press: The Continuing Adventures of Rock 'n' Roll Spin Doctors.'' Like so many authorized biographies, ``25 x 5'' is a documentary of selective candor. The truth is told, but never the whole truth. Good times, bad times, the Stones get the last word. You'll learn what kind of car Bill Wyman owned in 1966, and how former manager Allen Klein bullied executives into giving the Stones the best contract in the world. You'll also learn that Jagger would be happy to resume his acting career, if, of course, he received ``the right part.'' There's not a word about classic albums such as ``Aftermath'' and ``Let It Bleed,'' but there are highlights from the weddings of Richards, Wyman and Ron Wood (with only Wyman including an oath of fidelity), and lectures on the importance of family. Jimmy Miller, who produced ``Beggar's Banquet,'' ``Sticky Fingers'' and ``Exiles on Main Street'' among others, is ignored. Chuck Berry gets a single mention. The lowest point comes when Jagger brushes off the tragic 1969 concert at Altamont _ during which a young fan was murdered by Hell's Angels _ with the comment, ``It still doesn't sully the tour for me.'' As the Stones tell it, the real secret to their success was manager Andrew Loog Oldham, who boasted of their nasty habits, and Klein, who pushed them ahead financially. ``I just wanted to get the point of view from the guys' perspective,'' explained producer Andrew Solt, whose previous credits include ``Imagine: John Lennon,'' ``This Is Elvis'' and the acclaimed ``Heroes of Rock 'n' Roll.'' ``They really were hip to the press,'' Solt said. ``The press was critical to this process. They were bad boys to an extent, but they certainly weren't as bad as they were supposed to be.'' The press falls for it. ``Let's get down to brass tacks,'' a reporter asks an obviously delighted Jagger. ``Are you better at what you do than the Beatles are at what they do?'' ``Are you satisfied?'' another reporter asks Jagger. ``Sexually, satisfied. Financially, not satisfied. Philosophically, trying,'' is the response. The more sophisticated Dick Cavett can come up with nothing better to ask than will Jagger be performing ``Satisfaction'' as an old man. The Stones look happiest on stage, and the video would work better if the interviews were simply edited out. Just watch Richards bob his head and grin as the band rips through ``Around and Around,'' or Jagger step into ``Satisfaction'' and later prowl the stage during ``Midnight Rambler.'' Wonderful clips of bluesmen Muddy Waters and Howlin' Wolf, two major influences, are also highlights. But the clips are usually just that; only a handful of performances are shown all the way through. And after 1972, the only adventures are touring, making videos and finding new ways to keep the media on its toes. Even Solt got bored. ``I found it of less interest,'' he said. ``There were a few important songs and moments and events, but it was more the drama of the band. They really weren't on top of their form all the time.''

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``La Gioconda,'' opera in four acts by Amilcare Ponchielli, a three CD album (CBS Records)
What is one to make of ``La Gioconda'' anyway? It's a ``warhorse'' in the worst sense of the term, a clunky work with an absurd plot, cardboard characters and some long strecthes of third-rate music. Yet its big tunes are winners and given a strong recording such as this one, the opera should win over plenty of listeners to its crude but forceful charms. As the album notes by Barrymore Laurence Scherer point out, this relic is about the only surviving specimen of Italian opera from the long period when Verdi, late in life, temporarily retired from composing for the stage. (That would span the period between ``Aida'' in 1871 and ``Otello'' in 1887. ``Gioconda'' premiered at La Scala in 1876.) The title role of the anything-but-happy street singer is powerfully sung here by Eva Marton. Like Ghena Dimitrova (who sang the role at the Metropolitan Opera this year) she exemplifies the stentorian, rather than the lyric, school of soprano singing. That's fine, since subtlety seems beside the point in portraying a character who, from the moment the curtain rises, barely stops rushing from one crisis to another. In Act 1, she frets that her blind mother will be burned at the stake; in Act 2, she tries to murder her romantic rival; in Act 3, she turns around and saves the rival's life; in Act 4, she finally stabs herself to avoid the sexual advances of the villain. As Enzo, the nobleman-in-disguise whom Gioconda loves, tenor Giorgio Lamberti is no Pavarotti, but he sounds at least decent, and better than that in his big Act 2 aria, ``Cielo e mar!'' Baritone Sherrill Milnes enthusiastically throws what remains of his once impressive voice into the role of the evil Barnaba, but he can't avoid sounding frayed and occasionally flat. Mezzo Livia Budai is imposing as Laura; contralto Anne Gjevang does nicely by the lovely Act 1 prayer Ponchielli composed for La Cieca, Gioconda's mother; and bass Samuel Ramey is wasted in the silly and entirely uninteresting part of Alvise. The late Giuseppe Patane conducts the Hungarian State Orchestra with the verve and smoothness for which he was renowned. _ By Mike Silverman, Associated Press Writer.

``Jeff Beck's Guitar Shop'' (Epic) _ Jeff Beck
It's tough these days being a guitar hero. Every heavy metal band has at least one, leaving few riffs unturned. How can a guy attract some attention with so much competition? Jeff Beck, who first won fame as a guitar pyrotechnician in the 1960s, decided to make studio gadgetry the cornerstone of the mostly instrumental ``Jeff Beck's Guitar Shop.'' Bad idea; the result is high-tech but no-soul. This music contains a little rock, a little jazz and a lot of microchips. Beck filters his guitar through every gizmo money can buy, and he jumps from one timbre to another for no good reason. The synthesizers of Tony Hymas only reinforce the cold 21st century ambience. The music works best when Beck settles on one setting and just plays, which he does a few times. The slow ``Where Were You'' features a pretty melody but ends abruptly; ``Sling Shot'' is propelled by reckless, scorching licks; and ``Day in the House'' offers a great guitar break and even a political point of view in concise terms. But most of the rest is Beck dreck. Nothing here approaches his fine '70s fusion albums, ``Blow by Blow'' and ``Wired,'' or his more recent gorgeous work on Rod Stewart's cover of ``People Get Ready.'' Beck would do well to pay less attention to knobs and levels and more attention to melody and rhythm. _ By Steven Wine, Associated Press Writer.

Star Watch: Art Collides With Life
LaserPhoto LA3 of March 5
DOC.TEXT: Rob Lowe doesn't think anyone had a worse summer than he did, except maybe the Dodgers. Lowe was trying to add lightness to a grim subject: his involvement in a sex scandal and his efforts to resume his film career. ``You have to have a sense of humor about it,'' he said. ``You have to look at things in the long run. I knew that when this movie came out, people would be reminded of who I am and what I do. That is, that I'm an actor and I do have a private life, and everybody's private life gets out of control at one time or another. ``We're all human. We all make mistakes. I made my mistakes, and it got away from me for a bit, no different from anyone else. As I've said before, I made a mistake, and I tried to live up to it. I don't try to pretend that it never happened. It did happen, and we all go on.'' Every watcher of the scandal sheets and their television counterparts knows what happened. While attending the Democratic National Convention in the summer of 1988, Lowe made a videotape of sex involving himself and two young women in his Atlanta hotel room. Claims and counterclaims rebounded, and Lowe agreed to do 20 hours of community service to avoid prosecution for allegedly seducing one of the women, then a 16-year-old. Her mother's suit against Lowe is pending. The scandal is returning to the spotlight with the release of Lowe's new movie, bearing the wry title of ``Bad Influence.'' He portrays a charming drifter who invites a humdrum businessman, James Spader, into Los Angeles' fast-lane life of drugs and lawlessness. Lowe videotapes Spader in a sex episode, and Lowe is seen in bed with two women. ``This is due to the totally coincidental nature of life imitating art and art imitating life,'' declares Steve Tisch, the movie's producer. ``It's almost life and art having a head-on collision.'' Lowe tried to minimize the coincidence of the two sequences: ``They work so well to further the story. They are plot devices. The videotaping in the movie is to capture what happened in order to get somebody. If (the story) had taken place 70 years ago, I would have found a diary. Fifty years ago, it would have been the audio recording. In today's society, it's videotape. ``It's used so widely as a device in movies today. Sure, I had a videotape controversy, but when you consider all the movies where videotape is used, it's not really that big a deal. If it had been an elaborate sequence, we might have thought twice about removing it. But then what would I use to trap him, if not that?'' Curtis Hanson, director of ``Bad Influence,'' commented that the sex scene with Lowe and the two women was necessary, ``because through most of the picture, Rob is the force who causes things to happen; we needed to see him as a participant.'' Lowe was originally cast in the Spader role, but he opted to play the evil Alex, fashioning him after classic villains from Iago to Michael Douglas' Gordon Gekko in ``Wall Street.'' The actor usually creates his own ``back story'' of his film characters, but not this time. ``Curtis told me you can't apply the usual principles to someone like Alex; he is totally unredeemable.'' ``Bad Influence'' was in pre-production when the Atlanta scandal broke. Lowe was attending the Cannes Film Festival and returned immediately to confer with Tisch about continuing with the film. Lowe never considered withdrawing. ``We had to do the movie,'' he said. ``Everybody was committed. It was still as viable a piece of material as it was before. Nothing had changed as far as the movie was concerned. ``So I never looked back in that sense. It only made us more concerned that we couldn't let what was going on in my personal life affect my professional life. The set was the place to work. We didn't want any distractions, or for me to be distracted. ... I know that the performance would not be what it is without the emotional ammunition I got in going through such a tough summer.'' Whether ``Bad Influence'' succeeds or not, it's likely that Rob Lowe's persona, both on and off screen, will never be the same. During his brief film career, his striking good looks often cast him as a somewhat wimpish yuppy. In his personal life, he was known as a supporter of environmental and liberal causes and companion of such beauties as actress Melissa Gilbert and Princess Stephanie of Monaco. Lowe was born in Charlottesville, Va., and grew up in Dayton, Ohio, where he surprised his lawyer father by announcing at 9 that he intended to become an actor. He appeared in 30 stage plays by the age of 12, then his family moved to Los Angeles. At 15 he appeared in a TV series, ``A New Kind of Family''; at 18, he was picked by Francis Coppola for ``The Outsiders.'' ``St. Elmo's Fire'' provided his first adult role, as a burned-out sax player, then came ``About Last Night'' and ``Square Dance,'' which won him a Golden Globe nomination as a mentally disabled young man. ``My only consolation in losing was that Sean Connery won (for `The Untouchables'),'' he remarked. Unlike his co-star, Spader, who shuns the media, Lowe faced a series of interviews for the film's opening and responded to all questions. He was asked if his looks had been a drawback in winning some roles. ``I'm sure it's possible,'' he replied. ``There are a lot of movies being made today with guys who look like they could be delivering your paper, just average guys. ``For better or worse, I have a distinctive look. I was born with it; there's nothing I can do about it. I personally don't give it a thought, other than when people ask me about it in interviews. If I had a different face, they might be asking, `If you were only five inches taller ...' ``As Gilda Radner used to say, `It's always something.'''
