The Artists: Ancient Chinese Art Exhibit Wins and Loses
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Art patrons battling red ink and bad press over an exhibit of priceless imperial Chinese art believe the investment in prestige and tourism potential was worth the loss of millions of private and public dollars. The ``Son of Heaven: Imperial Arts of China'' exhibit attracted 500,000 visitors during a five-month stint in Seattle in 1988 and 672,000 during it's eight-month show in Columbus last year. It was the largest exhibition of historic Chinese art and artifacts ever seen in the United States. The show, which opened here last March and closed in September, featured objects from the palaces of Chinese emperors and kings who collectively ruled over a 2,600-year period. The works were primarily lent by museums in Beijing and eight Chinese provinces. The pieces included life-size terra-cotta horses and warrior sculptures from the tomb of China's first emperor, 2,500-year-old cooking vessels and temple bells, delicate scroll paintings from the 15th century and a 2nd century jade burial suit. Some of the items were found in recent archeological digs in China. ``Son of Heaven'' was China's term for its emperors, believed to be the human link to heaven. ``Unequivocally, yes, it was worth it. To use a sports analogy, maybe the score didn't come out quite like we thought and maybe the plays weren't executed precisely as we'd hoped, but we won,'' said David Baker, director of the Ohio Department of Development. ``And we'd play the game again.'' Despite publicity heralding the $66 million display of 225 artifacts spanning 26 centuries of Chinese history, sponsors in both cities who had predicted respectable profits reported stunning financial losses. Elling Halvorson, chairman of the Seattle-based Son of Heaven Inc., said his organization lost $2.3 million, leaving creditors and two charities that had pledged $1 million to the show, with the debt. In Columbus, the show lost nearly $1.7 million _ almost exactly the amount the state and city had pledged to guarantee creditors in case the exhibit lost money. Baker blamed the loss on the high cost of renovating a former high school to house the exhibit. The loss prompted some Ohio newspapers to delve into the financing of the exhibit. It also focused more attention on plans for ``AmeriFlora '92,'' the city's multimillion-dollar 1992 commemoration of the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus' arrival in the Americas. One local columnist already has dubbed the 1992 event ``Grandson of Heaven.'' It also surprised Ohio legislators and controllers, who said they never approved Baker's promise that the state would guarantee $1 million if the show lost money. The State Controlling Board, which approves many state contracts that are not competitively bid, has delayed payment on the advice of Ohio Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. He said such a deal was illegal. The city has paid much of its $750,000 guarantee. Baker contends that ``Son of Heaven'' paid off in other ways. ``My department's calculations show that more taxes were paid to the community of Columbus and the state of Ohio as a result of `Son of Heaven' than all the public dollars going into it,'' he said. ``That's not the way we intended to pay for this, but we're net ahead on this. We're not behind.'' But James Kraft, assistant director of the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, said he would have been surprised had the shows made money. ``You can't do something like this for the first time and expect it to be a success,'' he said. ``Look at it as a business _ very few companies make money in the first two or three years of operation. You have to do it once a year or once every two years to make it work.'' David Milenthal, a spokesman for Columbus Together Inc., the organiztion that managed the exhibit in Columbus, said other cities looking to build tourism and economic development by subsidizing the arts should not be disuaded by the ``Son of Heaven'' losses. ``If it hadn't been for the renovation of the high school at a cost $2.3 million for the exhibit, this thing would have made money,'' he said. ``But other things we got from this can't be measured. We've got a beautiful high school that's ready for the next show. We had people come here from all 50 states and 50 countries, people who wouldn't normally come here. There were hundreds of articles written all over the world about the exhibit and Columbus and Ohio _ all of them positive. You can't buy that kind of advertising.'' Nonetheless, Milenthal, who is president of an advertising agency, said that because of the controversy from the exhibit, which was managed by his wife, Bonnie, he will think twice the next time such an event is proposed. ``I enjoyed every minute of the exhibit and working with it, but when you've been slammed as badly as some of us involved have been slammed in the pasty few weeks, I just don't know if I'd do it again,'' he said.

Music Makers: A Bumpy Ride to Success
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Crammed into John Flansburgh's basement apartment in Brooklyn are film reels, old framed portraits, brand new Polaroids, used rugs, a box of punk 45s and a pharmaceutical typewriter. A small statue of Chiang Kai-shek is perched on the refrigerator. On the stove rests a large, scratched espresso pot. The answering machine that activates the ``Dial-a-Song'' telephone message for his rock group, They Might Be Giants, lies on the kitchen floor, next to a shiny silver trash can. No gold records hang from the walls, but a used copy of the group's first LP can be found slouched atop an old cabinet in the crowded living room-studio that's squeezed between the kitchen and bedroom. Flansburgh's lived there for years, near fellow Giant John Linnell. They first moved in when the two-man band was just getting started, playing to crowds that could fit comfortably into these tiny rooms. But Flansburgh, 29, and Linnell, 30, are no longer college age and They Might Be Giants is no longer just a college band. Sales for their second album, ``Lincoln,'' neared 100,000, and they should do even better with their new record, ``Flood.'' The group is now signed with a major label, Elektra Records, which, Flansburgh recalled in a recent interview at his apartment, rejected They Might Be Giants three years ago because ``they had no melodies.'' ``Some of the songs are incredibly old and some of them were incredibly new, and some were medium. It's your classic third album syndrome,'' Flansburgh said with a laugh. ``There's this sort of obsessive of melodic thing,'' Linnell said. ``We try and come up with a set of words that would be interesting to use with that melody. ``I think we're really into our kind of music. There's a small range of stuff that we feel we're actually good at. I definitely wouldn't say we're making a point.'' So don't look for duets with labelmate Anita Baker, or jam sessions with Elektra's heavy metal stars, Metallica and Motley Crue. ``Flood'' is more of the same, or the different _ catchy melodies, quirky arrangements and lyrics both sublime (``Letterbox'') and ridiculous (``Hearing Aid''). There is one change. Four of the songs are produced by Clive Langer and Alan Winstanly (Elvis Costello, Madness), the result of what Linnell reluctantly calls ``a compromise.'' ``We wanted to produce it ourselves,'' Linnell said, ``and we had never produced a record before by ourselves. Elektra said, `OK, produce the record, but for the single we want to get somebody to do it with you.' We went through a lots of producers and those were the guys we liked best.'' Flansburgh and Linnell both grew up in the suburbs of Boston but didn't write songs together until 1981, when they happened to move into the same building in downtown Brooklyn. Commercials nearly preceded commercial success. The two Johns _ as friends call them _ were on their first tour, at that ``tender rock moment'' after quitting their day jobs, when they learned Crazy Eddie's wanted to make use of their song ``I'm Insane.'' ``You're in a van and you're making $75 a night, and you need $80 a day to stay alive,'' Flansburgh recalled. ``Our manager said, `What difference does it make? Take the money, it'll be fun.' ``We definitely wanted the money. We really had basic needs to fulfill. That was very difficult to actually to go like `no' to. But then we said `no' and they did this song that was based on it. They pulled it right away.'' Sponsors stayed away, and so did radio. But thanks to heavy exposure on MTV _ ``Whitney Houston, us, Whitesnake, us'' was how Flansburgh described it _ and a live act that featured pre-recorded backing tracks and a most memorable stick, They Might Be Giants built an audience, two minutes at a time. ``When we first started out, all our songs were fairly short, had a verse, a chorus kind of thing happening, and there was always a middle section to break it up,'' Linnell recalled. ``The middle section was always the free range part of the song. I think 90 percent of all our songs still follow that format.'' With enough money in the bank, Flansburgh and Linnell calmly turned down the hamburger chain that recently approached them. They can even afford to look back, reflecting on success that thankfully didn't occur overnight. ``We get letters that say, `I'm starting a band and you guys make me feel like you can start a band.' It's been a bumpy ride but the cart has kept moving,'' Flansburgh said. ``We've been going for seven years doing this thing, and every month has been a little better than the previous month, by some small increment,'' Linnell said. ``We never had the frightening `wake up and suddenly your lifestyle is totally different' experience.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Poet Recalls His Struggles With Castro
DOC.TEXT: Socialism has come full circle in 70 years, a human life span, so a personal memoir may be just the right medium for recounting its history. Heberto Padilla, Cuba's leading dissident intellectual, has produced such a recollection in ``Self-Portrait of the Other,'' a book he calls a ``moral evaulation of myself.'' It is also an evaluation of socialism. In it, Padilla recalls his involvement with the Cuban revolution, how his enthusiasm soured and how the revolution punished him when he began to complain. Along the way he describes, with a condensed and powerful style, some memorable encounters with figures of the day _ Jean-Paul Sartre and Albert Camus, Che Guevara and Fidel Castro _ and provides warm and respectful epitaphs for friends whom the revolution mistrusted _ among them the poet Jose Lezama Lima and the playwright Virgilio Pineira. Padilla's complaints led in 1971 to his imprisonment, beatings and a public ``self-criticism'' session; the ``Padilla case'' was a key juncture in the Cuban revolution and an axiomatic event in the history of communism. Just as Stalin's show trials stripped many Western intellectuals of their faith in Soviet communism in the 1930s, Padilla's treatment disabused liberal followers of Castro of the notion that his tropical communism was blessed with a special saving grace. A legion of prominent left-leaning writers _ among them Sartre, Alberto Moravia and Susan Sontag _ signed a protest letter to Castro. More importantly, the episode drove a wedge into the virtually unanimous support that Castro had enjoyed among Latin intellectuals. Among the defectors was author Mario Vargas Llosa, who since has drifted steadily to the right; today he is a conservative party's candidate for president of Peru. Padilla's generation was raised to view revolution as inevitable, and to pursue it with ecclesiastic zeal, as if Leninism were the Holy Grail. Most of the influential Hispanic writers described in ``Self-Portrait of the Other'' had at least a brief courtship with a communist party. Now that a more pantheistic array of ideas has sprung from the shrouds of Leninism, the ``new generation of Latin American poets are freer than we, who believed that communism was the only hope for humanity,'' Padilla said in an interview from Princeton, N.J., where he has made his home since 1980. ``We had all those old communist poets from the 1930s _ Nicolas Guillen, (the Chilean Pablo) Neruda, (Spaniard Rafael) Alberti _ riding on our backs. But those people aren't very influential anymore.'' From the beginning, Padilla spurned the lush, baroque imagery associated with Neruda for a more lean poetics such as those of Robert Lowell and St.-John Perse. Ideologically, however, he was keen on revolution. After Castro's triumph he helped edit the literary supplement ``Lunes de Revolucion,'' then went abroad, working as a correspondent for the official Cuban news agency and as a commercial diplomat. A prolonged stay in Moscow quashed his hopes for socialism and sharpened his sense of the pathetic, both in himself and others. In ``Self-Portrait,'' he describes being ignored by Castro during the latter's visit to Moscow: ``We should have realized right then and there the kind of objects we were: small animals of history which someone superior knew how to make use of and then discard.'' Yet he manages a kind of sympathy for Anibal Escalante, a hard-line communist who had lost out in a Cuban power struggle and was consigned to a posting in the Soviet Union: ``When snow covered Moscow, he seemed to cringe inside his black overcoat, like a turtle in his shell. ... Fidel Castro had decreed his extinction, and he was never able to bring himself back to life.'' Padilla returned in the mid-1960s to Havana, and his book of troubled verse, ``Out of the Game,'' won a national prize in 1968. However, the authorities found fault in Padilla's sarcasm and bitterness. In the grim state security proceedings that followed his arrest in 1971, Padilla's aesthetic judgments were put on trial. The Cuban government was announcing that it no longer tolerated the personal criteria of its artists and wanted them to glorify the self-sacrifice required by the fatherland. Padilla never spells out whether he regrets having made the ``confession,'' in which he also indicted more than 20 friends. The reader is left to infer that he faced death or long imprisonment had he refused to do so. Under constant police surveillance, Padilla worked as a translator _ like the Soviet writer Boris Pasternak in an earlier time _ until Castro permitted him to emigrate in 1980. Padilla hopes some day to return home, and with walls falling around the world, he predicts that the one isolating Cuba also will tumble. ``It will be sudden, like with Ceausescu,'' he said, referring to Romania's deposed leader. ``I think it is inevitable.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: The Johnny Carson of Cable TV
LaserPhoto NS1 of March 5
DOC.TEXT: What Johnny Carson is to NBC, Ralph Emery is to cable. For the past seven years, Emery has been host of ``Nashville Now'' on the Nashville Network. The live, 90-minute show reaches 48 million households. Like Carson, Emery sits behind a desk interviewing guests. But there's more music on Emery's show and much of it is country entertainment. Virtually every country music star has performed on the program, which is broadcast from Opryland USA theme park 9-10:30 p.m. EST Monday through Friday. Emery has never met Carson but respects him as a professional and consistently good entertainer. ``I like him a lot,'' Emery said in an interview in his office suite a few miles from the cable network studio. ``He's always been one of my heroes. ``He's totally in command of every situation and I've seen people try to trap him and nobody can do it. ``He has built that all important element, credibility, and consistency. Carson can always be counted on to be entertaining. I can't say that about every entertainer. Having guest stars on is great, but you've got to be pretty good yourself every night,'' he said. Like ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson,'' Emery has a live band, stand-up comedians and some audience participation (cards from the studio members). He even occasionally does a monologue. ``We do a little talk and a lot of music and that's the big difference,'' Emery said. ``Our show has at least seven songs a night and sometimes eight, and with interview segments under three to four minutes each.'' Emery also admires the exuberance of another talk show host, Arsenio Hall of the Fox Network. ``He's very good. He has a very animated face, a great smile, great eyes and lots of energy and obviously good writers,'' Emery said. Emery and Pat Sajak worked together for a Nashville TV station before Sajak moved to Los Angeles and became host of ``Wheel of Fortune'' and his own late night talk show on CBS. ``I remember he was very glib and he was a big Chicago Cubs baseball fan,'' Emery said. ``His personality reminded me of Johnny Carson. I thought with his charm and personality, he would be an ideal host for that situation.'' On radio, Emery has had various syndicated shows since 1968. His current five-minute country music radio program is on more than 430 stations. In the 1960s, his all-night country music radio show on WSM in Nashville reached 38 states. For two years, beginning in 1981, he was host of a live country music show on SuperStation WTBS, ``Nashville Alive.'' From 1974 to 1979, he was host of the syndicated TV show ``Pop Goes the Country.'' He also is host of a live, 90-minute early morning country music-news show on WSMV-TV. Last October, Emery was inducted into the Disc Jockey Hall of Fame. In 1986, he was voted favorite cable personality of the year in a reader's poll conducted by ``Cable Guide'' magazine. And he has his own fan club with more than 5,000 members. One of his more celebrated guests on ``Nashville Now'' was George Bush, who appeared in 1988 when he was vice president. ``He was very affable and charming and not stuffy,'' Emery recalled. ``(Entertainer) Jimmy Dean was on the couch and cracked jokes and made everything loose and light. ``When it was over, he took pictures with the TNN brass and with me. And then he did an interesting thing. Just before he walked out, the crew was just standing around. He said he wanted to have a picture made with them, so he did. It's still hanging on the bulletin board backstage. I thought it was a nice gesture.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Forty eight of the world's most gifted young ballet dancers will be introduced to the New York dance world for the third New York International Ballet Competition. Four rounds of competition begin June 2 with the Peasant Pas de deux from ``Giselle'' at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall. The competition's first two weeks are devoted to repertoire study by the 17- to 23-year-old dancers who will come to New York from around the world. They learn three pas de deux that are announced upon their arrival. They also rehearse a pas de deux designated by the competition _ this year the Peasant Pas de deux. A gala performance and awards ceremony on June 25 cap the world's only competition that requires the participants to stay for the entire event. Even after a dancer is eliminated, he or she continues to take classes, attends performances and plays an active role in the final evening's festivities.

Some of the most provocative film releases of the past year that have been either underrated or overlooked commercially will be presented March 17-30 at the American Museum of the Moving Image. The series features ``Great Balls of Fire,'' ``They Live,'' ``In a Glass Cage,'' ``The Adventures of Baron Munchausen'' and ``84 Charlie Mopic.'' Also featured will be a personal appearance by Bob Balaban at a screening of his eerie psychological thriller, ``Parents.'' The show, called ``A Second Look,'' presents a more aggressive look at the current cinema than is likely to be found at the Academy Awards. The series has been organized by David Schwartz, curator of film.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Release Anytime

DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the Japanese ``risk having our market closed or at least gravely limited'' if they fail to open trade barriers to U.S. exports. Two key senators made similar comments Monday, suggesting a protectionist trade war, as Bush administration negotiators admitted making ``little progress'' so far in cracking Japanese trade bars. The negotiators said it is too soon to predict whether President Bush's weekend summit with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will produce results but that the Japanese now ``must move rapidly to provide solutions.''

Sales of cars and light trucks made in North America slumped 7.9 percent in late February compared with last year when consumers rushed to showrooms to snatch up expiring incentives. For the entire month, automakers said Monday, sales of domestic and imported automobiles and light trucks were down 4.7 percent, reflecting sagging interest in cash rebates and low-interest financing that were the rage in January and February 1989. The incentives in early 1989 turned many spring car buyers into late winter purchasers.

Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is closing as many as to 50 retail brokerage offices nationwide as part of across-the-board cutbacks under parent American Express Co., the investment firm said. Shearson also was said Monday to be trying to sell its troubled Balcor real estate management subsidiary, which has more than $1 billion in real estate loans and direct investments outstanding in a shaky market. The reductions are part of an overhaul being engineered by American Express, which over the last two months gradually has moved to take full control of Shearson, its Wall Street investment subsidiary.

Texas Air Corp.'s agreement to pay its Eastern Airlines subsidiary about $280 million was not an admission that it bought assets from the airline at unfairly low prices, Eastern's court-appointed bankruptcy examiner told congressional leaders. Examiner David I. Shapiro said his report investigating dealings between Texas Air and Eastern had been misinterpreted by the news media as a finding that Texas Air was liable for the money. ``I did not find that Texas Air had improperly diverted assets from Eastern,'' Shapiro wrote Monday in a letter to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and House Minority Leader Robert H. Michel.

Motorola Inc. unveiled a new computer line that the technology company hopes will propel it into the industry's major leagues. But some industry analysts said Monday that Motorola could end up alienating companies that buy its computers for resale under their own brand names. Others questioned whether Motorola stands a chance in the highly competitive computer field.

Students across the country got the news along with a sales pitch for candy, shaving razors and cheese snacks as the advertiser-supported classroom program Channel One went on the air. ``I think it is a good idea,'' said Powell High School student Jim Addington, 17, one of the first to see the Channel One news program, beamed Monday to 400 schools nationwide. Despite criticism from national education groups and bans by public educators in New York and California, Whittle said 2,900 schools in 34 states have signed up for Channel One.

Four large fast-food chains are breaking an agreement to offer on-the-spot nutritional information about their menus and to make sure customers know the brochures are available, a consumer group said. ``We are sorry to report ... that, after initial compliance, the voluntary program has broken down,'' the Center for Science in the Public Interest said Monday in letters to the attorneys general of Texas, California and New York. The three state officials won agreement from five chains in July 1986 to provide ingredient and nutrition information at all outlets.

Leo Melamed, a tireless innovator and cheerleader for the futures industry, announced that he would resign from the leadership of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange at year's end ``to recapture my life.'' Melamed, chairman of the Merc's executive committee, explained the surprise announcement Monday by saying that after 23 years of policy making and trend setting, he was ready for a quieter life. Melamed, 57, said he was not retiring for health reasons or for reasons associated with the ongoing federal investigation of fraud at the Merc and the larger Chicago Board of Trade.

In a sequel even Hollywood couldn't concoct, Scarlett O'Hara and Rhett Butler are together again, reunited by a Japanese company bent on selling wine to a nation in love with American popular culture. Fujisankei Communications International Inc., a Japanese media conglomerate, has secured licensing rights to ``Gone With the Wind'' and plans to market a line of wines in Japan named after the Old South epic. The line of California wines will be available only in Japan.

The stock market drifted lower in a quiet session Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 10.81 points to 2,649.55. The dollar fell sharply against most major currencies as central banks joined in an effort to hold down its value. Gold prices climbed. Bond prices tumbled amid expectations that Japan's central bank would raise interest rates. Coffee futures prices soared above $1 a pound; copper futures surged; cotton futures were up sharply; oil futures were higher; precious metals were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Merc's Melamed, Father Of Financial Futures, Stepping Down
LaserPhoto CX4
DOC.TEXT: He's known as the father of financial futures. But after 23 years as a leader of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Leo Melamed says he's stepping down to spend more time with his real family. ``They've always taken short change in my obligations and responsibilities, and they always get left behind,'' Melamed said of his wife, Bette, and three grown children. The 57-year-old chairman of the Merc's executive committee made the surprise announcement Monday, telling a news conference he wanted to ``smell the flowers along the way while I can still smell something.'' His resignation becomes effective at the end of the year. The Merc board has not yet named his successor. The Polish-born Melamed, a tireless innovator and cheerleader for the futures industry, said he was not retiring for health reasons or because of the continuing federal investigation of trading fraud at the Merc and the larger Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two biggest futures markets. He said he planned to continue trading, to devote more time to his trading firm, Dellsher Investment Company Inc., and to do more writing. Melamed published a science-fiction novel, ``The Tenth Planet,'' in 1987 and said he has finished a sequel. Melamed also said he expects the Merc to launch its Globex electronic trading system, one of his pet projects, by June 30. Implementation of Globex, originally slated for the spring of 1989, has been delayed in part because of trouble in getting approval from the Japanese government for Japanese companies to trade on the system. ``It's going to create a real vacuum,'' John Damgard, president of the Futures Industry Association, a Washington-based trade group, said of Melamed's pending departure. Under the leadership of the charismatic and outspoken Melamed, the Chicago Merc pioneered trading of financial futures that allow investors to hedge bets on the future prices of currencies and stock indexes. Before Melamed, futures exchanges were best known for trading agricultural commodities _ eggs, livestock and pork bellies, in the Merc's case. Futures are contracts to buy and sell commodities and financial instruments in the future at prices agreed upon when the contract is bought. With the help of Milton Friedman, a Nobel laureate in economics, the Merc introduced the first foreign currency futures in 1972. They gave investors the chance to bet on future values of the West German mark, the Swiss franc, the Canadian dollar and the Japanese yen. The contracts fueled explosive growth in the industry and brought futures greater respectability in the financial world. Financial products such as currency, bond and stock-index futures accounted for more than 60 percent of the 267.4 million futures contracts traded last year in the United States. In 1970, U.S. futures trading volume totaled 13.6 million contracts. The growth also brought controversy, though. Many investors blamed computerized trading strategies that use stock-index futures for accelerating the plunge of the stock market during the October 1987 crash. Melamed was one of the staunchest defenders of stock-index futures, and his lobbying helped fend off Congressional efforts to impose curbs on the market. Melamed was chairman of the Merc from 1969 until 1971, when he stepped aside to become chairman of a new affiliate set up to trade financial futures, the International Monetary Market. In 1976, the IMM merged with the Merc and Melamed became chairman of the combined institutions. A year later, the Merc board created the office of special counsel to the board and named Melamed to the position and to the position of chairman of the executive committee. Melamed began working as a runner at the Merc in the early 1950s while working his way through law school. He became an exchange member in 1954 and a member of the exchange's board of governors in 1967.

DOC.HEAD: American Express Takeover Gives Shearson Room To Cut in Private
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co.'s decision to acquire all the common stock of its Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. subsidiary gives it room to make broad cuts at the nation's second-largest securities firm in private, analysts said. The shakeout continued Monday as Shearson said it is closing up to 50 retail brokerage offices nationwide by April 1. Sources said the firm also is trying to sell an ailing real estate subsidiary. Wall Street observers wondered why American Express would go to the trouble of buying the remaining publicly held shares of Shearson when it already had pumped $1 billion into the brokerage and owned about three-quarters of its shares. ``The only thing they really said was it gives them greater flexibility in solving Shearson's problems, though if you already own 75 percent, how much flexibility do you need?'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an industry analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The decision amounted to a complete reversal for American Express, which as recently as last month had planned to decrease its stake in Shearson from 61 percent to under 50 percent to remove the brokerage from its balance sheet. American Express has seized total control in an attempt to turn around a firm that expanded wildly in the 1980s but has suffered because of overcapacity and excessive spending during an industry recession. It ousted former chairman Peter A. Cohen in late January and replaced him with an American Express executive, Howard L. Clark Jr.; agreed in the past three months to pump $1 billion into the firm to shore up the its credit rating, and finally decided to take over Shearson entirely. Analysts said the latest move, which involves exchanging $350 million worth of American Express shares for the 28 million publicly held Shearson shares, does not eliminate the possibility that the travel card company might sell all or part of Shearson. But it ended for now talks on merging Shearson with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., the brokerage owned by Primerica Corp. ``We're doing it to make crystal clear our very strong commitment to Shearson for the long term and to enable us to work with Shearson in using the capital we're providing most effectively and efficiently,'' an American Express spokesman said. The spokesman, who asked not to be named, said ownership of all common stock was ``the most prudent course of action in the current environment'' but declined to elaborate. While American Express will own all of Shearson's common, Nippon Life Insurance Co. will retain preferred stock that gives it a 13 percent voting stake in the brokerage. Taking Shearson private _ at about $12.50 a share compared to $34 a share at the brokerage's first public stock offering in 1987 _ will reduce public scrutiny of the firm's finances. American Express also said it will gain some tax benefits. Shearson insiders said the firm would be able to cut departments and negotiate with potential buyers more freely than if the firm were publicly held. ``It may be more geared toward when they want to get rid of this thing,'' Eckenfelder said. ``Even if the business starts to recover, I still think the idea long term is to sell.'' If Shearson does not rebound quickly in an industry still hurting from the October 1987 stock market crash, American Express will have to absorb all of the firm's losses. But if Shearson rebounds, American Express will have gotten a good deal in the cheap stock, analysts said. Shearson is engaged in a broad review of its businesses. The firm last week said it was laying off 2,000 of its 35,500 workers by the end of the month. Sources at Shearson said the firm was cutting back much of its real estate activities, including making attempts to sell its Balcor subsidiary, which had 145 loans worth about $1.1 billion outstanding last Nov. 30. According to federal filings, Balcor had $114 million in nonperforming assets, including loans and about $22 million in directly owned real estate. The subsidiary has just $10 million in reserves to cover its portfolio of loans to real-estate partnerships and client companies. A Shearson spokesman, Steven Faigen, declined to comment on whether Shearson was seeking a buyer for Balcor. Shearson also said 45 to 50 retail brokerage offices would be closed or consolidated with other offices. It said there would be no disruption to client accounts. Shearson is the nation's second largest retail brokerage with about 10,000 brokers at 600 branches nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Not to Worry About Car Sales Drop, Analysts Say
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Despite a 7.9 percent drop in late-February sales of North American-made cars and light trucks, the industry may be stronger than some have forecast, automakers and analysts say. In fact, sales during the first two months of 1990, a year forecast to be weaker than last year, are running just about even with the 1989 pace, automakers reported Monday. ``All our business is doing great,'' said Frank Bartolo, general sales manager of Celozzi-Ettleson Chevrolet-Geo in Chicago. ``It's just what I expected. I think it will be strong from here into October.'' The nine companies making cars and trucks in the United States reported Monday they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 42,688 in Feb. 21-28, compared with 46,336 in the same time last year. Car sales fell 6.7 percent during the period and truck sales were down 10 percent. Automakers and some analysts have predicted sales this year would be weaker than the 14.8 million cars and trucks that left dealer lots last year. But that may be changing. ``Looking at the first two months of the new year, sales are not only much improved from the fourth quarter but somewhat ahead of the pace we anticipated when establishing our industry forecast for 14.5 million units in 1990,'' said Robert Rewey, Ford Motor Co.'s vice president for North American sales operations. Auto analyst Jeannette Garretty of the Bank of America in San Francisco said she expects the 1990 sales pace to be roughly the same as last year's, and Monday's figures, while for only two months, back that prediction. ``I guess it's good news in the sense that there were some people who were concerned that the trend for 1990 was established by the sales rate of late 1989,'' she said. ``The market in the last quarter of 1989 was very weak. ``The overall market in 1990 is going to be stronger than that. I think auto sales are going to rebound at about the trend that was established last year.'' Domestic and imported car and truck sales for January and February seem to indicate that. Automakers said sales during the first two months of this year were down 0.8 percent from last year, with a 0.6 percent increase in domestic vehicle sales offset by a 5.4 percent decline in imports. Normally, March and April are good car and truck sales months as Americans shake off the winter and get ready for spring and summertime road trips. That pattern was disrupted last year when attractive incentives in January and February turned potential springtime buyers into actual late-winter purchasers. Fred Voelkel, sales manager of Brown and Brown Chevrolet-Geo in Mesa, Ariz., said he expects his new-car inventory to swell from its current 75-day level to about 90 days in anticipation of a springtime buying blitz. But Garretty said she wasn't so sure that would happen. ``I throw up my hands as to what the car-buying cycle is anymore,'' she said. ``Incentives have changed things so much it is really hard to go pick a time for increased sales.''

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Ordered to Pay More Than $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: An arbitration panel has ordered Shearson Lehman Hutton to pay damages totaling more than $1 million to three Oklahomans who claimed their broker made unuathorized trades and churned their accounts. An arbitration panel of the National Association of Securities Dealers ordered Shearson to pay $994,766 in compensatory and punitive damages and lawyers' fees to Temple, Okla. farmer Walter Earl Cox and his wife, Ardenia F. Cox. In a decision late last month, disclosed Monday, the panel also awarded separately a total of $60,694 in damages and fees to Mrs. Cox and her mother, Cuba E. Read, of Comanche, Okla. The toltal compensatory damages of $213,864 were trebled by claims made by the Coxes under the civil provisions of the federal racketeering laws. Both awards came in response to claims made against one-time Shearson registered representative Lindy Kent Ridinger of Wichita Falls, Texas. The Coxes' lawyer, Frank Lewis, of Phoenix, Ariz., said the decision was the first he knew of where both punitive and treble damages were awarded as well as attorney's fees. The NASD, which oversees the over-the-counter stock market, also supplies the majority of arbitrators for brokerage-client disputes: more than 3,600 case last year, compared to 1,100 handled by the New York Stock Exchanges and about 100 by other groups. The three customers alleged in a complaint first filed in August 1988, that Ridinger and Shearson ``engaged in unauthorized trading of their accounts; that their trading accounts were churned and that the trades placed in their accounts were highly speculative in nature.'' Shearson denied the accusations and Ridinger, who was fired June 2, 1986, never responded to the charges, according to documents of the NASD. Churning, which is illegal under Securities and Exchange Commission rules, is unnecessary trading in a client's account, which increases the broker's commission. Ridinger was formally censured by the NASD, barred from associating with its members ``in any capacity'' and fined $50,000. He was not reachable for comment. ``While we don't agree with the decision in this particular instance, it has done nothing to shake our confidance in the arbitration process which we feel is an equitable and efficient manner to resolve disputes of this nature,'' said Steve Faigen, a Shearson spokesman in New York. Many brokerage houses _ like Shearson _ require customers, upon opening accounts, to sign agreements that they will take disputes with the house to arbitration rather than court. Last year the U.S. Supreme Court, in cases involving Shearson, upheld the legality of compelling customers to sign arbitration agreements as the price of doing business. Several members of Congress have criticized the practice as unfairly restrictive. ``What's important about this award,'' said Deborah Masucci, director of arbitration for the NASD, ``is that it shows arbitrators are willing to make such awards where the conditions are egregious.''

DOC.HEAD: Strikers Make Noise, Tourists Make Do During Hotel Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `The walkout ...' to UPDATE with talks scheduled to resume today; DELETES 13th graf pvs, `The walkout ...' to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Under different circumstances, Rosalinda Caoili would have been cleaning hotel rooms for tourists who provide Hawaii with its No. 1 industry and help sustain her family of six. ``I love working for the people,'' said Caoili, a housekeeper at the Sheraton Waikiki hotel for the past 14 years. Instead, she walked a picket line Monday while tourists at 11 hotels dealt with making their own beds and doing without prompt room service during the biggest hotel strike in Hawaii history. Up to 7,500 workers are on strike for better pay and benefits. ``We have to make a living,'' said Caoili, who makes about $8.50 an hour. ``If we don't do something, there will be a time when these people cannot afford to live here.'' Nearby, Joe and Jill Cody of Atlanta said that although they are enjoying their stay, this has not been the Hawaiian honeymoon they were expecting. ``The biggest problem is having to make our own bed,'' Jill Cody said. ``They say they're going to try to clean the rooms every other day.'' Not all was bad, though: The hotel gave them a 20 percent discount. Despite having to walk past lines of chanting strikers, they said they are enjoying the palm trees and beaches that make Hawaii a dream vacation destination for millions of tourists each year. The walkout began Saturday after negotiators for Local 5 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees Union rejected a management offer. Talks were to resume today at the behest of Gov. John Waihee, said federal mediator Frank Shoeppel. The strike affects about one-fourth of the 37,000 hotel rooms in Waikiki, the state's prime tourist destination, and one-seventh of the 70,000 hotel rooms in the state, according to the Hawaii Visitors Bureau. The hotels were using non-union staff and temporary hires to maintain limited operations. Jeanne Park, director of public relations for Hilton Hotels in Hawaii, said she has helped clear tables, clean ashtrays and dispatch housekeeping services since the strike began. ``Nobody wins in this situation,'' Park said. ``When I see my buddies out there on the picket lines, I feel bad for them and I feel bad for us.'' The union turned down a four-year contract that includes what management calculates as a wage-and-benefit package of 7 percent annually, but which the union said is more like 4 percent a year. Hotel workers who do not receive tips average $9.22 an hour; tipped workers earn an average of $4.87 an hour. ``We can't afford to go on the way things are now,'' said Roberta Bennett, a restaurant hostess at the Sheraton Waikiki who makes $8.20 an hour. Bennett said she, her husband and their baby live in a studio apartment for $600 a month. With her hotel job, a second job making T-shirts and her husband's job with a tugboat company, she said they barely meet expenses. Some tourists were unsympathetic to the strikers. Others tried to pay them no mind. ``It's almost contradictory. They're yelling, `Scabs go home.' But it's those `scabs' who are doing the jobs that bring the money here,'' said Bill Carlile of Alexandria, Va., a guest at the Ilikai Hotel. ``On a scale of 10, right now I'd give my vacation a seven,'' said Terry Klein of Victoria, Canada. ``They really don't bug me. And if they've got a just cause, go for it.'' Economists say the strike could badly damage Hawaii's economy if it is long and if news reports give the impression the state's tourist industry is paralyzed. Hotel officials stressed that all hotels are operating. ``Anyone planning a Hawaii vacation can be assured of receiving the usual Hawaiian hospitality,'' said William Crawford, executive director of the Council of Hawaii Hotels.

DOC.HEAD: California Doctors Vote Down Ban on Medfly Spraying
DOC.TEXT: The California Medical Association has rejected a ban on aerial spraying of the Medfly pesticide malathion. ``To date, there is no documented evidence malathion is injurious to public health,'' said Dr. Richard Karlan, a Beverly Hills surgeon at the CMA's annual conference, at which the measure lost in a voice vote Monday of 450 delegates. ``We're using common sense here _ we'll be the first to respond if we think there is a danger.'' The state is spraying the pesticide to protect California's $14 billion farm industry from the crop-destroying pest. Residents of many Southern California communities receiving almost weekly dousings of the pesticide have staged emotional protests, some communities have gone to court and Pasadena banned low-level helicopter flights at night. Dr. H. Rex Greene of Pasadena, who introduced the measure, disagreed with Karlan and others that voting down the ban served as an endorsement of malathion. ``I think CMA really doesn't want to take a position,'' he said. Meanwhile, a Federal Aviation Administration official warned communities against banning helicopter spraying of malathion. FAA regional administrator Jerry Chavkin said Congress gave his agency sole authority to regulate the skies. ``Actions which interfere with the flight of any aircraft, including helicopters engaged in efforts to eradicate the Medfly, represent a serious threat to aviation safety,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sharp Develops Color Fax Machine
DOC.TEXT: Japan's Sharp Corp. has developed a desktop facsimile machine that can transmit photograph-like full-color images, the company announced Tuesday. The company said the fax machine is the first made for general office use that can transmit full-color pictures, although some newspapers use very expensive fax equipment to send page layouts from one printing plant to another. The machine can send a photograph the size of a standard sheet of typewriter paper over a regular telephone line in three minutes, and can reproduce subtle color shades, Tsutomu Muroi, a company official, said. The transmission time can be cut to about 20 seconds if the fax is sent over digital communications lines, which are used by some companies for telephone calls and data communications, he said. For each page, the cost for paper and a multicolor ribbon is about 300 yen, o about $2 at current exchange rates, the company said. In a public test between two Japanese cities Tuesday, the transmitted copy of a photograph closely matched the original, except the colors were slightly darker, Muroi said. The machine also can send and receive regular black and white faxes, he said. The machine will go on sale in Japan in the fall for about 3.5 million yen ($23,000) and overseas sales are expected next year, Muroi said. ``But that price is likely to drop quickly in the future, the same way that prices for regular fax machines fell rapidly,'' he said. Previously, manufacturers were unable to develop fax equipment that could send color images in a moderate amount of time because of the large amounts of color data involved. The new machine uses an advanced color scanner developed by Sharp and digital image-processing technology to compress the image information, Muroi said. Sharp also developed a way to cut transmission time by checking only a sample of about one-tenth of the information sent rather than the entire transmission, he said. An international standard does not exist for color facsimile transmissions, and compatibility problems could occur if other manufacturers introduce different systems in the future. But Muroi said Sharp is working on a worldwide standard for color faxes similiar to current ones for black and white facsimiles.

DOC.HEAD: Scarlett and Rhett Back Together to Sell Wine in Japan
DOC.TEXT: In a marketing marriage sure to make film purists wince, a Japanese company is putting Scarlett O'Hara and Rhett Butler on a bottle of wine. It's not the first time the characters from ``Gone With The Wind'' have appeared outside of the printed page or silver screen, and most U.S. fans of the Old South epic probably will never see a bottle of ``Gone With The Wind'' wine. The new line of wines is to be sold only in Japan, under a license granted by the owners of the movie, Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System Inc., to the Japanese media conglomerate Fujisankei Communications International Inc. Still, some people in the land of cotton wish this wine would soon be forgotten. ``Don't you think it cheapens the book and the movie?'' asked Hal Clarke, the lawyer for ``Gone With The Wind'' author Margaret Mitchell's estate. For Fujisankei officials, the wine represents a chance to cash in on Japan's love of American popular culture and the nation's ever-increasing affection for wine. Katherine Melchior Ray, senior account manager with Fujisankei, said the ``Gone With the Wind'' tie-in was a natural. ``We're always looking for high-quality, unusual American products to sell in Japan,'' she said Monday. ``We see a demand in Japan for more beers and wine. With the interest in fine wines and beer and interest in all American media, we figured why not put the two together?'' The line of California wines was to be unveiled today at a reception at New York's 21 Club. The wine label features the familiar ``Gone With the Wind'' movie poster, with stars Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh embracing against a backdrop of Atlanta burning. Ms. Ray said TBS officials initially were reluctant to slap ``Gone With the Wind'' labels on wine bottles. TBS agreed, she said, because ``we took a lot of care to show this was going to maintain the prestige of the movie and encourage the beauty of the scenes in `Gone With The Wind.''' TBS receives ``several calls a month'' from people wanting to use ``Gone With the Wind'' in some way, said Lois Sloane, TBS' vice president for licensing and merchandising. The requests are screened carefully and only those that properly honor the film are granted licensing agreements, Ms. Sloane said Monday from her New York office. ``We care very much about `Gone With The Wind,''' Ms. Sloane said. Most of the products approved for licensing are geared to adults, she said _ things such as commemorative plates, stationery and figurines. Items such as toys and hard liquor have been rejected, she said. TBS Chairman Ted Turner's fondness for ``Gone With The Wind'' is well known. It is shown daily at the movie theater at Turner's CNN Center in downtown Atlanta. Terms of the deal with Fujisankei were not disclosed. Attorney Clarke said the appearance of ``Gone With The Wind'' wine was unexpected. ``This came as quite a surprise to us,'' he said. Clarke said he intended to examine the agreement to make sure ``it's on firm ground,'' but doubted he had any legal grounds to oppose it. He said the estate has not objected to marketing schemes when they ``promote the sale of the movie or the book.'' The wine will go on sale in Japan May 1 and will cost between $11 and $17 a bottle, compared to about $8 a bottle for most California wines sold there. Currently most wine sold in Japan is French. About 10,000 cases of ``Gone With the Wind,'' to be distributed by Sanraku, are being shipped initially. Atlanta historian Franklin Garrett, who knew Miss Mitchell as a young writer, expressed amusement at the idea of a ``Gone With the Wind'' wine. ``I don't know _ `Gone With the Wind' wine sounds pretty good, though it probably hasn't got the remotest connection to `Gone With the Wind,''' Garrett said. ``I guess it's a compliment to the book,'' he added. ``But if you get to using it too much for things other than the book, it might lose its distinctiveness.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Seek Tax To Pay For Repainting
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting to eliminate garble
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group is calling for an excise tax to pay for repainting up to 2 million homes and apartments and rid them of old lead-based paint that it says poses a health risk to millions of children. In a report Monday, the Environmental Defense Fund said more than 3 million preschool children suffer from lead poisoning from paint in their homes, although such paint has not been sold for more than a dozen years. The group said toxic levels of paint are found in many youngsters under age 6 because an estimated 2 million apartments and houses still have lead-containing paint on the walls. It has been estimated that the cost of ridding homes of lead paint could be $2,000 to $10,000 per house, and the environmental group said Congress should pass an excise tax on domestic and imported lead to help pay for the work. ``We have built up an accumulation of lead from past uses that will not go away. ... Lead does not decay,'' Ellen Silbergeld, a senior toxicologist for the environmental group, said at a news conference. In an analysis based mainly on government statistics, the organization said children in scores of cities have lead levels in their blood of more than 15 micrograms per deciliter of blood. That is the level at which the Environmental Protection Agency and other authorities believe childrn suffer some damage. High levels of lead can cause serious brain damage. But health experts say that even low levels of exposure can cause decreased intelligence, short-term memory loss and underachievement in school. Ms. Silbergeld said that while children's exposure to lead from paint often was thought to come from eating paint chips, it is widely believed now that paint dust, normally released from paint as it ages, poses the greatest threat to children. The defense fund study said the greatest problem from lead paint is in older cities and is particularly acute among black children, who often live in older housing in inner cities. While nationally about 17 percent of preschool children are believed to have elevated lead levels in their blood, ``almost 70 percent of urban black children from poor families are estimated to exceed that level, as are 35 percent of white children in similar circumstances,'' the report said. The group used national figures on exposure provided by the U.S. Public Health Service and separate statistics on the age of houses to produce an estimate as to what cities are likely to have the worst problem with children exposure to lead from paint. This analysis showed 10 urban areas with roughly one-fourth or more of the preschool children having elevated levels of lead that exceeded 15 micrograms per deciliter of blod. The 10 areas and the percentage of children with those levels of lead were: New York City-New Jersey metropolitan area, 33.8 percent; Newark, N.J., 30 percent; Jersey City, N.J., 29.3 percent; Cleveland, 27.4 percent; New Orleans, 26.6 percent; Philadelphia, 26.4 percent; Chicago, 25.5 percent; Baltimore, 24.9 percent; Patterson-Clifton-Passaic, N.J., 25 percent; and Trenton, N.J., 24.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Big Japanese and German Companies Reveal Exploratory Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In 10th graf, name Edzard is CQ
DOC.TEXT: Japan's Mitsubishi Industrial Group and Daimler-Benz AG, West Germany's largest industrial conglomerate, are exploring the possibility of expanding their business ties, Mitsubishi officials said Tuesday. An announcement by Mitsubishi said the areas explored in recent discussions included ``high-growth industries such as aerospace, electronics and the service sector that would benefit from development on a global scale and make effective use of the skills of both groups.'' Executives from subsidiaries of the two industrial groups held talks in Singapore over the weekend. ``There was a far-reaching exchange of ideas about ways to expand the relationship beyond the automotive sector where Mercedes Benz and Mitsubishi Motors Corp. have enjoyed close ties,'' it said. The announcement said senior managers from Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz ``expressed pleasure at having gained greater familiarity with each other and agreed to hold further meetings in due course.'' Mitsubishi spokesman Kyosuke Mori, asked when they would meet again, said they had agreed to meet once a year and he expected the next meeting would be in 1991. The big Japanese and West German companies both make motor vehicles and electronics equipment and are active in the aviation and space fields. Mori pointed out that the four Mitsubishi companies and the four Daimler-Benz companies whose executives participated in the discussions were roughly comparable. Mitsubishi Motors and Mercedes-Benz make motor vehicles; Mitsubishi Electric and AEG make electrical systems and components; Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Deutsche Aerospace make aircraft and aerospace equipment; and Mitsubishi Corp. and Daimler-Benz Inter Services are in trading and investment services. Mori said the weekend meeting evolved from a meeting last November in Europe between Shinroku Morohashi, president of Mitsubishi Corp., and Edzard Reuter, chairman of Daimler-Benz. Morohashi was in Europe to mark the offering of Mitsubishi shares on the London and Paris stock exchanges, Mori said. Morohashi and Reuter led their companies' executives at the Singapore meeting, the spokesman said. Mitsubishi Corp. is the core company of the giant Mitsubishi Group of related firms and is Japan's largest trading company, with transactions in the last fiscal year of $118 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Finance Ministry Approves Merger Of Mitsui Bank, Taiyo Kobe Bank
DOC.TEXT: Japan's Finance Ministry Tuesday approved the merger of Mitsui Bank Ltd. and Taiyo Kobe Bank Ltd., paving the way for the establishment in April of the second largest bank in Japan as measured by deposits. Masaaki Tsuchida, head of the ministry's Banking Bureau, handed the letter of approval personally to Mitsui Bank President Kenichi Suematsu and Taiyo Kobe Bank President Yasuo Matsushita. The new bank, to be called the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank Ltd., will be the second largest following Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. when it opens for business on April 1. Since announcing the merger plan in late August last year, the two banks have been thrashing out details. Suematsu and Matsushita, in a joint statement, said the new bank, ``capitalizing on its broad networks in Japan and overseas,'' will try to maximize the effectiveness of the merger for the benefit of its customers. Taiyo Kobe maintains the greater number of local branches in Japan, totaling 363 at the time of the merger announcement last August, while Mitsui has 228. The merger will help Mitsui Bank improve retail banking activity in the country. Taiyo Kobe, on the other hand, can take advantage of Mitsui's strong overseas network of 86 bases of operation located in 30 countries, which include 16 branches, one sub-branch and 24 representative offices.

DOC.HEAD: Some Delays Reported for Taxpayers Filing by Computer
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 4, The foul-up..., to elaborate on paper returns
DOC.TEXT: A human error has delayed tax refunds for 53,000 taxpayers who took advantage of the Internal Revenue Service's much-publicized electronic filing system, the IRS said today. Electronic filers affected by the foul-up who elected to have refunds deposited directly into their bank accounts should receive those refunds by March 12, rather than Feb. 26, said IRS spokesman Frank Keith. Those choosing to take a paper check should have it in hand by March 16, rather than March 2. ``Obviously this is an inconvenience to taxpayers and we regret that,'' Keith said. He noted, however, that before this glitch, the IRS had been processing returns at a record pace and certifying refunds from paper returns in about five weeks. The foul-up affected only a portion of electronic returns filed into the IRS service center in Cincinnati from the Southeast and central states plus 250,000 other records, including some paper returns filed from the central states, Keith said. He said the error occurred at the IRS's Martinsburg, W.Va., facility, to which computer tapes containing tax-return files are shipped by the 10 regional processing centers once a week. Keith said the problem was caused by an employee who delayed running one day's work at the Cincinnati center through the Martinsburg computer. More than 2.5 million couples and individuals have filed their returns electronically this year in response to an IRS campaign promising refunds within as little as two weeks. Nationwide electronic filing is available this year for the first time, although it still can be used only by taxpayers who are due a refund. Under this process, a taxpayer completes his or her own return or hires a professional to do it, and it then is transmitted via telephone directly into an IRS computer. This dramatically reduces the number of errors and saves the IRS time and money by eliminating clerical work. The foul-up involving 53,000 electronic returns ``points up once again the fact that our computer system is antiquated,'' Keith said. Under an eight-year, $8 billion plan now being implemented, the agency's 1960s technology will be replaced by a computer system that will allow IRS computers across the country to communicate directly with each other. That will mean the agency will no longer have to ship computer tapes by truck from regional offices to the West Virginia center.

DOC.HEAD: Va. Power Will Buy Electricity From Mitsubishi Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: In an effort to increase its output and meet rapid growth in electricity demand, the Virginia Power Co. has received federal permission to buy electric power from a $400 million plant that a subsidiary of Japan's Mitsubishi Corp. plans to build in central Virginia. The deal was approved last week by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, according to today's editions of The Washington Post. Several industry experts call the deal the first of its kind in this country: a full-size conventional power plant built and operated by an independent company that is in the business of manufacturing electricity for the wholesale market. The plant will burn natural gas supplied by a new 120-mile, $65 million pipeline that will link gas lines in Loudoun County and the Tidewater, Virginia area. Traditionally, utility companies have built their own plants. In addition, for the past decade federal law has required power companies to purchase power generated by small independent producers burning renewable fuels, but the Mitsubishi project was negotiated outside the scope of that law, the newspaper reported. While the Mitsubishi plant falls outside the normal channels of state-regulated utilities, the rate it proposes charging for the power does not. Virginia Power and Mitsubishi have agreed on a rate equivalent to what it would cost Virginia Power to produce the electricity in a plant it had built. Officials said the deal should not effect the bills of Virginia Power retail customers. Mitsubishi has agreed to bear the cost if it is forced to pay more to produce the power than its sales contract allows it to recapture from Virginia Power. The company is willing to take the risk because it gains entry to a new area of business.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Legalizing Private Property Wins Approval
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with bill receiving final approval; Pickup 7th pvs, `A Western...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet parliament today overwhelmingly approved legislation that will allow people to own factories and hire workers for the first time in nearly 70 years. In the early 1920s, Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin and his Bolsheviks retreated from their drive to implement communism and allowed private ownership of the means of production under the New Economic Policy, or NEP. Today's vote by the Supreme Soviet was hailed by supporters as a great step forward. It is one of the key elements of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reform package. ``This is an enormous step forward because it lays down the principle of pluralism in the forms of ownership and the basis of their equality and their protection from the government,'' said deputy Alexei Yablokov. After a section-by-section vote on each of the bill's six parts, the legislation was given final approval by a margin of 350-3. Eleven deputies abstained. The joint meeting of the Supreme Soviet's two houses broke into applause as the total was announced. The section on the property rights of Soviet citizens, which includes the right to own factories and other means of producing goods, passed 354-0 with 13 abstensions. A Western diplomat watching the session said it would be the first time since the New Economic POlicy that private individuals would be allowed to own industrial plant. People have traditionally been allowed to own cars, summer homes, and other personal property. The law also gives individuals the right to hire others to work for them as long as their pay and benefits are in keeping with Soviet law. Both the private ownership of factories and hired labor are regarded in classic Marxism as exploitation of workers, and were one of the key targets of Lenin's revolution. Despite its strong stand on property rights, the bill continued to skirt the socialist bugaboo of private property. It makes no mention of private property, but refers instead to the property of citizens. ``It's unfortunate that there is no mention of private property, but the principle is there,'' Yablokov said. Noted political commentator Fyodor Burlatsky, also a deputy, said the bill was a good start but still inadequate to pull the Soviet Union from its economic quagmire. Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov, who chaired the joint meeting of the Supreme Soviet's two chambers, urged the legislature not to drag its feet on the bill, which is to become law on July 1. ``We need this law to go into effect fast,'' he said.

Futures prices for grain and soybeans were steady to slightly lower in early trading today at the Chicago Board of Trade. Good soymeal business this morning on European cash markets was sending soybean prices higher, traders said. Analysts said it was a mixed bag in the corn and wheat pits. With firmer soybean trading, nobody was aggressively selling corn. Rainy weather in growing areas for winter wheat was continuing to depress futures prices. In early trading, wheat was } cent lower to } cent higher, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.84\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1} cents lower, with March at $2.44 a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents higher, with March at $1.46} a bushel; and soybeans were { cent to 1\ cents lower, with March at $5.69} a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, livestock and meat futures prices were mainly higher following a stronger than expected cash market this morning. In early trading, cattle were .10 cent to .20 cent higher, with the contract for delivery in April at 76.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchange to .28 cent higher, with March at 81.10 cents a pound; hogs were ,03 cent to .25 cent higher, with April at 49.85 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .05 cent lower to .80 cent higher, with March at 47.75 cents a pound. On Monday, cattle prices were higher, but most hog futures were lower and frozen pork bellies slumped.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, March 11
DOC.HEAD: From AP Newsfeatures. Also moved on general news wires
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: They are only a tiny fraction of the prison population, but their jobs are a distinct departure from the days when inmates did laundry and made license plates or tilled the prison farm. Now the focus is computers, and possible big bucks when they get out.

Associated Press Writer= SOMERS, Conn. (AP) _ Most are doing hard time for crimes such as manslaughter and rape, but for some inmates at Somers State Prison ``hard time'' means working with software. Eight to 10 hours a day, seven days a week, inmates in the prison's computer class can be found hunched in front of terminals, writing sophisticated programs that have saved the state thousands of dollars and piles of paperwork. They have automated virtually everything that can be automated at the prison, from school attendance records to pay schedules for the 1,400 inmates. Their conversations are laced with terms like ``dBASE,'' ``XT'' and ``PC.'' They read all the computer literature they can get their hands on, write articles of their own about the field and share their expertise with other inmates. ``In prison it's important to fill your day, and if you can fill it with something productive it's all the better,'' says Peter Schickler, 45, the only one of the 16 inmates in the program with extensive computer experience. ``I'd say 80 percent of the people that come through will get a computer job, which, when you think about it, is a whole different world from what most people in prison are able to do. ``You'll find with a programmer, he's judged by how good a programmer he is and not by his personal background,'' adds Schickler, who is serving 20 years for manslaughter. The computer school at Somers was started in 1982. But under the tutelage of Department of Correction teacher Carl Gabbert, it has grown from a few small, unsophisticated computers to 15 IBM-compatible personal computers, all with the latest software. There's a waiting list to get in. ``Nobody turns their life around until they've made a decision to,'' says William E. Flower, a Department of Correction spokesman. ``But once they've made a decision to turn their life around, then they need a vehicle. That's what this program provides.'' A mainframe consultant before his 1984 conviction, Schickler could be ``in the top one-hundredth of 1 percent'' of the computer field in the United States, says Carey Prague, assistant director of corporate finance at Travelers Cos. and a volunteer adviser to the program. For 25-year-old Douglas Lavigne, computers have meant a focus, an eventual career and a source of pride that he never had when he was free. At 17, Lavigne was sentenced to 20 years for manslaughter in a drug-related shooting and stabbing when he was still a high school senior. While his classmates went off to college, Lavigne went to prison. The Parole Board recently reduced Lavigne's sentence to 18 years, which means a possible release within a few years. Lavigne is hoping for college and a computer career. ``I'm young enough. I got a second chance and I took advantage of it,'' the soft-spoken Lavigne said as he demonstrated a class-devised program that tracks health records at another prison. ``I got more hours on a computer than anybody else my age _ that's for sure. I can compete. I just got to get the old formal education and then I'm all set.'' William ``Toby'' Wright, who had a 10th-grade education and worked for a dry cleaner and carpenter before he was convicted of manslaughter eight years ago, landed an interview as a progammer at Aetna Life & Casualty when he became eligible for parole recently. Parole was denied so it never went any further, but Prague said Wright and the others will have no problem finding lucrative jobs. In fact, Prague, the author of 23 books on computers and a consultant for Ashton-Tate Co., says some of the inmates _ Schickler and Lavigne in particular _ are so good they could easily make annual salaries that top $100,000. Prague thought he would volunteer as a teacher, but, ``I found they knew more than I did.'' Now he advises them on their futures. Most of the schoolwork has gone to computerize various aspects of the prison, but Gabbert's class has also done work for the outside. The class recently signed on as a test site for Ashton-Tate, testing the software giant's newest products. It is ideally suited because the work is rigorous and time-consuming. When correction officials decided in 1988 that the prison's pharmacy system was obsolete, they turned to the computer class. Computer vendors had told the department that the equipment to make the pharmacy efficient would cost up to $60,000 or more. The inmates were able to do it for $13,500, and they trained the staff to use the low-cost system without outside help. The computer processes 300 prescriptions a day, produces labels, tracks medical histories and maintains an inventory of 1,200 drugs, serving two other institutions. All is not trust. The class instructor watches out for mischief as well. For the computer whizzes at Somers, money is clearly not the draw. The most they can make in prison is $1.40 a day. ``The word I keep going back to is `self esteem,''' Schickler says. ``The whole reason that we're in here is to pay a debt, you might say. I kind of feel good when one of the guys, someone who has never touched a computer before, gets a job or a letter of commendation. Knowing that I was a part of it gives me a lot of satisfaction.'' For Lavigne, computers may be the way he can restore the faith he believes his family lost in him eight years ago. ``I put them through hell and back again, and I have to try to do some making up there,'' he says. ``They stuck by me through this whole thing, so hopefully they'll be proud of me some day.''
