DOC.HEAD: Pinnacle West's Board Rejects Revised Offer by PacifiCorp
DOC.TEXT: PacifiCorp said it will continue its courtship of Pinnacle West Capital Corp. despite the Arizona company's rejection of a sweetened $1.7 billion takeover offer. Pinnacle West announced Monday that its board had rejected the offer by PacifiCorp, saying it was subject to a number of conditions which sharply reduced its value. PacifiCorp's offer to exchange 0.88 of its new common shares for each of Pinnacle West's 86.7 million outstanding shares of common superseded two previous offers, including one in December for $8 a share, or a total of $693.9 million. PacifiCorp's shares fell 37{ cents on the New York Stock Exchange Monday to $22.12{. At that price, its offer valued Pinnacle West at $19.47 a share or $1.7 billion. Pinnacle West stock fell 25 cents Monday to $11.75. ``The board unanimously determined that PacifiCorp's proposal is inadequate and not in the best interest of Pinnacle West and its shareholders,'' said Pinnacle West Chairman Richard Snell. ``PacifiCorp's proposal is highly conditional and faces regulatory hurdles.'' A PacifiCorp spokesman said the company is studying its options and that no decision had been made on what the company will do next. The spokesman said the company is still interested. PacifiCorp said it had intended its offer to be friendly and had left the door open for a complete restructuring of arrangements, including a cash purchase of Pinnacle West's largest unit in place of the proposed merger. Pinnacle West's subsidiaries include Arizona Public Service Co., Arizona's largest electric utility. PacifiCorp. is a Portland, Ore.-based electric utility whose service territories cover seven states. PacifiCorp has said it hopes to acquire Arizona Public Service because APS' summer high power needs would complement the winter high power needs of PacifiCorp's existing utility operations in the Northwest. PacifiCorp's previous offers were made in November and December. The first was approximately $1.7 billion for just APS while the second was for about $2 billion for all of Pinnacle West minus MeraBank, a troubled thrift which since has been seized by the federal government. Pinnacle West never responded to the first offer, and its board on Dec. 14 rejected the second, which was made Dec. 1. In rejecting the offer, Pinnacle West said it was conditional on various terms, including the equity of APS, liabilities of other subsidiaries and several regulatory matters. ``Our board strongly believes that the best course for Pinnacle West is to continue as an independent company and allow our shareholders to benefit directly from any improvement in the company,'' Snell added. PacifiCorp said its latest offer represented a premium of 75 percent above market value. The company had put the premium of its Dec. 1 offer at 52 percent. ``We increased our offer to reflect Pinnacle's resolution of its MeraBank obligations, refinancing of its debpt and additional analysis of the benefits of merging PacifiCorp Electric Operations with Arizona Public Service,'' PacifiCorp Chief Executive Officer Al Gleason said Monday in a statement. PacifiCorp spokesman Ed Grosswiller said the $1.7 billion of the latest offer includes $2.1 billion for APS and $850 for two other Pinnacle West and the Arizona company's debt of $1.2 billion, he said. Pinnacle West last month reported a $551.4 million loss for last year. The company said the loss was due mostly to discontinued operations at MeraBank and Malapai Resources Co., a uranium subsidiary. ``As to Pinnacle West's foreseeable future, I see a company focused on a recovery plan that won't be accomplished overnight but one certainly moving in the right direction,'' Snell said.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Objects to Proposed Sale of Eastern's South American Routes
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp. has formally objected to Eastern Airlines' proposed sale of its prized Latin American routes to rival American Airlines, saying the deal would hurt airline competition. Pan Am, the nation's eighth-largest airline, said Monday it had filed its objection with the Department of Transportation in Washington. Pan Am asked the department to conduct a hearing on the proposed $471 million sale. The transaction must be approved by the department and federal bankruptcy court in New York, where Eastern filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors last March after pilots, flight attendants and Machinists struck the Miami-based airline. ``In order to preserve the competitive balance in Miami, certain specific routes that are a part of the proposed transfer (to American) should instead be awarded to Pan Am,'' New York-based Pan Am said in a statement. Pan Am asserted that it, rather than American, should be awarded service from Miami to Guayaquil and Quito, Ecuador; Lima, Peru; and Bogota, Colombia. Pan Am also said it should be given the Miami-Toronto route, also included in Eastern's agreement with American. Pan Am said it objects to ``the wholesale acquisition of a comprehensive network of valuable restricted routes, giving American in one fell swoop an entrenched position at Miami.'' American, the nation's largest carrier, agreed in late December after months of haggling to buy the Latin American routes from Eastern. The sale would reduce Eastern to about two-thirds its pre-strike size. The transfer would ``convert Miami from a three-carrier, competitive hub...to a two-carrier hub that eventually may be dominated by American Airlines,'' Pan Am said. Eastern's other Latin American destinations include Guatemala City; Panama City; San Jose, Costa Rica; Asuncion, Paraguay; Cali, Colombia; and La Paz, Bolivia.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Trial to Determine if State Can Punish Amtrak for Dumping
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has scheduled an April 30 trial to determine if Florida can enforce state pollution laws against Amtrak and its practice of flushing toilets along the tracks. U.S. District Judge Howell W. Melton has set aside three days for the nonjury trial in Jacksonville. The trial will decide whether Amtrak and its officials can be sentenced in a state criminal case the railroad lost in December in Palatka. The state charged that Amtrak illegally dumped raw sewage from its trains, and that some entered creeks and rivers. A circuit court jury found Amtrak guilty, but Melton issued an injunction halting a Jan. 18 criminal sentencing. Amtrak's attorneys contend the rail service is exempt from state environmental law and that the state laws interfere with interstate commerce. The case stems from a Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission investigation into Amtrak dumping in November and December of 1988 and May of 1989. Amtrak was charged with dumping wastes into Rice Creek and the St. Johns River. State Attorney John Tanner, who took Amtrak to court on the four felony charges because the specific dumping occurred in his northeastern Florida judicial district, has said he will not seek to jail any Amtrak officials in the case, but wants the dumping stopped.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky's Grandson to Do Underwear Ad
DOC.TEXT: Take off the expensive suit, the suspenders, the designer socks, the silk shirt, and what would O. Stillman Rockefeller be? Just another scantily clad millionaire selling underwear. The grandson of former New York governor Nelson Rockefeller will soon be seen modeling Jockey brand underwear. He announced his plans at a news conference Tuesday with fellow underwear salesman Jim Palmer, the Hall of Fame pitcher. Rockefeller will donate his fee for doing the ad to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, said publicist Natasha Devlin. The first ad, which will be print only, is set to appear in the next issue of Forbes magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Company Begins Resupply of Sparkling Water
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, The company ... to CORRECT wording on new bottles to ``Nouvelle'' sted ``New.'' INSERTS 8 new grafs after 4th graf pvs, The new ... to include U.S. marketing plans. Picks up 5th graf pvs, The recall ...
DOC.TEXT: The producers of Perrier sparkling water began resupplying their distributors today, three weeks after ordering the recall of 160 million bottles worldwide. The company said bottles marked with the words ``Nouvelle Production'' would be available Wednesday in French stores and throughout most of Europe, Canada and the eastern United States by early April. The new bottled water will be available in the western United States by April 22, Perrier said. U.S. importers plan to spend $25 million on a marketing campaign aimed first at building anticipation of the return of the drink that became a status symbol in the 1980s and then to rebuild sales of the top-selling imported bottled water brand in the United States. Ads scheduled to run Wednesday in 22 major-market or national newspapers will use the theme ``Perrier. Worth Waiting For.'' A companion radio campaign also will be used in the 15 biggest markets that takes a humorous approach, using the format of the Perrier News Network detailing reported sightings of Perrier in various locations. A new advertising campaign is being prepared for use when the beverage is in wide circulation across the country. Ronald V. Davis, president and chief executive of The Perrier Group of America, told a news conference in New York that he expects the first bottles of the new Perrier to start appearing in New York in early April. He said the beverage will begin showing up in other U.S. markets over the next 60 to 90 days. He said it will take until the end of summer to make all varieties of Perrier available throughout the United States. Davis declined to estimate what the cost of the recall has been, but said Perrier normally could have expected sales of $30 million during the four months it will have been either off the market or in limited distribution. But at the same time, he said retailers have given about half of the shelf space that Perrier would have occupied to other brands distributed by Perrier Group, including Poland Spring, Arrowhead and Calistoga. The recall was announced Feb. 14 after traces of benzene, a cancer-causing chemical, were found in Perrier samples in several countries, including the United States, Canada, West Germany, the Netherlands and Denmark. Benzene, a naturally occurring chemical used in cleaning solvents, entered Perrier's bottling line when workers failed to replace a filter, the company said. Perrier said today that an international team of experts, using ``extremely sophisticated techniques,'' would ensure that the mineral water henceforth was pure. ``Our task now is to serve the consumer, whoser patience, confidence and understanding has deeply touched us,'' said Perrier's president, Gustave Leven, who founded the company in 1948. The company said it had commissioned a survey in France, Britain, the United States and Canada indicating that four out of five Perrier drinkers would start buying the sparkling water again as soon as it became available. The company said it had not yet been able to calculate the worldwide cost of the resupply program. In France, unlike other countries, the recall was voluntary. Some supermarket chains cleared their shelves of the product, while other shopowners continued to sell it.

DOC.HEAD: Replacement Drivers Quitting Greyhound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Unions representing...', with two grafs to ADD company's estimate of replacement drivers who have quit. Picks up 5th graf, `An internal...'.
DOC.TEXT: Some drivers hired by Greyhound Lines Inc. to replace strikers in the sometimes violent, 4-day-old nationwide walkout have quit. ``There have been a few of them that have left, and we are not surprised by that,'' Greyhound spokesman George Gravley confirmed Monday after sources who refused to be identified said some replacement drivers have walked off the job. In the company's central region, covering the northern third of the country roughly from Pittsburgh to Denver, 32 replacements have quit, the sources said. Unions representing 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenance workers began the strike Friday. Gravely estimated that about 8 percent of the replacement drivers had quit, or 56 of the 700 first hired, but he said the departures occurred in the first two days of the strike and have not caused the company to reduce service. An internal message sent to Greyhound reservations and district officials said the company is being forced to lower its level of service in the central region partly because of the loss of newly hired drivers. But Gravley said the change was forced mainly because fewer than expected replacements were hired. As for those who quit, he said, ``They knew what they were getting into. These people were recruited and they were told honestly and forthrightly ... the nature of the work. We told them that there could be times when they might be intimidated.'' Shots have been fired at a bus in Chicago, a striking driver was killed when he was crushed by a bus backing up to get around a picket line in Redding, Calif., and vandalism of buses been reported around the nation. Chairman Fred G. Currey has said Greyhound can withstand the strike in part because more than 6,500 people have applied to be permanent replacements for the drivers. Greyhound maintains it will be at full service before the end of March. Currey said 350 union drivers are at work and the company is providing about 29 percent of its normal service, though that rate is as high as 50 percent in the Denver area. The union said only 95 members have crossed picket lines. The strike began over wages and job security Friday when contract negotiations collapsed. No full scale talks have been held since. In another development, a judge in Portland, Ore., on Monday barred strikers from interfering with replacements. ``The potential for someone to be injured or killed is tremendous,'' Circuit Judge Robert W. Redding said. Six other such orders have been issued nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: South African Diamond Giant To Split Into Two
DOC.TEXT: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the huge South African diamond mining concern, said today it would split itself in two and base one of the newly formed companies in Switzerland. The move appeared to be an attempt by the company to minimize its exposure to potential political turbulence in South Africa, where a newly energized black majority has vowed to nationalize major industries if it wins power from the white minority. But De Beers Chairman Julian Ogilvie Thompson denied that there were political reasons for the company's split, saying it reflected the international nature of De Beers and the diamond business and that it was in the interests of shareholders and the industry. He also said the company's earnings jumped 37 percent last year. Thompson made his comments at a Johannesburg news conference to which London reporters were hooked up. De Beers' shares jumped 1.80 pounds, or $2.97, to 13.63 pounds, or $22.49, on London's Stock Exchange today after Thompson spoke. The South African company will continue to be called De Beers Consolidated Mines. De Beers' foreign businesses, which accounted for 80 percent of De Beers' 1989 net profit, will be grouped under a Swiss company to be called De Beers Centenary AG, it said. De Beers said it would split itself by giving existing shareholders one share in the Centenary company for each De Beers share they already own. Ogilvie Thompson also denied that the decision was linked to the failure of Minorco SA's failed hostile takeover bid for the British mining company Consolidated Gold Fields PLC last year. That bid by Minorco, which is controlled by De Beers and the Anglo American Corp., was seen as a move by the gold and diamond mining empire to diversify away from South Africa. Ogilvie Thompson said the plan had been under active discussion since last year. De Beers said its earnings for 1989 came to 2.87 billion rand, about $1.1 billion at current exchange rates, vs. 2.09 billion rand in 1988. Revenue rose 31 percent to 4.2 billion rand from 3.2 billion rand. The company didn't break out quarterly or six-month results.

DOC.HEAD: Raising Rates, How It's Done
With AM-Postage Increase, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Raising the cost of postage isn't like stamping a new price on cereal or changing the sticker on a car. Congress, which once had final say on stamp prices, surrendered that authority in 1971 when it established the quasi-independent U.S. Postal Service. But it set up a lengthy and complex system for rate changes when they do occur. As in any business, postal managers keep track of their costs and income and decide when they are losing money and a rate increase is needed. There's no longer a taxpayer subsidy to pay the difference. The first step is to go to the Board of Governors, a presidentially appointed panel that supervises the post office operation. If the board agrees with the managers, it votes to request a rate increase and sends that plan, along with a detailed justification, to the independent Postal Rate Commission. The commission, a separate presidentially appointed board, has 10 months to consider the request. It solicits comments from individuals and businesses, holds hearings and conducts studies before sending a series of recommendations back to the board of governors. If those recommendations are the same as the original proposal, or close enough that the board finds them acceptable, the governors can set a date for the new rates to take effect. If the governors disagree, they can ask the commission to reconsider, come up with a new set of proposals themselves or, if they vote unanimously, can overrule the commission and put the original proposed rate into effect.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Industry Publication Group Up For Sale
DOC.TEXT: Thomson Corp., a publishing conglomerate based in Toronto, wants to sell its Ward's Communications Inc., a group of automotive-related magazines and newsletters. Ward's employees were notified of the move Monday. Gerald D. Tenser, vice president of the Thomson subsidiary Thomson Information-Publishing Group in Stamford, Conn., said the organization hoped to make the sale within three months. Tenser declined to say how much the company was seeking or whether it had offers. He said Thomson has instituted a policy which has resulted in the divestment of several trade magazines. Ward's, whose publications are highly respected in the automotive industry, began in 1924 by publishing statistics on the industry. Thomson acquired Ward's in 1981. Publications include two monthly magazines _ Ward's Auto World and Ward's Auto Dealer _ and newsletters including Ward's Automotive Reports and Ward's Engine Update.

DOC.HEAD: Ratify New Contract
DOC.TEXT: News writers for CBS radio and television stations in four cities have ratified a three-year contract giving them two 5-percent raises over the life of the pact. The agreement covers 325 news writers, editors, desk assistants, researchers, promotion writers and graphic artists of the Writers Guild of America, East and West, in New York, Washington, Chicago and Los Angeles. Employees will receive an immediate 5 percent wage increase and another 5 percent raise in September 1991, as well as increases in various fees for special work, union spokesman Martin Waldman said Tuesday. The increases will raise the average news writers' salary to $951 by the end of the contract, Waldman said. CBS also agreed to provide special screens or hoods for all video display terminals, and where possible, space the VDTs at least three feet apart, Waldman said. The agreement was ratified late Monday night by a vote of 87.2 percent for and 12.8 percent against, Waldman said. Those covered include staffers at ``CBS News With Dan Rather,'' ``CBS Morning News,'' WCBS-TV and WCBS radio in New York, WBBM-TV and WBBM radio in Chicago and KCBS-TV and KNX radio in Los Angeles. The new contract is retroactive to last Friday when the old three-year agreement expired. The guild ratified a new three-year contract with Capital Cities-ABC on Feb. 5.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Arab States Planning Switch to Lead-Free Gasoline by 1995
DOC.TEXT: The six Gulf Cooperation Council member states are considering a plan to produce only lead-free gasoline by 1995, GCC officials said Tuesday. The plan would involve the Persian Gulf states of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Oman, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, according to oil industry officials attending a three-day meeting of petroleum refiners. ``Gasoline consumed in the U.A.E. will be lead-free by the year 1995,'' said Mohammed Abdullah al-Ojeil, head of the United Arab Emirates team. Mahmoud Sayar of the GCC secretariat said that, ``All GCC states now have their own plan to produce lead-free gasoline.'' Qatar is to start producing lead-free gasoline by the year 1993. Saudi Arabia has started producing methyl tertiary butyl ether, widely known as MTBE, a substance which compensates for the lower octane level of unleaded gasoline. Lead has long been used as an additive to improve the performance of automobile engines, but studies have shown that it is highly polluting and that in concentrated doses it can cause brain damage and mental retardation, especially among children. Unleaded gasoline was introduced in the United States in the 1970s and has more recently been distributed in European countries as well. The 11-member Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries, an all-Arab group of oil producers, has made the issue of air pollution one of its primary concerns. Oil ministers of the GCC countries, which also belong to OAPEC, have formed a working team to discuss the issue.

DOC.HEAD: Lose $56 Million In 20 Days
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. lost $56 million in the first 20 days after filing on Jan. 15 for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the companies reported. In a monthly financial statement required as part of their bankruptcy reorganization, the retail firms headquartered in Cincinnati reported $236 million in sales in those 20 days. Federated had sales of $158.6 million over that span but lost $37.04 million. Allied had sales of $77.3 million and lost $18.9 million, the statements released Monday reported. In financial statements filed with the bankruptcy court, Federated and Allied stated their combined bankruptcy expenses in those 20 days totaled $1.72 million. The operating loss before interest and taxes at Federated was $55.5 million. That includes an operating loss of $45.4 million from its 132 department stores, including Bloomingdale's, Lazarus, Abraham & Straus, Burdines and Rich's. Federated and Allied listed a total of $7.7 billion in assets when they sought protection from creditors in order to reorganize their finances, the biggest bankruptcy filing in retailing history. The companies were struggling partly because of billions of dollars owed in connection with the Campeau Corp.'s debt-financed takeover of Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. The unaudited results by division showed: _ Bloomingdale's had sales of $44.4 million and an operating loss before interest and taxes of $11.2 million; _ Lazarus and Abraham & Straus had sales of $59.1 million and an operating loss of $20.1 million; _ Rich's had sales of $26.2 million and an operating loss of $7.3 million; _ Burdines had sales of $28.8 million and an operating loss of $6.7 million; The operating loss for Allied's 128 stores was $22.4 million. Among Allied's retail units, which include Jordan Marsh, Maas Inc. and The Bon Marche, only Stern's reported an operating profit _ $121,000 on sales of $17.2 million. In the other units: _ Jordan Marsh reported sales of $19.7 million and an operating loss of $12.8 million; _ Maas reported sales of $21.7 million and an operating loss of $5.9 million; _ The Bon Marche reported sales of $18.6 million and an operating loss of $3.9 million.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Mixed; Gold Advances
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar turned in a mixed performance in European trading Tuesday, with a late surge against the yen and the West German mark. Gold was higher. The dollar had eased through much of afternoon in Europe, but dealers said it moved higher on a spurt of buying largely pegged to speculative interest in testing central bank resolve to hold the dollar down. The dollar closed at 1.7005 marks, down from 1.7035 marks late Monday. The U.S. currency closed in Europe at 149.75 yen, up from 149.50 yen at the earlier close in Tokyo. The Tokyo quote was down 0.45 yen from the previous day. Bank of Japan intervention in Asian dealings had pushed the dollar lower. Though dealers noted that even though the U.S. Federal Reserve was spotted in the European market, selling dollars for yen late in the day, the impact was minimal. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.4985 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.7450 French francs, down from 5.7515; 1.9105 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9155; 1,254.75 Italian lire, down from 1,255.00; and 1.1866 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1904. In London, British pound was quoted at $1.6495, up from $1.6390 late Monday. Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $405 a troy ounce, up from $403.75 late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $405.50 dollars per troy ounce, up from $403.25. Gold in Hong Kong rose $1.29 to close at a bid $404.73. Silver traded at a late bid price of $5.15 per troy ounce, up 2 cents from late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Trading Reform Tops Futures Industry's Agenda
DOC.TEXT: The panic in the pits has passed but not the ensuing push for commodity market reform, a sensitive subject that is foremost on the minds of futures brokerage executives meeting this week in Florida. Last year's Futures Industry Association meeting was a tense affair despite the traditional tropical setting as brokerage and exchange officials fretted over the revelation two months earlier of a trading fraud investigation at the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Since then, 48 people have been indicted and 16 have pleaded guilty to federal charges of cheating customers, and FIA leaders say the futures industry has stabilized. ``I think it's much more relaxed this year,'' said David Vogel, chairman of the New York-based trading company LIT America Inc. and vice chairman of the FIA, a trade association headquartered in Washington with about 270 member firms. The 1,200 people attending this year's FIA annual meeting in Boca Raton, which begins Wednesday, expect to hear from lawmakers, federal regulators and exchange officials on their progress toward restoring public confidence in the futures markets. Despite its problems, Vogel said the futures industry is healthier financially than the layoff-riddled securities industry. Futures are contracts to buy and sell agricultural commodities and financial instruments at a price agreed upon before the delivery date. FIA Chairman David Ganis said talk about congressional reauthorization of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the federal regulator of futures trading, is likely to dominate the meeting. At least 18 members of Congress, including some who have proposed reform measures, are expected to speak at the convention, most of them on Saturday. One of the most hotly debated reform issues in the reauthorization process has been dual trading, the practice among floor brokers of trading for their own accounts as well as their customers. Critics contend the practice invites fraud; proponents say it makes futures markets more efficient. Last year, the House of Representatives passed a CFTC reauthorization bill that would sharply curtail dual trading until futures exchanges demonstrate an ability to detect wrongdoing ``to the greatest degree that is technologically and humanly possible.'' The Senate is expected to vote on a similar bill this spring. CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm will address the convention on Thursday and is likely to tout reform measures the regulatory agency is pursuing on its own, including limits on dual trading, tougher record-keeping rules and increased use of undercover CFTC staffers in the trading pits. Leaders of the Chicago and New York futures exchanges also will attend to discuss the progress they have made on electronic trading systems that would supplement and possibly replace face-to-face trading in commodity pits. Several exchanges also are working on hand-held electronic devices that would replace the paper cards on which traders record their transactions. Ganis, president of Chicago-based Northern Futures Corp., said the Florida meeting will show there is no one-shot cure for commodity fraud but that everyone in the industry is contributing to a solution. ``We need to create an understanding that all of these actions, not just a law here, a regulation there, but all of these actions taken together will result in improved investor confidence in our markets,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``That's the key issue.'' Exchange officials are likely to criticize the Bush administration's budget proposal for an 11-cents-per-trade fee on futures transactions, which they say will drive business away from U.S. markets to cheaper exchanges overseas. Other issues likely to be addressed in Florida include proposals to increase the margin, or down payment, on stock-index futures and to transfer regulatory authority over stock-index futures from the CFTC to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Both proposals stem from the perception that computer-driven program trading techniques involving index futures inject harmful volatility into the stock market. Futures exchange leaders say that perception is erroneous.

DOC.HEAD: Stamp Prices Likely to Nibble Away Another Nickel
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with announcement; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Unlike a ...
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Postal Service today began the complex process of adding a nickel to the price of mailing a letter. With a record $1.6 billion loss looming in this fiscal year, Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank says the increase is necessary. The postal Board of Governors voted for increases averaging 19 percent and affecting virtually all classes of mail. The charge for first class is to rise from a quarter to 30 cents next year, with each additional ounce increasing from 20 cents to 23 cents. Post cards would cost 20 cents rather than 15 to send. And rates will also rise for advertising, magazines, parcels and other types of mail. ``Even at 30 cents, postage is one of America's best buys,'' said Frank. That increase would be somewhat more than the rate of inflation, said Frank, who promised to hold postal spending below the inflation rate at least through 1995. Unlike a store manager, however, Frank can't simply slap a new price tag on the goods. The proposal must go to the independent Postal Rate Commission, which has 10 months to consider the request, hold hearings and issue a report. If the commission agrees, rates can go up. If not, it's back to the drawing board unless the postal service board of governors votes unanimously to overrule the commission. Any rate increase would not occur before early 1991. But even though the process is only beginning, sides are being chosen for the battle. Vincent R. Sombrotto, head of the 315,000-member National Association of Letter Carriers, contends that stamps today are cheaper than they were in 1971, if inflation is taken into account. Sombrotto held a news conference Monday to defend the rate hike and to denounce critics of the post office, who have called for private business to be allowed to compete in mail delivery. James C. Miller, who was federal budget director under President Reagan, is spearheading the campaign in favor of private competition. And consumer advocate Ralph Nader is trying to organize opposition to the proposed rate increase. While first-class mail rates attract the most public attention, new charges would cover all classes of mail. Groups representing magazines, newspapers, advertisers and other large mailers will be intensely interested in the proposals. Postal charges last increased in 1988. Frank has said he hopes to have only one more price rise in this century. When the old Post Office Department was converted into the U.S. Postal Service in 1971, it was directed to operate like a business and break even over the long haul. The massive tax subsidy that had been used to hold down postage rates was phased out. The postal service has posted five surplus years and five loss years in the the last decade, finishing 1989 about $61 million in the black. The agency had a $404 million surplus in the first quarter of 1990, but rising costs are expected to push it well into the red by the end of the year. Postal officials anticipate a $1.6 billion loss this fiscal year, the largest ever for the agency. Contracts with the four largest unions representing more than 800,000 postal workers also expire this year, and negotiations for new pacts are expected to lead to higher costs. Even at 30 cents for a first-class letter, American postal rates will be the lowest in the industrialized world, officials say. First-class rates are the equivalent of 30.7 cents in Australia and 32.5 cents in Canada. The rate amounts to 33.5 cents in Switzerland and 33.9 cents in Britain. It is the equivalent of 40.5 cents in France, 42.8 cents in Japan, 56.4 cents in Italy and 59.9 cents in West Germany. Here is a rundown of the first-class rates in use since universal rates were introduced in 1863: March 3, 1863, 2 cents per half-ounce. March 3, 1883, 3 cents per half-ounce. July 1, 1885, 2 cents per ounce. Nov. 3, 1917, 3 cents. July 1, 1919, 2 cents. July 6, 1932, 3 cents. Aug. 1, 1958, 4 cents. Jan. 7, 1963, 5 cents. Jan. 7, 1968, 6 cents. May 16, 1971, 8 cents. March 2, 1974, 10 cents. Dec. 31, 1975, 13 cents. May 29, 1978, 15 cents. March 22, 1981, 18 cents. Nov. 1, 1981, 20 cents. Feb. 17, 1985, 22 cents. April 3, 1988, 25 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Post Office Proposes Raising Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with postal service governors voting to raise rates. Picks up 8th graf pvs `But consumer...'
DOC.TEXT: The governors of the U.S. Postal Service voted Tuesday to raise rates, including a nickel jump in the cost of mailing a first-class letter, but there could as much as a year of skirmishing before any increase takes effect. ``Even at 30 cents, postage is one of America's best buys,'' said Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank, noting that U.S. postage remains the lowest in the industrialized world. The proposal calls for the cost of a first-class letter to increase from a quarter to 30 cents, with the price for each additional ounce rising from 20 cents to 23 cents. Post cards would cost 20 cents, also up a nickel, while Express Mail would go from $8.75 to $9.75. Overall, rates will increase by about 19 percent on all types of mail. ``We cannot ignore that increases in postal operating costs do occur, just as they do in any business,'' Robert Setrakiam, chairman of the board of governors, said after the vote. He estimated the increase would cost the average person between $10 and $11 a year. Frank said the increases are needed because the post office could face its biggest deficit ever this year, between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion. The governors' vote was the first step in a nearly year-long process needed to increase mail rates. In addition to the first-class increase, the proposal would raise the cost of mailing a typical weekly newsmagazine from 13.5 cents to 16 cents, while a heavier monthly publication would rise from 29.7 cents to 37.4 cents. The parcel post rate for a 7-pound package would rise from $4 to $5.06. Some rate cuts were included for specially prepared business mail that requires little work on the part of the post office. The skirmishing over postal costs and efficiency began even before the vote was taken. On Monday, Vincent R. Sombrotto, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers, contended that postage today is cheaper than it was in 1971 when inflation is considered. But consumer advocate Ralph Nader is unhappy both with rising rates and service. ``The people are going to have to save the post office from itself,'' said Nader, who proposes setting up an organization of people who use the mail. Business, which will feel increases most in terms of total dollars, is also unhappy with the prospect of paying more. Tracey Schreft of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce called the planned increase ``unreasonable and unjustified.'' Robert Kamerschen, head of ADVO System Inc., the nation's largest advertising mailer, said he was concerned that raising rates would drive profitable mail out of the postal system when it's needed most. The proposed increase would be somewhat more than the rate of inflation, but Frank promises to hold rates below inflation at least through 1995. He has expressed the hope that rates might have to increase only one more time in this century. Increasing the cost of a postage stamp isn't a simple process. The proposal must go to the independent Postal Rate Commission, which has 10 months to consider the request, hold hearings and issue a repert. If the commission agrees, rates can increase. If not, it's back to the drawing board unless the postal board of governors can muster a unanimous vote to overrule the commission. At any rate, an increase will not occur before early 1991. While first-class rates attract the most attention, new charges would cover all classes of mail. Groups representing magazines, newspapers, advertisers and other large mail users are particularly concerned with any changes in the discounts for large-volume mailers who do some of the work themselves. For example, large mailers can get lower prices for pre-sorting their mail, arranging it by ZIP code or even according to the route walked by carriers. Postal charges last increased in 1988. Three years between rate increases has been about average over recent years. When the old Post Office was converted into the U.S. Postal Service in 1971, it was directed to operate like a business, breaking even over the long haul. The massive tax subsidy that had been used to hold down postage rates was phased out. The postal service posted five surplus years and five loss years in the last decade, finishing 1989 about $61 million in the black. The agency had a $404 million surplus in the first quarter of 1990, but rising costs are expected to push it well into the red by the end of the year. Contracts with the four largest unions representing the more than 800,000 postal workers also expire this year, and negotiations are expected to lead to higher costs. For comparison, postal officials report that first-class rates in Australia are the equivalent of 30.7 cents and Canadians pay 32.5 cents. The rate amounts to 33.5 cents in Switzerland and 33.9 cents in England. It is the equivalent of 40.5 cents in France, 42.8 cents in Japan, 56.4 cents in Italy and 59.9 cents in West Germany. Early in U.S. history the cost of mailing a letter varied according to distance. At one time the price was paid by the recipient, not the sender. When universal rates were introduced in 1863, they were for a half-ounce. The rate was changed to a per-ounce basis in 1885. Here is a rundown of the first-class rates in use since 1863: March 3, 1863, 2 cents per half-ounce. March 3, 1883, 3 cents per half-ounce. July 1, 1885, 2 cents per ounce. Nov. 3, 1917, 3 cents. July 1, 1919, 2 cents. July 6, 1932, 3 cents. Aug. 1, 1958, 4 cents. Jan. 7, 1963, 5 cents. Jan. 7, 1968, 6 cents. May 16, 1971, 8 cents. March 2, 1974, 10 cents. Dec. 31, 1975, 13 cents. May 29, 1978, 15 cents. March 22, 1981, 18 cents. Nov. 1, 1981, 20 cents. Feb. 17, 1985, 22 cents. April 3, 1988, 25 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Summary of Proposed New Postal Rates
With AM-Postal Increase,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The board of governors of the U.S. Postal Service voted Tuesday to raise postal rates. If approved by the Postal Rate Commission, the new charges could take effect sometime in early 1991. Here are some highlights of the rates being proposed: _First Class: First ounce rises from 25 cents to 30 cents, each additional ounce rises from 20 cents to 23 cents. Post cards increase from 15 cents to 20 cents. Bulk first-class mail, presorted by ZIP code, increases from 21 cents to 26 cents for the first ounce. Bulk first class sorted according to the route walked by the letter carrier increases from 19.5 cents to 24.5 cents for the first ounce. Discounts will be offered for bulk first-class mail that has barcodes imprinted to allow the mail to be sorted by machine. _Priority Mail: Rates of $2.40 to $72.24 would increase to a range of $2.75 to $85.75 depending on weight. A discount for presorting bulk Priority Mail would be established, a pickup service provided and a new rate set for a special Priority Mail envelope. _Express Mail: The price range of $7.75 to $89.05 would increase to a range of $8.75 to $103.30 depending on weight. The letter rate would rise from $8.75 to $9.75 and the 2-pound rate from $12 to $13.75. Volume discounts would be offered for the first time. _Second Class (newspapers and magazines): The regular rate, outside the home county, ranges from 12.4 cents to 30.2 cents per pound, plus 4.9 cents to 16 cents per piece. That would change to 7 cents to 36.9 cents per pound plus 6.9 cents to 20.1 cents per piece. The rate for non-profit groups is lower, as is that for materials circulating within the same county where they are published. _Third class (advertising mail): Single pieces range of 25 cents to $1.50 would rise to between 30 cents and $1.77. Basic bulk rates of 16.2 cents to 16.7 cents would change to a range of 14.4 cents to 22 cents, and a variety of discounts would be available for extensive presorting of mail. The additional per pound rate would increase from 48 cents to 53.7 cents. The basic non-profit rate of 7.9 cents to 8.4 cents would change to a range of 7.2 cents to 12.5 cents, also with discounts for presorting. The additional per pound rate would rise from 25 cents to 33.1 cents. _Fourth Class: Parcel post's range of $1.43 to $26.61 would rise to a range of $1.57 to $39.95. Printed matter's rates of 67 cents to $5.80 would rise to between 86 cents and $5.74. The library rate of 64 cents for the first pound and 23 cents for added pounds would rise to 65 cents and 24 cents. _Money orders would have a flat charge of 75 cents instead of the current range of 75 cents to $1. _Post office boxes would cost between $25 and $200, up from a range of $14 to $170. _Registered mail would be unchanged at $4.40, but the cost of sending certified mail would go up from 85 cents to 90 cents. _The minimum collect-on-delivery charge would rise from $2 to $2.50. _Insurance would rise to between 75 cents and $5.40, from the current 70 cents to $5. _Special delivery would go up from $5.35 to $5.60. _Return receipts would increase from 90 cents to $1.

DOC.HEAD: Sell InteCom to French Electronics Firm
DOC.TEXT: Financially troubled Wang Laboratories Inc. said Tuesday it will sell subsidiary InteCom Inc., a maker of communication switching systems, to the French electronics firm Matra S.A. for an undisclosed price. Proceeds from the transaction will further reduce the financially troubled computer company's debt and increase its cash, Wang officials said. ``We continue to make steady and deliberate progress in our program to sell non-strategic assets to eliminate Wang's debt to its bank group,'' said Richard W. Miller, president and chief operating officer, in a statement. In mid-February, Wang's bank debt totaled $308 million, spokesman Ed Pignone said. On Feb. 26 the company agreed to sell its international lease financing operations. This sale will reduce the bank debt to $93 million, Pignone said. The debt totaled $575 million last August. Pignone said Wang originally bought InteCom in a deal worth about $238.5 million because the company believed that technological trends in switching warranted such an acquisition.

DOC.HEAD: Eyes Prospects In Czechoslovakia, East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The president of General Motors Corp.'s European division said Tuesday he hopes to reach agreements with Czechoslovakia and East Germany this year to set up auto assembly plants in those countries. Robert J. Eaton, in an interview with The Associated Press, said talks are underway with both countries, but it was too early to say whether an agreement can be reached by the end of the year. ``I hope so, but you never know,'' he said. ``We're early enough in the discussions that it's just too early to predict how they might come out.'' He said the talks involve the possibility of establishing assembly plants in both countries as well as producing automotive components in Czechoslovakia. The negotiations are part of GM Europe's strategy to tap the potential of Eastern European markets as the region embarks on economic reform, Eaton said. GM Europe already has agreed with Hungary to establish a joint venture there to produce 200,000 Opel Kadett compact cars annually, starting in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Says Administration Not Aggressive on Pension Enforcement
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Howard Metzenbaum said Tuesday the Labor Department is not adequately policing the nation's $1.7 trillion pension system and suggested white collar criminals are getting preferential treatment. ``I'm concerned that our government isn't willing to prosecute white collar criminals as aggressively,'' Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said at a hearing on the government's pension investigations. But David Ball, who heads the department's Pension Benefits and Welfare Administration, said several people have been convicted of fradulent pension and gone to jail. Metzenbaum also complained about the Bush administration's plans to fire the Labor Department's acting inspector general, Raymond Maria, who has feuded with the department over its handling of pension investigations and suggested changes to the system. ``You should have the administration cheering for you, not seeking to remove you from your job,'' said Metzenbaum, chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources subcommittee on labor. Maria, whose ouster is believed to be imminent, has said the department improperly relies on civil instead of criminal remedies in policing the nation's pension system. Maria also has said problems with the pension system rival those blamed for the savings and loan crisis. But Ball called comparisons to the S&L crisis ``inflammatory rhetoric'' that was needlessly alarming millions of retirees. Ball said the pension system, with assets that have grown from $290 billion to $1.7 trillion in 15 years, is a ``great success story of the American economic system.'' Metzenbaum called it ``a disaster waiting to happen'' and said Ball's tenure at the Labor Department had been disappointing so far. ``I know nothing you've done except to speak out for the business community to tell them pensions are going to be left alone,'' Metzenbaum said. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole has asked Congress to approve funding for an additional 100 agents to police the pensions system and is studying Maria's suggestions. She has also said private citizens should be encouraged to sue pension officials who misuse the funds. ``In effect, the secretary has thrown up her hands and said she cannot do the job,'' Metzenbaum said. ``It is absurd for the Department of Labor to say that they cannot protect workers' pensions.'' Ball defended the department's pursuit of civil remedies and said criminal investigations are turned over to the Justice Department, where he said they belong. Maria has asked Congress to, in effect, overrule a Justice Department ruling from last year that prohibited inspectors general from launching their own investigations. Maria is expected to be replaced by Julian De La Rosa, secretary of the St. Louis Police Board.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Resists Moves To Raise OPEC Reference Price
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait is resisting moves by other OPEC members to raise the group's crude oil reference price of $18 a barrel, the Kuwaiti newspaper Al-Qabas reported Tuesday. The newspaper, quoting unidentified sources, said ``intensive contacts'' were taking place among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on the price issue ahead of the March 16 meeting in Vienna of the OPEC market monitoring committee. All 13 OPEC oil ministers are expected to attend the meeting. Iraq has suggested that OPEC should increase the $18 price to account for world inflation. Libya also wants a price increase to around $20 to $22, according to a report Monday in the Nicosia-based oil newsletter, Middle East Economic Survey. The reference price, set by OPEC in the mid-1980's, was endorsed at the cartel's last conference in November 1989. The cartel also agreed on a 22 million barrel-per-day production ceiling for the first half of 1990. Al-Qabas said Kuwait remains adamant in opposing any increase in the reference price, preferring instead to see higher production quotas and a higher overall OPEC ceiling. Oil ministers from Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Iraq discussed OPEC policy at a weekend meeting in Kuwait. A statement issued after the meeting said the three were ``in complete agreement that their countries should uphold OPEC's resolutions and its endeavors to stabilize the oil market.'' No other details were released.

DOC.HEAD: Sell Insurance Division to Big Italian Company
DOC.TEXT: The BMA Corp. said Tuesday it has agreed to sell Business Men's Assurance Co. for $285 million to an Italian company that is one of Europe's largest insurers. BMA Corp. announced in October that it wanted to sell the insurance subsidiary, saying it was too small to handle the industry's falling profit margins. The sale to Generali-Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. should be final in July pending approval of regulators and shareholders. The acquisition will give the Italian company a presence in the U.S. life insurance market for the first time, said U.S. representative Giorgio Balzer. Balzer spoke to employees Tuesday afternoon, assuring them the company planned to keep operations in Kansas City, said BMA spokesman Alex Matthews. ``He indicated that the company will be growing in Kansas City, that they would be adding to the base that we have here now,'' Matthews said. The sale would leave the BMA Corp., which was formed as a holding company in 1988, with interests in real estate, insurance services and venture capital. It also owns 69 percent of Home Office Reference Laboratory, a Lenexa, Kan., company that is one of the nation's largest blood-testing firms for health insurance policies. Under terms of the sale, Generali will acquire 95 percent of BMA's stock with an option to acquire the rest in four years. It will pay the BMA Corp. $157 million and transfer about $128 million in real estate investments and other assets from BMA to the holding company. Generali will receive shares in Home Office and be represented on its board. ``We believe this transaction is in the best interest of BMA Corporation shareholders, both because of the attractive financial terms and also because of Generali-BMA's continuing relationship with HORL,'' said Tom Grant, president and chief executive officer of BMA Corp. His father founded the insurance firm in 1909. He called the decision to sell the insurance division ``a difficult one,'' but said policyholders would be well protected by Generali's size and reputation. BMA sells life insurance and group health insurance in 48 states and had more than $31 billion in life insurance written as of Dec. 31. It had revenues of $325 million in 1988 while the holding company as a whole had revenues of about $500 million and profits of $20 million. The company has about 800 employees in Kansas City and almost 1,000 nationwide, Matthews said. About 750 employees in Kansas City work for the insurance division. The company sold its individual health insurance line and went through a restructuring in 1988 because of shrinking profits. Generali, based in Trieste, Italy, has 56 subsidiaries in 40 countries. It had assets of $24 billion in 1988 and revenues from premiums of $8.3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola Testing ``New'' New Coke
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, Meyers said... with 1 new grafs to UPDATE with Coke spokesman's description of Coke II label design. Picks up 7th graf pvs, The Coke... ^By MARC RICE
DOC.TEXT: New Coke, the reformulated, sweeter version of Coca-Cola that inspired a consumer rebellion before sinking to the bottom tier of soft drink sales, is trying out a new name and a different look, its maker said Tuesday. Coca-Cola Co. said it plans to test market new Coke under the name Coke II. Spokesman Randy Donaldson said Coke II would be sold initially in one city, which he would not identify, within the next few months. The formula of the newly named drink will not be changed, Donaldson said. Industry observers speculated that if the new name was adopted, the company could return the Coca-Cola brand name to the original formula, now called Coke Classic. Jesse Meyers, the Greenwich, Conn., publisher of the industry newsletter Beverage Digest, said the Coke II test marks the first big shot of the 1990s in the cola wars between Coca-Cola and archrival Pepsi Cola. Meyers said he has seen the proposed packaging for Coke II, and its red, white and blue design with blue lettering closely resembles that of Pepsi. Coke's Donaldson said the Coke II can is red, white and blue, but unlike Pepsi it has a red background with white letters and a blue outline. The Coke II test comes as new Coke, regarded by some as one of the great blunders in marketing history, nears its fifth anniversary. Atlanta-based Coca-Cola announced in April 1985 that after extensive taste tests it was changing the formula of Coke, the world's best-selling soft drink. Consumer reaction against the new, sweeter-tasting product was so strong that the company two months later apologized and brought back the original formula under the name Coca-Cola Classic. Coke Classic regained the position as the No. 1 soft drink. New Coke also remained, but its market share now is a relatively tiny 1.4 percent compared to Coke Classic's 20 percent share. Coke officials always have maintained that new Coke, despite its Coca-Cola label, essentially is a new product and that its sales should be judged in that respect. Donaldson denied that the Coke II test means the company is running up the white flag on new Coke. ``After five years, new Coke is no longer new, though it's still called new Coke,'' he said. ``We just want to make it easier to distinguish between Coke II and Coke Classic.'' And he said there are no plans to change the name of Coca-Cola Classic back to Coca-Cola. ``There are no plans to change anything about Coke Classic at all,'' he said. But Meyers, a respected observer of the soft drink industry said, ``The name Coke Classic may be on the way out.'' Emanuel Goldman, who follows the soft drink industry for Paine Webber Inc. in San Francisco, said the Coke II label, if adopted, would remove the perception that new Coke is a failure. Coca-Cola is ``the premier brand name in the world,'' he said. ``You don't want something called Coca-Cola that doesn't work, so you call it Coke II,'' Goldman said. ``I think it's not such a bad thing to do. The name of the game is Coca-Cola.'' Pepsi spokesman Tod MacKenzie called the Coke II test an acknowledgement by Coke that Pepsi was a superior product. ``Whether it's Coke II or new new Coke, it's another validation of Coke's interest in the great taste of Pepsi,'' MacKenzie said from his office in Purchase, N.Y. ``This isn't the first time they've tried to imitate us, and it likely won't be the last,'' he said. Coke's recent advertising has pitted diet Coke, rather than Coca-Cola or Coke Classic, against Pepsi. Meyers said he expected Coca-Cola now wants to position Coke II against its competitor. ``They've had a very subtle approach,'' he said. ``If this approach works, they'll go to a gross all-out attack.''

DOC.HEAD: Livestock Futures Higher
DOC.TEXT: Most livestock and meat futures rose strongly Tuesday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, helped by short-term demand and favorable shipping weather. On other futures markets, soybeans soared, grains were mixed, while oil products, precious metals and coffee all dipped. A higher-than-expected cash market and a belief that Monday's futures market was oversold pushed pork prices higher, said Phil Stanley, a trader-consultant. Contract highs were set on live hog futures for delivery in June, July, August, October and December. An improvement in weather conditions for animal movement in the U.S. Midwest was credited for better cattle prices, said analyst Paul Hare of Linnco Futures Inc. Cattle settled .05 cent lower to .27 cent higher, with the contract for delivery in April at 76.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .37 cent to .55 cent higher, with March at 81.35 cents a pound; hogs were .25 cent to .85 cent higher, with April at 50.32 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .25 cent to 2.00 cent higher, with March at 48.27 cents a pound. Futures prices for soybeans rose, while grains were mixed at the close Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. A rally in soyoil futures Monday, good soymeal business on European cash markets and talk of Algerian interest in U.S. soymeal helped send soybean prices higher, said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. The soybean contract for delivery in March was at a seven-week high, closing up 7 cents. The rally in soybeans kept corn prices from falling significantly, said Jerry Zusel, manager of CBOT floor operations for Balfour Maclaine Corp. Rainy weather improving the U.S. winter wheat crop and lack of large-volume export business depressed futures prices for that commodity, traders said. Wheat settled 3} cents lower to 2{ cents higher, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.81\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1{ cent lower, with March at $2.44 a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to 1} cents higher, with March at $1.45} a bushel; and soybeans were 5{ cents to 7{ cents higher, with March at $5.77} a bushel. Oil products sank lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Peter Cardillo, commodity adviser with Josephthal & Co., said a build up of stocks, especialy gasoline, weighed on futures trading. Crude oil settled 12 cents to 28 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in April at $21.30 a barrel; heating oil was .68 cent to .98 cent lower, with April at 57.22 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was .45 cent to 1.51 cents lower, with April at 57.79 cents a gallon. Precious metals prices were down slightly on the Commodity Exchange in New York. A slight rally early in the session was erased when the U.S. dollar strengthened against foreign currencies, Cardillo said. Gold and the U.S. dollar prices normally in opposite directions. Gold settled 30 cents to 50 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $403.60 a troy ounce; and silver was .1 cent to .2 cent lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $5.12 a troy ounce. Coffee futures closed lower after a volatile session on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. Prices whipped higher then lower on profit-taking and differing views over supply. On Monday, March coffee had hit an eight-month high. On Tuesday, coffee settled 1.75 cents to 3.83 cents lower, with the contract for March at $1.01 a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Exports Soar with Start of Free Market
DOC.TEXT: World exports of coffee jumped by nearly 25 percent last year after international controls on sales were abolished in July, the International Coffee Organization said Tuesday. Exports to all destinations in the last half of 1989 totaled 39.6 million bags, compared with 31.9 million in the comparative period of 1988, the organization reported. One bag equals 60 kilos or 132 pounds. The July-December exports brought total sales for 1989 to 73.2 million bags, up from 65.2 million in 1988, when the coffee organization's system of export quotas was limiting supplies to prop up prices. The quota system was abandoned on July 4 when producer and consumer member governments failed to agree on the terms for its continuation. In the sales free-for-all that followed, the wholesale price of coffee collapsed and hit a 14-year low earlier this year. Brazil lifted its exports in 1989 to 18.269 million bags from 17.082 million in 1988 and Colombian shipments rose to 10.828 million from 9.784 million. Most other countries recording sharp improvements were Latin American producers of the prized mild arabica variety of bean. Mexican exports last year rose to 4.427 million bags from 2.775 million in 1988, Guatemala's were up at 3.067 million from 2.479 million and Costa Rica's at 2.302 million from 2.019 million. Other export totals included Ecuador 1.747 million bags from 1.404 million, Peru 1.432 million from 825 million, Honduras 1.420 million from 1.263 million, Nicaragua 606 million from 549 million and the Dominican Republic 530 million from 439 million. El Salvador was one of the region's few big producers to record a drop in exports at 1.603 million bags from 2.051 million. There was little change in exports of the less popular robusta coffee variety, apart from increased sales by Indonesia which shipped 5.423 million bags, compared with 4.994 million. Ivory Coast shipments dropped last year to 2.623 million bags from 3.660 million in 1988 and it was overtaken as Africa's biggest exporter by Uganda, which shipped 2.937 million bags against 2.404 million in 1988. Exports by Cameroon fell to 1.317 million bags from 1.633 million, while Zaire was up at 1.372 million from 915,000. Other exports by leading producers included Kenya with 1.739 million bags from 1.383 million, Ethiopia 1.699 million from 1.408 million, Papua New Guinea 1.317 million from 748 million and Tanzania 822 million from 613 million.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Close Mixed
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed Tuesday, closing mostly higher in domestic trading after falling overseas in the absence of any major developments to move the foreign exchange markets. Gold prices were mixed. The dollar declined in early going due to trader speculation that an interest rate hike in Japan, which would bolster the yen against the dollar, was imminent. When the increase never materialized, the dollar recovered some ground in Europe, although still closed down from Monday's levels. The dollar then moved higher against most currencies in New York. Robert Ryan, senior foreign exchange trader with Bank of New York Co., said the market shied away from testing the upper end of the dollar's trading range, the point at which central banks, including the Federal Reserve, would be expected to step in and try to push the dollar down. The Bank of Japan intervened in Asian dealings overnight, selling the dollar lower. Dealers said the Fed sold dollars for yen late in the day in the European market, but the impact was minimal. The dollar closed in New York at 149.85 yen, up from Monday's 149.025 yen. In Europe, it closed at 149.75 yen after slipping 0.45 yen in earlier Tokyo trading to 149.50 yen. Ryan said traders generally were awaiting the Labor Department's employment report for February, scheduled for release on Friday. The market expected the nation's non-farm payroll to have expanded by 225,000 jobs, indicating that the economy is stronger than many have thought. Such a report is expected to move the dollar higher because the Fed is less likely to nudge U.S. interest rates downward _ which would diminish returns on dollar-denominated investments _ when the economy shows signs of strength. The dollar fell against the British pound Tuesday. In New York, sterling was quoted at $1.6475, up from $1.6445 late Monday, and in earlier London dealings, it rose to $1.6495 from $1.6390. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.7035 West German marks, up from 1.6970; 1.5000 Swiss francs, up from 1.4970; 5.7565 French francs, up from 5.7330; 1,257.00 Italian lire, up from 1,252.00; and 1.18565 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18905. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.7005 West German marks, down from 1.7035; 1.4985 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.7450 French francs, down from 5.7515; 1.9105 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9155; 1,254.75 Italian lire, down from 1,255.00; and 1.1866 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1904. Gold fell in New York. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fell 50 cents a troy ounce to $403.60, and Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $403.45 a troy ounce, down 85 cents from Monday. Gold traded earlier in London at a late bid of $405 a troy ounce, up from $403.75 late Monday. In Zurich, the bid was $405.50 per troy ounce, up from $403.25. Gold in Hong Kong rose $1.29 to close at a bid of $404.73 an ounce. Silver was unchanged on New York's Comex, closing at $5.116 a troy ounce. In London, silver traded at a late bid of $5.15 per troy ounce, up 2 cents from Monday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the story slugged AM-Ryder, f0178, that moved March 2 under a Miami dateline are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported March 2 that Ryder System Inc. Chairman M. Anthony Burns predicted the company would post a first-quarter loss. Burns actually said the company's net earnings in the first quarter likely would be lower than first-quarter net income in 1989. Also, the company sold off four subsidiaries in 1989, not three, and the company's divisions did not post a loss for that year, although their earnings were lower than the previous year's earnings.

DOC.HEAD: First Qtr Profit Down Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Communications Inc. reported Tuesday its first-quarter profit tumbled 69.4 percent from results a year earlier that included a big contribution from a financial services company that has since been sold. The publishing and entertainment giant said its earnings rose 81.2 percent in comparison with earnings from continuing operations last year, excluding the results from The Associates financial services unit. Paramount said it earned $21.2 million, or 17 cents a share, in the three months ended Jan. 31 compared with earnings of $69.2 million, or 58 cents a share, a year earlier. The first-quarter 1989 results included $57.5 million, or 48 cents a share, from discontinued operations, mainly from The Associates, which was sold in October for $3.35 billion to Ford Motor Co. Revenue for the quarter rose 9.3 percent to $844.6 million from $773.1 million a year ago. The latest results include net interest income of $37.9 million, mainly from the investment of proceeds of The Associates sale. Martin S. Davis, chairman and chief executive, said he expects the company will earn between $2.10 a share and $2.60 a share for the year. The company said its operating income from entertainment was lower despite a sharp gain in television operations, because contributions from motion pictures failed to match strong results a year ago. Gains in television results stemmed mainly from higher operating income from home video operations, the success of ``The Arsenio Hall Show'' and ``Entertainment Tonight,'' and increased contributions from Paramount's 50 percent interest in USA Network. The company posted a larger operating loss in publishing than a year ago, reflecting the impact of more conservative accounting procedures adopted in the fourth quarter of 1989. Gains in higher education, consumer and international publishing operations were more than offset by seasonal losses in school and supplementary education operations, lower earnings in professional information, lower royalty income related to the Silhouette romance book line and higher operating expenses.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose broadly Tuesday in quiet trading, boosted by several waves of computer-driven buying and strength in dollar-trading and the bond market, traders said. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 27.25 to 2,676.80. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,028 up, 489 down and 484 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Board volume totaled 143.64 million shares, up from 140.11 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 175.55 million shares. The currency and bond markets provided little initial direction for the stock market, and stock prices drifted slightly higher. But in the early afternoon, the dollar strengthened, bond prices rose and the buy programs kicked in. ``You had a bond market that waffled a bit and then came on strong,'' said Austin George, head of equity trading for mutual-fund operator T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. By late afternoon, the benchmark 30-year government bond was up 25-32 point, or $7.80 per $1,000 face amount. The dollar rose to 149.85 yen from 149.03 late Monday. Robert L. Kahan, manager of equity trading at Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco, said trading also was quiet until early afternoon due to a lack of market-affecting news. The government reported that orders to factories fell 5.4 percent in January. But the figure was in line with analysts' estimates and had little market impact, traders said. The buying driven by computer programs was launched when stock index futures jumped in price relative to the underlying stocks. ``It just kind of touched the level (to activate the programs) a couple of times,'' George said. Among blue-chip issues on the NYSE, General Electric was up | to 62], American Telephone & Telegraph was up } to 40| and Philip Morris was up 1] to 38\. American Express, the most-active NYSE issue, was down \ to 27\, on top of losing 1~ Monday. Over the weekend, the company announced plans to reacquire the publicly held shares of its troubled Shearson Lehman Hutton brokerage through an exchange of stock. Texaco, another blue chip, was up ~ to 59~. Standard & Poor's Corp. upgraded the rating on Texaco senior debt and preferred stock, citing the oil company's continued improvement in financial performance. Among other most-active issues, Pinacle West jumped 2[ to 13~. The utility and bank holding company rejected a sweetened takeover bid from Pacificorp. Pacificorp fell ] to 21}. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $33.350 billion, or 1.03 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 2.02 to 186.17. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 5.05 to 389.54, and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 4.19 to 337.93. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.18 to 432.33. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 2.17 to 358.81.

DOC.HEAD: Breeden Tells Senate Panel About SEC's Needs
With AM-Congress-Securities, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Regulating a securities firm like Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. without financial data on its parent company is like being a doctor who can only examine part of the body, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission told a Senate panel on Tuesday. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden used a budget hearing before the commerce subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee as an opportunity to lobby for additional authority. Questioned about the recent collapse of Drexel, Breeden said one difficulty for the SEC was lack of data about the parent holding company, which filed for bankruptcy code protection last month. The SEC regulates broker-dealers but not their parent companies, which don't have to disclose their financial status. Legislation pending in both the House and Senate would give the SEC access to such financial data. Breeden likened the limitations on such information to being a physician ``who can only look at the right arm from the elbow to the wrist. It's very unrealistic.'' The Bush administration is seeking $192.4 million for the SEC in 1991, a 14 percent increase over the 1990 appropriation of $168.7 million. Breeden noted that Congress should be mindful that SEC revenue production through filing fees ``have significantly exceeded its appropriations.'' He pointed out that in 1989, while receiving only $142.6 million in appropriations, the SEC generated $213.8 million in fees. But Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., chairman of the subcommittee, asked why the administration was seeking to increase SEC fees an estimated $80 million in 1991. ``Why are you increasing the fees when you got more than enough to run the business? Did you recommend any (increases)?'' he asked. ``This proposal is not a commission proposal,'' said Breeden. ``Ahh, there we go,'' said Hollings, prompting laughter in the cramped hearing room in the Capitol building. Hollings hinted that the fee increase might be an administration move to cut the deficit but Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., noted that the fee increase, approved by Congress last year, was only temporary and the latest administration request would make it permanent.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses To Bar Executive From Trading Stock
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday refused to bar a former Philips Industries executive accused of insider trading from selling more stock in the company, but froze about $1 million of his assets. U.S. District Court Judge Walter Rice approved a request by the Securities and Exchange Commission for the temporary freeze on Robert H. Brethen's assets being held in an escrow account. The SEC sought the freeze to assure payment of any future damages. The SEC has asked the judge for a preliminary injunction to keep Brethen, a former Philips vice chairman, from trading his Philips stock. Rice refused to grant a temporary restraining order pending a hearing. An SEC civil lawsuit against Brethen last week alleged he used non-public information about unfavorable company news to avoid $570,000 in losses in the stock market in January when he sold 109,733 shares for more than $2 million on the New York Stock Exchange. The SEC claimed Brethen would continue to violate securities laws unless he is restrained from further securities trading. The judge had postponed a ruling on the temporary restraining order from last week after the SEC alleged Brethen lied to the commission and tried to cover up his access to inside information. The case is considered unusual because the government said three attorneys and a stockbroker for Brethen have testified that they advised him not to sell the stock because it may violate securities laws. ``Brethen's violations are continuing,'' Jeffrey Zuckerman, assistant regional administrator for the SEC, said in a letter to the judge. ``Brethen was engaging in an ongoing violation in January ... when he was caught in the breach by the commission.'' ``Rather than cooperate with the commission, however, Brethen compounded his violations by engaging in an attempt to cover up,'' the letter said. SEC attorney James Tyne said in court last week that Brethen may be financially strapped because of a new business venture, Celstar Group Inc., and might lose the $1 million he had earlier agreed to place in escrow after the SEC launched an investigation. David Cupps, Brethen's attorney, said his client has cooperated fully with the SEC, including giving voluntary testimony, and should have his money returned ``to conduct his business.'' Brethen, 63, retired at the end of last year from Philips, a manufacturer or components for construction and recreational vehicles. Previously he had been president and chief executive of the compny. Cupps said Brethen no longer has access to inside information and sold some of the stock only after an attorney assured him doing so would be proper. But Tyne said there was a ``very strong likelihood'' of repeated violations because Brethen still owns 100,000 shares of Philis stock, misled the SEC and ignored the advice of at least three lawyers not to sell the shares. The SEC alleged Brethen sold the stock while possessing non-public information that Philips' earnings would be dramatically lower than expected for the final quarter of 1989, which would have an adverse impact on a proposed buyout of Philips.
