DOC.HEAD: Weak Manufacturing Economy Sends Factory Orders Plummeting
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 8th graf to CORRECT name of McDonnell Douglas Corp.; picks up 9th graf pvs bg'ng, ``Aside from ...
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods took their biggest plunge in more than 15 years in January, the government said Tuesday. Analysts described the 5.4 percent drop as temporary and not widespread but said it still indicated an anemic manufacturing economy. The Commerce Department said orders for durable and non-durable goods fell to a seasonally adjusted $227.7 billion, the steepest drop since they sank 7 percent in December 1974. A sharp 10.5 percent January decrease in durable goods orders, to $117.8 billion, led the plunge. A 28.8 percent drop in transportation orders accounted for 85 percent of the durable decline, said economist Michael P. Niemira of Mitsubishi Bank in New York. ``Obviously, if 85 percent of it is in transportation, that doesn't say that it is widespread,'' Niemira said. Automakers laid off 90,000 workers in January while they attempted to shave bloated inventories, but most workers have since returned and, Niemira said, motor vehicle production increased 30 percent in February. ``That will feed directly into this report next month,'' he said. Also down in January were orders for aircraft, which had shown huge increases the previous two months, and for defense goods. Both sectors are volatile and Niemira said both the Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. already have reported increased aircraft orders during February. ``Aside from those three sectors, basically industry is showing a modest pace of growth,'' explained economist Priscilla Trumbull of DRI@McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. ``Fairly small, but at least it's growing.'' Economic weakness has been concentrated in the manufacturing and housing sectors since the Federal Reserve began its high-interest policies to curb inflation. Both sectors are often sensitive to interest rates since their products often are financed by loans. The Commerce Department reported the 10.5 percent decline in durable goods orders last week, saying it was the biggest drop in 32 years of recordkeeping and surpassed the previous record of 9.2 percent set in February 1982 during the last recession. It followed a 1.2 percent gain in December, which was revised down from 1.9 percent reported last month. Orders for non-durable goods rose 0.8 percent to $109.9 billion in January after falling 0.5 percent in December. The December drop was revised downward from a 0.3 percent gain reported last month. Defense orders fell 28.8 percent to $6.95 billion in January after dropping 13.3 percent a month earlier. Excluding defense, factory orders were off 4.4 percent. Orders in the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, fell 14.2 percent in January to $38.1 billion, reversing a 14.1 percent gain in December. Shipments of manufactured goods dropped 1.9 percent in January to $226.6 billion. Inventories rose 0.7 percent to $373.9 billion, nearly offsetting a 0.5 percent decrease in December. If inventories increase without a corresponding gain in new orders, it could signal production cutbacks in the future as factories attempt to get rid of stored goods. Among the durable goods orders, electrical machinery was down 15.5 percent to $19.2 billion, most of which was in communications equipment. Non-electrical machinery, including computers and a wide variety of industrial equipment, rose 2.4 percent to $22.3 billion. Primary metals were up 1.2 percent to $11.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Big Japanese and German Companies in Talks on Joint Ventures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edzard in 12th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Misubishi Corp. said Tuesday it was negotiating with West Germany's Daimler-Benz Group to form a series of joint ventures between the industrial giants in aerospace, electronics and other fields. If completed, an agreement would unite Japan and West Germany's two largest business groups, giving Mitsubishi a toehold in a united European Economic Comunity in 1992 and Daimler-Benz access to Japanese technology. Top executives from Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz held talks on expanding their cooperation last weekend in Singapore, Mitsubishi said in a statement Tuesday. Mitsubishi said the areas explored included ``high-growth industries'' such as aerospace, electronics and the service sector ``that would benefit from development on a global scale and make effective use of the skills of both groups.'' Japanese newspapers reported Wednesday that the companies had signed an agreement to pursue cooperation in many areas, including mounting a challenge on U.S. dominance of aerospace technology. ``There was a far-reaching exchange of ideas about ways to expand the relationship beyond the automotive sector, where Mercedes Benz and Mitsubishi Motors Corp. have enjoyed close ties,'' Mitsubishi said. The statement said senior managers from Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz ``expressed pleasure at having gained greater familiarity with each other and agreed to hold further meetings in due course.'' Mitsubishi spokesman Kyosuke Mori said the executives had agreed to meet once a year, and he expected the next meeting would occur in 1991. The companies both make motor vehicles and electronics equipment and are active in the aviation and space fields. Mori said the four Mitsubishi companies and the four Daimler-Benz companies whose executives attended the meeting were roughly comparable. They were Mitsubishi Motors and Mercedes-Benz in the automotive sector; Mitsubishi Electric and AEG in electrical systems and components; Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Deutsche Aerospace in aircraft and aerospace equipment; and Mitsubishi Corp. and Daimler-Benz Inter Services in trading and investment services. Mori said the weekend meeting evolved from a meeting last November in Europe between Mitsubishi Corp. President Shinroku Morohashi and Daimler Benz Chairman Edzard Reuter. Morohashi was in Europe to mark the offering of Mitsubishi shares on the London and Paris stock exchanges, Mori said. Morohashi and Reuter led their companies' executives at the Singapore meeting, the spokesman said. Mitsubishi Corp. is the core company of the giant Mitsubishi Group of related firms and is Japan's largest trading company, with transactions in the last fiscal year of $118 billion. Mitsubishi's 29 companies had total sales of about $82 billion in 1988, while Daimler-Benz had sales of $37.3 billion.
